HEADLINE: Debating Stadium Costs and Benefits

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 16

 BODY:
If Michael Graney has his way, this perennial second city will be looking for a band of young men to banish its chronic inferiority complex and improve the economy.
Their job: throwing, catching and hitting for a still unnamed minor-league expansion team in an as-yet-unbuilt $21.3 million stadium called Peter Pan Park. 
 But some in this industrial city long overshadowed by Boston say the plan will not work, and a referendum to stop the project is gaining support.
"This proposal just doesn't make sense," said Richard Stebbins, a leading opponent of the 5,300-seat stadium.
"It is a travesty to mortgage some of our economic future for a facility that will be used about 200 hours a year," said Mr. Stebbins, a retired banker.
Cities across the nation are struggling with the question of whether new sports complexes will be economic boons or boondoggles. In this decade, 46 major league stadiums and arenas have been built or renovated for teams in the four principal professional sports leagues, and 49 more are under construction or in the planning stages, said Andrew Zimbalist, sports economist at Smith College, about 20 miles north of Springfield.
The cost/benefit analysis goes beyond the bottom line, with civic pride and family entertainment all fitting into the mix. But the question often boils down to who will pay for the infrastructure.
Even when governments pay, there are no guarantees, as Hartford, Conn., learned this spring. The Connecticut Legislature agreed to pay for a new $375 million stadium after the New England Patriots said it would move to Hartford, 26 miles downriver from Springfield. But when the football team received another offer from Massachusetts, it decided to stay put.
Cities that want to get in on a boom in minor league baseball face similar issues. In the case of Springfield, the city is putting up $2 million and the state has promised $4 million in transportation and economic development grants to get the site ready for a team from the Northern League, which is not affiliated with Major League Baseball.
Mr. Graney, president of the nonprofit Springfield Baseball Corporation, which would own the team, says the mostly private financing sources his group assembled insulate taxpayers from risk.
But Mr. Stebbins said debt service on bonds and loans alone would exceed revenue even if optimistic attendance figures of 4,200 per game held, insuring that the city would never attract a quality ball club to its stadium.
The grants promised by the state would come at the expense of potentially more productive projects, Mr. Stebbins said.
The City Council recently voted 6 to 3 to use eminent domain to take the proposed site for the stadium, a shopping center in the shadow of two interstate highways. But a group called Citizens Action Network is mounting a petition drive to force a referendum to block the project, and the seizure is being fought by some merchants and the owners of the shopping center.
This is the fifth effort in five years to find a minor league team for Springfield, which had professional baseball on and off from 1902 until its ball park burned down in 1965. In 1995 a deal was all but done with a group of investors who had bought Pennsylvania's Harrisburg Senators of the Eastern League for $4.1 million. When Harrisburg officials heard of the deal, they complained to the league and were able, at the last minute, to buy the club for $6.7 million.
"They've been to the altar many times," said Andrew Linker, a sportswriter for The Harrisburg Patriot-News, an observer of Springfield's travails.
This time, Mr. Stebbins said, the city's power brokers "have fallen in love with the allure of baseball." He added that the stadium was destined to become a white elephant, an assessment shared by Professor Zimbalist.
New stadiums, whether for the minor or major leagues, are never sound investments, Professor Zimbalist said, and the Springfield plan is especially ill-conceived because almost a quarter of the proposed budget is for seizing property and relocating 16 businesses.
Mr. Graney contends that the stadium will increase traffic for local businesses as part of a broad revitalization effort that includes expanding the Basketball Hall of Fame, building a new convention center and reviving two downtown theaters.
The team will give the city a "psychological boost," he said.
The stadium, planned to open in 2001, is supported by the Mayor and a majority of the City Council. It is being designed by HOK Sports Facilities Group, responsible for high-profile projects like Camden Yards in Baltimore and the proposed new Fenway Park in Boston.
One supporter, Peter Picknelly Sr., owns the Peter Pan Bus Lines, a long-distance service based in Springfield. He has promised a $3 million donation of his own money to the project, and his company is buying naming rights for $1 million more.
Mr. Picknelly's father named what was then a jitney company with two vehicles for his son 65 years ago. His mother was reading the story of Peter Pan to the 3-year-old Peter, and his parents decided he resembled the fabled boy who refused to grow up.

HEADLINE: Leo Lionni, 89, Dies, Versatile Creator of Children's Books

BYLINE: By STEVEN HELLER 

 BODY:
Leo Lionni, who introduced an introspective sensibility to children's literature through the metaphorical characters Frederick, Swimmy and Little Blue and Little Yellow, died on Monday at his home near Radda in the Chianti district of Italy. He was 89.
Mr. Lionni was an artist, magazine art director, graphic designer, children's book illustrator and author. He had many careers, including Futurist painter, architectural critic for the Italian magazine Casabella, advertising designer for the N. W. Ayer agency in Philadelphia, graphic design consultant to Olivetti in Milan and the Museum of Modern Art in Manhattan, art director for Fortune, Print and Panorama magazines and professor of design at Cooper Union. 
But he earned worldwide popularity as the author and illustrator of more than 30 children's books, many of which were translated into numerous languages and are still in print.
He turned to creating children's books at 50, and, even after he began to suffer from Parkinson's disease 15 years ago, he was extraordinarily productive.
"Little Blue and Little Yellow," Mr. Lionni's first children's book, began as a desperate effort to calm his two rambunctious grandchildren on an hourlong train ride from Manhattan to Greenwich, Conn. It was 1959, and Mr. Lionni, then the art director of Fortune magazine, was taking the two to his suburban home. Unable to quiet them, he took a copy of Life magazine from his briefcase and turned to a page dominated by blue, yellow and green. He tore the paper into small circles, then improvised a story that captured their attention.
His story was about two circles, Little Blue and Little Yellow, the best of friends, who go on a hike. While playing hide-and-seek in a forest, they lose sight of each other. They search everywhere to no avail. Suddenly, behind a large tree, they are reunited and hug; doing so, they become Little Green.
"The children were transfixed," Mr. Lionni recalled in his memoir, "Between Worlds" (Alfred A. Knopf, 1997). "And I noticed that the passengers who were sitting within hearing distance had put down their papers and were listening, too. So for their benefit, I had Little Green go to the Stock Exchange, where he lost all his money. He broke out in yellow and blue tears, and when he was all tears, he was Little Blue and Little Yellow again and their stock rose 12 points."
Mr. Lionni eventually presented a refined version of the story to Fabio Coen, the children's editor for MacDowell Obolensky in New York, who agreed to publish it.
"It would take more than one evening with Fabio before I could fully understand how much the simple little tale of two blobs of color would affect my soul, my mind and my way of life," Mr. Lionni wrote.
Leonard Lionni was born in the Netherlands in 1910. His father was a diamond cutter and his mother was a singer. His Uncle Piet, an architect, gave the boy his first set of drafting tools; two other uncles, both collectors of modern art, fed his artistic inclinations. One uncle hung a Chagall painting outside the boy's room.
Mr. Lionni studied arts and crafts in primary school and was permitted to draw at the Rijksmuseum, where he copied plaster casts; he later recalled feeling that Rembrandt, van Gogh, Mondrian, architecture and music were "one big mood to me."
When he was 14, he lived in Philadelphia, where his father worked for the Atlantic Richfield Company. A year later, he moved to Genoa, Italy, where he attended a commercial high school, learned Italian and became conversant in Italian art, literature and poetry. At 16, he met Nora Maffi, who a few years later became his wife. The marriage endured for 69 years.
In addition to his wife, he is survived by a son, Louis Manny; four grandchildren, Pippo Lionni and Annie Lionni (for whom "Little Blue and Little Yellow" was conceived) Gina Zucker and Sylvan Lionni, and six great-grandchildren.
His wife's father was a founder of the Italian Communist Party and was placed under house arrest by the Fascists after their rise to power in 1922. This had a strong effect on Mr. Lionni's own political consciousness.
By the late 1920's, he had become interested in commercial art and produced his own advertisement proposals for Campari, which had a progressive graphic policy. Inspired by Futurist art, he found himself painting turbulent abstractions in 1931. His work caught the eye of F. T. Marinetti, leader of the faded Futurist movement.
Mr. Lionni was ambivalent about such recognition: Futurism celebrated Fascism, and its chaotic esthetic conflicted with his own rationalism. "I am really Dutch," he wrote. "I felt closer to de Stijl, and respond to the patterns and symmetry of the tulip fields."
While designing advertisements for a living, he attended classes at the University of Genoa, earning a doctoral degree in economics. He returned to Philadelphia to work as a designer for N. W. Ayer.
Mr. Lionni's other early jobs included art direction for advertisements for Ladies' Home Journal, the Ford Motor Company and the Container Corporation of America, for which he commissioned illustrations from Willem de Kooning, Alexander Calder and Fernand Leger for a celebrated series of ads based on great ideas. He also worked with a young Andy Warhol on the Regal Shoes account.
In 1947, Mr. Lionni moved to New York, and one of his first assignments was for Fortune magazine.
"Once Henry Luce asked me," he said, " 'Why can't Fortune be as good looking as Harper's Bazaar?' My answer was obvious: 'Because businessmen are not as good looking as fashion models.' "
He accepted the challenge nonetheless, changing the magazine's format and typography and giving unparalleled exposure to illustrators and fine artists who created pictorial essays.
He was a consultant to Luce on the prototype for Sports Illustrated. He designed the Museum of Modern Art's catalogue for Edward Steichen's milestone photography exhibition "The Family of Man," which is still in print, and the American Pavilion for the 1958 Brussels World's Fair.
At 50, Mr. Lionni decided to resettle in Tuscany, where he painted and created huge fantasy plants in brass and iron. Seeking a way to combine his applied and fine art work, he hit upon children's books as the perfect means. There he found the key to unlocking decades of personal fears, joys, insecurities and loves, by presenting them through animal metaphors. The books offer windows onto what he called "the soul." "Little Blue and Little Yellow," "Swimmy," "Frederick," "Nicolas, Where Have You Been?" and "Matthew's Dream," among his most popular and introspective books, are, on one level, autobiographies.
For his second book, Mr. Lionni did not resort to, as he said, "Little Blue Goes to the Zoo." Instead, he wrote and illustrated "On My Beach There Are Many Pebbles," a collection of drawings of fish pebbles, people pebbles and so on, hidden among the real pebbles, realistically rendered in pencil.
In his third book, "Inch by Inch," he developed the first of his animal fables. "Although it doesn't have an explicit moral, it invites a search for meaning," he said.
In "Inch by Inch," a helpless inchworm uses ingenuity to outwit a powerful bird. The story carries a recurring messages: that the imagination can transcend all obstacles.
His best-known book, "Swimmy," is about a diminutive fish bamboozling its predator, a giant tuna, by organizing other smaller fish into the shape of a large one. When Swimmy says, "I will be the eye," it is clear that this is also a portrait of the artist as seer.
Frances Foster, his editor for many years, said, "I think that's certainly the way Leo saw his role as an artist, seeing for people."
"Tillie and the Wall," from 1989, a book about seeing beyond impenetrable barriers, was published in Germany around the time that the Berlin wall fell, and it sold well there. Mr. Lionni was so excited by the potential of this book to impart more worldly ideas that he decided that from then on, everything he did would have some sort of social message.
"He felt that the world was in such a state that he really couldn't afford not to use the picture book as a kind of soapbox," Ms. Foster said.
In 1997, his critically praised memoir was published. Bruce McCall wrote in The New York Times Book Review that it was the story of "a man with exquisitely fine-tuned creative imagination, a clear mind, perfect taste and mercilessly high standards."
A year later, Parkinson's disease left him unable to type or sketch, but he kept conceiving ideas for more stories and fables.
Mr. Lionni once confessed in an interview that he had trouble with children, even grandchildren, in small groups. "I don't know how to get to them," he said, "and so I do banal things," like making noises.
"I wish I could just read them something."

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths
KOVENETSKY, SAM

 BODY:
KOVENETSKY-Sam. October 15, 1999, at age 87. Adoring and beloved husband of Betty. Loving father of Rolf and Regina. Dear grandfather of David and Rachel Kovenetsky. Devoted step-father of Rick and Chris Shain. Stepgrandfather of Brahman, Autumn and April. Great-grandfather of Cody. A man of all seasons. A pioneer of the labor movement. Founding father of Local 1-S, dedicated to serving the workers of Macy's for 40 years. Labor liaison to Governor Carey. Appointed by Governor Cuomo to serve as Commissioner of the Unemployment Appeals Board for 17 years. He served on the Boards of United Way of NYC, Empire Blue Cross Blue Shield, Group Health Insurance Inc., American Cancer Society-New York Divison, Brooklyn Psychiatric Center, Greater New York Fund, City of Hope-Robal Chapter, B'nai Brith-Business and Labor Lodge, past president of the New York Chapter of the Industrial Relations Research Association. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the NYC Central Labor Council's Camp Program. Rest in peace, my darling, my best friend. Service Monday, 11:15 AM, at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.
KOVENETSKY - Sam. Former Treasurer and active Member of Labor and Business Lodge 2201, B'nai Brith, passed away on Friday, October 15. Funeral services will be held on Monday, October 18, at 11:15 AM, in the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Our condolences to the family. Louis L. Levine, President Labor and Business Lodge 2201 B'nai Brith

HEADLINE: DANCE;
Old-Time Rivals Make A Date to Go Dancing

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER REARDON; Christopher Reardon's most recent article for Arts & Leisure was about the coming New Year's Eve celebration at Times Square.

 BODY:
MORE than most dance companies, American Ballet Theater prides itself on its versatility. And rightly so. Last spring it presented "Giselle" and other Old World heirlooms. For the fall season, which opens on Tuesday and runs for two weeks at City Center, the troupe will flaunt its progressive side, taking on the macabre expressionism of Agnes de Mille, the wry populism of Twyla Tharp and the quicksilver partnering of Nacho Duato.
As disparate as these dances are, however, one piece in the program stands out as a real stretch: Martha Graham's "Diversion of Angels." 
 Such a union of classical and modern might have been thought treasonous when the piece was first seen in 1948. Back then, ballet was lofty and lithe, a passport to the heavens. Graham's work was its antithesis, an earthbound art that bared the human soul. Her signature move, an abdominal contraction and release that starts deep in the pelvis, would have made a naif like Giselle blush with shame.
Even now, with choreographers shuttling back and forth between classical and contemporary troupes, adding Graham to Ballet Theater's repertory is a rare and risky endeavor. Only three other ballet companies have performed her work, and never in New York, where her troupe is based.
"There's an expression in England about taking coals to Newcastle," said Wayne Eagling, artistic director of the Dutch National Ballet, which will stage its fifth piece by Graham next month. "It's like a company bringing Balanchine to New York; it better be bloody good."
Some purists are aghast at the notion that dancers with no prior training in the Graham technique could, after six weeks of rehearsals, do her work justice. Others wonder why Ballet Theater's Ashley Tuttle, a paragon of classical form, would bother with Graham's barefoot modernism. But the most common refrain is simply, "What took so long?"
Ballet Theater has been a crucible of crossover ballet at least since 1976, when it asked Ms. Tharp, who was known for setting dances to songs by Petula Clark and the Beach Boys, to make a piece for Mikhail Baryshnikov. The result was "Push Comes to Shove," a public sensation that breached the wall between ballet and modern dance for good. (The company will perform it, minus Mr. Baryshnikov, at City Center.)
There was talk of adding Graham to the repertory a dozen years ago. She and her rehearsal director, Peggy Lyman, even came and taught a class. But the project stalled with Mr. Baryshnikov's departure as artistic director in 1989, Graham's death two years later and financial crises at both companies. (Ballet Theater paid off the last of its $5 million debt in 1998, while the Graham troupe retired its $2 million debt earlier this year.)
Kevin McKenzie, Ballet Theater's artistic director since 1992, eventually resumed the conversation with Ron Protas, his counterpart at the Graham studio.
"I felt it was important for the company to do a Graham piece, and do it well, because she's such an influential figure," Mr. McKenzie said. "You're going to get it watered down, three times removed, from some present-day choreographer anyway. So why not go to the source?"
Mr. Protas was game. At the time, he was laying the groundwork for the new Martha Graham Trust, which licenses her work to dance companies and schools. The goal, he said, is to keep her work alive and help it reach a broader audience. To that end, he struck a deal that allows Ballet Theater to perform "Diversion of Angels," Mr. McKenzie's first choice, at a cost of $55,000 for the first year.
"Angels" was an anomaly for Graham. Sprightly and tender, it came just after three of her darkest works: "Cave of the Heart," "Night Journey" and "Errand Into the Maze." Instead of Medea, Jocasta and Ariadne, the tragic heroines of those glosses on Greek myth, it presents three couples happily in love.
To Graham, who created the piece during her brief marriage to Erick Hawkins and never performed in it, the couples represented different shades of devotion. The two lovers dressed in white should appear "mature and balanced," Mr. Protas told the dancers after watching a rehearsal earlier this month. The red couple should be erotic, he added, the yellow one playful and elusive. The dancing, to an ebullient score by Norman Dello Joio, is arguably lighter and more linear than anything else in Graham's oeuvre. But it's no cakewalk.
"You cannot hide behind a narrative or a story or a dramatic portrayal," said Peter Sparling, a former Graham dancer whose modern-dance troupe in Ann Arbor, Mich., recently performed "Angels." "It's essential, lyrical Graham. The technique is laid bare."
Some of her dancers once dubbed the piece "Perversion of Angles," a sobriquet that seems even more apt at Ballet Theater. Four weeks into rehearsals, the dancers had the basic structure down. But the women were still struggling to throw themselves into radical tilts without falling off balance and learning to leap without letting their center of gravity ride too high. The men, wearing knee pads and ballet slippers that will have to be gone by opening night, grimaced as they plunged to the floor and tried to spiral right back up.
"This is the purest modern-dance technique there is," said Keith Roberts, a principal dancer who has created roles with Ms. Tharp, James Kudelka and Lar Lubovitch. (Mr. Roberts will also dance in Mr. Lubovitch's newest work, "Meadow.") "It's like asking a modern dancer to do 'Sleeping Beauty.' "
Even so, the effort is not unprecedented. Many notable Graham dancers (including Graham herself) mastered her technique after years of classical training. Rudolf Nureyev, who was jeered during his clumsy debut with the Graham company in 1984, eventually became an important interpreter of her work. And last year the Colorado Ballet scored a hit with its production of "Appalachian Spring" (1944), after six solid weeks of rehearsal.
Takako Asakawa, a Graham protege who is teaching them the piece, said she had hoped to start off with a few weeks of classes. But the troupe's busy schedule made that impossible. So after showing them a 1976 video of "Angels," with herself as the red girl, she dived right in, demonstrating each of the roles herself.
"Our best way of bringing it to life is through imitation," said Mr. Roberts, who dances as the red boy. "We may not fully grasp what's going on, but if we can imitate it until we get it into our body, then we can start understanding the feeling of it. It's kind of a backward approach, but it's all we can do in the time we have."
ONE of the more striking images in rehearsal was that of Ms. Tuttle, her feet wreathed in adhesive tape, laying a string of altered arabesques across the floor. Every few steps she stopped, lifted herself up on point with a visceral contraction and then surged ahead.
Mr. McKenzie had initially pegged her as the yellow girl, an effervescent role that seemed to suit her persona. "My natural movement quality is to be more upright, more flighty, more like Giselle," she said. But Ms. Asakawa, sensing an untapped potential, shrewdly recast her as the red girl.
On the whole, Ms. Asakawa said, she has found Ballet Theater's dancers more receptive to Graham than their peers at the Paris Opera Ballet, where she restaged "Temptations of the Moon" (1986) a few years ago. But with two weeks to go, she was still dissatisfied with their timing and spacing, and she thought their transitions were rough. Again and again she instructed them to flex their feet, molded their torsos with her hands and shared emotional insights into the roles. In a dance studio, it was pretty much business as usual.
"They're not going to look like people who have studied Graham technique for 12 years," Mr. Protas said. "But I think they will have mastered it to a degree that's acceptable and dramatic."
Then he offered an anecdote that, if true, appears to call the entire enterprise into question.
"Martha's disciples have much more rigidity about her work than she did," he said. "One time she told Misha, 'Darling, this contraction and release thing: it's so overrated.' Of course, it's the whole basis of her work."

CORRECTION-DATE: October 17, 1999, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article on page 11 of Arts & Leisure today about American Ballet Theater's season at City Center misstates the fee that the Martha Graham Trust is charging Ballet Theater to perform Graham's "Diversion of Angels." According to Jane Hermann, who wrote the contract for the trust, it is a flat three-year agreement, not a one-year agreement, and the fee is considerably less than $55,000.

HEADLINE: The Return of the Suit That Speaks (Quietly) for Itself

BYLINE: By RUTH LA FERLA

 BODY:
LAST summer, Dr. Andre L. Churchwell bought himself a new blue suit. Not just any blue suit, but a single-breasted, two-button model with peak lapels and a dapper ticket pocket -- a ringer, he was quick to note, for "the suit Pierce Brosnan was wearing when he first met Renee Russo in 'The Thomas Crown Affair.' "
Dr. Churchwell, 45, a cardiologist in Nashville, makes it a point to know about such things. Speaking by phone from his office, he all but crowed describing another recent acquisition, a dove-gray coat and trousers made in New York by his tailor, Leonard Logsdail, and cut, he said, from the poshest "Super 100" wool flannel. 
 Terms like Super 100 and Scabal (a luxury fabric from a British textile mill) have also leeched into Dennis Saul's conversation. The head of his own stock brokerage firm, Mr. Saul, 56, has his suits made in Brooklyn by a tailor whose name he won't disclose -- for fear of driving up his prices. Each new ensemble sets Mr. Saul back about $2,000; a bargain, he maintained, since "I'm getting the difference between a Chevy and a Porche."
"Last Saturday, I looked at 20 different fabrics," he recalled. "I like to feel that in the course of examining this stuff, I'm building a body of knowledge."
Dr. Churchwell and Mr. Saul are devout members of an exclusive but growing fraternity of affluent clothing buffs, who have turned their backs on off-the-rack apparel in favor of a garment uniquely tailored to their whims.
Men like these contend that they are wild about a custom suit's superior fit and quality. But they are just as taken with its unspoken function as a badge of rank, an expression of their rarefied tastes and connoisseurship -- as though it were a rare wine or a vintage car they had studied up on before acquiring.
Increasingly brand-conscious, a prosperous minority of men with a passion for finery have given rise to dynamic sales of hand-made apparel for the first time since the boom years of the 1980's. In this decade, suit sales over all have taken a beating as consumers lean toward casual wear. But when men do buy suits, retailers and tailors say, they are more likely to splurge these days, investing in top-of-the-line goods. Just as in the 80's, men's wear's last gilded age, when a peacock display of red suspenders or an Hermes tie were thought to be status symbols, consumers with well-lined pockets are not blinking at the $2,000 to $7,000 price tag for a custom suit. It's the sartorial equivalent of a platinum card.
Members of the custom club like to subtly signal one another by flaunting their ticket pockets -- slim pockets on the jacket originally used to fit a pair of theater tickets -- and functioning buttonholes on jacket sleeves, which Wall Street's young turks leave undone in a quiet show of status.
"In the last few years, the custom business has picked up dramatically," said Clifford Grodd, the president of Paul Stuart, a high-end men's-wear emporium in midtown Manhattan, where the custom business has doubled since the mid-90's.
Other merchants cite a similarly robust growth -- about 15 to 25 percent annually -- in hand-tailored suits, though no industry-wide figures exist.
"One of the hallmarks of affluence, besides buying your Range Rover, is having a suit made," Mr. Grodd said. "Saying you have a custom-made suit is like name dropping."
The lineup of clothiers offering men's custom services in the New York area, including suits, shirts and sometimes ties, includes tailors like Leonard Logsdail; specialty stores like Saks Fifth Avenue, Neiman Marcus and Bergdorf Goodman, and such lofty labels as Oxxford, Kiton, Zegna, Brioni, Attolini and, most recently, Giorgio Armani, who began selling made-to-measure suits just this fall under the Collezioni label.
Even Moe Ginzburg, the venerable rack-and-pipe operation on lower Fifth Avenue that is home to $250 budget suits, is trading up. Next spring, the store will feature made-to-measure men's apparel in its newly renovated and gentrified store. Paul Ginzburg, the third-generation owner of Moe Ginzburg, expects made-to-measure customers to come from the ranks of those who are "bestowing fine wine on themselves, along with good caviar, expensive girlfriends and even more expensive wives," he said, adding, "A custom suit is one more luxury that makes them feel they have arrived."
Consumers, and some retailers, are often confused about the terminology of tailored clothing. Essentially, there are three levels of quality and expense:
* A custom suit, the cordon bleu of tailored apparel, is cut and stitched from scratch, using a paper pattern designed for each client that is fitted in muslin. Known as a bespoke suit in England. Prices range from $2,000 to well over $7,000.
* A made-to-measure suit is a Betty Crocker variation on custom tailoring. Customers are measured, and choose from a wide range of fabrics, but their suits are cut using standard patterns, not made from scratch, then fitted to them. This is what men's-wear designers offer when they do "trunk shows" at stores. Priced from $700 to $2,500.
* Off-the-rack suits, those hanging in stores when customers walk in, are made in standard sizes and can be altered in simple ways by a tailor. Priced from $100 to $3,000.
Hand-made suits appeal to the kind of man who wants a walnut dashboard in his car and a cherrywood floor in his dining room. "The more prosperous the man, the more difficult it is to satisfy his needs," said Lawrence Kudlow, 52, the chief economist at Schroder & Company and for CNBC.com, and a commentator for Bloomberg News. Mr. Kudlow, who buys his hand-made pinstripe suits from Mr. Logsdail, views the craving for hand-made apparel as the indicator of a larger trend. "Customization is a theme in all consumer goods," he noted. "The suit business is part of that."
Indeed, Kurt Salmon Associates, a New York consumer research group, which conducted a survey of middle- to high-income shoppers earlier this year, forecasts increases of 20 to 30 percent in sales of custom-made apparel over the next decade.
Younger consumers, men now in their 30's and 40's, whose notions of style were honed on aggressively voguish labels like Prada, Helmut Lang and Dolce & Gabbana, are among those giving made-to-order suits a push. Disenchanted by the indifferent construction and evanescent life span of designer brands, some have discovered custom apparel.
"Men's clothes are becoming so fashion forward that I can't wear them," complained Giovanni Russo, one such recent custom convert. Mr. Russo, 33, an art director and the head of his own New York design firm, called Design No. 11, has mostly abandoned designer suits, which he deems too flashy, for the subtlety of a trim-fitting gray wool coat and pair of trousers, like those he ordered last summer from Seize Sur Vingt, a downtown clothier to the young and hip.
Learning about the arcana of style -- the names of fabrics, the types of stitching -- is part of the allure of a custom suit, said Dan McCampbell, the fashion director for men's wear at Saks Fifth Avenue, who based his observations on findings from a survey by the store of 300 consumers aged 25 to 64 and earning $75,000 a year or more. "Men are turning increasingly to a tailor or a knowledgeable sales associate to inform them about how clothes are made," he said. "Why? They see clothes as an investment."
And he might have added, an instant passport to James Bondian self-assurance. Some tailors trade on their clients' eagerness to become connoisseurs -- a trait hard-wired into many men, the same instinct that leads them to become audio buffs -- while preying slyly on their insecurities. One television executive, who didn't want to go on record as buying high-priced suits, told of visiting the New York hotel suite of Gianni Campagna, a Milanese tailor, who says he has made suits for the billionaire Ronald O. Perelman and Henry Kravis, the financier.
"I had on my best Zegna suit," the client recalled, laughing ruefully, "but they looked me over, and told me my cuffs were too short, my shoulders too low and my buttons too high. All I could think was, Oh my God, do I look that bad?" He succumbed just the same, buying one suit in solid gray wool and another in a navy Prince of Wales plaid. Cost: $3,800 each. He also bought a cashmere sportscoat for $2,600.
Some men take the passion for personalization to extremes. Mr. Logsdail, a midtown tailor with a Savile Row pedigree, tells of one client who asked to have his suit coat lined with a patchwork of silk Hermes scarves.
But Americans more often shun such display, opting for refinements as faint and elusive as the scent of English lavender. They include Jeffry Schneider, 31, an investment banker and longtime patron of Paul Stuart. His latest purchase is a Tasmanian wool suit decorated with plaid so fine it is all but invisible. "A hand-made suit is a subtle thing," he said during a fitting at the store the other day, pointing out the hand-stitching along the edge of the lapel. "But this is my favorite detail," Mr. Schneider said, turning his jacket inside out to show off his pen pocket -- a one-inch slash just beneath his left breast pocket.
Retailers acknowledge that the advantage of such features may well be in the wearer's eye. "So much of this business is psychological," said Mr. Grodd of Paul Stuart. "A hand-sewn buttonhole is a sign of status, sure, but one that is much overrated. With all the technology available now, handwork doesn't necessarily make something better."
True custom fans brush such reservations off like lint. Eager to stand out from the herd and, at the same time, blend in with their peers, some take a line from their tailors, contending, a bit solemnly, that their suits are an addiction -- not to say the plushest of security blankets. They certainly serve that purpose for Mr. Russo. "I hate being self-conscious," he said. "I like to feel that my clothes aren't wearing me. And when I find a suit I really can relax in, well, I just go with it."
 
Where to Find a Custom Fit
CUSTOM and made-to-measure clothes can be found at the following tailors and stores.
BARNEYS NEW YORK -- Madison Avenue and 60th Street. Made-to-measure clothes can be ordered from brands like Oxxford, Armani Le Collezioni, Brioni, Belvest, Battistoni, Zegna, Ralph Lauren Purple Label and Huntsman. Suit prices start at $795 and rocket into the ionosphere.
BERGDORF GOODMAN MEN -- Fifth Avenue and 57th Street. Hand-made and made-to-measure clothing by Oxxford and Kiton, as well as suits and sportscoats by the store's star tailor, Domenico Spano. Prices for a custom-tailored suit hover around $4,000. Shirts by Charvet, Turnbull & Asser and BG, the store's brand, are $175 to $340.
GIANNI CAMPAGNA -- This Milan-based tailor sees New York clients about once a month by appointment at a suite in the Pierre Hotel. Mr. Campagna creates a pattern and cuts a suit for about $3,400 to $5,600. For an appointment: (212) 966-0021.
CHEO -- 30 East 60th Street. Savile Row is the model for Chewoo Park's hand-made suits, which sell for about $3,000. Fabrics, linings and even buttons are imported from top British suppliers.
THE CUSTOM SHOP -- 618 Fifth Avenue (50th Street). Suits, blazers, shirts and coats are made to order at this flagship store and eight other New York locations. Prices start at $70 for a cotton-and-polyester shirt and climb to about $140 for one in Sea Island cotton. A made-to-measure suit from fabrics by top British and Italian mills averages $900.
J. DILLON SIMPSON -- 200 Central Park South. Paul Newman and Colin Powell are among the cognoscenti who have found their ways to this purveyor of made-to-measure suits, shirts and ties, said Liliana Labelle, who is in charge of marketing for the shop. Average suit cost: $2,000; shirt, $250; tie, $150.
LEONARD LOGSDAIL -- 9 East 53d Street. Devotees of this transplanted Londoner say he has made Savile Row a local option. His signatures are a subtly nipped waist and roomy sleeves. Prices start at about $3,500 for a wool suit made in London.
SEIZE SUR VINGT -- 243 Elizabeth Street. Snug but classically tailored made-to-measure suits, flat-front pants and easy-fitting shirts are the forte of this clothier to the downtown set. Suits are priced from $920 to $2,000, shirts from $130 to $250.
SAKS FIFTH AVENUE -- Fifth Avenue at 50th Street. Made-to-measure suits from Oxxford, Brioni, Hickey Freeman, Chester Barrie and Armani Le Collezioni start at $850 and climb to $7,000. Saks is headquarters for the Alan Flusser Shop, selling custom suits for $1,995 to $2,295, and made-to-measure suits for $1,295. Made-to-measure shirts by Zegna and Individualized Shirtmaker come in conventional solids and sportier tattersall checks and plaids, priced from $85 to $350.
TURNBULL & ASSER -- 42 East 57th Street. Colorful striped shirts are the insignia of this British shirt maker. There is a choice of 10 collars, including the wide spread style favored by Prince Charles. RUTH LA FERLA

HEADLINE: DANCE;
Old-Time Rivals Make A Date to Go Dancing

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER REARDON; Christopher Reardon's most recent article for Arts & Leisure was about the coming New Year's Eve celebration at Times Square.

 BODY:
MORE than most dance companies, American Ballet Theater prides itself on its versatility. And rightly so. Last spring it presented "Giselle" and other Old World heirlooms. For the fall season, which opens on Tuesday and runs for two weeks at City Center, the troupe will flaunt its progressive side, taking on the macabre expressionism of Agnes de Mille, the wry populism of Twyla Tharp and the quicksilver partnering of Nacho Duato.
As disparate as these dances are, however, one piece in the program stands out as a real stretch: Martha Graham's "Diversion of Angels." 
 Such a union of classical and modern might have been thought treasonous when the piece was first seen in 1948. Back then, ballet was lofty and lithe, a passport to the heavens. Graham's work was its antithesis, an earthbound art that bared the human soul. Her signature move, an abdominal contraction and release that starts deep in the pelvis, would have made a naif like Giselle blush with shame.
Even now, with choreographers shuttling back and forth between classical and contemporary troupes, adding Graham to Ballet Theater's repertory is a rare and risky endeavor. Only three other ballet companies have performed her work, and never in New York, where her troupe is based.
"There's an expression in England about taking coals to Newcastle," said Wayne Eagling, artistic director of the Dutch National Ballet, which will stage its fifth piece by Graham next month. "It's like a company bringing Balanchine to New York; it better be bloody good."
Some purists are aghast at the notion that dancers with no prior training in the Graham technique could, after six weeks of rehearsals, do her work justice. Others wonder why Ballet Theater's Ashley Tuttle, a paragon of classical form, would bother with Graham's barefoot modernism. But the most common refrain is simply, "What took so long?"
Ballet Theater has been a crucible of crossover ballet at least since 1976, when it asked Ms. Tharp, who was known for setting dances to songs by Petula Clark and the Beach Boys, to make a piece for Mikhail Baryshnikov. The result was "Push Comes to Shove," a public sensation that breached the wall between ballet and modern dance for good. (The company will perform it, minus Mr. Baryshnikov, at City Center.)
There was talk of adding Graham to the repertory a dozen years ago. She and her rehearsal director, Peggy Lyman, even came and taught a class. But the project stalled with Mr. Baryshnikov's departure as artistic director in 1989, Graham's death two years later and financial crises at both companies. (Ballet Theater paid off the last of its $5 million debt in 1998, while the Graham troupe retired its $2 million debt earlier this year.)
Kevin McKenzie, Ballet Theater's artistic director since 1992, eventually resumed the conversation with Ron Protas, his counterpart at the Graham studio.
"I felt it was important for the company to do a Graham piece, and do it well, because she's such an influential figure," Mr. McKenzie said. "You're going to get it watered down, three times removed, from some present-day choreographer anyway. So why not go to the source?"
Mr. Protas was game. At the time, he was laying the groundwork for the new Martha Graham Trust, which licenses her work to dance companies and schools. The goal, he said, is to keep her work alive and help it reach a broader audience. To that end, he struck a deal that allows Ballet Theater to perform "Diversion of Angels," Mr. McKenzie's first choice, at a cost of $55,000 for the first year.
"Angels" was an anomaly for Graham. Sprightly and tender, it came just after three of her darkest works: "Cave of the Heart," "Night Journey" and "Errand Into the Maze." Instead of Medea, Jocasta and Ariadne, the tragic heroines of those glosses on Greek myth, it presents three couples happily in love.
To Graham, who created the piece during her brief marriage to Erick Hawkins and never performed in it, the couples represented different shades of devotion. The two lovers dressed in white should appear "mature and balanced," Mr. Protas told the dancers after watching a rehearsal earlier this month. The red couple should be erotic, he added, the yellow one playful and elusive. The dancing, to an ebullient score by Norman Dello Joio, is arguably lighter and more linear than anything else in Graham's oeuvre. But it's no cakewalk.
"You cannot hide behind a narrative or a story or a dramatic portrayal," said Peter Sparling, a former Graham dancer whose modern-dance troupe in Ann Arbor, Mich., recently performed "Angels." "It's essential, lyrical Graham. The technique is laid bare."
Some of her dancers once dubbed the piece "Perversion of Angles," a sobriquet that seems even more apt at Ballet Theater. Four weeks into rehearsals, the dancers had the basic structure down. But the women were still struggling to throw themselves into radical tilts without falling off balance and learning to leap without letting their center of gravity ride too high. The men, wearing knee pads and ballet slippers that will have to be gone by opening night, grimaced as they plunged to the floor and tried to spiral right back up.
"This is the purest modern-dance technique there is," said Keith Roberts, a principal dancer who has created roles with Ms. Tharp, James Kudelka and Lar Lubovitch. (Mr. Roberts will also dance in Mr. Lubovitch's newest work, "Meadow.") "It's like asking a modern dancer to do 'Sleeping Beauty.' "
Even so, the effort is not unprecedented. Many notable Graham dancers (including Graham herself) mastered her technique after years of classical training. Rudolf Nureyev, who was jeered during his clumsy debut with the Graham company in 1984, eventually became an important interpreter of her work. And last year the Colorado Ballet scored a hit with its production of "Appalachian Spring" (1944), after six solid weeks of rehearsal.
Takako Asakawa, a Graham protege who is teaching them the piece, said she had hoped to start off with a few weeks of classes. But the troupe's busy schedule made that impossible. So after showing them a 1976 video of "Angels," with herself as the red girl, she dived right in, demonstrating each of the roles herself.
"Our best way of bringing it to life is through imitation," said Mr. Roberts, who dances as the red boy. "We may not fully grasp what's going on, but if we can imitate it until we get it into our body, then we can start understanding the feeling of it. It's kind of a backward approach, but it's all we can do in the time we have."
ONE of the more striking images in rehearsal was that of Ms. Tuttle, her feet wreathed in adhesive tape, laying a string of altered arabesques across the floor. Every few steps she stopped, lifted herself up on point with a visceral contraction and then surged ahead.
Mr. McKenzie had initially pegged her as the yellow girl, an effervescent role that seemed to suit her persona. "My natural movement quality is to be more upright, more flighty, more like Giselle," she said. But Ms. Asakawa, sensing an untapped potential, shrewdly recast her as the red girl.
On the whole, Ms. Asakawa said, she has found Ballet Theater's dancers more receptive to Graham than their peers at the Paris Opera Ballet, where she restaged "Temptations of the Moon" (1986) a few years ago. But with two weeks to go, she was still dissatisfied with their timing and spacing, and she thought their transitions were rough. Again and again she instructed them to flex their feet, molded their torsos with her hands and shared emotional insights into the roles. In a dance studio, it was pretty much business as usual.
"They're not going to look like people who have studied Graham technique for 12 years," Mr. Protas said. "But I think they will have mastered it to a degree that's acceptable and dramatic."
Then he offered an anecdote that, if true, appears to call the entire enterprise into question.
"Martha's disciples have much more rigidity about her work than she did," he said. "One time she told Misha, 'Darling, this contraction and release thing: it's so overrated.' Of course, it's the whole basis of her work."

HEADLINE: The World;
The Real Power Struggle Isn't Just About Nukes

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
STEP outside the United States for even a few days, and the country has never looked more powerful: An economy that won't quit, a military that has never faced fewer direct challenges, a popular and business culture that has become the world's most eagerly-sought export.
But take one step back into Washington and it's easy to wonder if you are talking about the same country. The President of the most powerful nation at its most powerful moment has rarely looked weaker than he did last week, when the Senate overwhelmingly defeated the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty. 
 Mr. Clinton responded with an hour-long recitation of the dangers of a "new isolationism." Republicans shot back that Mr. Clinton had cynically sought to turn a popular but hard-to-enforce treaty into a political weapon. Bickering along these lines will doubtless go on for months. But it masks the real debate.
The test ban treaty was only the latest of a number of divisive issues in the capital that share a common subtext: An argument not over whether the United States is strong, but over how it should use its power. Should it strut the global beach alone, or leverage that power by accepting restraints on its freedom to act?
It is that debate that has eroded the "vital center" that Mr. Clinton talks about so often in his laments about the disappearance of bipartisanship in foreign affairs.
Mr. Clinton himself, who has been episodic in focusing on foreign policy, has ranged all over the map on this question. He preaches cooperation one day and acts unilaterally the next -- whether the issue is swatting Saddam Hussein or slapping huge tariffs on low-cost Japanese steel. Usually, though, he has come down on the side of power-sharing, either pressing for more arms control accords even if that means a slow deterioration of the American nuclear fleet, or granting more power to the World Trade Organization even if sometimes strikes down American laws.
Over the past three years battles have gradually gotten more and more vociferous, as the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty showed. Now it has turned into an open fight, bound to haunt Mr. Clinton as he finishes the last 15 months of his term. It is also certain to plague his successor in a city where the consensus about American responsibilities in the world has splintered.
It is a battle in which Mr. Clinton has steadily been losing ground. In his first term he won over moderate Republicans to push through the North American Free Trade Agreement and the global trade treaty that created the World Trade Organization. True, these victories came only after desperate legislative battles, but unlike the test ban treaty, they were at least fought out in hundreds of hours of hearings and public debate. But lately, with the exception of the war in Kosovo, he has been unable to stitch together any kind of majority for his international initiatives. He was unable even to convince his own party to vote to give him authority to negotiate new trade treaties -- a reminder that, for all his denunciations of isolationism on Thursday, most of the economic isolationists in Congress are Democrats.
And now, in a treaty that involved national security rather than economic prosperity, the culmination of an idea whose intellectual roots go back to Eisenhower Republicans, he became the first President since Woodrow Wilson to face outright rejection of a major international accord. The fact that Democrats and Republicans were unable to agree on the obvious face-saving compromise -- a delay of the vote until after the Presidential election -- seems to prove that the politics of post-cold war Washington really are different. "It's inconceivable," one of Mr. Clinton's top advisers said, "that this would have been the outcome if the country still felt under an imminent threat from a major enemy."
Even so, many of those who had doubts about the treaty and thus voted against it would have preferred to see it postponed, amended or at least fully aired in hearings rather than killed. Moderate Republicans who voted no like John McCain, the Presidential candidate, were clearly uncomfortable with the message that the treaty's rejection sent around the world. "There has always been an isolationist wing in our party and they were transcendent in the 20's and 30's," Mr. McCain said on Friday, trying to distance himself from that group as fast as he could. "It's still there, it will always be there, yet I have every confidence that the majority will take an international viewpoint."
Others say that the instinct in evidence on the Senate floor on Wednesday night was less about isolationism than about unilateralism -- preserving America's ability to use its power unchallenged. In the case of the test ban treaty, that means retaining an ability to go back to traditional deterrence, constantly improving America's nuclear arsenal and forcing a resurgent Russia or an ambitious China to fear a financially ruinous arms race. After all, the Soviet Union went that route and bankrupted itself along the way.
"I don't think the Republican party has ever been or is now a party of isolationism," said Michael Mandelbaum, a fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations. Many of the Republicans who voted against the treaty, he noted, rank among the Senate's strongest internationalists. "But there is a very strong unilateralist impulse manifesting itself. That's very different. It's not opposed to foreign entanglements, it just sends a message: 'Don't tie our hands.' "
Mr. Clinton argued vociferously against that approach during his press conference on Thursday, warning that if an anti-test ban treaty President ever gets elected (he named no names, but clearly had George W. Bush Jr. in mind) "we'll have China testing; we'll have India testing; we'll have Pakistan testing." The result, he argued, would be a return to an economically destructive arms race. Sooner or later, he predicted, Republicans would be pressing for "30 or 40 or 50 billion a year" in additional defense spending.
He may be right. But it is also possible that the lessons of the cold war run deep, and countries now feel far more competitive pressure than they did a decade ago to invest that money in their economic well-being.
"At the same moment that Clinton is talking about isolation, American foreign investment is off the charts, American economic engagement around the world is breaking all records," said Jeffrey E. Garten, a former Under Secretary of Commerce and now dean of the Yale School of Management. "In some subtle way this has ricocheted back to Washington, and perhaps there are a lot of people who feel that you can reject an arms control treaty and still not be withdrawing from the world."

LENGTH: 1084 words

HEADLINE: Mozart Isn't the Answer

BYLINE: By Carol Tavris; Carol Tavris, a behavioral scientist, is the co-author of three textbooks in psychology.

 BODY:

THE MYTH OF THE
 FIRST THREE YEARS
 A New Understanding of Early Brain
 Development and Lifelong Learning.
 By John T. Bruer.
 244 pp. New York:
 The Free Press. $25. 
 This century began with the ascendancy of the unconscious and is ending with the ascendancy of the brain. These very different explanations of behavior have two things in common. Both the unconscious and the brain are invisible to the naked eye, therefore requiring phalanxes of experts to explain them. And both notions have been used to serve the deeply held American cultural belief in infant determinism -- the idea that the first three years of life determine a child's development and personality.
It was bad enough when parents were told that their baby would form a lifelong unconscious image of them, based on how sensitive they were to the tiny tyrant's every emotional need. Now parents are being told to forget the unconscious and attend to brain wiring. As Rob Reiner's "I Am Your Child" campaign puts it, "The early years last forever." This is because, the public is told, the baby's brain is forming trillions of synapses (connections between nerve cells), many of which have, by puberty, been "pruned away." Enriched environments and mental stimulation are critical to synapse production, and thus to a baby's mental, musical and artistic abilities. Kindergarten is too late.
In this era of the brain, such an argument is powerful. Do you know how many synapses you have? Of course not, but if you're like me you will jump at the chance to add a few more, or at least keep the ones you have. So it's no wonder that millions of parents are panicked. When you could only wreck your child's unconscious, the kid could always go to therapy. But if you miss that critical early period for stimulating your baby's brain, your child might never get to Harvard. As Hillary Rodham Clinton said during the 1997 White House Conference on Early Childhood Development and Learning, this emphasis on the brain does "ratchet up the guilt."
That is why "The Myth of the First Three Years" is important. John T. Bruer, the president of the James S. McDonnell Foundation, which supports research on neuroscience and cognition, has written a clear and balanced assessment of what research has and has not discovered about infant brains, one that illuminates the connections between research, political values and social policy.
First, Bruer shows that "most learning is not subject to critical-period constraints, not confined to windows of opportunity that slam shut." For example, the years roughly until puberty are, in general, crucial for acquiring an unaccented second language. But most people can learn another language and improve their skills at any age.
Second, the most exciting discoveries in neuroscience are that the brain develops throughout life and that brain structure is continually affected by experience. Neuroscientists once believed that lost neurons could not regenerate; now it turns out that sometimes they can. "The brain is not 'cooked' by age 3 or age 10," Bruer writes. "Our brains remain remarkably plastic and we retain the ability to learn throughout our lives."
Third, infants subjected to severe, prolonged deprivation do indeed suffer intellectually -- though long-term studies find that many recover from even this poor start. But there is no single, correct way to stimulate a baby in order to produce maximum mental benefits. In those famous rat studies showing the benefits of "enriched" environments, the environments were actually typical of how rats live in the wild. Similarly, the natural environments in which most human babies live provide all the stimulation necessary for normal development.
Bruer's most debatable claim is that the rapid explosion of synapses in infancy is "under genetic, not environmental, control." But he is right that "more synapses do not necessarily mean more brainpower" and that the loss of synapses is not a result of inadequate stimulation; it is normal, necessary and unrelated to brain function. We lose synapses by the fistful by adulthood, but our knowledge and mental abilities continue to expand.
As Bruer observes, nowadays everyone feels the need to claim that science is on his or her side. Thus, the "I Am Your Child" campaign claims that "brain science" shows that you should be attentive; read, sing and talk to your baby; be selective about television; choose good day care. But how much reading and singing? How much attention? Neuroscience is silent.
Of course, the heart of this debate is not about what kind of mobiles middle-class parents should hang over their babies' cribs or whether listening to Mozart increases intelligence (it doesn't). It's about where society's resources should go in helping poor and disadvantaged children. Bruer argues that even the most intensive early-intervention programs, notably the Abecedarian Project in North Carolina and the nationwide Infant Health and Development Program, have had modest effects at best. They do boost school performance, but what matters most seems to be intensive training in academic skills over time. Otherwise, many of the benefits of early intervention wear off by adolescence.
BRUER worries that "the myth of the first three years" will persuade the public and lawmakers that once a child is older than 3, we might as well forget any other programs. According to Bruer, bills to reduce or eliminate support for programs for older children (let alone adults) are already being considered in some states: no point providing literacy and education programs in prisons or the military; no point improving schools -- such efforts are too little, too late. What the new brain science really shows is that it's never too late. Brain science can therefore be used to argue both that it's important to give babies a good start and that a good start is not enough. It can be used to support programs to help underweight, underprivileged babies and programs aimed at older children and their unemployed, malnourished or illiterate parents.
The book has several annoying qualities. It is poorly edited (at least 200 of my synapses were deadened by its repetitive conclusions). It lacks a bibliography, so readers cannot find sources easily or check for important citations without struggling through the inadequate notes. Over all, however, these complaints are like ants at a picnic: nuisances, but they need not detract from the ample food for thought. 
http://www.nytimes.com

LENGTH: 1026 words

HEADLINE: MEDIA;
A Strained Relationship Turns Sour

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB 

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 17

 BODY:
Like many relationships in Hollywood, the one between the trade papers -- Variety and The Hollywood Reporter -- and the movie studios is an odd one. The papers need studio advertisements to survive. And the studios need the trade papers to promote their latest deals, spin the news and learn what rivals are doing.
In this sometimes strained symbiosis, studios hold the economic leverage but haven't used it for years. Until last week. 
 In an unusual move, 20th Century Fox stopped all movie studio advertising in The Hollywood Reporter indefinitely, a move intended to damage the trade paper financially. Though executives at the studio, which is owned by the News Corporation, insisted that the decision was based on long-standing unhappiness with the way the trade paper was covering Fox, editors at The Hollywood Reporter, and just about everyone else in town, said that the reason for the economic boycott was simple: studio anger at the caustic comments in the newspaper about the new Fox film "Fight Club." The film opened this weekend with disappointing ticket sales and as of Sunday was No. 3 at the box office. The movie is a violent fantasy about men who pummel each other and go to physical extremes because they view their lives as miserable.
What enraged Fox executives were two Hollywood Reporter articles about the movie in the last two weeks. One brief article, written by Anita M. Busch, the newspaper's editor, and Thom Geier, a reporter, said that the openings of the film in Los Angeles and New York had been disastrous. Producers and agents were quoted, anonymously, as saying the big-budget movie was "loathsome," "absolutely indefensible" and "deplorable on every level."
Last week, in a prominently displayed column, Ms. Busch said that the movie "has drawn more gut anger from the industry than I've ever heard." Ms. Busch added: "And for good reason."
Ms. Busch said that the film "will become Washington's poster child for what's wrong with Hollywood. And Washington, for once, will be right." She wrote: "The film is exactly the kind of product that lawmakers should target for being socially irresponsible in a nation that has deteriorated to the point of Columbine," a reference to the high-school shootings in Colorado.
Fox followed with an economic boycott. Several rival studio marketing chiefs said that Fox would never take such a step against a big newspaper like The Times Mirror Company's Los Angeles Times, which printed a devastating review of the movie on Friday but is hardly as vulnerable to studio pressures as a trade paper.
And they said that because the studio had taken pride in the movie's provocative nature, and admitted that it would polarize audiences, Fox should not respond angrily to condemnations of "Fight Club." "It's part of the bargain to get attacked when you make this kind of movie," one marketing executive said.
Robert J. Dowling, the publisher and editor in chief of the newspaper, told his staff at a Monday meeting that Fox had warned him of "consequences" as a result of the "Fight Club" coverage, according to a participant. The potential loss of hundreds of thousands of dollars for The Hollywood Reporter could have a direct impact on raises, bonuses, travel and other contingencies, people close to the newspaper said. The paper is owned by the Dutch company VNU, which also owns trade magazines like Billboard and Adweek.
Mr. Dowling and Ms. Busch declined to discuss the matter.
Whatever the reason, the message sent to The Hollywood Reporter, and its rival, Variety, which is owned by Reed Elsevier Inc., was unmistakable. Both newspapers depend for their survival on nearly a dozen film studios and production companies and, to a lesser degree, television network advertising. In fact, the trade papers earn a hefty share of their income from November to January, during the Academy Award season. That's when studios with Oscar-hopeful films spend as much as $700,000, and perhaps far more, on campaigns in each of the trade newspapers. Television studios may also allot about $300,000 a year in trade paper advertising, mostly for the Emmys, though HBO spends far more.
In addition, both newspapers earn hundreds of thousands of dollars a year on ads placed by studios that appeal to the vanity of stars and filmmakers by congratulating them on their newest films and latest honorary awards.
The last time a Hollywood studio used leverage against a trade paper was in 1992, when Paramount stopped advertising in The Hollywood Reporter for at least four months after a series of articles that said, essentially, that the studio was using exploitative advertisements for the film "Juice," about Harlem teen-agers.
That year, Paramount took another unusual step. A studio spokesman said Paramount, now a unit of Viacom, would halt all company advertisements in Variety because of a scathing review of the film "Patriot Games." The editor of Variety, Peter Bart, sent a letter to Paramount executives, saying that the review, by Joseph McBride, "was, to put it in a word, unprofessional," and that the critic "will not review any more Paramount films." Mr. Bart later said the review was politically biased and did not address the artistic merits of the film, which negatively portrayed the Irish Republican Army. Mr. McBride later left the newspaper. Eventually, the advertising issue faded, though Mr. Bart said that the studio actually never stopped advertising.
But the studios learned the limits of their power in 1993. At the time, The Los Angeles Times was told by Columbia Studios, owned by Sony, that it was not welcome and that the studio was weighing a halt of its advertising in the newspaper, then $5 million a year. The reason? A Times article said that a research screening of "Last Action Hero" had taken place with poor results.
The studio said no such screening took place and demanded a correction and an assurance that the journalist who wrote the story would no longer cover the studio. The newspaper held its ground and in a few days, the issue faded. Michael Cieply, a Columbia producer, termed it "a tempest in an Evian bottle."

SECTION: Section E; Page 1; Column 3; The Arts/Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 1380 words

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
Design Fantasies for a Strip of the West Side

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
There are only three more days to see an exhibition of new designs for the redevelopment of the far West Side of mid-Manhattan. I strongly urge you to see the show, on display through Wednesday in Vanderbilt Hall, the former waiting room at Grand Central Terminal. The five proposals on view are not uniformly great, but each is packed with intelligence, energy and pure, raw city love. And one, by the British architect Cedric Price, is a gem.
The designs are finalists in a competition conceived by Phyllis Lambert, founding director of the Canadian Center for Architecture in Montreal. Every three years the competition (officially titled the International Foundation for the Canadian Center for Architecture Prize for the Design of Cities) will address the needs of a different city. New York was the chosen site for the inaugural year. 
 In addition to Mr. Price, the architects chosen to compete include Thom Mayne of Santa Monica, Calif.; Jesse Reiser and Nanako Umemoto of New York, and Ben van Berkel and Caroline Bos of Amsterdam. Peter Eisenman of New York won the competition and its $100,000 prize with a design developed with David Childs of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill.
The site for the competition is a 20-block strip of Manhattan that stretches from Eighth Avenue west to the Hudson River and is bound on the south by 30th Street and on the north by 34th. Included in the area is the General Post Office, formally known as the James A. Farley Building, which is scheduled to become the new Pennsylvania Station. Much of the site is occupied by a tangle of transportation infrastructure: train tracks, highway overpasses, tunnel entrances and bus parking.
The exhibition at Grand Central can be seen as an effort to fill the void left by the collapse of city planning in New York in recent decades. It is far from certain that architects are qualified to fill this vacuum, but it has become reasonably clear that local community boards aren't up to the task. Community activists can be highly effective at preventing projects from disrupting neighborhoods, but they have little interest in fostering new architecture of character and no reason to think about the vitality of the public realm beyond their own backyards.
Reactivating the public realm is the express concern of these five designs. How to draw people in? What combination of functions and forms can create a sense of place and a sense of time? The architectural teams are not your usual cast of warm, fuzzy people pleasers. No Hugh Hardy, no David Rockwell, no Jon Jerde. Rather, with the exception of Mr. Price, the competitors are known primarily as formalists. They set great stock in the pure esthetics of design, and their designs tend toward the cool and experimental.
The choice of these architects was clearly polemic. At a time when New York is stuck in the formulaic belief that the only way to attract people is by creating ersatz versions of the past, the competition's organizers hoped to stimulate innovative ideas for structuring social space.
Unfortunately Rem Koolhaas, the Dutch architect, chose not to compete. But most of the projects on view display Mr. Koolhaas's influence, if not in form then in scale. His concept of bigness, advocated in his 1995 book "S, M, L, XL," is the ruling principle that enables these architects to justify what are, in essence, megastructures: oversize buildings that contain an urban array of functions. Too, Mr. Koolhaas's firm, the Office for Metropolitan Architecture, established in 1975, has long advocated the expansion of architecture's sphere of influence over urban planning.
With the exception of Mr. Price, the finalists share some common traits. All use curves or waves to set the site area off from the surrounding regularity of the Manhattan grid. With varying degrees of looseness, they adopt the megastructural approach: bringing together urban activities within a large, comprehensive architectural framework.
The dense mix of functions -- offices, apartments, parks, indoor recreation, sports stadiums, shops -- corresponds to what Mr. Koolhaas has called New York's "culture of congestion." But it also holds appeal for developers eager to squeeze the last economic drop out of the city's limited land.
Perhaps New Yorkers will be most interested in the scheme proposed by Mr. Eisenman. I plan to write about this design later, along with another recent competition-winning proposal by Mr. Eisenman: a new cultural center for the Spanish pilgrimage town Santiago de Compostela. But I left Grand Central thinking that Mr. Price's design is the one that best deserves our attention before the exhibition closes.
Mr. Price, 65, is not well known in this country, but he has been a legendary figure in British architectural circles since the 1960's. His best-known project is the unbuilt Fun Palace, designed with the theatrical impresario Joan Littlewood in 1962. The work exerted considerable influence over the development of "high tech" architecture in the 1970's.
The Georges Pompidou Center in Paris, designed by Richard Rogers and Renzo Piano in 1971, is clearly descended from Mr. Price's Fun Palace. And his palace is also an ancestor of the megastructural approach adopted by most of the finalists in New York.
Mr. Price, however, has taken a very different route here. Playing a game of one-upmanship, his plan is as mortifying as only an Englishman knows how to be. In the Grand Central exhibition, allegedly avant-garde architects are falling all over themselves trying to show that they can outdo the developers on the developers' terms, and Mr. Price just strolls casually onto the site as if he were hiking across a moor, takes a few deep breaths and says: "Oh, no. It would be best if we didn't build here at all. Instead of building, we ought to be thinking about taking things down." Another deep breath. "We'll call it 'A Lung for Midtown Manhattan.' "
Mr. Price's "lung" essentially treats the site as a rectangular nature preserve. Train tracks would remain uncovered. New development would be banned. Over time some existing buildings would be eliminated. The site would be marked with a sparkling covering composed of small glass spheres.
The east and west boundaries would be fitted with tunnel-like structures that Mr. Price calls sleeves. These would be places people could go in any weather to contemplate views of the city and the river. They would also channel air from the river into the heart of the city. A third observation post would be created by excising two floors from an existing building that straddles the tracks.
Mr. Price's one-upmanship style extends to his mode of presentation. Instead of the glamorous computer renderings used by the other contestants, he offers rough pencil sketches that look as if they could have been dashed off on napkins between sips of claret. Even the term sleeves evokes drop-dead informality: custom tailoring of such exquisite refinement that a jacket turns out looking utterly shapeless.
Yet the truth is that this design is really the only one of the five that reaches beyond the formal qualities of architecture to deal with the quality of urban life. Mr. Price's chief concern, very simply, is with public health. It aims to improve the air, the amount of available light and the psychological release that open space provides. It is, in effect, a park in which the archeology of the industrial city takes the place of pastoral landscaping.
The design probably never stood a chance of winning. It can't pass for practical. City officials had already defined the site as the city's next great development corridor. But the idea of practicality is completely relative in this context. None of the projects are officially authorized. None have clients. The quality they project is not reality, but rather realness, to employ a term coined by uptown drag queens. They are practicality impersonators, developers en travesti.
Mr. Price chose not to go along with the impersonation. No massive new construction. No sports stadiums. No urban bone crunching. No high-tech structural calisthenics. No hay to be made. Just a light dusting of glass frosting and a breeze blowing from the river. Just a place for a city to breathe.

Bear Stearns Securities To Pay $3.5 Million More
Bear Stearns Securities, which processes securities transactions for thousands of smaller firms, has agreed to pay an additional $3.5 million to cover losses incurred by customers of A. R. Baron, a defunct brokerage firm whose trades it cleared.
The payment settles the claims against Bear Stearns brought by the trustee appointed to liquidate A. R. Baron. It brings to $42 million the total fines, restitution and court costs the firm has agreed to pay. Page C2. 

Nisource Raises Bid for Columbia
Nisource, a large Midwestern utility, has increased its bid for the Columbia Energy Group, a large natural gas company in the East, to $74 a share in cash, or $6.2 billion, Nisource said over the weekend. C22.
 
A 'Fight Club' Counterpunch
In the sometimes strained symbiosis between Hollywood studios and the trade papers Variety and The Hollywood Reporter, the studios hold the economic leverage but haven't used it for years. Until last week. In an unusual move, 20th Century Fox stopped all studio advertising in The Hollywood Reporter indefinitely because of caustic comments about the new Fox film "Fight Club." Ford to Revamp Its Organization
After five years of experimenting with a complex management structure that gave managers global responsibility for certain functions, like worldwide small-car development, Ford Motor plans to return to a more traditional organization in which many executives will have regional responsibilities. C14.
 
Linux Seen Going the Way of Unix
Just as the Unix computer operating system once promised to be the common language of open systems, Linux, itself a variant of Unix, has been held out as the standard for the open-source movement. But there is growing concern that just as Unix slid into chaos, the commercialization of Linux will lead to systems that cannot understand one another. C5.
 
Using Fans to Sell Internet Service
Marketing Internet access under the name of a group, school, team or other organization could prove a boon to profit-starved Internet service providers. Some analysts and executives predict that these so-called affinity service providers will become the dominant way Internet services attract subscribers. C5.
 
It's One Way to Get Attention
A small protest group, despairing of getting attention for their concerns about Year 2000 readiness of nuclear power and weapons systems, paraded naked through downtown San Francisco earlier this month. The march was led by Patch Adams, the iconoclastic physician, and Helen Caldicott, a noted figure in the antinuclear movement. It slowed traffic, made headlines and was ignored by the police. It also generated plenty of conversation among Year 2000 campaigners. C5.
 
SBC to Set Up Fast Web Links
SBC Communications intends to announce today that it will spend $6 billion over three years to deploy high-speed Internet connections, people close to the company said. C10.
