(Andy Manis for The New York Times); Remnants from Leopold's work: unused bird bands and notes about tagged birds written on his stationery. (Andy Manis for The New York Times)
 
Chart: "The Wisdom of Aldo Leopold"
 With his book "A Sand County Almanac and Sketches Here and There" (Oxford University Press, 1949), Aldo Leopold laid out a visionary philosophy that has shaped many of today's conservation efforts. Here are some excerpts.
 
 
 On the January Thaw
 A meadow mouse, startled by my approach, darts damply across the skunk track. Why is he abroad in daylight? Probably because he feels grieved about the thaw. Today his maze of secret tunnels, laboriously chewed through the matted grass under the snow, are tunnels no more, but only paths exposed to public view and ridicule. Indeed, the thawing sun has mocked the basic premises of the microtine economic system!
 The mouse is a sober citizen who knows that grass grows in order that mice may store it as underground haystacks, and that snow falls in order that mice may build subways from stack to stack: supply, demand and transport all neatly organized. To the mouse, snow means freedom from want and fear. ...
 A rough-legged hawk comes sailing over the meadow ahead. Now he stops, hovers like a kingfisher, and then drops like a feathered bomb into the marsh. He does not rise again, so I am sure he has caught, and is now eating, some worried mouse-engineer who could not wait until night to inspect the damage to his well-ordered world.
 The rough-leg has no opinion why grass grows, but he is well aware that snow melts in order that hawks may again catch mice. He came down out of the Arctic in the hope of thaws, for to him a thaw means freedom from want and fear.
 
 
 On Shooting Wolves
 We reached the old wolf in time to watch a fierce green fire dying in her eyes. I realized then and have known ever since, that there was something new to me in those eyes - something known only to her and to the mountain. I was young then, and full of trigger-itch; I thought that because fewer wolves meant more deer, that no wolves would mean hunters' paradise. But after seeing the green fire die, I sensed that neither the wolf nor the mountain agreed with such a view. ...
 Since then I have lived to see state after state extirpate its wolves. I have watched the face of many a newly wolfless mountain, and seen the south-facing slopes wrinkle with a maze of new deer trails. I have seen every edible bush and seedling browsed, first to anaemic desuetude, and then to death. I have seen every edible tree defoliated to the height of a saddlehorn. Such a mountain looks as if someone had given God a new pruning shears, and forbidden Him all other exercise. In the end, the starved bones of the hoped-for deer herd, dead of its own too-much, bleach with the bones of the dead sage, or molder under the high-lined junipers.
 I now suspect that just as a deer herd lives in mortal fear of its wolves, so does a mountain live in mortal fear of its deer. And perhaps with better cause, for while a buck pulled down by wolves can be replaced in two or three years, a range pulled down by too many deer may fail of replacement in as many decades.
 
 On the Land Ethic
 When godlike Odysseus returned from the wars in Troy, he hanged all on one rope a dozen slave-girls of his household whom he suspected of misbehavior during his absence.
 This hanging involved no questio of propriety. The girls were property. The disposal of property was then, as now, a matter of expedience not of right and wrong. ...
 The ethical structure of that day covered wives, but had not yet been extended to human chattels. During the three thousand years which have since elapsed, ethical criteria have been extended to many fields of conduct. ...
 There is as yet no ethic dealing with man's relation to land and to the animals and plants which grow upon it. Land, like Odysseus's slave-girls, is still property. The land-relation is still strictly economic, entailing privileges but not obligations.
The extension of ethics to this third element in human environment is, if I read the evidence correctly, an evolutionary possbility and an ecological necessity. ...
 All ethics so far evolved rest upon a single premise: that the individual is a member of a community of interdependent parts. His instincts prompt him to compete for his place in that community, but his ethics prompt him also to cooperate (perhaps in order that there may be a place to compete for).
 The land ethic simply enlarges the boundaries of the community to include soils waters, plants and animals, or collectively: the land. ...
 In short, a land ethic changes the role of Homo sapiens from conqueror of the land-community to plain member and citizen of it. It implies respect for his fellow-members, and also respect for the community as such.

HEADLINE: Some Urban Renewal For Country Music;
A Brash New Yorker Takes On Nashville

BYLINE: By NEIL STRAUSS 

DATELINE: NASHVILLE, Oct. 19

 BODY:
Earlier this month Pat Quigley, the president and chief executive of Capitol Nashville records, sat in his office with a computer printout of the previous week's national CD sales spread across his table.
He had just seen the first-week numbers for Garth Brooks's ambitious new project, an apocryphal greatest-hits rock album released under the pseudonym Chris Gaines, and Mr. Quigley was far from pleased. 
 Mr. Brooks, the Oklahoma-bred superstar, and Mr. Quigley, the brash New Yorker, knew that the Chris Gaines record would hardly sell as well as Mr. Brooks's country albums, which have shattered sales records with as many as a million copies sold in one week. But the label had sent three million copies of the rock album to stores, expecting sales of around 400,000 in its first week. Instead it sold only 262,000 copies, coming in at No. 2 in the pop charts.
"It's our fault," Mr. Quigley muttered. "Fans were confused. We have to do a better job educating them."
For Mr. Quigley's enemies in Nashville, this was a day of celebration. Since he moved here from New York just over two years ago, he has made few friends. Upon his arrival, the local alternative weekly blared a blood-red headline, "The Outsider: Will He Destroy Music Row?," and soon after, The Chicago Tribune dubbed him "the least liked man in Nashville."
Two years later Mr. Quigley has done little to change his status as an outsider. An unapologetic New Yorker, he was wearing a gray East Hampton sweatshirt and instead of beer in his office, there was a glass-front refrigerator full of wine bottles.
"I'm certainly not one of them," he said, referring to the denizens of Music Row. "I don't believe I'll ever be accepted as one of them. They're probably not going to be in my social calendar anyway."
Mr. Quigley is emblematic of the juncture at which Nashville now finds itself, caught between the old small-town, family-style way of doing business and a big-city, results-driven attitude, especially recently as the business has been rocked by cutbacks from the labels' multinational parent companies. It is represented not just in country music, with the taste gap widening between older legends like George Jones and contemporary pop stars like Shania Twain, but in the city itself, where country charm is being paved over to make way for urban sprawl.
The kitschy Opryland amusement park was torn down for a gargantuan mall, and the once-rustic honky-tonk-filled downtown is now overrun by scaffolding and cranes promising a shiny cosmopolitan future. Add to this Dell Computer's recently announced plan to relocate part of its operations to the Nashville area, the construction of a $192 million stadium and $140 million arena (plus N.H.L. and N.F.L. teams to put inside them), and a metro-area population that has boomed past the one million mark, and you have a city with major growing pains.
Mr. Quigley is one of them. He is a strong-willed stranger whose heart and head remain entrenched in New York and his international marketing background, bent on remaking country in his own image.
"I get Town and Country magazine, and it's very elegant magazine," he said, settling into a couch in his office. "Country for me in Manhattan was the Hamptons. Why does country have to be some backwards place in 'Deliverance'?
"As I watch what is selling in country, the superstars making traditional country aren't moving big volume anymore. It's the poppier influenced country music that's really moving the big volume. Look at the statistics: Faith Hill's No. 1 market is New York City; Shania Twain's is New York City; Garth's is either New York, Los Angeles or Chicago. As you start to see the New York, Chicago, and Los Angeles influence, I think country music gets afraid that it's losing its identity."
Doing his part to add to the identity crisis, Mr. Quigley, 49, has registered the words "town and country" as a trademark for music, hoping to dress country up in new clothes that will make it look less rural and more middle-class.
"I own those words for music," he said proudly. "When I do town and country music, it will also be Bruce Springsteen, Bonnie Raitt, Bob Seger. America is so much better educated than a lot of the music this town makes." Although Mr. Quigley's ambition to think nationally instead of regionally when selling country music (just as the pop-music industry has begun to think internationally instead of just nationally) seems good for the genre, almost every move he has made here has been dogged by protest or controversy. These range from his ascendancy as president of Capitol Nashville (even his supporters say it was a result of a coup engineered by a disgruntled Garth Brooks) to the unorthodox techniques he has used to market his albums. Those include paying radio stations to announce the names of Capitol acts after playing their music, lowering the prices of new records below the industry norm, and taking Mr. Brooks's old albums off the market before releasing a box set of his past music.
In a music scene as tight-knit and familial as Nashville's, Mr. Quigley makes no attempts to be a team player. This is evident in Capitol's absence from the board of the Country Music Association, and in the location of its offices.
While all the other major labels in Nashville are lined up along the parallel streets of town houses and small office buildings known as Music Row, Capitol Nashville sits in an anonymous building more than a mile away. The label's previous president had planned to relocate to Music Row, but one of the first things Mr. Quigley did when he took over was to break the lease, at a loss.
As a result of Capitol's isolationism, other record labels have not been quick to leap to the company's aid. Concerned about the lack of a radio station playing country music in a market as vital as New York, Mr. Quigley once offered to buy half the advertising time of a prospective New York broadcaster if it would take on a country format, but only if the other labels in Nashville agreed to buy the other half. They unanimously declined.
Mr. Quigley probably would have been driven out of town if his label were not doing so well, a success owed to the sales juggernaut that is Mr. Brooks. Even one of Mr. Quigley's detractors on Music Row, speaking on condition of anonymity, admitted: "While a lot of the music industry was down on the fact that Pat lowered the price on Garth's CD's, he shipped 32 million units. I don't think anyone has done that before or is likely to do that again."
Last year 1 in every 10 country records that sold was a Brooks album, making Capitol the most profitable label in town. Although rival executives may be impressed, they refer condescendingly to Mr. Quigley as a "Garth robot," a figurehead at a label they say is run by the singer whose album sales pay its bills.
"I read something the other day that called me 'the self-proclaimed yes man of Garth,' " Mr. Quigley said. "I do what he wants -- my way."
Steve Wariner, a respected singer and songwriter since the early 70's who began recording for Capitol Nashville last year, said he had witnessed many arguments between Mr. Quigley and Mr. Brooks. "As far as Pat being a yes man to Garth, that's not true," he said.
Mr. Wariner said one of the reasons he chose to sign with Capitol, besides his friendship with Mr. Brooks, was Mr. Quigley's style. Mr. Wariner recalled his first meeting with Mr. Quigley: "He said: 'I know your name. Garth's talked about you. Some of the people here have talked about you. But I've never heard of you. I don't know any of your music. I don't know anything about you.' I thought it was refreshing, and I loved the honesty of the approach.
"The only thing is, I lean on Pat a little bit because he does not want people in Nashville to like him," Mr. Wariner added. "He makes statements that I wish he wouldn't. I find myself defending him a lot."
Spending time with Mr. Quigley, one realizes that one of the most repeated criticisms about him is true: He is a marketing man, not a music man. With a background of selling everything from skis to watches to beer, he is representative of a new breed of executive in the recording industry, where the music men -- the former songwriters and producers who have dominated the business -- are being replaced by international businessmen who could just as easily be selling Internet stocks.
Mr. Quigley often refers to Capitol Nashville not as a record label but as a marketing company. He is not an executive who uses his ears, but one who uses his eyes, analyzing audience research statistics and sales charts. When playing music from a new album by Keith Urban, who collaborated with the rhythm-and-blues producer Stevie J., Mr. Quigley stopped the CD.
"Listen to that lyric, 'You're the only one,' " he said. "Doesn't everyone want to hear that?"
"I was looking for Keith to get the female agenda and apply it to a sensitive new man," Mr. Quigley said.
In a move that is not too surprising, considering the sudden explosion of all-female country groups, Mr. Quigley has also been looking to create a country equivalent of the Backstreet Boys, or, as he likes to call his pet project, the Backwoods Boys.
"We're deep in the inquiry process," he said. "I want these kids to have something to say to normal people, to America. But they can't talk to the inner city. They have to talk about small-town life. That's where America is, that's where their heart is. Whether you live on 79th Street or Main Street in some small town, you want to care about each other."
"I think it should be the goal of Nashville to have 33 percent of all pop radio air play country, and none of the country air play pop," he continued. "We're culturally important. We're not just dinosaurs here."
So far the Chris Gaines project has been Mr. Quigley's first significant setback in Nashville. Although the album has made Mr. Brooks the butt of many jokes around town, Mr. Quigley remains optimistic about the singer's future. He plans to resuscitate Mr. Brooks's country career quickly with an album of Christmas songs. And rival executives in Nashville will not be too happy about the cutthroat price he plans for the full-length CD: $11.99, or $9.99 with a special offer.
"It's tough on my family sometimes because there's very little positive in this town," Mr. Quigley said. "But they've got a nice house, a nice car and a father who seems to be very happy with what he does. We'll get through it."

SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 1; Dining In, Dining Out/Style Desk

HEADLINE: EN ROUTE: Australia;
Sydney's On Top Of the World

SERIES: The second of three reports from Australia.

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: SYDNEY, Australia

 BODY:
PARIS, surely, and New York and probably London, but after that it's hard to think of another city that matches Sydney, the home port of the good life, for the sheer excellence and exuberance of its restaurants.
Fabulous raw materials -- especially fish and shellfish from the unpolluted seas that surround this island continent, and tropical fruits from Queensland -- give Sydney's cooks a head start. Drawn from a polyglot population, they bring the techniques and traditions of China, France, Malaysia, Thailand, Italy and a dozen other nations to their work. 
 You can taste Greece in Janni Kyritsis' food and French Canada in Serge Dansereau's, Japan in Tetsuya Wakuda's and Britain in Daryll Taylor's. Along with home-grown talents like Neil Perry and David Thompson, they are helping to define a national approach to food, rooted in a love of Australian produce.
Sydney attracts great chefs for the same reason that the University of California at San Diego attracts Nobel Prize-winning scientists: they jump at the chance to work alongside talented peers in a benign climate. Once here, they are egged on by a horde of foodies -- prosperous, cosmopolitan folk who think nothing of hopping onto a jet for a weekend in San Francisco or a week in the south of France.
Tens of thousands of American and other foreign visitors will travel here for the 2000 Olympics, the Millennium Games. In the months leading up to the sporting spectacle, which starts in September, Sydney will offer not one but two world-class arts festivals organized by Australia's leading impresario, Leo Schofield. "There is an incredible optimism among restaurateurs in Sydney about what the Olympics will bring us," said Carolyn Lockhart, editor of Australian Gourmet Traveller. "We've been little old deprived Australia for a long time. Now we're stars. It's incredible. I love it."
Many of the foreigners will be surprised to see passion fruit on sale for 15 cents apiece at downtown fruit stands, or to find 800 people jamming a single dim sum restaurant on a Sunday, with 200 more waiting, as my wife, Betsey, and I did not long ago. Most will be astonished by the subtlety and variety of what they find on their own lunch and dinner plates.
UNTIL the late 1970's, eating in Sydney was about as exciting as a two-note symphony. The city had more lager louts than epicures. Most people ate because they had to, and for no other reason. Now even the grace notes are attended to. Salads are perfectly dressed, and good coffee, often from Illy or Lavazza or Segafredo in Italy, has become a national obsession.
The restaurant revolution here has been matched in many other cities, of course. You eat unimaginably better food today in Toronto and Dallas and Munich than you did only a few years ago. But in Sydney the change has penetrated much more deeply into the food culture; it is not just in the most ambitious restaurants that times have changed. Standards have also improved in the corner bistros, neighborhood joints, cafes and delis.
Australian wine has also taken giant steps, and service has kept pace as well. In the United States, we are often told that overfamiliar, underinformed waiters and waitresses are the inevitable products of a classless society. But Australia is at least as egalitarian as we are, if not more so, yet people wait on table with a perfect mixture of good cheer and deep knowledge of what they are serving.
Stodge is out, light is in and the Herculean helpings of old have been banished. In just two years, the compulsion to combine five civilizations and three continents in a soup bowl has eased. But the Asian influence, pervasive if not quite omnipresent, still sets Sydney apart.
"We're just as happy with chopsticks as a knife and fork," says the current edition of The Sydney Morning Herald's comprehensive "Good Food Guide." "To us, the Far East is the Near Northwest, and eating in an Asian manner -- albeit a modernized one -- is as natural as breathing."
ALL by himself, Neil Perry sums up the Sydney food scene. Like Jean-Georges Vongerichten in New York, he speaks many culinary languages, all fluently. Rockpool, his home base, is an oasis of high-tech urban chic in the city's oldest neighborhood, with brushed-steel chairs and lighting cunningly devised to flatter the profiles of the city's beautiful people. But Rockpool draws people from many races, age groups and economic levels, not just the cream of Nescafe society.
Like many of the best Sydney restaurants, Rockpool makes no distinction between starters and main courses; you choose as you like, as if you were in China or Japan. We didn't choose at all. Mr. Perry, who wears a ponytail and is habitually dressed in black when not wearing chef's whites, sent out a series of things he said he felt especially proud of. All showed his special talent for fusing improbably matched ingredients to produce new flavors -- one example after another of the sum's far exceeding its parts.
Examples: a delicate shrimp custard, shimmying on the plate like My Sister Kate, with cauliflower puree and just a filament of spinach oil; translucent slivers of slow-cooked abalone -- often tough and tasteless, here tender and succulent -- with tree mushrooms and a noodle salad, and a plate of new-age surf and turf: a chunk of tuna, cooked Texas-rare, studded with anchovies and roasted garlic, perched on a bed of mashed potatoes, with bone marrow and red wine sauce.
"It all comes back to produce," Mr. Perry said after dinner. "A cook in London uses Asian vegetables flown from Thailand, usually two or three days old. We're more like California, with everything close at hand. Especially fish; Nobu in New York gets some of its fish from my supplier."
Wockpool, a second Perry enterprise, is less formal, more overtly Asian and breathtakingly situated at the edge of Darling Harbor. Two of the best dishes we ate on this latest trip to Sydney -- right up there with the most dazzling creations of David Thompson's Darley Street Thai, which is sadly scheduled to close soon, when Mr. Thompson retires -- came out of the Wockpool kitchen.
A salad including bits of crispy pork, hot chilies, batons of green pawpaw and slices of cucumber was sweet and acid and hot and cool, all at the same time. An irresistible dessert combined layers of ginger ice cream and intensely flavored pineapple sorbet in a crumb crust, with see-through slices of pineapple on top.
Mr. Perry's latest, called Bistro Mars, pays homage to the everyday cooking of provincial France, with solid renditions of dishes like ouefs en meurette -- poached eggs in a red wine sauce, with lardons and tiny onions. The setting is button-bright, with glass-top tables, buttercup-yellow plastic chairs and a giant Moreton Bay fig tree just outside, but the service, to tell the unvarnished truth, reminded us more of Mars than of France.
WHAT Sydney has lacked has been a formal, celebratory space with first-class cooking. None of the Perry operations qualifies, and Tetsuya's, Sydney's shrine of fusion cuisine, where the confit of ocean trout sends many diners into sighs of rapture, is a plain room in a plainer suburb.
Banc has closed the gap. With tall, octagonal marble pillars, Limoges plates and Christofle cutlery, it slips easily into its tony neighborhood, and the food is made for high rollers. I liked a frothy cauliflower soup with beignets, a fine example of how to take a cheap ingredient and turn it into something elegant, and an old favorite given a face lift: tournedos Rossini, with the fillet rolled in truffle oil, left to marinate for a week, grilled stuffed with foie gras and truffles and wrapped in prosciutto.
In the same part of town, Sydney has just acquired a gastrodome on the scale of Dean & DeLuca in New York, Peck in Milan and KaDeWe in Berlin, something it has never had. Simon Johnson, grocer to the city's carriage trade, and Stan Sarris, proprietor of successful coffeehouses and restaurants, including Banc, have filled the entire bottom floor of Sydney's grand old General Post Office with a foodie's fantasy. It includes an enormous selection of meat and cheese, fish and shellfish, fruits and vegetables, along with prepared foods from Australia and overseas and meals to take home. Also a first-class steakhouse (Prime), which meets another need here; a bar called Tank, complete with tapas; a sushi bar (So Su Mi) with a tiny train carrying the goodies to the customers; a crustacean bar; an espresso bar, and a brasserie.
"This is all about theater," Mr. Johnson said. Exotic Australian shellfish, including antipodean specialties like yabbies, marrons and Balmain bugs, are laid out on ice. Sides of beef, lamb and game hang in a glass-sided aging room, and cheeses from Europe and Australia are kept in a walk-in larder at 95 percent humidity.
The whole thing is epic in scale and ambition: 500,000 square feet of black-and-white marble floors, tile, glass and stainless steel, representing an investment of about $3.5 million. What also sets it apart is its location squarely in the city's business center, on a broad pedestrian plaza called Martin Place. It is as if Balducci's were to move to Wall Street. No fewer than 67 banks have offices within a couple of blocks.
IF Banc is Sydney's answer to the Four Seasons, Forty-One is its counterpart to the old Windows on the World. You sit in deep leather chairs, sipping a glass of Krug, eating Tasmanian oysters with a Vietnamese dipping sauce, aquamarine walls behind you, the vast harbor spread out beyond the glass in front of you. That's for starters. Later, a floor higher, you might try Dieter Sawyere's Yamba prawns with Indian spices or crown roast of hare, a masterpiece in miniature.
A Swiss, Mr. Sawyere has no patience with the empty flourish, but his capacity for taking pains with details is vast. "He missed a career in microsurgery," said Mr. Schofield, a gourmand as well as a showman.
The harbor is also part of the charm at the newly refurbished Bathers Pavilion in Balmoral, a close-in suburb. The water lies alluringly just beyond a row of louvered windows, open in good weather (which is to say about 350 days a year), and the day we ate there with Australian friends a whale was cavorting offshore, or so people said. Between bites, they were debating whether it was male or female, Alexander or Alexandra.
Built in 1928, the Pavilion has been transformed by the arrival of Serge Dansereau, a Quebec native who helped reshape Australian cooking during his years at the Regent Hotel in Sydney, persuading farmers to raise crops like fir-apples especially for him. In an improbably green, deliriously delicious pea soup with garlic and sorrel, and a chocolate miroir with blood orange sauce, he uses sharp-tasting secondary ingredients to set off the richness of the primary products.
Like any good eating city, Sydney has its Italian stars. Bob Carr, the premier of New South Wales, took us to one of his favorites, Lucio's, an artists' hangout where Lucio Galletto, who comes from La Spezia, near Genoa, served us a whole fish beautifully roasted in a salt crust. Bel Mondo, more modern and more Milanese in style, serves the best homemade pasta in town, a barbecued duck with balsamic vinegar and superbly chosen wines. But I would give the Mediterranean medal to a master from another peninsula.
Janni Kyritsis, a soft-spoken Greek, used to cook at Bennelong in the spectacular Sydney Opera House when it was the toast of Sydney. Now he cooks in a converted auto showroom called MG Garage, with a real MG on display (and priced on the menu). His food is decidedly Mediterranean, and he uses citrus flavors in many dishes: grilled lemon with a Sicilian-style red mullet, which he stuffs with pine nuts, and a touch of orange in a lip-smacking galantine of suckling pig served with broad beans and lentils.
But he is equally adept at the fusion game. His bone-marrow dumpling is made from Australian beef, marinated in tapenade from southern France, encased in an English dumpling batter, served on wok-fried spinach. It tasted entirely logical, as if it came from some great-aunt's cookbook.
THE influence of modern British cooking is writ large in Sydney, partly because Britain, too, is a kind of gastronomic magpie.
At Jersey Cow, a cozy neighborhood bistro in Victorian Paddington with charming chalk drawings of bemused bovines hanging on the walls, the menu lists things like house-made pork sausages with bean puree, a tomato and caramelized onion tart and Lancashire hot pot. Daryll Taylor cooked at Franco Taruschio's celebrated Walnut Tree Inn in Wales, and a couple of its Italian specialties, like a seafood brodetto, make an appearance as well.
Luke Mangan, another Englishman, and Lucy Allon, an Australian, greet guests at Salt, another of the city's hot new places, with a not-quite-hard-boiled quail egg, rolled in salt and celery salt. Ms. Allon read not long before the restaurant opened that salt symbolized hospitality and friendship in ancient Greece.
The room is lean and mean, with lavender banquettes. The menu is packed with innovations like shredded shoulder of lamb with cabbage, thyme and black olives. But few people can resist, at least on a first visit, Mr. Mangan's trademark rabbit tart: a crust filled with creamy polenta instead of creme patissiere, then topped with strips of slightly gamy roasted rabbit, shiitake mushroom slices and rich juices from the roasting pan.
On top of everything else, Australia has developed a cafe culture to rival Vienna's. Try breakfast at Bill's, a street-corner spot in the trendy Darlinghurst section. You sit around a big square table next to media types, moms with kids in strollers and people from nearby design offices, and you eat: big bowls of sliced tropical fruits, coconut-bread toast, sweet corn fritters, spring onion pancakes with gravlax, ricotta hotcakes with butter and honey. Why doesn't my town, or your town, have something like this?

SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 4; Dining In, Dining Out/Style Desk 

LENGTH: 1390 words

HEADLINE: RESTAURANTS;
A Face Lift For a Polished Performer

BYLINE: By William Grimes 

 BODY:
AUREOLE may be New York's foremost celebrity restaurant. It deserves the title not because celebrities eat there but because, in the classic definition, it is a restaurant famous for being famous. Diners fill Aureole's tables day after day and night after night, partly because it serves very good food but mostly because, like Everest -- the quintessential celebrity mountain -- it is there, and famously there. In the last 10 years, however, the surrounding peaks look a lot higher.
Aureole opened its doors in November 1988 on a swelling wave of expectation. Charlie Palmer, its chef and owner, had earned a warm spot in the hearts of New Yorkers at the River Cafe in Brooklyn, where he specialized in a French-American hybrid style usually described as New American. His new venture, in a self-effacing Upper East Side town house, took off quickly and never slowed down, riding out the recession without a bump. It was awarded three stars by Bryan Miller in The New York Times in 1991 and today, Aureole is still one of the city's most popular and revered restaurants. 
 The reasons are perfectly understandable. Aureole serves appealing food in stylish surroundings. The service is polished, the atmosphere warm. But Manhattan has no shortage of restaurants that could be described in the same way. Very few of them have achieved Aureole's invincible appeal.
It is no coincidence that the restaurant's ascent coincided with the growing influence of the Zagat Survey. Aureole's reputation exemplifies, to an extreme degree, the self-levitating phenomenon that I think of as the Zagat Effect, in which a restaurant, once it has achieved a top rating, continues to do so year after year, regardless of the quality of the food. Diners flock to it, Zagat guide in hand (either literally or metaphorically) and, convinced that they are eating at a top-flight establishment, cannot bring themselves to believe otherwise.
The approach and style that once dazzled New York seem rather commonplace today, however. The rising culinary tide that has made New York such an important international restaurant city has behaved in a peculiar way, lifting most restaurants while leaving others not exactly high and dry, but a little stuck. Aureole, despite a brand-new face lift by the designer Adam Tihany, is one of these.
Mr. Palmer likes big effects. His dishes tend to come on strong, make a big statement and then, as often as not, wear out their welcome, in part because portions are large, in part because his hand can be heavy. Aureole's signature sea scallop sandwich is a good example. The scallops, although rich and flavorful, come surrounded by a nimbus of finely shredded deep-fried potato that makes them look like two tumbleweeds on a plate. It's a sight to see, but a very oily eating experience.
An appetizer of seared foie gras, accompanied by an ingenious round cushion of gingerbread and a caramelized pear, is sweeter than most of the desserts, and the filet mignon also lands with a thud. It's a substantial tower of tender beef accompanied by a fistful of plain haricots verts and what seems to be an enormous charred egg roll, which on closer inspection turns out to be grated potato in a thin potato casing. It has all the subtlety of a blackjack.
When Mr. Palmer pulls it all together, his food has an unfussy, direct appeal that makes other chefs seem neurotic. His stuffed squid, served on a bed of arugula and celery root, is a Mediterranean feast, with crunchy tentacles providing a textural contrast to a smooth, fragrant stuffing of ground shrimp, cod and squid.
The chowder of crab and littleneck clams, a brawny, no-nonsense appetizer, takes an unexpected turn with potato dumplings enriched with braised leeks. A terrine of eggplant caviar, goat cheese and tomato confit, sharpened up with a touch of balsamic vinegar, seems a little austere at first, but Mr. Palmer gives it a touch of distinction by folding in some basil mousse. It's good enough to disguise the fact that like many of the offerings on the menu, it's little more than a fancified bistro dish.
The best entrees, like pan-seared quail with sauteed foie gras, cornbread and chanterelles, have a winning simplicity to them. The flavors are direct and concentrated, and there's an imaginative twist that adds intrigue to what otherwise might be a plodder. Pork tenderloin, for example, comes in a wrapping of prosciutto that gives a salty bite to the meat and brings out the sweetness of the apple jus. Caramelized pork cheeks and a white-bean ragout make the dish a very high-toned blue-plate special.
Two dishes jump off the high dive into sheer indulgence. Braised lobster with lobster ravioli luxuriates in a satiny tarragon-butter sauce that has a Gilded Age opulence to it. Stewed root vegetables add a brilliant common touch, the culinary equivalent of knocking off a top hat with a snowball. The ballottine of duck, another platinum-card dish, pulls no punches. A whole deboned duck, juicy and tender, becomes the very expensive gift wrap for a stuffing of porcini mushrooms, roasted figs and foie gras. The intelligently selected wine list does not have the category "monster reds," but it might be a good idea. This is one occasion when you want a bottle that's led snarling from a cage.
Richard Leach, Aureole's original pastry chef, has long since departed for Park Avenue Cafe, taking his quirky brilliance with him. The restaurant's desserts are rather tame and undistinguished on the whole, although I liked the loose, custardy creme brulee, served in a deep ceramic pot, and the creamy lemon custard, a triple threat served with citrus mousse and lemon creme anglaise.
If diners tend to inflate the Aureole experience, it's not hard to see why. The food comes in a very attractive setting, made more so by Mr. Tihany's subtle but effective makeover. For sentimental reasons, he has left intact a section of white wall with white bas-reliefs of flying ducks, but the rest of the restaurant has been done over in brown, red-orange and beige, warming up the dining rooms and giving them a cozy feel without looking stodgy. Subtle hip-retro touches suggest a showplace modern living room, circa 1959, an effect reinforced by the abstract art borrowed from Pace Prints.
Perhaps most important, Mr. Tihany has eliminated "Siberia," the upstairs section near the kitchen, by installing a divider and a booth that put the kitchen activity at a distance.
Aureole continues to be what it has always been, a very civilized dining spot on the edge of a very tony Upper East Side. It continues to attract, in large numbers, the crowd that it always has. The restaurant has changed very little, in fact, but the world around it has changed a lot.
 
Aureole
**
 RATING: Two Stars
34 East 61st Street; (212) 319-1660.
 
ATMOSPHERE: French-accented American cuisine in an intimate, elegant town house setting.
SOUND LEVEL: Somewhat louder than the setting might suggest.
RECOMMENDED DISHES: Shrimp-stuffed squid; eggplant caviar, goat cheese and tomato terrine; quail with foie gras; braised lobster with lobster ravioli; ballottine of duck; lemon custard with citrus mousse; creme brulee.
SERVICE: Highly professional.
WINE LIST: A solid, reasonably priced 325-bottle list, mostly French and American, with 21 half bottles and 20 wines by the glass.
PRICE RANGE: Lunch, appetizers, $8 to $42; entrees, $20 to $29; desserts, $8.50 to $10; three-course "market lunch," $33. Dinner, three-course prix fixe, $65; tasting menu, $85.
HOURS: Lunch, Monday through Friday, noon to 2:30 P.M. Dinner, Monday through Friday, 5:30 P.M. to 11 P.M.; Saturday 5 P.M. to 11:30 P.M. Closed Sunday.
CREDIT CARDS: All major cards.
WHEELCHAIR ACCESS: Four steps down at entrance, three steps down to the dining room. Restrooms are in the basement.

SECTION: Section E; Page 1; Column 2; The Arts/Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 1509 words

HEADLINE: A Doyen Endures the Dishing-Out

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL 

 BODY:
Not for 25 years has Schuyler Garrison Chapin endured such indignities -- carping friends, and days of opening the papers to read about when he might be thrown out of his job.
But Mr. Chapin, the city's genteel 76-year-old Cultural Affairs Commissioner, who finds himself in a cross-fire over Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's punitive measures against the Brooklyn Museum of Art, is not easily offended. "At my age," he said, citing the late Harold R. Medina, a Federal judge who died in 1990 at 102, "it's very hard to get insulted by anything." 
 Still, critics are trying. Since Oct. 8, when Mr. Chapin politely dissented with the Mayor's cutoff of $7.2 million in city funds over the museum's "Sensation" exhibition and urged him to restore the money, support for his stand from those who oppose the Mayor critics has been tempered by complaints that he spoke out too little too late. Arts groups in particular have maintained a disdainful silence while their members privately deride Mr. Chapin for equivocating and clearing his dissent with City Hall.
"Everyone second-guesses, everyone is gifted with 20-20 hindsight," Mr. Chapin said in a recent interview, while acknowledging that in retrospect he might have handled the matter directly, seeking a meeting with the Mayor to voice his concerns instead of merely transmitting City Hall's message that the Brooklyn Museum either cancel the exhibition or lose city financing. The museum has sued the city in Federal Court in Brooklyn to get its funding back; a decision is expected shortly.
The affair, centering on a painting of the Virgin Mary that Mr. Giuliani denounced as "sick" and insulting to Roman Catholics, sent the usually cheery Mr. Chapin hurtling from initial shock to despondency. "I hoped it would explode and go away," he said. But now, he added, "everybody's emotion is like a tinderbox."
Attired in a crisp blue shirt and print tie impaled with a large safety-pin tie clip -- "I hate a flopping tie," he noted -- with his steel-gray hair swept back into an accustomed pompadour, he said he was committed to staying on as the $133,000-a-year official who coordinates cultural policy for the city's roughly 1,400 art groups and institutions and administers more than 500 cultural service grants. In his one trip to City Hall since his statement he said he detected no signs of hostility from the Mayor.
"The fact that the Mayor agreed to let me be public says a great deal about the relationship I seem to have with him," Mr. Chapin said. In his statement on Oct. 8, Mr. Chapin said that while he personally found many exhibits in the show "distasteful," the city's contribution "is not intended to support any particular exhibit, nor the viewpoint of any particular artist," and he urged the Mayor to restore financing.
He called the restoration of an arts curriculum to the schools after a 25-year absence a high point of the Mayor's achievements, and a goal that Mr. Chapin worked hard to realize. When Mr. Giuliani, crediting Mr. Chapin, announced it at his State of the City speech in 1997, Mr. Chapin recounted unabashedly, "I started to cry." He said that when some friends once assailed Mr. Giuliani as combative, he said he knew there was another side to the Mayor, which included a love for the arts, and he told his friends: "I am the commissioner of his soul."
If Mr. Chapin, a doyen of the arts who makes light of a lineage going back 10 generations to New Amsterdam, cherishes hopes of surviving this crisis, it may be because he has weathered so many others in a career stretching back half a century.
Most painful, although now he jokes about it, was his stormy tenure as general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, a role he was thrust into in 1972 after the newly named successor to Sir Rudolf Bing, Goeran Gentele, died in a car crash. With meager support from the board, he grappled with a financial crisis, a fire that destroyed thousands of costumes in a Bronx warehouse and dilution of his authority in favor of an overseer, Anthony A. Bliss, in the newly created post of executive director. All the while newspapers offered regular accounts of how he was about to be dumped, which he and unceremoniously was, in June 1975.
He became the dean of Columbia University's School of the Arts, although he had never attended college or even finished high school after his father's death left the family in precarious straits. Columbia's president at the time, William J. McGill, glossed over Mr. Chapin's educational shortcomings with the justification, "Oh well, it's the arts."
He went on to write three books and and in 1983 was named by President Ronald Reagan to the President's Committee on the Arts and the Humanities. He was married for 46 years to Elizabeth Steinway, of the piano family, who died in 1993. In 1995 he married Catia Z. Mortimer in a ceremony at Gracie Mansion, with the Mayor officiating.
Mr. Chapin had set his eyes early on a career in composing, not arts management. But his teacher, the redoubtable Nadia Boulanger, sized him up quickly with the pronouncement, "My dear, you've no talent." After service as a pilot in World War II, he worked for the premier classical music agency, Columbia Artists Management, and then Columbia Records, was hired as vice president for programming for the new Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts and became executive producer for Leonard Bernstein's Amberson Productions.
If his administrative skills as an opera manager were sometimes devalued, his character and integrity were not. When he hired John Dexter, the British director, as the Met's production supervisor in 1974, Mr. Dexter said, "I have no contract -- only what used to be called a gentleman's agreement with Schuyler Chapin, which with him means an agreement like iron."
Unlike some other more fearsome arts managers, Mr. Chapin did not give ulcers -- he got them, collapsing in 1977 with an attack requiring an operation called a Billroth II, which he proudly notes was named for a physician friend of Brahms's. It ended his lifelong devotion to vodka martinis, leaving him a happy devotee of La Doucette, his favorite Loire white.
As the Brooklyn Museum controversy swirled recently and he was agonizing over what to do, Mr. Chapin sat in his 14th-floor offices in the old McGraw-Hill Building at 330 West 42d Street, as impeccably groomed as an escapee from the windows of J. Press.
He said he had never met Mr. Giuliani before the 1993 election, but was consulted during the search for a cultural affairs commissioner and resolved, "If this job is offered to me I'm going to take it." It was and he did.
He said that he and the Mayor-elect had hit it off from the outset, although Mr. Chapin confessed that it was he, as manager of the Metropolitan Opera, who had terminally insulted one of Mr. Giuliani's idols, Renata Tebaldi, by suggesting that she seek easier repertory to preserve her declining voice.
But his path as Commissioner was often strewn with boulders, Mr. Chapin acknowledged. In particular, he said, in the administration's first term, he and John S. Dyson, the Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, clashed repeatedly over allocation of the arts budget. Mr. Dyson favored grants to large institutions at the expense of more marginal groups. Mr. Chapin championed a balance, but, undoubtedly more than appointees in the mayor's inner circle, he was frequently bypassed in the decision-making process, a pattern re-enacted in the Brooklyn Museum episode.
Since the issue erupted with a mayoral denunciation on Sept. 22, said Mr. Chapin, he has been deluged with calls and letters. One person who prodded him for a strong response was a longtime friend, Kenneth Dayton, a retired chief executive of the Dayton Hudson Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest retailer. In an interview, Mr. Dayton said that in a private letter to Mr. Chapin he offered this advice: "As a leading spokesman for the arts he should speak out; if he couldn't he should resign."
Mr. Dayton excoriated arts groups for not speaking out more quickly and forcefully. "I couldn't believe it," he said. "I just couldn't believe that an arts community pictured as not provincial would fall so low as to be silent in the face of this threat to artistic freedom."
Arts groups say they acted swiftly to condemn the Mayor, but waited a day to give the museum and City Hall a chance to quietly resolve their differences.
Vartan Gregorian, president of the Carnegie Corporation and a former president of the New York Public Library, said that Mr. Chapin had called him for advice and Mr. Gregorian did not hold back. "Time is of the essence," he said he urged Mr. Chapin. "One way or the other, you either support the Mayor or disassociate yourself from him. You can't do both."
"If you lose the cultural institutions' trust, you're of no use to the Mayor," Mr. Gregorian said he told the Commissioner, adding, "If the Mayor is smart he will recognize you are needed as a bridge of understanding."

HEADLINE: Annan Says Quick Elections in Kosovo May Not Help Tensions

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19

 BODY:
The Secretary General of the United Nations, Kofi Annan, warned today that the "built-in tension" between the ethnic Albanians in Kosovo who want independence and the United Nations, which is administering the territory as part of Yugoslavia, would mount as time goes on.
Mr. Annan suggested that he had no immediate solution to the problem but stressed that holding quick elections was not an easy answer. He said he was determined that the United Nations should not repeat what he called the "mistakes" made in Bosnia, where the results of national elections nine months after the Dayton peace accord "legitimized those who caused the war" when hard-line ethnic leaders were voted into office. 
 Speaking to reporters here after his first trip to Kosovo, last week, Mr. Annan said: "We have a mandate to administer the territory as part of sovereign Federal Republic of Yugoslavia. But those we are administering want independence. This ambiguity is going to bring problems down the line."
It well could develop, he said, that the ethnic Albanians who make up an overwhelming proportion of the population regard the United Nations administrators as an "occupation force."
Clinton Administration officials who have recently visited Kosovo acknowledge that relations between the people and the administrators have deteriorated. Some of that problem stems from unrealistic expectations by ethnic Albanians who thought the United Nations would bring instant independence, and some stems from slow progress on rebuilding damaged homes in time for winter.
The atmosphere has not been helped, Administration officials have said, by the continuing high level of ethnic tension between the estimated 97,000 Serbs who have remained in Kosovo and the ethnic Albanians, as well as by tensions between Albanian factions.
Mr. Annan did not commit himself to a date for elections but said he favored holding local elections first. He is to receive an assessment in about two weeks on the technical aspects of holding elections in a place where voter rolls are mostly destroyed and where ethnic Albanians have boycotted elections for more than a decade in a protest against the federal Government.
It is essential, Mr. Annan said, to give time to new political parties to organize so the entrenched forces do not automatically win.
The State Department has said it would like to see municipal elections next spring. But the Balkan Action Council, a nongovernment organization headed by former senior American diplomats, argues that "rolling municipal elections" should start immediately.
With quick registration of voters in one or two towns, there is a chance for new parties, including one formed by a breakaway group from the Kosovo Liberation Army, to gain ground, said James Hooper, executive director of the council.
Mr. Annan said that in administering Kosovo, the United Nations had to tread a fine line between making decisions that would help create an independent entity and relying on the authorities in Serbia and its leader, Slobodan Milosevic. Under the United Nations mandate, Kosovo is to be administered as a self-governing autonomous region of the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia.
Mr. Annan said that was a difficult task, particularly in building a sustainable economy. For example the mines, traditionally a major employer, are owned by Serbs who now live in Belgrade.

Serb Acquitted of Genocide
 THE HAGUE, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The United Nations war crimes tribunal acquitted a Bosnian Serb of genocide charges today, ruling that the 31 counts of crimes against humanity that he has confessed to do not constitute a campaign of atrocities.
Ending its first genocide trial, the tribunal said the Serb, Goran Jelisic, did not commit crimes consistent with the strict definition of genocide.
"The accused could not be found guilty of genocide," Judge Claude Jorda of France said in reading the verdict.

HEADLINE: Inflation and the Economy

 BODY:
Two recent price reports appear to signal that the hated scourge of inflation may be on the rise. Consumer prices, the government reported yesterday, rose at about a 5 percent annual rate last month, and at a 4 percent rate over the last three months -- about 50 percent faster than in the recent past. Wholesale prices did even worse, rising at about a 10 percent rate in September and at a 7.5 percent rate for the last three months.
Will rising inflation force the Federal Reserve to slam on the monetary brakes and bring the bountiful economy to a threateningly slow gait? Almost certainly not. Recent price spikes remain well within the range that the Federal Reserve can handle without punishing the economy. 
 Consumer prices have picked up because of temporary factors limited to isolated markets. Most prominently, oil prices, after falling steeply last year, are playing catch-up, rising at an annual rate of about 30 percent over the past three months. Excluding oil and food prices, consumer prices have risen by a rate of only about 2.5 percent during the last quarter, slightly faster than last year. Wholesale prices spiked in September after a year of near-stability. If temporary factors keep emerging, it would be unwise to ignore them, but for now it is unwise to hyperventilate about such short-term aberrations.
Prof. Benjamin Friedman of Harvard, like many economists, worries more about recent wage trends. He points to the generous contract with the auto workers that will push up wages by 3 percent more than inflation. Wages generally have been rising at an annual rate of 4 percent. If productivity -- the output workers turn out in an hour -- rises fast, employers can pay the higher wages without raising prices. But fast-rising productivity is far from guaranteed. Even if inflation does pick up slightly, the economy is not doomed. The Federal Reserve has all the tools it needs to bring modest price spikes under control.
So if recent prices are cause for concern but not alarm, is something worse lurking? Judging from his cryptic comments last week, Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, appears to think so. For three years he has worried that an inflated stock market might crash, driving investors to take cover and producing billions of dollars of losses that could force consumers to pull back spending. That could be a prescription for recession.
Mr. Greenspan does not worry about falling stock prices if they move gradually. Three years ago he tried to nudge them lower by openly wondering about "irrational exuberance" among investors. Then the Dow was around 7,000. Now it is 3,000 points higher. Mr. Greenspan is still wondering.
There is a debate among economists whether Mr. Greenspan is correct. A best-selling book predicts, on the basis of robust corporate earnings and increased awareness among investors that stocks are as safe as bonds over the long haul, that investors will drive stock prices mightily higher, perhaps to 36,000 or beyond. Most other economists do not agree. One recent analysis says they could drop by a third, after inflation, over the next decade.
But whatever the case, falling or rising stock prices pose no threat to the economy as long as they move gradually. Professor Friedman points out that the Dow has already fallen by 10 percent or more with little impact on spending and could fall another 10 or 15 percent without major incident. Stock prices would remain well above levels of several years ago. Most investors would still feel wealthy and feel no pressure to cut purchases.

HEADLINE: A Larger Legacy May Await Generations X, Y and Z

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Boston College researchers say that the widely cited estimate that $10.4 trillion of wealth will be transferred to younger generations over a half-century is far short of the likely amount. They estimate the wealth transfer will be $41 trillion to $136 trillion.
"It can now be safely said that the forthcoming wealth transfer will be many times larger than anyone has previously estimated," said Paul G. Schervish, director of the Boston College Social Welfare Research Institute, who has spent the last 15 years studying wealth and who created a computer model to study wealth transfers. 
 The new figures suggest that charities, in particular, stand to benefit from a platinum era of giving. Mr. Schervish and John J. Havens, his deputy at the institute, estimated that between now and 2055 charities would receive bequests of $16 trillion to $53 trillion, measured in 1998 dollars, assuming that the estate tax remains unchanged.
The widely cited estimate of $10.4 trillion -- about $13 trillion today adjusted for inflation -- in wealth transfer was made in 1993 by two Cornell University professors, Robert B. Avery and Michael S. Rendall, using data from the Census Bureau and other sources. Their estimate was restricted to households in which the chief wage earner was 50 or older and who had living children; it covered 1990 to 2044.
The Boston College analysis, using a computer simulation model created to estimate wealth transfers, covers all Americans who were at least age 18 in 1998. It estimates wealth transfers from 1998 to 2052, when the youngest of those in the study will turn 73.
The Boston College study is based on modest assumptions about growth in wealth compared with historical experience. The study's low estimate that $41 billion will be transferred between generations by 2055 assumes that the value of all assets, adjusted for inflation, increases at 2 percent annually, while the high estimate assumes 4 percent annual real growth. Another profile assumes 3 percent annual real growth in the value of assets and projects $73 trillion in wealth transfers.
Actual growth in wealth, adjusted for inflation, averaged 5.3 percent annually from 1950 to this year, according to Prof. Edward N. Wolff, a New York University wealth expert.
Total wealth in 1998 was $32 trillion, the Boston College researchers estimated. Professor Wolff, who had not seen the new study, said, "That figure is in the right neighborhood," noting that his own research indicated total wealth of $29.1 trillion today.
The amount of wealth transferred can be greater than current wealth for two reasons. One is economic growth. The other is that over 55 years some fortunes will pass through two -- even three -- generations. Mr. Avery, now an economist with the Federal Reserve, said that while he had some qualms about the techniques used by the Boston College researchers, as described to him in a telephone interview, their estimates sounded reasonable over all.
Mr. Avery warned, however, that while economists could make fairly accurate predictions about death rates far into the future, assumptions about how much wealth people would accumulate were risky, especially looking out a half-century.
"The important message is that there is a lot of wealth in this country," Mr. Avery said.
John J. Havens, a co-author of the Boston College study, said that while he was confident of the economic model he wanted to focus on the low end of the estimate, $41 trillion, because "it helps protect against potential charges of irrational exuberance arising from" the computer model's assuming steady economic growth without a depression or a sustained recession in the first half of the 21st century.
A quarter-century ago Professor Havens developed one of the first computer programs to model economic behavior. The model estimates that for estates of $20 million or more, 39 percent of the money will go to charity, 23 percent to heirs, 34 percent to taxes and 3 percent for fees and burial expenses. Data from the Internal Revenue Service show the same ratios in 1995 for large estates.
For estates of $1 million to just under $5 million, the study assumes that charity will get 8 percent; heirs, 66 percent; taxes, 22 percent, and fees and burial expenses, 4 percent.
For estates of less than $1 million, Professors Schervish and Havens estimated, nearly 90 cents of each dollar would be passed to heirs and little would go to charity or taxes.
One recent analysis found that among estates valued at $600,000 to $1 million in 1997, estate taxes averaged 6 percent, even though the estate tax rate began at 37 percent on amounts above the $600,000 exemption then in effect.
The Boston College study covers what are known as final estates, meaning the death of a single person or the second spouse in a married couple, since bequests to a spouse are tax free. The estimates of how much will be bequeathed to charity may be low, based on I.R.S. data in recent years, which show that growing numbers of people are engaging in estate planning so that more of their money will go to charity after their deaths and less to the Government. The I.R.S. data show that the share of money in estates going to charity is slowly rising, a trend that if continued through 2055 would mean far more for charities than the $16 trillion to $53 trillion cited in the study.
If the estate tax is repealed or significantly reduced, however, as Congress voted to do earlier this year in a bill that President Clinton vetoed, bequests to charities might be smaller than the Boston College model predicted.

HEADLINE: A Suburbiascape Grows In Inner-City Chicago

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 19

 BODY:
It is the familiar mallscape of suburbia, a big supermarket and a strip of gleaming shops behind a parking lot the size of a football field. But it is a stone's throw from a public housing tower.
This is 47th Street in the pockmarked North Kenwood section of Chicago, where the population has dwindled by two-thirds in the last 30 years, with whole blocks sitting vacant, rejected as untouchable by investors who saw more danger than hope. 
 Now investors see an urban Lazarus, a long-moribund neighborhood coming back to life, a striking example of how economic prosperity is changing the face of America. It is also a vivid illustration of how a City Hall, which in Chicago is the landlord for much of the cleared land, can transform a neighborhood by knocking down eyesores, readying parcels and recruiting developers.
"You walk inside this place, and you forget you're on the South Side of Chicago," said Marty Murray, 43, as he marveled at the selection at the Lake Park Pointe Shopping Center, which opened this month. "People out in the suburbs have had this forever. It's just wonderful. You can get everything you need."
Anchored by the big Co-Op Markets supermarket, the $9.1 million shopping center includes a bank, a real-estate office, a drugstore, a dry cleaner and an eyesight clinic.
"A supermarket is the single most important ingredient to betterment of life in poor, urban neighborhoods," said Joe Schwieterman, an urban planner who is director of the Chaddick Institute for Metropolitan Development at DePaul University.
Supermarkets provide a savings of 15 percent to 20 percent compared with little neighborhood stores, Mr. Schwieterman said. And money spent in supermarkets is turned over in the community perhaps three times, largely because such big grocery stores hire so many local workers. Co-Op Markets, for example, employs more than 200 people.
"It also creates a perception of prosperity or commercial vibrancy," he said. "There's a place to go in the neighborhood where there is the constant movement of people. It also helps give a community a sense of identity."
"What we're seeing here," he added, "is gentrification gradually extending its reach into neighborhoods that had been desolate."
North Kenwood was long been regarded as the poor, sometimes frightening area near Hyde Park, an upscale neighborhood known for its stately stone buildings and its Nobel laureates at the University of Chicago.
"You'd go through Kenwood on the way to a White Sox game and that was about it," said Nancy Kiernan, a city planner. "But its time has come."
In the last six months, residential property costs in the neighborhood have soared to $10 a square foot from $4 a square foot, with a flurry of new construction and remodeling driven largely by demand from affluent young black professionals.
Alderwoman Toni Preckwinkle, whose ward includes the shopping center, said several people had told her, with evident pride, "It's as nice as anything on the North Side."
Ms. Preckwinkle said that for many years developers had seen the neighborhood as "too dicey" for investment, especially with a high crime rate stoked by the illicit drug trade. But the new development, residential and commercial, has chased away many of the outlaws.
"The criminals want peace and quiet and isolation in which to do their business," she said. "Now they've got neighbors who will call the police on them."
Richard Fisk, the general manager of the Co-Op Markets, said he was convinced a few years ago that the neighborhood was a market to be tapped.
"We all seem to eat," Mr. Fisk said. "And there were not too many choices for people to shop."
Mr. Schwieterman, the urban planner at DePaul, said many people in poor urban neighborhoods traveled to inner-ring suburbs to shop for groceries, a hardship for the consumers and a huge loss of potential business for cities.
Officers with the Chicago Police Department have been highly visible around the new shopping center, as City Hall lends its weight to make sure the new venture goes smoothly.
Mr. Fisk, the general manager, said his store had also hired a big complement of security guards, inside and outside the store.
"If people don't feel safe," he said, "they won't come to shop."
One of the hundreds of new jobs spawned by the shopping center belongs to Jeffrey Billips, 17, who now earns $6.31 an hour bagging groceries at Co-Op Markets.
"Some guys my age have gotten into stealing, selling drugs; some of them have even been shot at," said Mr. Billips, the youngest of five children, whose mother died last year of an asthma attack. "This job is going to help me pay for college."

HEADLINE: An October Bust? Not This Time

BYLINE: By Bruce Steinberg; Bruce Steinberg is chief economist for Merrill Lynch.

 BODY:
For those who tirelessly warn that the economic boom is a bubble overdue to burst, these must seem like perilous days. Last week, worries about inflation and possible interest-rate increases sent stock prices into their biggest swoon in a decade -- in what some noted was the week before the anniversary of the infamous Black Monday of 1987. When stocks rebounded this week, after consumer prices showed only a modest increase, there was talk of volatility.
But the doomsayers are looking for signs of disaster where none exist. The American economy has performed better in the 1990's than at any time in history, and there is no end of that success in sight. 
 The bubble theory rests on arguments that the stock market is overvalued, Americans are not saving and the trade deficit is at a dangerous level. Assets are said to have become overvalued, leading to overconsumption and an overheating of the economy that will inevitably end in a violent correction -- a stock market crash. But this argument will not stand up to a careful analysis.
The pessimists' misinterpretations begin with stock prices, which have indeed grown rapidly. Even after a 10 percent correction in the past two months, stocks in the companies that make up the Standard & Poor's 500 index are trading, on average, at more than 24 times their 1999 operating earnings per share -- near-record levels. However, values are highest in the sector where growth prospects are highest and demand is accelerating: technology. With the technology stocks excluded, the price-earnings ratio for the rest of the companies in the index is around 19. Adjusted for interest rates, that's comfortably in line with the experience of the past few decades.
Some analysts also think they see a real estate bubble -- a dangerous trend if it were real. Who can forget Japan's bubble economy of the 1980's, when the grounds of the Imperial Palace were supposedly worth as much as California? But in the United States, mortgage borrowing has been relatively weak in the 1990's and, despite dizzying prices in pockets like Manhattan and Silicon Valley, the national median price of existing homes rose just 4.5 percent a year.
The negative national savings rate is another fiction. The official savings rate has plunged from 5 percent at the end of the 1980's to minus-1.5 percent now, leading alarmists to say that Americans are on a spending binge fueled by rising asset prices and excessive borrowing. But the figures are flawed. Wage income has actually grown faster than consumer spending during the past several years. And while total income grew more slowly than spending because interest and dividend income grew slowly during the 1990's, that weak growth was more than offset by the rise in the value of stocks. The official calculations of the savings rate do not count capital gains income -- though Americans who pay taxes on it can attest that it is quite real. When it is included, the savings rate is 8 percent.
As for the trade deficit, it is indeed at a record level, but it doubled during the past two years because weak growth in the rest of the world hurt American exports. Now the world economy is recovering. In September, export orders rose to the highest level in 30 months.
What the unprecedented performance of the American economy in this decade really reflects is a revolution in productivity. Productivity grew during the past five years at double the pace of the prior 25 years. That is what allowed the economy to grow by more than 4 percent last year while the core inflation rate dropped by half a percentage point and the unemployment rate was stable.
The economy may have to slow a bit now to keep the Fed happy. But although the United States will undoubtedly have a recession someday, don't look for it anytime soon.

HEADLINE: NEW ON WEDNESDAY;
National Urgency And a Local Focus

BYLINE: By ETHAN BRONNER 

 BODY:
AL GORE vows an education revolution if elected President. Bill Gates pledges $1 billion for minority scholarships to college, one of the largest gifts in the history of philanthropy. Voters say education is the top domestic priority.
With the nation sharpening its focus on education, The Times today introduces a new Wednesday Education page. The contents will pair a new national column with a more intense focus on the New York area. 
 The column, called Lessons, will be written every other week by Richard Rothstein, an education researcher in California. In the weeks when he is not writing, the column will be by a member of the Times staff.
Each week's page will include a feature article that looks at an educational institution or figure in or around New York as well as briefer reports, gathered under the rubric Bulletin Board, that will track movements and people in the region's education community. The page will appear in copies of The Times distributed in the New York area. In other regions, The Times will include the Lessons column in the national news pages.
The Times is also increasing its overall coverage of education. Articles on the subject will appear throughout the national, metropolitan and business reports.
At least three factors explain the increased national attention to education.
First, with the military draft gone, the public school classroom is one of the last forums in which large, varied segments of society come together. How and what a nation chooses to teach its young is a reflection not only of who it is but also of who it hopes to be.
Second, with the cold war over and well-being often defined largely through economics, many believe that the nation's future depends specifically on how well it trains its students to foster and manage technical and knowledge-based industries.
Finally, most Americans are persuaded that there is no clearer path to personal prosperity and well-being than through education. As Nicholas Lemann puts it in his new book, "The Big Test" (Farrar, Straus & Giroux): "A thick line runs through the country, with people who have been to college on one side of it and people who haven't on the other. This line gets brighter all the time."
There is a tension between two vital forces in education today: standards and equity. If improved education is really the key to an improved national economy, schools need to be more rigorous or their graduates will be poorly trained and the economy will decline. But if education is really the key to personal prosperity, is there any more vital goal for a nation pledged to equal opportunity than to expand the franchise of education, to make it more fully available to those who have largely been denied it? Can education be made more difficult and more available at the same time?
Education is taking on such a large role in national politics because what purports to be about education is often about something else -- religion, race, technology, economics. The conflict between higher standards and greater educational equity is a proxy for a debate over race and class.
Even issues that seem at first purely pedagogical -- how to teach reading or mathematics, for example -- are often stand-ins for philosophical disputes like whether children are best viewed as flowers to be cultivated or beasts to be tamed.
Education in America is increasingly about money, not only how much to spend, or how much can be made by those who graduate, but also, for the first time, how much can be made by those who provide it. Learning, even elementary-school learning, is now seen as a profit center for some large companies setting up for-profit schools, universities and training centers. Higher standards lead inexorably to more tests, and tests are often provided by private companies. And so the links between education and the economy grow tighter, creating a nexus of relationships requiring close scrutiny.
The goal of this page will be to contribute to that scrutiny. ETHAN BRONNER (Education Editor)

HEADLINE: U.S. Bishops Urging Catholics To Be Politically Involved

BYLINE: By GUSTAV NIEBUHR 

 BODY:
Calling the election year 2000 both a "great spiritual milestone" and an "important civic challenge," the nation's Roman Catholic bishops are to issue a statement today saying participation in the political process is a moral obligation for Catholics and asking them to reflect on how politics can be used to advance church principles like stopping abortion, helping poor children, protecting immigrants' rights and providing families affordable housing.
The statement, "Faithful Citizenship: Civic Responsibility for a New Millennium," is directed at the United States' 61 million baptized Catholics, who, accounting for nearly a quarter of the population, are the country's largest single religious group, once strongly Democratic, now far more politically divided. 
 The document, which the National Conference of Catholic Bishops will send to all 19,000 American parishes in January, is carefully nonpartisan in tone. It explicitly disavows any intention by the bishops to try to create "a religious voting block" -- an effort that would most likely be doomed from the outset anyway, given how socially and ethnically diverse the American Catholic population has become.
Still, its central point -- that major church teachings should be considered in the voting booth -- may carry important weight among churchgoing Catholics with no firm commitment to either Democrats or Republicans.
"In the Catholic tradition," the statement says, "responsible citizenship is a virtue; participation in the political process is a moral obligation." It also says Catholics ought to measure candidates and political platforms by "whether they enhance or diminish human life, dignity and human rights; and how they advance the common good."
Archbishop Theodore E. McCarrick of Newark, chairman of the bishops' International Policy Committee, who had a major hand in developing the document, said in a telephone interview yesterday that the bishops viewed it as a way to convey the practical implications of the church's social teachings.
"It's an attempt to speak to the questions that are around today," Archbishop McCarrick said.
The bishops have a tradition, dating from 1975, of issuing statements on Catholics' civic responsibility in the autumn before a Presidential election year. But the new document differs from its predecessors in that it is more plainly written and, at 17 pages, considerably shorter, and in that it urges Catholics to steer clear of political cynicism -- an implicit recognition of how politics has been roiled by President Clinton's impeachment, and of the bishops' disappointment over the failure of recent efforts to enact legislation curbing a late-term abortion procedure.
"Sometimes it seems few candidates and no party fully reflect our values," the statement says. "But now is not a time for retreat. The new millennium should be an opportunity for renewed participation."
The statement places the church's teachings against abortion and physician-assisted suicide at the top of a list of concerns that also include protection of the environment and workers' rights. Unlike its predecessors, the statement gives a high profile as well to certain other issues, like opposition to the death penalty and support for efforts to relieve poor nations of their foreign debt, that have drawn particular attention from Pope John Paul II and the bishops this year.
Once a fairly reliable Democratic constituency, Catholics have become a far more difficult group to categorize politically since the 1960's, populating as they do all economic classes and including a large and growing number of immigrants from Asia, Africa and Latin America.
Within this diverse population, however, the group that political scientists describe as white, non-Hispanic moderates -- about one-third of all Catholics, and 7 percent to 8 percent of the electorate -- may be most moved by the bishops' statement. In its politics, this group is "genuinely ambivalent" with regard to party affiliation, said Prof. John Green, director of the Ray C. Bliss Institute of Applied Politics at the University of Akron.
Professor Green said surveys showed that moderate Catholics had been politically mobile during the last five years. A majority voted Republican in 1994, helping that party capture control of Congress. But they split their ballots in 1996, supporting both President Clinton and Congressional Republicans, and last year they sided largely with the Democrats, helping the minority to pick up House seats.
