HEADLINE: G.M. and Canadian Union Reach Tentative Agreement

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 20

 BODY:
Dodging a threatened strike, the General Motors Corporation reached a tentative contract agreement tonight with the Canadian Auto Workers union that will provide generous raises to the company's 21,000 Canadian factory workers even as it allows the company to continue to downsize.
"It is an excellent agreement," said Basil E. Hargrove, the union's president. "It recognizes the contribution our workers have made to General Motors' profits." 
 Under the three-year agreement, G.M.'s Canadian workers will receive annual raises of 3 percent in addition to inflation adjustments. In addition, they will receive a $1,000 (Canadian) signing bonus and an annual holiday bonus of $1,200 (Canadian). And each year, they will receive an additional week of paid time off, improved pension benefits, a $2,000 (Canadian) child care subsidy for children younger than 5 and an $800 (Canadian) tuition refund for workers with children in college.
With the agreement, the auto industry breathed a collective sigh of relief. The Canadian labor deal with G.M. wrapped up this fall's rush of negotiations between G.M., the Ford Motor Company and DaimlerChrysler A.G. and their American and Canadian unions. Both unions negotiated hefty raises for the more than 450,000 auto factory workers, sending some of the record profits the auto industry has been earning to the pockets of its workers.
The Canadian union had threatened a strike after G.M. proposed eliminating 1,300 jobs. G.M. reversed course, promising to invest $1.1 billion (Canadian) in various factories. "We're saving lots of jobs here," Mr. Hargrove said. Still, G.M. is expected to downsize through attrition.
G.M. may close a Canadian factory in the fall of 2002. Workers in St. Therese, Quebec, now build Pontiac Firebirds and Chevrolet Camaros, but that production is scheduled to end in September 2002. G.M. agreed only to study the feasibility of building a niche vehicle in the factory after work on the Firebirds and Camaros ends.
The Canadian union took a different approach to a challenge faced by the United Automobile Workers. The Canadian union agreed to allow G.M. to use "modular" factories, in which suppliers assemble large pieces of the vehicle, which are then shipped to unionized assembly factories and pieced together into cars and trucks.
The American union vehemently opposed the approach, arguing that work done by its well-paid members would be lost to lower-paying suppliers. The Canadian union simply stipulated that if G.M. plans such moves, the workers in the parts factories must be covered under the agreement with the union. That would effectively force G.M. to favor sending work to Delphi Automotive Systems, the auto parts unit it spun off in May.

HEADLINE: Long Line in the Bronx, but for Jobs, Not the Yankees

BYLINE: By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
By 9 A.M. yesterday, the line snaked around three sides of the Bronx County Building. Was someone giving away World Series tickets?
No, it was jobs that were being offered -- or at least the hope of them. More than 40 employers were inside at a job fair, trying to fill positions from sales clerk to registered nurse. 
 About 5,000 potential job candidates -- from welfare mothers to recent college graduates -- showed up, some waiting more than three hours to get into the fair.
A few said they were curious; some said they wanted to see if they could get a better-paying job. But most said they were drawn by desperation.
While the economy may be soaring, many said, in their lives the economic boom has a hollow echo.
Unemployment in the Bronx has dropped significantly -- to 8.2 percent in August, compared with 11.4 percent in August 1997 -- but it is still double the national average. It is also higher than in the city as a whole, which had 6.7 percent unemployment in August.
There are a variety of reasons, from the decline of manufacturing to the Bronx's high population of young people, among whom unemployment rates tend to be higher. There is also poverty, which translates into fewer skills and fewer options.
Many of those in line yesterday, some of whom had come from Manhattan, said they had been looking for work, most often entry-level clerical positions, for months.
Hassan Kelliehan, 25, said he has been on the hunt since March, when he lost the job he had had for two and a half years at Caldor's, the retailer that is now in bankruptcy. "I send my resume," he said, "but there's no response."
The economy is booming all over, said Jose Ithier, the president of the Bronx Overall Economic Development Corporation, which co-sponsored the fair with the Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer. "But maybe," Mr. Ithier said, "the world needs to see the people lined up here looking for a job."
Looking for work is hard and humbling: trudging to offices, filling out applications, being told to await calls that never come. But yesterday, for just one day, potential employers eagerly accepted resumes, showed friendly faces and offered words of encouragement. The aspirants collected business cards, filled out applications, and in some cases signed up for job-training programs.
But as the stack of resumes grew higher at each table, it became clear that each job-seeker's chances grew slimmer.
"I've never seen a job fair this well attended," said Lucy Mayo, an employment specialist. "There is a huge pool of people with entry-level skills and not enough jobs for them."
Those jobs that are available, Ms. Mayo continued, offer low pay and no benefits.
For example, Barnes & Noble -- which is scheduled to open a new bookstore at Bay Plaza in the Bronx in early December and has 50 to 75 jobs to fill -- pays $7.25 an hour for starting jobs, which are all part-time with no benefits.
Some jobs, at Jacobi and Montefiore Medical Centers, for example, pay better, and the Correctional Services Corporation, one of the employers at the fair, offers benefits after six months.
And at least, Mr. Ithier and others said, jobs are being created in the Bronx -- some 2,600 last year alone, mostly in retail and construction. Still, 250,000 Bronx residents work outside the borough.
That takes a toll in time and money. Anthony Uribe, 25, said he had left his last manufacturing job, in Chatham, N.J., because the transportation was eating up half of his $7 hourly pay. With two children to support, he had been looking for work for six months.
Many of those in line and inside were on public assistance, and in many cases were trying to get off it after years out of the work force. Teodora Brea, 45, one of many single mothers at the fair, said she had been on public assistance for 10 years and was now struggling to move back into the workplace in anticipation of time limits on her benefits.
Carlos Herrera, a recent immigrant from Peru who lacks working papers as well as English, said: "I need help urgently. I need money to buy clothes for the cold."
He and his fellow unemployed share an experience that Jeffrey Winn, 39, likened to what he imagined being locked up would feel like: "No control."
Mr. Winn, 39, has been looking for work for 10 months, since cutbacks at the shipping and receiving department at Oxford Health Plan. He has four children, and counts himself lucky because his wife has a job.
"Being out of work -- I wouldn't recommend it to anyone," he said as he waited near the end of the line.

HEADLINE: Political Stalemate Continues Over Banking Bill

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19

 BODY:
Senate Republicans and senior officials in the Clinton Administration failed to agree today on legislation to overhaul the nation's financial system, and said they would resume negotiations on Wednesday.
The lawmakers are nearing completion of a bill that would repeal more than 60 years of laws that restrict the ability of banks, insurance companies and securities firms to expand into each other's industries. 
 Over the last week, the differences between the White House and the Republicans have substantially narrowed, raising the prospects for legislation that Congress has tried unsuccessfully to adopt for more than 20 years.
The White House spokesman, Joe Lockhart, said today that the Administration was satisfied with the law's provisions on consumer privacy. Consumer and privacy groups said, however, the measure would do little to protect customers from having their confidential information disclosed.
Despite the progress in resolving most differences over the legislation, strong disagreements remain between Senator Phil Gramm, the Texas Republican who heads the Senate Banking Committee, and President Clinton over the measure's treatment of the Community Reinvestment Act, a 1977 law aimed at eradicating discrimination in lending.
Mr. Clinton has stood strongly behind civil rights groups and the Congressional Black Caucus, which was a crucial ally in the Presidential impeachment proceedings. The President's top aides have denounced provisions of the legislation that they contend would make damaging changes to the Community Reinvestment Act.
Mr. Gramm has maintained that the act is unduly burdensome on small institutions and that the changes he has suggested would not undermine it.
These are the Community Reinvestment Act issues in dispute:
*Whether a new kind of financial business known as wholesale financial institutions -- and nicknamed woofies -- must meet the requirements of the Community Reinvestment Act. The new institutions take deposits of more than $100,000 and are not subject to many of the regulations that affect traditional banks. The legislation produced by the conference committee would authorizes companies to set up woofies but would exempt them from the act. That has raised concerns that woofies would create large new loopholes, allowing traditional institutions to avoid compliance with the act.
*Whether community groups, which often make deals with banks about their community lending practices, must make such arrangements public.
*Whether the examination cycle for small and rural banks for compliance under the Community Reinvestment Act should be less frequent, as Senator Gramm contends, or remain the same, as the Administration wants.
*Whether banks entering new lines of business need to maintain satisfactory ratings under the Community Reinvestment Act.
In talks at the Capitol today, Mr. Gramm; Lawrence H. Summers, the Treasury Secretary, and Gene Sperling, the President's top economic adviser, failed to resolve the differences.
In recent days Mr. Sperling has met regularly with the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who has been critical of the banking legislation. Mr. Jackson contends the legislation fails to provide adequate protection for minorities and others historically denied access to credit.
Lobbyists from the financial services industry said they expected that a deal could ultimately be reached. Nonetheless, they were concerned that differences remained between the White House and Senate Republicans.
"It's so frustrating because we're very very close and have not gotten the ball over the finish line," said Tom Block, a senior vice president in charge of Federal relations for Chase Manhattan Bank.
"We've come so close and solved so many of the issues," he added. "We can't be this close and not solve the problem, but crazier things have happened. It is a highly charged political issue that is hard for some to negotiate on. C.R.A. should be resolvable. The banks have learned to live with C.R.A."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

A Platinum Era of Giving Is Foreseen by Researchers
Far more wealth will be transferred to younger generations over a half-century than the $10.4 trillion previously thought, Boston College researchers say. They put the amount at $41 trillion to $136 trillion.
The new figures suggest that charities stand to benefit from a platinum era of giving with bequests of $16 trillion to $53 trillion between now and 2055. Page C2. 

Drug Makers' Profits and Shares Up
Continuing the drug industry's strong quarter, Pfizer, maker of the impotency pill Viagra, surprised analysts by announcing a 36 percent earnings increase, while Johnson & Johnson reported a 14.4 percent gain and Bristol-Myers Squibb posted a 14 percent advance. Shares of all three climbed, with Johnson & Johnson's stock up 5.5 percent. C6.
 
McDonnell Douglas Is Indicted
A Federal grand jury indicted McDonnell Douglas, a unit of Boeing, and a state-owned aerospace company in China on charges of conspiring to hide important details of a 1994 sale of American machining equipment. A1.
 
Dow and S.& P. Rise; Nasdaq Slips
Drug makers' earnings and expected inflation numbers helped send the Dow Jones industrial average up 88.65 points, to 10,204.93, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index up 7.19 points, to 1,261.32. But the Nasdaq composite index slipped 0.97 point, to 2,688.18. C13.
 
I.B.M. to Stress Internet Sales
I.B.M., which lost $1 billion on personal computers last year, said that it would sell its Aptiva desktop machines, which are intended for home use, only on the Internet after Christmas. Its Thinkpad laptops will continue to be sold in retail stores. C6.
 
Bell Atlantic Gains on Long Distance
Bell Atlantic appeared likely to become the first regional Bell to succeed in its bid to sell long-distance services as the New York State Public Service Commission told Federal regulators that the company had opened its local networks to competitors. C11.
 
Harold Evans to Leave Daily News
Harold Evans, the editorial director of The Daily News and U.S. News & World Report, said that he would leave the post at the end of the year to work on two book projects that are likely to become television documentaries. Asked whether Mr. Evans would be replaced, Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the publications' chairman and editor in chief, said: "I don't know. We are certainly appreciative of what he did." C7.
 
G.M. Reaches Canadian Labor Pact
General Motors, averting a threatened strike, reached a tentative agreement with the Canadian Auto Workers union that would provide generous raises to 21,000 workers. C2.
 
The Split Personality Of an Internet Guru
Two of his great-grandfathers worked in the same building -- one as a judge, the other as a janitor. Gerald Kearby, chief of Liquid Audio, says that helps explain who he is. Management, page C8.

HEADLINE: Lifting Spirits On Wall Street, Microsoft Profit Beats Forecasts

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
The Microsoft Corporation reported quarterly earnings yesterday that convincingly surpassed Wall Street's expectations and reflected strong demand for personal computers and their software.
Analysts said the encouraging report from Microsoft, the world's leading software maker, is likely to lift investors' confidence in the shares of high-technology companies, which have recently fallen sharply. "This will probably be a bullish signal for the beaten-down technology stocks," said Rick Sherlund of Goldman, Sachs & Company. 
 In after-hours trading, Microsoft shares jumped more than $3 on news of the strong earnings report. They had declined $1.5625, to $86.3125, in the regular session.
Both Dell Computer and Intel have recently issued warnings of slimmer profits. Both companies attributed the expected slippage to temporary circumstances like higher memory-chip prices and supply disruptions caused by the earthquake in Taiwan. But the announcements raised fears of a fundamental weakness in the technology sector, which has fueled the United States economy's growth and the stock market's ascent for years.
Microsoft executives sought to quash those wider concerns yesterday. Their tone was more forcefully optimistic than in previous earnings announcements, a practiced quarterly ritual in which Microsoft reports extraordinary profit figures accompanied by guarded commentary about the many challenges the company faces in the months ahead.
Yesterday, however, a press release announcing the earnings carried the headline, "Awesome PC Demand Drives Outstanding Microsoft Quarterly Results." In an interview, Gregory B. Maffei, the chief financial officer, described the financial performance as "a really big quarter" and later "a great quarter."
Microsoft's earnings per share, after excluding the gain from the sale of one business, rose 36 percent, to 38 cents a share. The consensus estimate of Wall Street analysts had been for profit of 34 cents a share for the quarter, which ended on Sept. 30. The result was ahead, as well, of the so-called whisper number of 35 cents a share, the estimate analysts mention to favored clients, which may differ from their published earnings projections.
Microsoft's revenue increased 28 percent, to $5.38 billion, up from $4.19 billion in the quarter a year earlier. Including a $156 million gain from the sale of the entertainment city-guide portion of its MSN Sidewalk on-line service, Microsoft's net income rose more than 30 percent, to $2.19 billion, up from $1.68 billion a year earlier. The 1998 results had included a $160 million gain from the sale of a software subsidiary, Softimage.
Company executives were sharply questioned about one balance-sheet item: a decline of $110 million from the June quarter in deferred revenue, to just under $4.13 billion. The reason analysts focus on this item is that they regard it as a financial cushion: the time when Microsoft recognizes revenue on its software licenses to corporations can sharply affect the quarterly earnings. Recognizing more revenue in a particular quarter can give a one-time lift to that quarter's earnings. Mr. Maffei said the drop from the June quarter reflected seasonality in the business.
Microsoft's quarterly statements, and the follow-up conference call with securities analysts and reporters, are scrutinized as much for nuance as for numbers. The performance this time was intended to emphasize that the company is successfully making the transition to becoming an Internet software company.
The personal computer, Microsoft points out, remains the main conduit people use to get onto the Internet. And its Windows NT server software, which runs on hub computers that send World Wide Web pages to users, is becoming increasingly popular among Internet service providers and "dot.com" Internet start-ups, according to Microsoft.
"We're getting an enormous kick from the Internet," Mr. Maffei said.
Microsoft is unquestionably a beneficiary of the Internet, analysts agree. But they say a question remains as to how successful Microsoft will be in competing against Sun Microsystems, I.B.M. and others in supplying the industrial-strength software required to run big central data centers, which are proliferating because of the Internet.
The long-delayed new upgrade of Windows NT, called Windows 2000, is the operating system that Microsoft is betting on to move into the markets for heavyweight corporate computing and data centers. In its conference call, the company reiterated that it expects to release Windows 2000 later this year.
Microsoft also said that there was little evidence yet that concerns about the Year 2000 software problem, or Y2K, were causing a halt in computer buying. The fear had been that corporate customers would spend all their information technology budgets on fixing Y2K problems in existing computers instead of buying new ones.
By region, the biggest rise in sales was in Asia, where revenue increased 82 percent compared with the 1998 quarter. Japan accounts for about 80 percent of sales in the Asian region. A stronger Japanese economy and a rising yen helped lift the result, Mr. Maffei noted, but the global spread of the Internet phenomenon was also a big factor. "Japan is getting very focused on the Internet," he said.

HEADLINE: Social Security Benefits Are Set to Rise by 2.4%

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19

 BODY:
Beginning in January, retirees will get the biggest cost-of-living increase in their Social Security checks in three years, an average of $19 a month.
The 2.4 percent increase, announced today by the Social Security Administration, will be nearly twice the 1.3 percent rise of this year, largely because of a recent spike in energy prices. 
 With overall inflation remaining relatively tame, however, the 2000 Social Security adjustment will continue a 1990's trend in which the increases were modest in historical terms.
Monthly checks from Social Security, the Government's biggest benefit program, with 44.2 million Americans on the rolls, are adjusted annually to keep rising prices from eroding beneficiaries' buying power.
Since 1975, the adjustment has been automatic, requiring no vote by Congress. It is based on the change in the Consumer Price Index, the Government's inflation yardstick, from the third quarter of one year to the corresponding quarter of the next.
Because of low inflation, the yearly benefit increases have been below 3 percent since 1994. The only previous time the automatic adjustment had slipped under that level was in 1987, when it hit a record low of 1.3 percent, a figure matched in 1999.
The 2000 adjustment, the biggest since 2.9 percent in 1997, will bring the average monthly check for retirees to $804, from $785. Social Security payments will also rise for disabled workers and for families whose breadwinners have died, and 6.6 million low-income people receiving Supplemental Security Income will get the increase as well.
Some economists argue that Government statistics overstate inflation. As a result, lawmakers have suggested reducing the annual adjustments to help avert a financial crisis that, in the absence of a change in law, is expected to besiege Social Security after baby boomers begin retiring.
Many current retirees, however, complain that the modest adjustments of recent years have not kept up with increases in their day-to-day expenses.
"You get an increase, but your rent goes up, your gas goes up and even your phone bill," said Edith Bailey, 79, among those interviewed at a senior citizens expo near Baltimore earlier this month.
Indeed, advocates for the elderly say that while the smaller adjustments of recent years do track standard measures of inflation, they may nevertheless seem inadequate to the aged, who have special purchasing needs.
For example, though overall prices have been rising at a 2.8 percent annual rate this year, the cost of medical care is rising at a 3.7 percent rate, and prescription drug prices are climbing at a 6.2 percent rate.
While benefits rise next year, so will Social Security taxes. For 148 million working Americans, the maximum annual earnings subject to the 6.2 percent Social Security payroll tax will increase to $76,200 from $72,600. Thus, the maximum Social Security tax paid by workers will be $4,724.

HEADLINE: House Approves Medicare Extension for the Disabled

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19

 BODY:
With an overwhelmingly bipartisan vote, the House of Representatives today passed a bill expanding Medicaid and Medicare so that hundreds of thousands of people with disabilities could return to work and keep their health insurance coverage.
Under existing law, when disabled people return to work, they often lose Medicaid and Medicare, and without such coverage, they cannot obtain the health care or medical equipment they need to retain their jobs. 
 The bill sailed through the House on a vote of 412 to 9. All the opponents were Republicans. The Senate passed a similar bill, 99 to 0, in June.
Supporters say the legislation is the most important step to help the disabled since passage of the Americans With Disabilities Act in 1990.
President Clinton said tonight that he was "extremely pleased" with the House vote. But he asserted that the House bill "has flaws," including limits on the health insurance options for disabled workers. Mr. Clinton also said he disliked some proposed financing for the new benefits, including a provision that affects student loans.
Mr. Clinton said he hoped that negotiators from the House and Senate would address those issues when they met to work out their differences. Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, a co-author of the Senate bill, said he hoped Congress would send "this landmark legislation" to the President before adjourning this year.
Representative Rick A. Lazio, the Long Island Republican who is chief sponsor of the House bill, said, "Our economy needs Americans with disabilities in the work force."
But, Mr. Lazio said, they are discouraged from working because under current Federal rules, "people with disabilities must get poor and stay poor if they're going to retain their health benefits."
The legislation has been been carried on a bipartisan tide, extremely unusual in this Congress.
Liberal Democrats have long championed the rights of the disabled and want to expand Federal health programs to cover more people.
Republicans are eager to minimize the use of many Federal benefit programs and want to encourage work effort by people who now rely on the Government for most of their income.
Members of both parties said they had heard many appeals from disabled people who want to work.
"Rarely do we have a group of people who come to us saying, 'We want to be taxpayers, we want to be productive,' " said Representative Kenny Hulshof, a Missouri Republican and co-author of the House bill. "Our message to the disabled is that we hear you, and we want to provide more opportunities."
The cost of the Senate and House bills is roughly $750 million in the first five years and slightly more than $1 billion in the next five years, for a total of $1.8 billion from 2000 to 2009.
The Senate did not specify how to pay or offset these costs. And House Republicans said the Clinton Administration had provided little assistance.
Mr. Lazio said the Senate did not propose "one dime of offsets" to the cost of the legislation. Moreover, he said, "we got zero help from the White House" in finding ways to pay for it.
Representative Sherrod Brown, Democrat of Ohio, said those assertions were "patently false." Other Democrats said House Republicans had rejected various methods of financing proposed by the White House.
The House and Senate bills would help disabled people in these ways:
*People who lose eligibility for Social Security disability benefits because they return to work could keep their Medicare coverage.
*People with disabilities could buy Medicaid coverage even if they took jobs and earned income that would otherwise disqualify them.
*States could provide Medicaid to workers who are not actually disabled, but have physical or mental impairments that are "reasonably expected" to become severe disabilities in the absence of medical treatment.
This provision could help people who have been infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, but have not developed symptoms of the disease. With Medicaid coverage, they could obtain the expensive prescription drugs they need to fight off the disease and continue working.
Lawmakers said this provision would also help people with cerebral palsy, multiple sclerosis and Parkinson's disease.

HEADLINE: Congressional Memo;
Agenda of Budget Fight Turns Largely on Politics

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19

 BODY:
In this year's version of their annual budget showdown, President Clinton and the Republican-led Congress are fighting over how much money the Federal Government should spend to hire teachers and police officers.
They are battling over how much money the United States should pay to support the Middle East peace plan. They are at odds over whether mining companies should be able to dump unlimited quantities of waste on public land. 
 But their bitter standoff is about more than those issues or the taxpayer dollars they represent. It is about seeking political advantage as they enter an election year in which the White House and control of the House are up for grabs. It is about fundamental ideological differences over the size and role of the Federal Government. And it is about the accumulated hostility between Mr. Clinton and Republicans who fear the President as much as they loathe him.
"The budget battle is to some degree a symbol of the hostility, magnified by the fight for control of the House," said Thomas Kahn, the Democratic staff director of the House Budget Committee. "Having said that, it's a mistake to underestimate the significance of the fundamental philosophical differences between the parties."
The two sides met this evening at the White House in a first high-level effort to bridge the differences, and both said afterward that they were off to a good start. Specifically, Republicans said, both sides have affirmed their commitment not to dip into the Social Security surplus to pay for any programs.
Still, Mr. Clinton is unlikely to rush into a deal. If the last several years are any guide, the Republicans will grow increasingly eager as the fall goes on to adjourn and go home, and will prove willing to meet Mr. Clinton's main demands to do so. Republicans, some of whom attribute their disappointing showing in last year's Congressional elections to giving in to Mr. Clinton's budget priorities, ruefully refer to it as an exit fee -- the levy, in concessions on spending, that Mr. Clinton will charge to let them out of Washington.
"Ultimately, the President is going to get most of what he wants, and it's going to look like a Democratic victory," said Stanley E. Collender, managing director of the Federal Budget Consulting Group at Fleishman Hillard, the public relations firm. "The question is whether the Republicans can do it in a way that doesn't annoy the Republican base like it did a year ago."
It does not hurt Mr. Clinton that Republicans are stalled in their efforts to complete work on the budget for the fiscal year that began on Oct. 1. Every day that Congress remains in session is another day in which newspaper headlines will inform voters of the gimmicks Republicans are adopting to pass spending bills (Thirteen-Month Fiscal Years! The 2000 Census: The Fiscal "Emergency" No One Saw Coming!).
But having been repeatedly burned by Mr. Clinton in past budget negotiations, Republicans have a strategy this year. They say that every dollar Mr. Clinton wants to add to spending bills will come out of the portion of the budget surplus generated by Social Security, a new and somewhat arbitrary standard of fiscal discipline, but one with undoubted political resonance.
In one sense, Republicans have already won that fight. At the beginning of this year, Mr. Clinton was proposing to spend some of the Social Security surplus. Under pressure from Republicans, he adopted their position this summer.
"This is a huge victory for every American who sends money to Washington from every paycheck and expects that money to be saved for their retirement," said Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader.
In fact, spending some or all of the Social Security surplus -- something that Washington has done for decades -- has no direct effect on the retirement system's finances and is a separate subject from efforts to extend the system's solvency.
But the Republican shorthand -- that spending the money amounts to a "raid" on Social Security -- is already being used by the party in advertising directed toward vulnerable incumbent House Democrats.
The problem for Republicans is that they have yet to show they can meet their own standard. Despite using every budget trick they can think up, Republicans are still billions of dollars short in their efforts to pass all the spending bills without using Social Security money. They are down to some last-ditch options, including an across the board reduction in all spending, a meat cleaver approach that leaves Republicans vulnerable to accusations from Democrats of gutting popular programs.
For his part, Mr. Clinton would rely on increased cigarette taxes and other tax increases to provide the money for his spending priorities. But the tobacco tax is anathema to Republicans and has critics even among Democrats, and without it Mr. Clinton is in the same spot as the Republicans, claiming a level of fiscal virtue he cannot live up to.
In a friendlier political atmosphere, Mr. Clinton and the Republican leadership would probably sit down and agree to take joint responsibility for spending some of the Social Security surplus one last time. But given the almost total lack of trust between them, they seem more intent on maneuvering to assure that the other guy takes the political hit.
"The game is really about which side gets blamed for fiscal malfeasance," said Thomas D. Gallagher, a political analyst with the International Strategy and Investment Group.
Yet by the standards of the last two decades, when the mounting budget deficit was one of the most serious economic and political problems facing the country, there will be no fiscal malfeasance. Even if spending amounted to tens of billions of dollars more than either side currently contemplates, the Government would still run a large Social Security surplus this year and reduce the national debt by at least $100 billion.

Light on Nuclear Arms' Locales
The United States stored 12,000 nuclear weapons and components in Morocco, Japan, Iceland, Puerto Rico, Cuba and at least 23 other countries and five territories during the cold war, according to a newly declassified document. A1

HEADLINE: CUNY Students Ask Regents To Keep Remedial Program

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
They chanted no slogans and carried no placards, but a panel of students from the City University of New York yesterday urged New York's Regents to vote no on CUNY's plan to phase out remedial education at its four-year colleges.
"Improving standards and having remediation are two separate issues," said Edward Ellis, a Baruch College student dressed in a gray suit. "But if there is a problem with remediation, the logical step would be to improve remediation." 
 Maryana Zubok, a Queens College student in a black turtleneck shirt and gray knit pants, rapidly ticked off her objections to CUNY's plan: "It is racially and economically discriminatory. The timetable is unreasonable. It is unfair to the community colleges."
Besides, she added, "Why segregate these students? It's like saying you can ride in the bus, but you have to sit in the back."
The students were the first of four panels the Regents consulted yesterday at the Schomburg Center in Harlem. They will decide in November whether to allow CUNY to proceed with its plan to remove remedial students from its bachelor's degree programs beginning in January. Other panels included CUNY officials and faculty members, representatives from New York businesses, and higher education experts.
The students drew the admiration of the Regents, who commented several times on how impressive and articulate the students were. Although the six students reflected CUNY's diverse student body, all but one opposed CUNY's plan.
"I probably look like the type who would look at remediation with disdain, and that was true when I first attended Hunter," said Aliyah Khan, a Hunter sophomore who graduated from Stuyvesant High School with a 95 average and SAT scores of 1460 and chose Hunter for financial reasons and because she wanted to stay in New York.
But she said she had come to appreciate the college's diversity and feared it would be lost under the remedial plan. "This is a cosmetic solution," she said. "You might get a few more students who would not have come before. But you will also deny education to those who need it most."
Only Deena New, the president of the premedical society at CUNY's College of Staten Island, suggested that CUNY should be more restrictive so it could maintain quality. But Ms. New, who has been accepted to SUNY Downstate medical college, said the education she is receiving "is as good as any student at Harvard."
Cristina Cocheo, a City College senior, offered her sympathies to the Regents, but told them to reject CUNY's plan.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Penny Pinchers

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

 BODY:
You can think about the tug of war between the Republicans and President Clinton over the State Department's budget in a lot of ways. I prefer to think about it like this: Out of every dollar spent by the U.S. government each year, about one penny goes to pay for our embassies and diplomats abroad, democracy support programs, denuclearizing Russia, foreign loans and foreign aid. One penny. The Republicans now want to take that penny and cut it back more.
One might have understood this if the U.S. economy were doing poorly or if the U.S. were not the keystone of the whole international system. And one might have understood this if the Republicans were acting out of some coherent global strategy. But they aren't. Rather, the Republicans' drive to cut the foreign operations budget by 15 percent, or $2 billion, below what Mr. Clinton is seeking (he vetoed their budget Monday) is all part of a cheap gimmick led by the House majority whip, Tom DeLay, and his merry band of right-wing nuts, whose only guiding principle in world affairs is: "Dumb as we wanna be." 
 Think about it for a second. What possible foreign policy strategy would prompt a Republican lawmaker to want to reduce by some $300 million the amount of money the U.S. spends on its Expanded Threat Reduction Initiative, which pays for taking apart Russian nukes and chemical weapons and employing Russian nuclear scientists in commercial fields so they won't go to work for Iran or Iraq?
What possible foreign policy strategy would prompt him to want to reduce by 37 percent the funds the U.S. deposits in the global development banks, which are promoting capitalism in Africa and Latin America by lending to small businesses so they become America's customers?
What possible foreign policy strategy would say, "Let's help Israelis and Palestinians reach an agreement at Wye, but then not give them the money we promised to help them institute it -- even though we know, as Mr. Clinton said, that the cheapest Mideast war would cost us far more than the most expensive peace"?
It's no wonder that pro-Israel lobbies on Capitol Hill are deeply distraught about where the Republican Party is heading today, since the G.O.P. seems determined to shrink the foreign operations budget. The Republican strategy is to silence the Jews by giving Israel its full foreign aid allotment (but not the Wye supplement) and cutting everyone else. But Jewish groups understand that this will only isolate Israel and eventually imperil its aid too.
The fact is, DeLay & Co. have no adult supervision anymore. Republican internationalists like Bob Dole and Newt Gingrich are gone; Trent Lott and Dennis Hastert together don't add up to zero; George W. is still learning basic geography; and Ronald Reagan, who built up our foreign affairs budget because he knew how critical it was, is now a fading memory. The G.O.P. is led by people with no sense of how important America is to the world, both as an example and as a stabilizer. Bill Clinton has made the Republicans crazy.
So to embarrass Mr. Clinton, the Republicans have decided to pit the State Department budget against Social Security and to say that if you are for giving money to Ghana you are for taking it away from Grandma. The foreign operations budget, says Mr. DeLay, "will come straight out of the pockets of American seniors." Hogwash. There is no more direct connection between Social Security and foreign aid than there is between Social Security and the Marine Band.
But who cares? As Representative Sonny Callahan said during the House debate, back home in Alabama "when I say, 'Folks, I voted against increasing foreign aid,' they seem to like that."
Yes sir, I bet they do. But when the next Alabama exporter shows up in some country and needs help from the embassy commercial officer but the job has been cut; when the next U.S. embassy gets blown up because the world despises an America that tells everyone what to do but won't pay its U.N. dues; when a Russian-designed nuke shows up in Iran; when an environmental disaster in Mexico washes up on Alabama's shores, we'll see how much the people of Alabama like that.
They might just say: "You mean we could have prevented this with just one penny out of every budget dollar, and we cut the penny? Who was the idiot who did that?"

HEADLINE: Hollywood, City Hall and a Production Deal That Wasn't

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY 

 BODY:
Robert De Niro, a star in two of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's all-time favorite films -- "The Godfather Part II" and "Analyze This" -- came to Gracie Mansion last spring to flesh out his proposal to build film studios at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. The meeting went well enough for the Mayor to perform his Godfather routine for the accomplished actor.
When Mr. De Niro, his partner, Harvey Weinstein of Miramax Films, and several city officials left the mansion that day in late April, they thought they had a deal in progress, even without something in writing. And a week later they stood alongside Mr. Giuliani at a giddy news conference at which Mr. Weinstein, the co-chairman of Miramax, teased the Mayor about a future in film. 
 But their laughs and tolerance for amateur imitations ended last week when the city and the Navy Yard chose another set of developers to build the studios. Mr. De Niro and his partners quickly charged that the Giuliani administration had lured them into considering the Navy Yard as a site for their studios, only to suddenly double-cross them.
The city's official response is: Tough luck; the other development team had offered the city a better deal. Unofficially, though, city officials say Mr. Giuliani did not know of the final deal until after it was signed, irking the Mayor and revealing a kink in the administration's well-honed ability to maintain a united front.
A primary reason appears to be a disagreement between two deputy mayors.
Randy L. Levine, the Deputy Mayor responsible for economic development, had cast his lot with the De Niro group, figuring that it had the wherewithal to build film studios. But Rudy Washington, the Deputy Mayor for business services, had sided with the other group: two entrepreneurs who originally proposed the idea for film studios at the Navy Yard and their financial backer, a New Jersey firm called Steiner Equities.
In the end, the confusion that ensued from having two deputy mayors -- both of whom declined to comment -- working at cross purposes resulted in a miffed Mayor, an embarrassed administration, an angry couple of Hollywood power brokers and lingering questions within the administration about the successful bidder's ability to bring the project to fruition.
One high-ranking member of the administration said the case signaled that the Mayor's "early-warning system" -- vital to a candidate poised to begin a campaign for the Senate in the next few months -- had broken down. "We're not happy," the official said.
For all the internal intrigue, city officials say -- on paper at least -- that the deal struck with Steiner Equities would reap millions of dollars more for the city. And the city's corporation counsel, Michael D. Hess, said that members of the Steiner group had signed an agreement with the city in 1998 that could have led to a lawsuit if the city had chosen the De Niro group.
Mr. De Niro and Miramax "never had anything in writing," Mr. Hess said. "They had nothing. They had a press conference."
Spokesmen for Miramax and Mr. De Niro's company, TriBeCa Productions, declined to comment. But an associate of the partners with knowledge of the negotiations said the news conference on May 3 -- in which Mayor Giuliani took part and which was held at the city-controlled Navy Yard -- had come after an agreement to do a deal.
"We clearly thought this deal was going to happen," the associate said. "And we clearly had a different impression of what a deal is."
That would explain the dual personality of the press release that the Mayor's office issued to trumpet the news conference with Mr. De Niro. It repeatedly said the city would "explore" a deal. But its headline also implied a done deal:
"Mayor Giuliani Announces Major Film and Television Production Facility to Be Built At The Brooklyn Navy Yard -- Facility to Serve as Pre-eminent East Coast Film and Television Production Studio and Create Thousands of Film, Television and Construction Jobs."
Plans to build a production complex on a part of the Navy Yard were first raised by Cary Dean Hart, a movie-set designer, and Louis Madigan, a computer consultant. In the summer of 1998, the two entrepreneurs signed an agreement with the city's Brooklyn Navy Yard Development Corporation, a quasi-public agency that manages the former shipbuilding site, to construct a $160 million complex.
But as Mr. Hart and Mr. Madigan struggled to secure financing for their ambitious plan, people close to the negotiations say, the Giuliani administration invited TriBeCa Productions, owned by Mr. De Niro and Jane Rosenthal, to consider building a production site at the Navy Yard. That raised the poignant possibility that the originators of a plan for redevelopment of the yard might be cut out of their own proposal.
The movie producers soon enlisted Mr. Weinstein and Steven Roth, the chairman of Vornado Realty Trust, to invest in a $150 million plan to convert 15 acres into a production center that would include 12 sound stages and create thousands of jobs.
But there remained the matter of Mr. Madigan and Mr. Hart, who eventually were included in the new calculations, but in a much smaller capacity. "Nobody wanted to cut anybody out," one city official explained.
For a while it appeared that Mr. Levine had won his subtle battle with Mr. Washington. There was the Gracie Mansion meeting between the Mayor and Mr. De Niro, followed a week later by the press conference charged with Hollywood glamour. Mr. Madigan and Mr. Hart stood glumly at the back of the dais as Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Weinstein joked before the cameras. The best that Mr. Washington could do was suggest that Mr. Madigan and Mr. Hart represented "the American dream."
Shortly afterward, the two entrepreneurs notified the city that they wanted no part of the De Niro deal. Instead they would be resurrecting their own proposal with the backing of Steiner Equities. They also reminded city officials that a lawsuit was possible.
That split led to a long summer for Mr. Washington and Mr. Levine and particularly for Mr. Hess, who was assigned by the Mayor to choose the best offer. "There were phone calls back and forth, tit for tat," Mr. Hess said.
Throughout, an associate of the De Niro group said, Mr. De Niro and his partners thought that negotiations were well past mere exploration. With Mr. Levine as their City Hall advocate, they believed they could wait out the Steiner group until its agreement with the Navy Yard lapsed or until it simply backed out. There was even talk of buying out the other set of developers.
And when they kept hearing rumors earlier this month that the city was closing the deal with the Steiner group, they received assurances from city officials that no agreement could be reached without the knowledge of the administration's top people, according to people involved in the negotiations.
Finally, last week, Mr. Hess concluded that the Steiner group's offer was superior -- "on paper," a distinction that he and other city officials repeatedly cite. The De Niro group insisted that its project had to be supported by a $25 million loan from the city, and said that it could not begin construction for at least six months. The Steiner group needed no public assistance, offered millions of dollars more in rent and promised to break ground in 30 days, Mr. Hess said in explanation for his decision. The threat of a lawsuit also figured in his decision.
The afternoon of Oct. 12, Mr. Hess notified the De Niro group of his decision -- a call that flabbergasted its members. Mr. Hess then forwarded a written legal opinion to Mr. Washington, the Mayor's representative on the board of the Navy Yard corporation. According to one side in the dispute, Mr. Washington interpreted the letter to mean that the deal had the Mayor's approval. He immediately alerted the other members of the board, and within an hour or two an agreement was signed with the Steiner group.
When Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Levine learned that night that a deal had been struck without their knowledge, they fumed. According to one City Hall official, Mr. Giuliani kept asking, "Why? Why? Why?"
At the very least, two city officials said, a meeting should have been held first to apprise the Mayor and discuss the implications of the legal opinion.
When told that Mr. De Niro, a star of his favorite films, had felt double-crossed, Mr. Giuliani answered: "Well, that's some other world. That's some other world, other than the world of equity, fairness."

HEADLINE: Puerto Rico Governor Faces Senators Over Firing Range

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH BECKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19

 BODY:
In a standoff with powerful senators, the Governor of Puerto Rico told a Congressional committee today that the United States military should never resume live firing exercises on the territory's island of Vieques, despite the recommendation of a Presidential panel that the exercises resume.
"Not one bomb?" asked Senator John W. Warner, Republican of Virginia and chairman of the Armed Services Committee, which held the hearing on the issue. 
 "No," answered Pedro J. Rossello, the Governor.
Despite Governor Rossello's strong words, President Clinton will ultimately decide whether any more live ammunition is fired on the range, which is the property of the Navy and takes up nearly two-thirds of the 20-mile-long island. The four-member Presidential panel recommended on Monday that the United States military be permitted to resume the exercises but that the range be shut down within five years. Since April, when a Marine pilot killed a Puerto Rican guard in a bombing accident there, Puerto Rican protesters have occupied it and prevented any firing exercises.
Several senators said today that they feared that political calculations would take precedence over the report's recommendations. Vieques is a major issue for Puerto Ricans, who are unusually united against the firing range and are using their electoral strength to lobby Democratic candidates. Hillary Rodham Clinton, who is considering a run for the United States Senate in New York, said on Monday that she opposed resumption of the exercises there.
At today's hearing, Senator James M. Inhofe, an Oklahoma Republican on the committee, said the firing range should be reopened immediately. He said it was the only site on the East Coast where American sailors and marines preparing for deployment over the next few months could engage in live firing exercises critical in preparing for combat.
But the panel's report said the Navy should be able to find alternatives in the next five years.
The committee also heard testimony from members of the Presidential panel, who criticized the Navy for creating this crisis by failing to address long-held grievances of the people of Vieques. They said the range was largely responsible for an unemployment rate of 25 percent on the island, which might otherwise be a desirable tourist spot, and environmental and health problems.
"We feel the Navy has lost the respect and confidence of the people of Puerto Rico and Vieques," said Gen. Richard I. Neal, a panel member who is retired from the Marine Corps and who admitted under questioning that he was an official in the Marines when the situation deteriorated in Vieques.
Richard Danzig, the Secretary of the Navy, testified today that he had accepted several recommendations of the panel and would appoint an admiral to begin improving relations between the Navy and Vieques.
Admiral Jay L. Johnson, chief of naval operations, argued at the hearing for reopening the range by pointing out that in Operation Desert Fox against Iraq, pilots who had trained at Vieques were nearly 20 percent more effective in hitting targets than those who had not trained there.
While insisting that Puerto Rico was a friend of the Navy, Governor Rossello said the Vieques firing range had to be closed.
"The bottom line is that the Navy has repeatedly been a shabby steward of the delicate ecology of what was once one of the most uniformly beautiful islands in the Caribbean Sea," the Governor said.

HEADLINE: Rate Debate Heats Up on Rise in Consumer Prices

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
The Consumer Price Index rose four-tenths of one percent in September, the biggest monthly increase since April, the Labor Department reported yesterday. But only petroleum prices exerted any lasting inflationary pressure.
Still, the fully expected and essentially mild inflation report seemed to stoke rather than settle a debate over what the Federal Reserve should do next: raise interest rates to pre-emptively stifle inflation or leave rates alone and avoid the risk of slowing the economy unnecessarily. 
 Although the stock market dropped sharply last week in part because investors were concerned that the Fed might raise rates, some Wall Street economists and forecasters are worried the Fed is not acting quickly enough. They are actually pushing for a rate increase, preferably at the Fed's next policy meeting, on Nov. 16, and then are looking for a signal from the central bank that no more increases are in the offing. In their view, that would help to stabilize the market.
"When the Fed is in a tightening mode, the markets are always looking for a signal that the tightening is over, and right now they don't have that signal," said Joshua Fineman, chief economist for Deutsche Asset Management, referring to the Fed's announced stance in favor of raising rates, if any action is taken at all.
Taking the opposite tack, two powerful representatives of the companies that make and sell the nation's goods and services -- the United States Chamber of Commerce and the National Association of Manufacturers -- urged the Fed to leave rates alone. They insist that inflation is nowhere on the horizon and higher rates will slow the economy unnecessarily, hurting business -- just when the economy may be slowing on its own.
"Rate increases at this juncture might be a situation of piling on too much downward pressure," said Martin Regalia, chief economist for the Chamber of Commerce. He noted, for example, that retail sales eased off in September. Housing starts also fell, by 3.2 percent, to 1.618 million, the Commerce Department reported yesterday.
The two sides agreed on one point: that inflation, as measured by the latest Consumer Price Index report, is not accelerating quickly. The index has risen by 2.6 percent over the last 12 months, slightly faster than last spring. But with food and energy removed, the so-called core inflation rate rose three-tenths of a percent in September and has gone up 2 percent over the last year -- a rate that is down slightly from last spring.
"To our way of thinking, there has not been any clear upside breakout in underlying inflation," said John Youngdahl, a senior money market economist at Goldman, Sachs.
"But that said," he added, "the big issue for the markets is whether we are at an inflection point, at which labor costs or prices or both will begin to rise."
Investors, pleased at first by the mild inflation report, pushed up the Dow Jones industrial average by more than 200 points in early trading. But then they let prices fall, and the Dow closed up 88.65 points, at 10,204.93. Bond traders, in a similar reaction, drove down interest rates and then let them rise as the concern about inflation reasserted itself -- and with it, the pressure from Wall Street for an interest rate increase.
"The markets are starting to perceive that the Fed could be falling slightly behind the curve and, to catch up, should raise rates at the November meeting," said David M. Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a bond trading house.
The excitement level on Wall Street rose considerably last Friday when the Labor Department announced a 1.1 percent jump in the Producer Price Index for September. Those are the prices that manufacturers charge for their finished products. But the producer price jump did not carry through to the much broader Consumer Price Index, which measures what the public pays not only for goods but also for services.
More than half of the September increase in the C.P.I. came from higher prices for cigarettes (20 percent of the total increase), hotel rooms (13 percent), apparel (14 percent) and petroleum products (20 percent), the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics said.
Cigarette prices jumped in response to a recent increase imposed by the manufacturers. Apparel prices climbed 1.2 percent, apparently reflecting the introduction of winter clothing. And hotel room rates rose sharply in September because the bureau has not yet adjusted its formulas to a change in the way hotels price their rooms from season to season.
None of those prices are likely to post similar increases this month, said Patrick Jackman, a senior economist in the bureau division that calculates the consumer index. And there are no signs of inflationary pressures in other key categories that turned in mild performances in September.
Home prices, for example, are rising smartly in many parts of the country, but in the bureau's eyes, the purchase of a home is an investment, not a cost of living. What the C.P.I. calculates is the "consumption cost" of operating a home from month to month. That monthly consumption cost was up only 2.5 percent over the last year, including less than three-tenths of a percent last month.
Medical care costs continued their unexpectedly mild rise -- three-tenths of a percent in September and 3.4 percent over the last 12 months. And prices of new vehicles, up sharply in September at the producer price level, rose only two-tenths of a percent in the showrooms, mainly because of differences in the ways factory and retail prices are calculated for new models. Over the last 12 months, vehicle prices at the producer and consumer levels have paralleled each other, Mr. Jackman said, and they are both down five-tenths of a percent.
Petroleum prices are another matter. As long as the main oil-producing nations continue to restrict their output, gasoline and heating oil prices are likely to continue rising, analysts say. In time, there should be secondary effects, pushing up airline fares, for example, or food and apparel costs once truck shipping rates rise in response to higher fuel prices.
"These secondary effects have not shown up yet, or they may be muted by other factors," Mr. Jackman said. "Airline fares, for example, fell in September. One of the arguments in airline fares is that the airlines have more flights and more seats available and they have to fill those seats."
Excess capacity in many industries appears to play a role in holding down prices. The percentage of industrial capacity needed to meet demand, for example, fell in September to the low rate of 80.3 percent.
"The markets expect a rate increase from the Fed," said Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch, "but the fact that the inflation data remain benign gives them encouragement that there won't be a series of tightenings."

HEADLINE: Usual, and Unusual, Offers of Help to Flood's Victims

 BODY:
After weeks of complaints that flood relief was slow in coming, efforts to help pay for damage and dislocation from Tropical Storm Floyd have picked up some speed this week in Washington, Trenton and, of all places, Atlantic City.
President Clinton announced Monday that next month, the Federal Department of Housing and Economic Development would release $43 million in Community Development Block Grant money for New Jersey that otherwise would not have been distributed until next year. The money will be distributed to nine counties -- Bergen, Essex, Middlesex, Morris, Somerset, Union, Hunterdon, Mercer and Passaic -- as well as the state government. 
 Mr. Clinton also authorized the Department of Health and Human Services to provide $5 million from the Low Income Home Energy Assistance Program to victims of the flooding that followed the storm last month.
For the first time, the Federal Emergency Management Agency began offering qualified recipients of its rental assistance program the option of receiving a lump sum of up to $10,000 in cash, said Mary Margaret Walker, an agency spokeswoman. Ordinarily, the program makes quarterly payments for up to 18 months, she said.
In the New Jersey Legislature, the budget committees of the Senate and Assembly approved a bill on Monday that would provide $50 million in grants and loans to flood victims, plus $10 million to reimburse public agencies for overtime, supplies and other flood-related expenses. Both chambers have scheduled a full vote on the proposal for Monday.
Another bill awaiting action would use $50 million in state open space bond money to buy flood-prone properties. The intent is to avoid repeated bailouts every time a flood occurs.
And New Jersey's Casino Reinvestment Development Authority, which typically uses casino tax money to build housing in Atlantic County, voted yesterday to contribute $100,000 to flood victims in Bound Brook, about 100 miles away in Somerset County. "We'll grab it -- I'll go to Atlantic City tomorrow," said Mayor Frank Gilly of Bound Brook, which was hard hit by the storm and was loud in protesting the pace and size of the official response.
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman supports the flood relief bill and the casino agency's plan, but she has not taken a position on the buyout bill, said Steffanie Bell, a spokeswoman for Mrs. Whitman.
Russ Edmunston, a spokesman for the emergency agency, said that by yesterday, 17,470 callers had registered for some kind of home or business assistance on the agency's automated help line (800-462-9029). So far, he said, the emergency management agency has awarded $18.7 million in housing assistance grants, and the Small Business Administration had made $14.1 million in business loans. The deadline to call for assistance is Nov. 17, he said.
The acceleration of HUD grant money, distributed by counties, comes as good news to nonprofit organizations, which use it for projects like low-cost housing, counseling or food and shelter for the poor. A spokeswoman for HUD, Debbie Pickford, said that the same types of services provided by organizations that usually receive block grants are in stronger demand because of the flood.
Rosalee Yurasko, director of community development for Somerset County, said that normally, the county would award year 2000 block grants in September, when the money becomes available.
She said that applications were normally due in March but that she had not received guidelines on how to accelerate the process and get the money to the agencies that were already inquiring about it yesterday. "A lot of people have been calling and saying, 'Where's the money?' " she said.

HEADLINE: A New Universal Language;
In Class of Many Tongues, Computer Skills Are Focus

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
For generations, Henry Street, on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, has been a first stop for immigrants learning to adjust to America. At settlement houses, churches and community centers, newcomers from Europe and Asia all learned the skills -- and the language -- they would need to survive in the new world.
So perhaps it is not surprising that in a church basement on Henry Street last month, a group of women from Ghana and Lebanon, Hong Kong and Brazil (as well as three of the boroughs) were learning the new language they need to survive: Microsoft Powerpoint. 
 Their situation says much about the changing nature of work and unemployment, and the new challenges of job training and job seeking, in New York City near the close of 1999. The 10 women in this class are all experienced office employees, energetic, ambitious and charming. And they have all been out of work for months, despite the booming economy and the plunging unemployment rate.
Though each of their stories is different, their problems boil down to one thing, they say: technology. "I wanted to find a job, but most of the jobs require computer knowledge," said Marie Ceran, 32, who spent years working as an office manager at Caldor before the bankrupt retailer started closing its stores in January.
And employers do not just want familiarity with a computer; they are demanding up-to-the-minute skills in the most current software. "It seemed like computers came up at every last interview," said Sheron Mickie, 23, the youngest student in the class. "I'd say, 'I learned the Word Perfect version from 1990,' and they'd say, 'We'll call you.' "
All this helps explain why the Chinatown Manpower Project, which in the past has focused on teaching unemployed people English and business skills, this year switched to straight computer instruction. The program, for workers who have been "downsized" or unemployed for a long time, is financed by the Federal Government and administered through the New York City Department of Employment, which sponsors about 16 computer skills programs for adults.
There is a certain "only in New York" quality to the class: where else would women born in six countries, speaking half a dozen languages, take computer lessons from a man with a strong Chinese accent? And in their ambitions, their pride and their strong personalities, these women struck even their teachers as unusual, though their lack of software skills is common.
In fact, economists and labor experts say that in many ways, the experience of these women reflects the situation across the country, now and in the future. Technology has become so pervasive in the workplace that at least half the entry-level jobs for people who have not graduated from college involve computer use, said Harry J. Holzer, the chief economist for the Federal Department of Labor. And that was several years ago, when Mr. Holzer surveyed 3,200 businesses in four cities.
"Futurework," a report issued last month by the Labor Department, predicts that within a few years, "Most workers will need basic computer skills to enter their chosen occupations and additional specialized training in field-specific applications to advance."
The world is already rewarding workers who can use computers. Mr. Holzer found that all else being equal, entry-level workers who use computers on the job make 5 to 10 percent more than those who do not.
And for experienced employees, the premiums may be much greater. Wendy Alfus Rothman, managing partner of Advantage Human Resourcing, a placement agency, said she might pay 50 percent more for someone who has mastered the "holy trinity" of Microsoft Word, Powerpoint and Excel.
"I can get that person a job in 10 minutes," she said.
The job market is also penalizing workers who do not have the necessary computer skills, according to Alan B. Krueger, a Princeton economist. "Skill mismatches," Professor Krueger said last week, are one reason that those who are unemployed today tend to be out of work a long time. Further reducing the unemployment rate, which nationally hovers around 4 percent, "will mean lowering long-term unemployment, which will require more retraining," he said.
Short-term unemployment has declined, Professor Krueger said, in part because of the rise of temporary help agencies, which have been booming in New York and across the country.
At Henry Street, several of the older women, like Aida Spielmann and Shelley Haynes, who spent most of their careers with one employer, said they wanted to work at temporary assignments to "test the waters a little bit and observe a company from the inside," as Ms. Haynes put it.
Ms. Haynes, an elegant, soft-spoken woman of 39, still seems a little shell-shocked after the company where she worked for more than 15 years closed two offices and laid off many employees, including her. "It's like a woman who got married and had kids and her husband passes away, and she has to go out into the working world," said Ms. Haynes, who was born in Barbados.
Temporary agencies pay premiums for workers who have mastered software programs, but jobs in every industry call for computer skills these days.
That is what Frances-Odessa Davis found out when she was forced to look for a new job. Ms. Davis, who is in her 30's, spent more than six years in the Navy and then worked for an airline and for a carnival. She returned to Queens from Hawaii in 1991 and, until a year ago, worked at a medical bookstore while going to York College to get a degree in psychology and special education.
But then, Ms. Davis hurt her back. She decided to look for an office job while she continued her studies -- and ran into the computer problem. "I'm a college student; we use computers," she said. "But they would ask me, 'Do you know Excel?' and I was like, 'Huh?' "
To get into the class, all of the women had to have some familiarity with computers. The city government judges the program on how successful it is in placing graduates in jobs that pay at least $11 an hour, or about $22,000 a year, well below the citywide average of $47,000.
To try to maintain its high success rate, the program does not accept technological neophytes, and it takes a maximum of 16 students for every three-month session.
Those limits frustrate Bing Chen, the class's chief instructor, who has been working for Chinatown Manpower since 1996. "We're here to help people," he said. "Let them come."
Only one of the women in the class was from the neighborhood (and ethnic background) that Chinatown Manpower has traditionally served. Luckie Ko, whose parents brought her here from Hong Kong when she was 3, spent six years as a data analyst for a financial information company; she used a computer but, she said, did not really understand how it worked.
Last spring, the company moved her department to Ohio. Ms. Ko, who is married to a trucker and whose mother helps care for her five children, ranging in age from 18 months to 21 years, decided not to move. "I have a lot of baggage to carry," she said dryly.
Like most of the women in the class, Ms. Ko would ultimately like to have her own business, perhaps running a day care center. In the meantime, she said, "I just want to go back to doing what I was doing before."
That desire is common -- and it is frustrating for the trainers. The problem, they say, is that many workers cannot accept the fact that they are basically starting over. They want the same salaries, benefits and titles that they had before. "We get you jobs," said Cassie S. Young, the program's job counselor. "We don't get you what you want."
Her big success story in this group, she said, is Lisa Marie Caruso, 27, who lost her job as an executive secretary in April and was recently divorced.
"I feel old sometimes," Ms. Caruso said with a sigh, adding that she had been desperately seeking work and could find only receptionist jobs. And though she has an associate's degree from Kingsborough Community College, she did not score well on the tests administered by employment agencies.
After six weeks of class, Ms. Caruso's skills -- and her self-confidence -- improved a lot. She started doing temporary work right away. But Ms. Caruso has been in the job market for only four years, and her goals are relatively modest (move out of her mother's house in Bay Ridge, for example).
The training was much less satisfying for some of the older, more experienced and more ambitious women, like Emelia Benin, 42. Smart, serious and slightly prickly, Ms. Benin came to the United States from Ghana to attend the Fashion Institute of Technology in 1979. She spent more than a dozen years working for a lingerie company, where she was in charge of shipping.
Her old employer used a Unix operating system, and Ms. Benin was determined to learn Windows. Once she got into the class, she studied hard; some of her fellow students said she was a whiz.
Yet she was also frustrated by the experience, as were some of the other women. The program was not well organized, they said, and could not give them the same kinds of tests the agencies used. And several said they found the attitude of some of the staff disrespectful.
A fabulous baker (her poppy seed cake is scrumptious), Ms. Benin hopes someday to go to the French Culinary Institute and to open her own small cafe. "It would be nice to know I did something I love," she said.
Meaningful work and dignity can be hard to come by, even for women who have mastered computer skills. Safa Hadla, 35, is an ebullient and dynamic woman who made a big impression on her classmates (Ms. Caruso said she wants to name a daughter Safa). She also speaks five languages, and she spent several years managing doctors' offices in New York.
But she complains about the rudeness and disrespectful treatment she receives at employment agencies here. "In other countries, they don't see you just as a skill machine," said Ms. Hadla, who was born in Lebanon and lived and worked in Venezuela and France before she "met my Prince Charming in Queens."
Still, Ms. Hadla has already found a new job, at a bank. (She started on Monday.) So has Ms. Davis, the former Navy seaman, who is now working for an Internet start-up company as a receptionist. Ms. Benin found a job for herself and referred another potential employer to Ms. Ceran, the former Caldor worker, who was hired on the spot as an assistant office manager.
And as they leave the program, a new group of women is eager to replace them. Mira Kreposter, who came to the United States from Baku, Azerbaijan, 12 years ago, worked for a financial company that merged and closed her department. Explaining why she wanted to take the computer training, she said, "At the end of this century and the portal of the next, we need to know everything of the highest technology."
