HEADLINE: U.S. Indicts McDonnell Douglas And Chinese in Equipment Deal

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19

 BODY:
A Federal grand jury indicted the McDonnell Douglas Corporation and a powerful state-owned aerospace company in China today on charges of conspiring to hide important details of a 1994 sale of American machining equipment, some of which was diverted to a Chinese military site.
The case could complicate relations between Beijing and Washington just as China and the United States are trying to complete one of the biggest trade agreements in history: China's entry into the World Trade Organization, American and Chinese officials said. 
 Bonni Tischler, the assistant commissioner for investigations for the United States Customs Service, said at a news briefing today that the indictment was the "first time a Chinese Government entity has been indicted for violations of U.S. export laws."
The indictment charges McDonnell Douglas, a unit of the Boeing Company, and the Douglas Aircraft Company with 13 counts, including conspiracy, false statements and misrepresentations in connection with a 1994 export license to sell 13 pieces of machining equipment to China. It also contains 12 charges against the buyer of the equipment, the China National Aero Technology Import and Export Corporation, or Catic, and Catic affiliates in Beijing and California.
Two Chinese nationals employed by Catic were also indicted, as was a mid-level McDonnell Douglas employee, Robert J. Hitt, the director of the China Program Office at Douglas Aircraft in California.
Both Boeing and Catic representatives denied any wrongdoing and vowed to contest the charges.
"McDonnell Douglas Corporation did not commit any criminal violations in regard to the sale of the machine tools to the People's Republic of China and intends to vigorously defend against the charges brought by the United States Attorney's Office," Boeing said in a statement. "It is unfortunate that the prosecutors have apparently not taken the time to learn the facts and gain a full understanding of a rather complicated matter."
Fred F. Fielding, a partner in the Washington law firm of Wiley, Rein & Fielding who represents Catic and its affiliates, said: "Catic has cooperated fully with the Government investigation and has strongly maintained throughout that it has never intentionally violated any U.S. laws. This is a commercial transaction involving the sale of used machinery, and the Government's position that this is a criminal or national security case is absurd."
But Ms. Tischler said the diversion of civilian technology for military uses by China was a top priority for investigators.
At issue is whether McDonnell Douglas knew or should have known that the equipment was likely to be used for something other than the intended commercial purpose.
Boeing also released a lengthy background paper that suggested that one of the company's defenses is that top Clinton Administration officials knew important details of the deal, so they could not have been misled.
The criminal investigation began in 1996. Lengthy plea-bargain negotiations between defense lawyers, and Lisa Prager, the Assistant United States Attorney who handled the inquiry, broke down Monday night, lawyers said.
Catic bought the machining equipment, which is used to bend steel in manufacturing aircraft, for $5 million. But the sale was part of a billion-dollar deal in which McDonnell Douglas was to build trunkliner, or middle-size commuter, aircraft in China.
The indictment cites an October 1993 meeting of Douglas executives in which they discussed the machining equipment sale as being part of "the pending $1 billion trunkliner program," in which the equipment was to be used to manufacture the commuter aircraft.
A few months after the sale, McDonnell Douglas discovered that some of the equipment had not gone to the intended destination, a civilian site in Beijing, but instead wound up 800 miles away, at a military site in Nanchang that makes surface-to-surface missiles and fighter aircraft.
McDonnell Douglas reported the diversion in 1995, before the equipment had been put to use. The giant machines, which are still in China, were later moved to a civilian location, and the equipment was never used for any military purpose. Meanwhile, the airliner deal, which President Clinton hailed on the eve of the 1994 election as a job-rich program for 20 planes, has produced only one plane, according to the indictment.
The airliner deal was promoted by Mr. Clinton and Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown, who died in a plane crash in Croatia in 1996, as a centerpiece of the Administration's commercial diplomacy, the policy of using economic engagement to broaden ties with Beijing and promote exports. On the eve of a trip to China in 1994, Mr. Brown wrote a letter to China's vice premier about the airliner deal based on a draft letter from McDonnell Douglas, according to Boeing's background paper. The machining equipment export license was issued soon after Mr. Brown returned from Beijing.
State Department cables obtained by defense lawyers in the case show that Administration officials delayed seeking timely assurances from Catic on how it planned to use the machining equipment so as not to disrupt Mr. Brown's announcement about the airliner deal in China, according to lawyers and officials who have read the cables.
The indictment accuses Catic officials of being responsible for the diversion of six of the machines to Nanchang. It also charges that McDonnell Douglas officials concealed or failed to disclose important information to Commerce Department licensing officials, including that the airliner deal was in jeopardy. If the deal was in jeopardy, it could be less likely that the equipment would be used for its intended commercial purposes.
The indictment also says that McDonnell Douglas, which was bought by Boeing in 1997, concealed its hiring of a "high ranking former Government official and his consulting firm" that was paid $4 million "to intercede with Catic" and China "because the trunkliner negotiations were stalled."
Lawyers involved in the case said the former official referred to in the indictment was Alexander M. Haig Jr., the former Secretary of State. Woody Goldberg, a spokesman for Mr. Haig's firm, confirmed their representation of McDonnell Douglas on the China airliner deal.

HEADLINE: INSIDE

 BODY:

Consumer Prices Edge Up

Light on A-Arms Locations

Nathalie Sarraute Dies at 99
The French novelist created a stark literary form stripped of characters, plot and chronology, which Sartre termed the antinovel. PAGE C25

HEADLINE: METRO BUSINESS;
Alexander's to Get Loan for Old Store

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Vornado Realty Trust agreed to lend $50 million to the real estate developer Alexander's Inc. to finance development costs at the site of its former flagship store in midtown Manhattan and at a Brooklyn shopping center.
The companies, both based in Saddle Brook, N.J., said the loan will be under the same terms as a $45 million loan from Vornado made in March 1995. That loan carries an interest rate of 14.18 percent, according to a recent regulatory filing. Vornado owns 29.3 percent of the common stock of Alexander's and manages, develops and leases its properties. 
 Alexander's, a former retailer, owns the site of its old store on the block between 58th and 59th Streets on Lexington Avenue in midtown. In 1998, the company also became the sole owner of Kings Plaza Shopping Center in Brooklyn.
The Manhattan site is one of the few spaces open for development in midtown, where vacancy rates are at their lowest levels in 17 years.

HEADLINE: Car Artists Make Their Every Trip A Traveling Show

BYLINE: By ANDREA KANNAPELL 

 BODY:
ON a recent, drizzly Friday, a navy blue '85 Impala cruised slowly down a leafy street in suburban Clifton, N.J. The passenger window framed a grin of pure delight directed toward Stephen Hooper's driveway. The Impala circled around and crept to a halt. From the driver's side beamed another enchanted smile.
"I get this all the time," said Mr. Hooper, who prefers to be known as Hoop, as he stood at the door of his garage. "I'm like my own museum." 
 Behind him was a peculiar sculpture that looked something like his own head, oversized front teeth, scraggly red beard and all. It was about the size of a small car. In fact, underneath the felt and fake fur was a small car, a rare 1961 British Trojan that opened from the front like a refrigerator.
That wasn't all the Impala was there to gawk at. In the driveway was the Can-vertible, a 1972 Fiat covered with crushed cans, and a 1941 Packard hearse wrapped in black and tan fur with giant fingerprints. At the curb was a van with two front ends; one side, layered with glued-on timepieces, was labeled "Millennium Machine."
Hoop's fleet, unique as it is, is part of a phenomenon that has been taking shape and rolling onto the roadways of America for the last 20 years. The art car -- its roots tangled in everything from the proselytizing chariots of traveling preachers to the billboard-style signs on delivery trucks to the tie-dyed school buses of hippiedom -- seems to have been invented in dozens of places simultaneously.
"A lot of people who do this don't know about anyone else when they start," Hoop said. He certainly didn't in the early 1980's, when he banged a dent out of his 1958 Isetta, covered it in fake fur and hit the New York club scene.
One result is the extreme diversity of the cars. If the Fords, Saturns, Chevies and Hondas sparkling in dealers' lots are so many streamlined Rockettes in a perfect kick line, art cars form more of a riotous mosh pit.
A Volkswagen Beetle in California is mosaicked in marbles. A 1970 Oldsmobile 98 in Montana is covered with mirrors. A draftsman in Hackensack, N.J., painstakingly painted his 1985 Buick Skyhawk a fine red plaid, and a musician in nearby Montclair drives a 1991 Toyota pickup that has an earth goddess on the rear door. Kelly Lyles, a Seattle artist, not only drives an art car -- a Subaru station wagon done up like a leopard -- but she also paints formal portraits of them. In New York City, 53 television sets stud Dan Lohaus's 1992 Toyota pickup and several hundred remote controls plaster its hood.
And Phillip Treuvey, a professional spackler who lives near Wayne, N.J., has been adding layers of images onto his Volkswagen bus for the last nine years, using found objects -- fly swatters, key chains, flowers -- as stencils.
Getting a convincing explanation for these efforts is not easy. Tim McNally, who has spent more than 300 hours on his Plaidmobile, said he began after reading a letter from a friend enthusing about her new car, which was a special blue color.
"I thought it would be fun to write back that my car is plaid," he said.
Perhaps the clearest explanation comes from Harrod Blank, a Berkeley, Calif., artist, who has written books and made films about the phenomenon of the art car. "It's a personal totem, a shrine on wheels," said Mr. Blank. "Something you put love and time into, to transform it from something that's mere transportation to something that's special. Because you spend so much time in it, you want it to be you. It's like taking refuge in your room. Same kind of energy, just a bit more extreme."
Some art cars are subtle. A man in Houston glued a beer can, upright, onto the roof of his car and drives around delightedly eliciting yells from the helpful: "Hey, you got a beer on your car!"
"It's like the Wright brothers," said Gene Pool -- his legal name -- a New Yorker once famous for growing fields of living grass on automobiles. "There are all these people trying to fly at the same time."
Now that such vehicles -- once the provenance of individual oddballs, determined artists and Deadheads -- show up regularly in the rearview mirrors of sedate sedans and rugged suburban sport utility vehicles, there is an explosion of events focused on them.
There are established art-car festivals and parades in Houston; San Francisco; Minneapolis; Baltimore (where there are actually two); Key West, Fla.; Decatur, Ill., and Lawrence, Kan., to name just a few. Some attract a handful of odd cars, others draw hundreds of art-car pilgrims from across the country.
Mr. Blank has even found he can eke out part of his living by acting as an agent for artists willing to hire their cars out for advertising or movie work. (For instance, he has arranged for art cars to appear in a Hewlett-Packard advertisement for a printer and on a French billboard for an insurance company.) "That's the only way I can survive," he said.
Mr. Pool said the trend is evidence of the strength of the nation's individualism. "The people who do this get sick of being just another car," he said.
But it also testifies to the relatively open laws of the American road. Japanese and German visitors ooh and ah over the cars, then ask if they are legal. And the trend is also a product of the economy of the automobile market, where new cars regularly cost $20,000, while battered but serviceable and insurable junkers trade hands for no more than a few hundred dollars.
And it's not just about getting attention. "It's not, 'Look at me!' " Hoop said. "It's like, 'How do you like this?' "
Tim McNally, the painter of the Plaidmobile, said that his car spreads a little cheer. "Especially on the road," he said, "where a lot of people need cheering up."
Philo Northrup, an artist who, with Mr. Blank, founded the Artcar Fest in San Francisco, which held its third gathering last month, said that art cars address a gap in American culture: "The institutions for art and religion are not meeting the needs that are out there. I think you've got a population that has as much spiritual and creative energy as any other, but the churches, synagogues and museums are all talking to each other -- they're not talking to us."
Still, even the art world no longer considers art cars only as outsider art or folk art. On Saturday, the Triton Museum of Art in Santa Clara, Calif., will open a show dedicated to art cars made by Californians. The Cincinnati Contemporary Arts Center is exhibiting the "Inside-Out Car" -- a '79 Volkswagen Rabbit that Dan Devine, a New York artist, cut apart, turned inside out, and rewelded and reupholstered. (If more proof of art-world recognition is needed, consider this: There is no Blue Book listing for a Rabbit that old. Mr. Devine's price tag is about $40,000.)
In a most human sign that the art-car phenomenon has really arrived, it is already showing signs of factionalization. The granddaddy of art-car events, the Orange Show Foundation Art Car Weekend, held in Houston every spring for the last 12 years, attracts creators from around the country. Perhaps a third of the scores of cars are made specifically for the parade and are stored or disassembled in between.
In contrast, the San Francisco festival focuses on cars that Mr. Blank refers to proudly as daily drivers.
But some art-car creators think even that kind of festival strays too far from normal driving, ruining the point as they see it -- to bring a surprising dash of art into everyday life. As Hoop put it, "I have my own art-car parade every time I go to the grocery."
 
Parade Routes
ART-CAR festivals and parades occur around the country at all times of the year. Many are listed on the Art Cars in Cyberspace Web site at www.artcars.com. In testament to the grass-roots nature of the phenomenon, most of the festivals take place in smaller cities; none are scheduled for urban strongholds like New York, Chicago or Washington.
Nearby suburban areas, though, seem to be fertile art-car soil. In the New York area, for example, Jan Loe, a musician and artist who lives in Montclair, N.J., expects to put together her fourth art-car parade next summer. (For information, telephone (973) 746-1412.) Past parades have drawn a dozen or so of the region's eclectic cars, including the Plaidmobile, by Tim McNally, of Hackensack, N.J.
The oldest and largest of the nation's festivals is the Orange Show Foundation's weekend event in Houston. It has been held for 12 years and usually includes more than 200 hot rods, low riders, classic cars and what the organizers call "artist-built rolling contraptions." Next year, the festival, officially the Pennzoil Art Car Weekend, is scheduled to run April 14 and 15. For information, send E-mail messages to orange@insync.net or telephone (713) 926-6368.
A Baltimore artist, Conrad Jay Bladey, is trying to organize a cyberfestival in the next month. Mr. Bladey has invited art-car owners, via an E-mail list-serve, to register their location on Nov. 6 at a Web site (www.geocities .com/MotorCity/Garage/1329 /artcarshow.html). Would-be spectators can visit the site to see whether any art cars are in their vicinity.
 ANDREA KANNAPELL

HEADLINE: RACING;
How Nascar's Power Figure Keeps Everybody Happy

BYLINE: By JOSEPH SIANO 

 BODY:
PLAYERS' UNIONS and egotistical team owners in most sports have turned the iron-fisted commissioner into a rusty relic. So why, then, has everyone in stock-car racing been so eager to submit to the near-dictatorial control of one man?
Probably because that man, William C. France, is making them wealthy. Mr. France, 66, is the president of the No. 1 race organizing group in the United States: the National Association of Stock Car Auto Racing, better known as Nascar. He also heads the International Speedway Corporation, which owns many of the tracks where Nascar drivers compete. And if that leaves any authority unexercised, there is his wife, Betty Jane; their children, Brian and Lesa; and Mr. France's brother, James -- all of whom are top executives in Nascar, International Speedway or both. 
 Mr. France's father, William H. G. France, created Nascar 51 years ago from what was little more than some moonshine runners getting together on Saturday night to see who had the fastest hot rod. Today, the Frances control a sport whose top division, the Winston Cup series, surpasses the regular-season television ratings of every other professional sport except the National Football League; its top 20 money winners, almost position for position, are ahead of the top 20 golfers on the P.G.A. Tour.
The sport's appeal is manifold. The noise, speed, color and spectacle are unlike anything except perhaps a Super Bowl or big heavyweight fight. And as in boxing, there is the element of physical peril.
In a sport with plenty of grease, Nascar's star drivers assiduously maintain squeaky-clean images -- a change that may cause old-timers to grumble about the loss of whisky-watered roots, but that is essential to the sport's growth as family fare. "They're accessible, they're open, they're modest, and they come out of a Southern culture that's respectful," Neal Pilson, a former CBS Sports executive, once said. Antisocial behavior, the bane of other pro sports, is almost unheard of.
 Nascar has also done something no other auto racing group has done: it has relegated the cars to a supporting role and made people the stars -- the drivers (the cream of the circuit, like Rusty Wallace, Mark Martin, Jeff Gordon and Dale Earnhardt), the chief mechanics, even the tire changers on pit crews. You don't have to be a gearhead to understand Nascar, because a stock car is quite unsophisticated technologically, to a degree that a typical microchip-laden luxury sedan makes it seem like a cannon in an age of cruise missiles. It uses a carburetor, long eclipsed by electronic fuel-injection in passenger cars, and a pushrod engine instead of the more common overhead cam engine. Independent rear suspensions and on-board computers are banned.
Stock-car racing had plenty of outlaws in the 1950's and 60's -- hard drinkers like Curtis Turner, who once landed his plane on a town street and parked a rental car in a motel pool -- but no more.
"Well, we're not the Wild West, like we used to be, but then, the Wild West is not the Wild West like it was 80, 90 years ago," Mr. France says to those who complain that the sport's old romance is gone. "If we were real rough-and-tumble, I doubt we'd be doing this interview now."
By wiping the blood off its knuckles and cleaning the grease from under its fingernails, stock-car racing has attracted blue-chip nonautomotive sponsors, like Mattel, McDonald's, Procter & Gamble and Home Depot. "I like to say that we were the leaders compared to other sports in sponsorships and so forth," Mr. France said. "Now, the colleges and universities are doing it. For a long time we were criticized for it, but we were just ahead of our time."
Things were plenty rough-and-tumble when Mr. France's father (known as Big Bill) arrived with his wife, Anne, and their 2-year-old son, Bill, in Daytona Beach, Fla., from Washington in 1934, looking for work as a mechanic. "He figured if he was going to work on cars, he might as well do it where it was warm," said Mr. France, who is known as Bill France Jr. (although Jr. is not part of his legal name).
Back then, Big Bill drove in the races run along the hard-packed sand of Daytona Beach (motorists can still drive onto the beach). But stock-car racing, then confined to the rural Southeast, suffered from two plagues: rampant cheating, and race promoters who ran off with the prize money. So Big Bill gathered some partners at the Streamline Motel in Daytona Beach in 1947, where Nascar was created to address those abuses.
He and his wife established their dominion over stock-car racing when they built the two-and-a-half-mile Daytona International Speedway (there are bronze statues of them outside its offices). When it opened, in 1959, no one had ever seen anything like its sweeping, towering turns, banked at 31 degrees.
"One of the key things I learned from him was evaluating the long-term benefit against the short-term negative and also the reverse," Mr. France said about his father, "and then trying to rationalize whether you are better off to take the hit now because it makes sense tomorrow, or take the good today and worry when tomorrow comes."
THE Streamline Motel "office" has been replaced by a suite at Nascar's New York branch. Mr. France, sitting in a corner office overlooking Park Avenue recently, was wearing a business suit, looking not nearly as streamlined as the young man in a photograph taken in July 1958 during the construction of Daytona. There, operating a road grader, in a white T-shirt and work pants, is Bill France Jr. -- trim and looking happy in his labors.
That photo helps explain how he came to earn his authority as much as he inherited it after his father died in 1992. "He's done everything in the sport," said Chip Williams, a former Nascar public relations director. "He's driven race cars, he's dug post holes, he's parked cars, he's sold programs."
Big Bill may have been an unashamed despot, but the philosophy of his son's regime is summed up by Mr. Williams, "Essentially, he's a dictator, but in fact he rules by consensus." Before turning over the day-to-day operations of Nascar racing to Mike Helton in February, Mr. France was noted for his willingness to listen to drivers, car owners, race promoters and sponsors.
He explained how he has managed to keep all the track owners and car owners in his camp. "Right now, we've got just about all of them making money," he said. "There's nothing like making money to be happy. Sometimes they're not happy because they think they should be making more, but usually they're more happy if they're making money than if they're not making any."
Track owners have benefited from attendance figures that have risen an average of 7 percent annually from 1992 through 1998. Last year, average weekend attendance for one of the 33 Winston Cup races was 190,940. With attendance that high, the cost of building one new seat -- by various estimates, $350 to $380, including ancillary amenities -- can be amortized in two to five years.
This has fueled an unprecedented boom in track construction and expansion, with much of the capital coming from equity sales. Individual investors can buy shares in both Mr. France's International Speedway Corporation -- which after recently acquiring Roger Penske's speedways, now owns nine major tracks and the operating contract for another -- and in Speedway Motorsports, which owns six major tracks. An analysis by Bear, Stearns in August estimated that a Winston Cup race at a 100,000-seat track yields a $7.7 million profit.
A new television contract should increase earnings. For years, spotty network interest in auto racing made it more profitable for each Winston Cup track to deal directly with broadcast or cable outlets. When ESPN was created 20 years ago, it needed programming to fill its 24-hours-a-day sports schedule, and Winston Cup races soon became a staple that helped both Nascar and ESPN to grow.
"It's been reciprocal," said Mark Quenzel, the vice president for programming at ESPN, which showed its first Winston Cup race in 1981 and at one point televised 20 Cup races a year. "I think had we not gotten together, Nascar would still exist and ESPN would still exist, but neither group would be where it is today."
With the growth in ratings, Nascar recently asked all its track operators to cede their television rights starting in 2001. The owners gladly agreed -- including the one person outside the France family with the wealth and influence to rival them, O. Bruton Smith, the chairman of Speedway Motorsports.
"It surprised me, given the politics of the sport," said Neal Pilson, who brought the Daytona 500 to CBS for the first time in 1979 and who now works as a broadcast consultant to Nascar. "It's hard for Bruton and Bill to be on the same wavelength. But if you look at the economics, with every example you see that where you have a single seller, like the N.F.L., and many buyers, you can achieve the best price.
"Plus there's a confidence among all the track owners in the fairness of the process, and that goes back to Bill France."
Mr. Pilson is helping to shop the television rights to the major networks. "Where we are today is about $100 million a year," he said. "Although nothing is certain, I've seen estimates that I'm not going to quarrel with that we can triple that."
The sport's appeal has been built on one fundamental principle: accessibility of the drivers to the fans. But the popularity boom threatens to turn this into a myth.
"You used to literally be able to make every fan at the track happy," said Darrell Waltrip, the 1989 Daytona 500 winner and one of Nascar's most successful drivers ever. "You could autograph everything they wanted you to sign. Today, you can take care of about 10 percent. So now, 90 percent of the people you come into contact with don't have the same opinion of you when they leave the track that they had when they came in."
Life isn't easier as a racing mechanic. The current schedule of 34 Winston Cup races means that pit-crew members are kept away from their families for 34 weekends a year. And the pressure to increase the number of races is growing as tracks have opened in major population areas and more are on the way.
Mr. France suggested that the secret to expanding the Winston Cup schedule is to increase team owners' earnings enough to allow them to hire an extra crew of mechanics. The new television contract will help do that (under Nascar rules, 25 percent of TV money must be distributed as prize money). The car owners would also like to see Nascar more fully exploit the Winston Cup's drawing power by moving races out of smaller, older tracks in rural areas and into its larger tracks near big cities.
But that touches upon a thorny issue: which tracks get Winston Cup races. The oldest tracks, a few of them owned by International Speedway, continue to have two Cup races annually, a legacy of the days when Nascar went begging for places to race. Now, the newest tracks, although bigger and much closer to major cities, must make do with only one race a year. It's as if the N.F.L. continued to play in Canton, Ohio, because that's where it began.
Mr. Waltrip points out that it's harder to ask sponsors to invest $8 million to $10 million a year when the tracks in small towns like Darlington, S.C., and Rockingham, N.C., (both owned by Mr. France's International Speedway) each have two Winston Cup races, while those near Las Vegas, Nev., and Fort Worth, owned by Mr. Smith's Speedway Motorsports, have only one race a year.
With about 168,000 seats, far more than in either Darlington or Rockingham, the Fort Worth track can afford to pay more prize money. This year, its one race awarded about as much money to competitors as the two races at Darlington combined.
"I know I have taken more financial risk than anyone in this sport to help Nascar grow," Mr. Smith said. His tracks near Las Vegas, Fort Worth, Atlanta and Charlotte, N.C., are showcases for modern racing, with luxury boxes and trackside condominiums.
Yet Mr. Smith says he cannot get Nascar to grant him a second lucrative Winston Cup race each year for Fort Worth. "We've been promised for three years that we will get a second date for Texas, and that's a promise that should be kept," he said. In fact, Nascar has never granted any Winston Cup race to the Texas track -- Mr. Smith had to buy the race he has there now from another track.
LIKE Mr. France, Mr. Smith is the head of a publicly traded company, so he seems to understand that Mr. France would face angry shareholders if he took away a Winston Cup race from an International Speedway track. "I don't think any track should be asked to give up a Winston Cup date," Mr. Smith said. "I think that would be cruel."
But if and when the Winston Cup schedule is again expanded, it may very well be to accommodate tracks that Mr. France's company is building near Kansas City, Kan., and Chicago -- and Mr. Smith doesn't think that would be fair, either. "If you own a track like Rockingham and you build a track in Kansas City, you should take a date from Rockingham," Mr. Smith said. "But I don't think you should add to the schedule unless you consider Texas first."
Mr. France answers those who see a conflict between his ability to distribute Winston Cup races as Nascar's leader and his ability to profit from them as International Speedway's leader by noting that three of his nine tracks have only one Winston Cup race a year, including the fancy new California Speedway near Los Angeles. And besides International Speedway, a number of independent track owners who have stuck with Nascar through the lean years have been allowed to hold on to their two Winston Cup races.
"The other track owners should be glad we're involved as track owners, because we know the trials and tribulations that a promoter goes through," Mr. France said.
While saying that "I think Bill has done a great job in bringing better management to Nascar," Mr. Smith nevertheless suggested that Mr. France follow the example of one Nascar sponsor.
"If you built an exemplary McDonald's," he said, "I believe McDonald's would send you a few extra hamburgers."

HEADLINE: Five Commutes That Make You Feel Better About Yours

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER 

 BODY:
IT wasn't long after workers jumped off their horses and into trains, buses and cars that commuting became a small American obsession. Few people really enjoyed it. Even 30 years ago, when more people commuted by public transit and highways weren't nearly as crowded, train delays, bus breakdowns and traffic jams marred many a family dinner.
Today, commuting is often the most distressing part of working. 
 American communities are much more spread out than they were 30 years ago. More people commute by car, and they are more often alone. Since 1960 the vehicle population has grown seven times faster than the human one. Traffic jams that once were a headache are now a migraine.
And while in one sense a backup is a backup is a backup, every traffic nightmare has its own set of nightmarish details. Here are some of the nation's worst commutes and the reasons they are so bad.
 
Silicon Valley
Even in California, where traffic jams are a familiar symbol of a car-crazy culture, the rush-hour commute over the Sunol Grade -- at an average speed of 17 miles an hour -- is so bad it may be the worst in the state, and just possibly the nation.
It's 35 miles from Livermore, Calif., to the heart of Silicon Valley in Santa Clara County. But for computer workers who aren't up before the sun, the commute south on Interstate 680 over the Sunol Grade, a series of hills, has become an infernal mess.
"You can't believe it," said Constance Allen, a video conference specialist at the Amdahl Corporation, a software company in Sunnyvale. "If you leave before 5 A.M., it takes 45 minutes. If you leave at 5:15, you can count on 90 minutes to 2 hours."
As Santa Clara made the transition from orchards to computer chips, housing prices rose so high that most of the industry's workers could not afford to live near their offices. Tens of thousands of them now descend from distant counties.
Last year, to begin easing congestion, a commuter rail started service from Stockton to San Jose. The 85-mile, $54 million Altamont Commuter Express serves 1,100 people a day, a small slice of the 24,000 vehicles that crawl through the grade each morning. Its two trains stop in nine communities, including Livermore. The line is so popular that a third train will be added next year.
Among the most ardent supporters of the train is Ms. Allen, who climbs aboard weekday mornings at 5:30 or 6:38 for the hourlong trip to Santa Clara, where she takes a free shuttle to her job. "I moved here in 1970, and you could drive between San Jose and San Francisco in 22 minutes," Ms. Allen said. "Nowadays, forget it. Even on Saturdays, you're in traffic that's backed up."
 
Aspen, Colo.
Here, too, economics is a force behind the daily traffic jam. With average home prices in Aspen in the $1 million range, most of the city's work force lives in the seven small towns served by the Roaring Fork Valley's one-way-in-one-way-out Highway 82.
But geography is also a factor. Mountain peaks and valleys produce exhilarating views, but are tough places to build highways.
Even though the Colorado Department of Transportation has widened parts of the road to four lanes and introduced high-occupancy-vehicle lanes, the road's tight curves and two-lane stretches can make the 40-mile trip from Glenwood Springs to Aspen a two-hour ordeal. Alice Hubbard commuted for two years from Basalt to Aspen, a 17-mile trip that often took 60 minutes. "The highway is so full that traffic just can't move," Ms. Hubbard said.
In 1996, Aspen and its neighboring towns formed the Roaring Fork Railroad Holding Authority to buy 33 miles of railroad right of way. The authority is studying whether to re-establish passenger train service that was halted in the late 1960's. Ms. Hubbard is the authority's public involvement director. "We want to recreate what was here 100 years ago," she said, referring to the Glenwood Springs to Aspen line that carried silver for the mining industry and passengers.
"People will use the train. I think of all the parents who spend so much time commuting. They get home angry, tired, stressed out."
 
Detroit
Motown's culture and economy have been distilled by its experience with roads and cars, and now it is paying an unexpected bill. Detroit is the largest metropolitan region in the nation without light rail, subway or commuter rail service. And the bus service is unreliable.
The absence of convenient alternatives has also accelerated the deterioration of Detroit's highway system. As a result, the Detroit region is entering a generational transition not of highway construction but of continuing, disruptive and expensive repairs and rebuilding. Commutes, for instance, from Lake Orion in suburban Oakland County to Detroit that once took 40 minutes now take twice as long.
The repair costs, 80 percent of which are paid by the Federal Government, are astonishing. The state transportation department is considering rebuilding 11 miles of Interstate 94 in Detroit, including four miles of interchanges with two other freeways. The estimated cost -- $1.3 billion -- places the job among the most expensive highway rebuilding projects in the country, highway engineers in other states said.
As much as 20 percent of the project's budget, or $260 million, would be spent just to manage traffic during construction -- twice what it would cost to build a commuter rail network in Detroit with 100 miles of track and 30 stations, a recent state transportation department study said. Such a system, the study said, could serve 20,000 passengers a day.
 
Atlanta
Urban sprawl might have been invented in Los Angeles. But Atlanta seems determined to perfect it.
Since 1990, the 10 counties around Atlanta have added 602,000 residents, many drawn by its reputation for quality of life, bringing the population to 3.11 million. In 1990, the region considered to fall within the metropolis was 65 miles from north to south. Today it is 110 miles.
The result is a city where it is almost always drive time. Atlantans drive an average of 34.9 miles round trip to work, more than commuters in any other American city. The average is 20 miles.
Air pollution is so serious that the Federal Government told state officials they could not have more money to build highways until they reduced it. Last year the city's once-vaunted reputation as a place to do business was damaged when the Hewlett-Packard Company said it was reconsidering plans to expand in suburban Atlanta because its employees were complaining about declining quality of life.
All these issues helped Gov. Roy Barnes, a Democrat who campaigned last year on a promise to address congestion, to push a bill through the Legislature in March that established the Georgia Regional Transportation Authority, a superagency with authority to improve public transit, direct local governments to curb sprawl and decide on other steps to ease congestion.
Angel Torres, a city planner and adjunct professor at Clark Atlanta University, said he had commuted by bicycle, bus and car in Atlanta and had found all of the commutes to be terrible. "Ever since the Olympics in 1996, you could see the traffic get worse and worse," Mr. Torres said. "We thought all these people would go home. They never did. It's bad everywhere. It doesn't matter where you go, and it almost doesn't matter what time you go."
 
Northern Virginia
Rush hour used to refer to the rush into and then out of a city center. But suburb-to-suburb commutes also create bottlenecks. The Washington area boasts a superb regional subway system, yet congestion is getting worse as more of the region's population shifts to its edges, and commuting patterns become a crazy weave of personal routes all over the region.
No matter how many destinations commuters have, there are only so many major roads, and the points where they intersect can be trouble even far from downtown.
This year, the Virginia Department of Transportation started a $350 million, eight-year project to speed traffic on Interstate 95 and the Capital Beltway by expanding the interchange where the two highways meet in northern Virginia, about 15 miles from the White House. The interchange, known as the Mixing Bowl, is the region's busiest and most dangerous, handling 375,000 vehicles a day.
Last spring, when a gunpowder truck overturned and authorities closed the Mixing Bowl during rush hours, motorists gained a clear understanding of the interchange's importance. Traffic stopped for hours on every highway in the area, and on the side streets that served as exits and entrances. Tens of thousands of employees never made it to work.
Stacy Luks, a consultant for management and organizational development at the American Red Cross, negotiates the Mixing Bowl on her regular 18-mile commute from Woodbridge to Falls Church. On good days, she makes the drive in 45 minutes to an hour. On bad days, the drive can take twice as long.
Ms. Luks says she misses the Monica Lewinsky scandal, especially the impeachment hearings on public radio, because it provided "constant interesting fodder to keep your mind alert while you were driving."

HEADLINE: Natural Gas Has Many Selling Points, but Few Buyers

BYLINE: By DAN NEIL; Dan Neil is a contributing editor at Car and Driver magazine.

 BODY:
WHAT if there was a fuel that was cheap, limitless and clean-burning? A fuel whose supply and price were strategically secure, free from the caprice of oil-producing nations? A fuel that relied on engineering fundamentally no more esoteric than that of a restaurant stove?
It sounds like an environmentalist's giddiest daydream. Yet such a fuel is natural gas -- simple, guileless methane, the perfume of the plains. It even comes in two flavors: compressed natural gas (C.N.G. for short) and its cryogenic cousin, liquefied natural gas (L.N.G.). It is a fuel with a host of attributes, a seemingly elegant solution to issues as diverse as air pollution and trade imbalances. 
 Yet even its most ardent supporters concede that compressed natural gas will probably never be more than a niche source of energy, one best suited to large fleets of buses, cabs and delivery trucks, which can be fueled at a central location. The Natural Gas Vehicle Coalition, which speaks for the industry, has all but given up hope that large numbers of compressed natural-gas stations will ever be built.
At best, it appears, C.N.G. vehicles will account for a small part of America's rolling stock in the next decade. At worst, they may be stalled for the foreseeable future.
Either way, the recent history of compressed natural gas is an object lesson in the difficulties facing alternative transportation energy, and how hard it is to displace gasoline as the fuel of choice.
Certainly, recent events have seemed favorable for an alternative fuel. Two years ago, Congress approved the Environmental Protection Agency's plan to ratchet up pollution standards on oxides of nitrogen and diesel particulate matter, the city-choking residue of automobiles and trucks burning gasoline and diesel fuel.
Last spring, the E.P.A. proposed new tailpipe-emission standards that would essentially federalize California's stringent standards. The agency's so-called Tier Two rules also call for refineries to produce cleaner-burning low-sulfur gasoline, a provision opposed by the petroleum industry.
Diesel fuel, gasoline's grimy sibling, is also under attack. In a move that could have far-reaching consequences, both California and the E.P.A. have declared diesel particulate -- a k a soot -- a toxic substance.
Natural gas, by comparison, is clean. Compared with gasoline vehicles, C.N.G. vehicles emit 70 percent less carbon monoxide, 87 percent less nitrogen oxide (a principal culprit in smog) and 87 percent less nonmethane volatile organic compounds. Because natural gas contains less carbon than other fossil fuels, it contributes significantly less carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases to the atmosphere.
Meanwhile, gasoline is becoming more vulnerable on price. Oil-exporting nations crimped the petroleum pipeline to the United States just in time for the summer travel season. From a historic low of $9.84 a barrel in December 1998, crude oil prices had risen to $22.78 in early October.
In California, where supply problems this year have added to the price increase, gasoline was up $1.48 a gallon in early October; a gasoline gallon equivalent of compressed natural gas is about $1.
ASIGNIFICANT price disparity should be good news for natural-gas advocates. So should the Alternative Fuel Promotion Act, which Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th, Democrat of West Virginia, and Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, introduced in early May. (A similar bill was introduced in the House of Representatives in June.) If the act is passed, it would give sellers of clean-burning fuels a tax credit of 50 cents a gasoline-gallon equivalent, radically changing the economics of alternative fuels, particularly natural gas. The legislation has been caught up in the tax-cut dispute between the White House and Congress and is still pending. "If we get that, it's very likely that we'll see prices in the range of 55 cents" a gasoline-gallon equivalent, said Richard R. Kolodziej, the president of the Natural Gas Vehicle Coalition. "Then I think you are going to see people say: 'I like this. I want to do it.' "
The Rockefeller-Hatch bill is opposed by the petroleum industry, which has defeated similar initiatives in state legislatures. "We feel that no fuel ought to be disadvantaged or advantaged by tax subsidies," said Bill O'Keefe, the executive vice president of the American Petroleum Institute. "Let the market decide."
But the bill, should it pass, would signal a renaissance in vehicles that burn natural gas.
So, what could be wrong? One word: range. Most gasoline cars can go 300 miles or more on a tank of fuel. When they run low, they pull into a gas station to fill up.
Natural-gas vehicles typically can go about half that distance, and when they run out of fuel, there are few places to fill up. That's why these vehicles work best -- indeed, almost exclusively -- for fleets, like buses, cabs and delivery trucks, in which high-mileage users travel regular, local routes and return to a central refueling point.
"We recognized that our business will be built up not by going after a few vehicles in a large population, but a larger percentage of a small population," Mr. Kolodziej said. "It doesn't mean that others are going to be ignored -- early adopters, environmentalists and so on."
But that is often the message. In January, I was part of a team from Car and Driver magazine that tried to cross the country in a compressed natural-gas vehicle using the Natural Gas Vehicle Coalition's guide to refueling stations. Many stations, listed as public, were inaccessible, or had no means to measure out quantities of gas or accept payment for it, or kept irregular hours, or had been abandoned.
While companies in the West and Northeast have built chains of C.N.G. refueling stations, real growth awaits a better market or Government incentives. Stations, it seems, are costly to build and operate, primarily because they require large compressors capable of supplying the industry standard of 3,000 pounds a square inch of pressure on demand, around the clock.
The Rockefeller-Hatch bill offers a $30,000 tax deduction toward the installation costs of alternative fueling stations. "For too long, we have been caught in a chicken-and-egg cycle, with the infrastructure not available to support alternative-fuel vehicles and consumers not interested in the vehicles because there is no support infrastructure," Senator Rockefeller said.
For determined environmentalists, there is another way. Fuelmaker, a Canadian company, sells home fueling stations that can be plumbed directly into a home's natural-gas supply. C.N.G.-powered cars can then be refueled in the driveway. Fuelmaker units cost about $2,500, and some manufacturers offer rebates on purchases. The Rockefeller-Hatch bill would grant the same tax credit to home refuelers, who could deduct costs up to $100,000 from their Federal taxes.
But the oil industry, which controls 60 percent of America's natural-gas reserves, is the least interested in building a C.N.G. infrastructure. On the face of it, it seems odd that the industry would not be eager to sell its wares to the public. Why not build the C.N.G. stations, and let them come?
It doesn't work that way, said Mr. O'Keefe of the American Petroleum Institute. "My members are in the business of providing what consumers want," he explained. "Right now the consumers want S.U.V.'s, not C.N.G.'s. Supply follows demand."
Mr. Kolodziej said the institute's members "would like to sell more natural gas, but not to cannibalize their transportation market." They have billions tied up in refineries, pipelines and service stations designed to deliver a liquid petroleum product, he said.
For their part, auto makers are wading into the C.N.G. market, despite lackluster consumer demand. The reason? The E.P.A.'s Corporate Average Fuel Economy rule, in which every alternative-fuel vehicle sold is calculated to get 120 miles a gallon. This gives car makers considerable slack on their big-selling low-mileage vehicles. More than a dozen light-duty compressed natural-gas models are on the market, and more are on the way. At the North American International Auto Expo in Detroit in January, DaimlerChrysler displayed a 325-horsepower Dodge Charger concept car that employed a new compact storage system and a range, it said, of up to 300 miles.
A sister project using the Plymouth Breeze/Dodge Stratus as a platform yielded a C.N.G. car virtually indistinguishable from its gasoline-powered twin. "Our goal was to find C.N.G. technology that was transparent to the driver, so he wouldn't even be aware that he was driving a C.N.G. vehicle," said John Wozniak, the project manager for the Applied Physics Laboratory. "That's the only way C.N.G. is going to make real progress."
But there have been unexpected complications. In Seattle, government administrators abandoned plans to expand the city's C.N.G. fleet after determining that such an expansion would require extensive garage renovations.
THE course of any technology never did run true. By the time compressed natural-gas technology sorts itself out, it may be superseded by another technology, the hydrogen-driven fuel cell, which has the petroleum industry's support. Fuel cells catalyze fuels instead of burning them, so they produce only oxygen and water as byproducts.
Dave Lefever, the executive director of the National Association of Fleet Administrators, said that what car manufacturers are telling the fleet managers "is that all these alternative and flex-fuel approaches are basically interim approaches until they get the fuel-cell technology up and running," perhaps in 10 years' time.
But compressed natural-gas advocates remain hopeful. Noting that hydrogen and C.N.G. are both compressed gases, Mr. Kolodziej of the Natural Gas Vehicle Coalition said: "The same infrastructure that delivers C.N.G. can deliver hydrogen in the future. We are the logical bridge between petroleum and hydrogen."

HEADLINE: He Sets the Values Car Makers Live By

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON 

DATELINE: SANTA BARBARA, Calif.

 BODY:
FAR from the nation's automotive capital toils a respected analyst who influences one in every three new cars driven off dealer lots. That totes up to $80 billion in purchasing each year.
Part soothsayer and part statistician, Doug Aiken, along with his 25 employees, forecasts what cars will fetch at wholesale auto auctions once their leases end. He publishes his predictions every other month in specialized guidebooks that are regarded by auto makers, consumer lenders and Wall Street investment bankers as the industry benchmark. 
 An unknown outside the world of automotive finance, Mr. Aiken and his Automotive Lease Guide, known almost universally as A.L.G., are both revered and feared in Detroit's corridors of power. His relationship with the major car makers is a love-hate affair, because, aside from fickle consumer tastes, perhaps no other independent factor can ignite car sales like the pocket-sized guide.
Though competition has emerged in recent years, the Automotive Lease Guide is considered the voice of authority. The finance divisions of Ford and General Motors use it exclusively to predict residual values, an all-important figure indicating a vehicle's worth after its lease lapses in two to five years. That value is a critical figure to new-car dealers, who use it to calculate a buyer's monthly lease payments. Leased cars now account for a third of the 12 million new cars sold domestically, a percentage that has grown by leaps and bounds in 20 years.
Because payments are lower on leased cars that best retain their value in the used-car market, Mr. Aiken is under unremitting pressure from auto executives to "enhance" the guide's figures to spur sales. Pushing back are lenders' insurers, who reserve capital against leases and want the figures to be low to insure profits.
"If they're all mad at us, then we're probably at the right mix," said the 48-year-old Mr. Aiken, who wears a close-cropped beard and appears unaffected by his clout with auto titans. He is dispassionate about cars (as opposed to golf). That detachment and his analytical bent overcome the best efforts of auto makers to dazzle him.
And try they do. Like automotive editors from the trade press, Mr. Aiken is treated royally, receiving all-expenses-paid trips to new-model introductions and test drives at factories and proving grounds around the world. As a measure of its importance, Automotive Lease Guide is sometimes invited exclusively. Every few months, a new set of models -- from Kias to BMW's -- are parked behind the guidebook's inconspicuous office, ready for the 10-person editorial staff to try out, gratis.
"They've not abused their position regardless of our efforts to present information that's favorable," said John T. Treter, the rental sales manager for Ford fleet leasing in Dearborn, Mich.
IN the boardrooms of major auto makers, Mr. Aiken, who appears as patient as a schoolteacher, has defended his method in person to top-level managers, who over the years have fumed in disagreement with his guide's findings. "There's not a lot of people willing to be called on the carpet," Mr. Treter said.
Because of his willingness to be accountable and his guide's unyielding conservative approach, Mr. Aiken's stature has evolved from bit player to industry sage. He is now sought for "fireside chats," when senior automotive executives enlist his opinions, which only enhances his guide's dominance of its arcane niche. "There isn't another guidebook that has availability to the top auto management of the world," Mr. Treter said.
Mr. Aiken owes his place in the catbird's seat to his father, James, now 83, a former Oldsmobile dealer in Los Angeles, who is a seminal figure in automobile leasing. In the 1960's, the elder Mr. Aiken persuaded some of his dealer friends to help him start a leasing company after banks refused to carry auto leases on their books. With borrowed capital, customized accounting software and a mimeographed list of residuals on 20 domestic makes, the Automotive Leasing Group became the dealers' bank of choice.
By 1972, the group had 5,000 leases from 250 Western dealers. The strategy gained legitimacy when Security Pacific, the California lender, acquired the portfolio, becoming the country's first bank to offer auto leases. The leasing group's founders retained rights to its software and residual guide. The younger Mr. Aiken, a mathematics whiz who studied economics at Arizona State University, spent five years installing computer systems for bank clients before persuading his father to sell him the lease guide.
"Over the course of a year, I developed programs to mimic what I was doing on mainframes," said Mr. Aiken, who started on a Radio Shack computer.
His timing was perfect. Leasing accelerated early in the 80's, thanks to the expansion of a Federal tax credit on business equipment and a favorable ruling by bank regulators. It helped that the G.M. finance unit, the first auto maker to offer leases, pegged them to Automotive Lease Guide. "It gave our book a lot of credibility," Mr. Aiken said.
Randall McCathren, a Nashville lease consultant, said, "Doug Aiken had the wisdom to go out and market these as national data."
Eager to stand apart from competitors, lenders clamored for their own private-label guides. Thanks to Mr. Aiken's computer proficiency, he could blend the Automotive Lease Guide's benchmarks with specialized criteria important to lenders -- for example, a dealer option like gold trim to a lease's cost.
The basic guide predicts values for 1,200 different models five years in the future. The figures are distilled from 15 years of dealer and auction sales' records, along with demographic and economic data. They are weighted by the staff's "historical insights," said John Blair, the guide's president and Mr. Aiken's business partner, who refused to divulge proprietary details. The sort of questions the staff debates is whether antilock brakes have become so prevalent that they no longer add to a used car's value.
"They do as good a job as any in anticipating the market," said Richard T. Schliesmann, the executive vice president of Wells Fargo's leasing division in San Francisco. The guidebook says that on any car, its figures are accurate within two to three percentage points.
Sometimes, to popularize a model or gain new customers, auto makers' captive finance companies and some traditional lenders take a calculated risk and disregard the guide's benchmarks. They inflate their own residual values to gain more business. That's what Chrysler, then financially strapped, did early in the 90's with its Jeep Grand Cherokee, a bet that eventually went wrong as prices on used sport utility vehicles fell when the market became crowded with competing models.
Losses could have gone higher and the credibility of leasing could have eroded had the Automotive Lease Guide followed the crowd, said R. W. Christiansen Jr., the chief executive of Westar Financial Services, a leasing company in Olympia, Wash. "Doug didn't bend. He helped maintain discipline in the industry. Those who have stood with him have benefited."
Automotive Lease Guide has two rivals: the Black Book, published in Gainesville, Ga., and owned by the Hearst Corporation; and the Kelley Blue Book, published in Irvine, Calif. Both started as publishers of used-car price guides for dealers and have tried with little success to expand into residual guides.
Next year, a third rival is expected. The National Automotive Dealers Association, based in McLean, Va., plans a guide that emphasizes demographic trends.
"It's been interesting to me to witness Doug's transition from hanger-on to being the point person for information," conceded Charles J. Vogelheim, a Kelley Blue Book editor, with a hint of professional jealousy. "It's a known fact," he added, tongue-in-cheek, "if he was in Boise, he'd be zero."
Golf-crazy auto executives who like to leave snowy Michigan in the dead of winter keep flocking to Mr. Aiken's spare offices in sunny Santa Barbara. So do insurers and Wall Street analysts, who ask Automotive Lease Guide for a pulse on lenders' portfolio risks. Many of them seem happy to lose $3 bets to Mr. Aiken at La Cumbre, a favorite course near his home near the Santa Barbara waterfront. Given he has a 2 handicap, it's a sucker bet.
In the beginning, when Mr. Aiken was the guide's sole employee, he did everything from stuffing envelopes to calling past-due subscribers. Now, he is considering expanding abroad, and demands for custom analyses have required the addition of more workers and a partner, John Blair.
The division of labor suits him. "I'm making the snowballs now," Mr. Aiken said, "and he's throwing them."

LENGTH: 889 words

HEADLINE: At Rallies in Europe, Africa and Asia, Pocket Rockets Rule

BYLINE: By JACK SMITH 

 BODY:
TO most Americans, motor sports mean big, V8-powered mutants thundering along Nascar ovals or sleek, needle-nosed Indy cars or Ferraris and Porsches streaking along impeccably smooth concrete and blacktop tracks. But the world's most popular form of auto racing, rallying, is populated by names synonymous with economical transportation: Subaru, Mitsubishi and even that Czech-built anomaly, Skoda.
They are the ultimate pocket rockets, high-powered, lightweight coupes and sedans built for the World Rally Championship series, an event that takes place in 10 countries on real roads replete with bumps and potholes and, sometimes, on terrain barely suited for hiking. 
 "It's totally different from circuit racing in the states," said David Richards, the chairman of Pro-Drive, the Subaru factory team. "One minute you're running along paved roads; the next you'll be in mud or sand. If you see kangaroos in the distance, you know you're in Australia. If you see lions and giraffes, you're in Kenya. If you're racing in England, there are days when you can barely see the side of the road for the fog."
Here is where the co-driver comes in. The driver is usually "flying by instruments," outrunning his line of sight along a course whose hairpin turns, dips, ruts or icy patches may be obscured by darkness, sandstorms or spectators (drivers call them the "human guardrail") within an arm's length of the race cars.
The driver gets data from the co-driver, who rarely looks up while shouting instructions from notes -- often hundreds of pages compiled during reconnaissance runs conducted before the race. Not surprisingly, drivers' and co-drivers' heart rates are reported to rise two to three times their normal rate during competition.
Most manufacturers here don't like to talk about rally cars. "Rallying is too disconnected from the American market," said one rally official who asked not to be identified. "It's the second biggest sport in the world behind soccer, but Americans know nothing about it."
 
SUBARU IMPREZA
One of the only car makers eager to chat about rallying is Subaru, the winner of World Rally championships in 1995, 1996 and 1997. "We like rallying because the cars and the conditions are the closest thing in racing to real life," said Alex Fedorak, a Subaru spokesman. "The competition car looks just like the showroom Impreza, it has the same wheelbase as the Impreza and it uses the same suspension as the Impreza." The racing version, however, is clad in a welded body shell with protective roll cage and honeycomb side panels of aluminum and carbon fiber for lightness.
The 2-liter engine is based on the Subaru's horizontally opposed four-cylinder "boxer" power plant, turbocharged and intercooled to produce 300 horsepower with 347 foot-pounds of torque. As does every Subaru, the rallying Impreza features all-wheel drive; a viscous, limited-slip rear differential enables the rally car to alter side-to-side power distribution.
This Impreza also costs more than its more docile siblings; exactly how much more, Subaru won't say, but a used rally car can be had for a mere $280,000.
 
FORD FOCUS
 Ford entered the rally fray this year with an all-new, European-built World Rally Championship Focus, some 30 percent more rigid than the older W.R.C. Escort and, it says, 15 percent stiffer than any of its competitors.
Based on the three-door Focus, the all-wheel-drive rally car retains the look of the street car except for the 45 meters of steel tubing that is the roll cage.
The rally car is designed to concentrate the weight of components like the engine and transmission as low and as far within the wheelbase as possible for stability, while the rear differential is intended to give as much ground clearance as possible. One unusual feature is the six-speed gear lever mounted on the dash by the driver's right hand to minimize "hands off the wheel" time. The Focus uses 18-inch wheels on asphalt courses and 15-inch wheels for gravel events, while distribution of braking force may be adjusted from the cockpit.
There is a little wing over the rear hatchback window and a ballistic (high-velocity) carbon-composite under tray to protect its belly from those moments when the car goes . . . uh, ballistic.
 
MITSUBISHI LANCER
Mitsubishi won the World Rally Championship manufacturer's title for the first time last year and claims cult object status for its newest entry, the Lancer GSR Evolution VI, which in street trim sells in Japan for 3.3 million yen (about $30,355). A Mitsubishi spokesman said that the factory-sponsored race cars were not for sale, but he estimated they would cost well over $1 million.
Though competition figures are not available, the garden-variety Lancer is no slouch; its 2-liter, four-cylinder engine is turbocharged and intercooled to produce 280 horsepower.
Mitsubishi's attention to detail is evident in the car maker's claim that performance -- specifically engine cooling and aerodynamics -- have been enhanced by changing the position of the license plate on the front bumper. The car rides on 17-inch Oz alloy wheels and stops on oversize Brembo brakes. Its gaping maw of a radiator grille and twin rear spoilers are designed to conform to 1999 World Rally Championship regulations rather than esthetics.

HEADLINE: With Rover, BMW Got More and Less Than It Asked For

BYLINE: By RICHARD FEAST; Richard Feast is editor at large of Financial Times Automotive World in London.

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
BMW of Germany is one of the world's great automotive icons. Its cars ooze class, sophistication and engineering excellence. Land Rover, the British sport utility vehicles made by the BMW-owned Rover Group, enjoys a similar profile in another part of the motoring firmament.
The appeal of these two big names is evident in showrooms around the world. Both are heading for global sales records once more this year. In the United States, for example, in the first eight months of 1999, BMW sales were up 19 percent, and Land Rover's soared by 35 percent. 
 From an outside point of view, then, the union of BMW and Rover probably looks like the perfect marriage.
But appearances can be deceptive.
While BMW and Land Rover have never been in better shape, the Rover brand of passenger cars (which are not sold in the United States) has been a continuous drain on the overall health of BMW A.G. In Germany these days, Rover is known as "The English Patient."
In early 1994, BMW paid the equivalent of $1.35 billion for the Rover Group, and it has nearly doubled that figure in subsequent investment. For what? For BMW, Rover's poor productivity, so-so quality and rapidly declining sales were like handicapping an Olympic sprinter with winter boots.
So what looked like a bargain -- Ford paid $2.4 billion for the much smaller Jaguar company -- was actually a liability. For the first time in nearly four decades, BMW looked vulnerable, and it was all because of the Rover purchase. BMW's main shareholders, the Quandt family (which owns 46 percent of the stock), began to question the wisdom of the deal.
The situation resulted in a sudden reverse in strategy last fall, when Rover lost all its operating autonomy. That led to the departure of Walter Hasselkus, the BMW-appointed chairman of Rover. A few months later, in February, Bernd Pischetsrieder, the chairman of BMW A.G., and his heir apparent, Wolfgang Reitzle, BMW's engineering director, left abruptly.
What made it worse was that Mr. Reitzle, the man responsible for the design and development of so many cars used as benchmarks by other auto makers, quickly landed the key job in charge of Ford's newly created Premier Automotive Group, made up of Aston Martin, Jaguar, Lincoln and Volvo.
It all began with BMW's recognition that, like its rival, Mercedes-Benz, it needed to find greater economies of scale. As Mercedes expanded organically with additional models -- the merger with the Chrysler Corporation came later -- BMW decided on growth by acquisition. In 1994, it bought Rover from British Aerospace and the Honda Motor Company.
The purchase was seen at the time as a dazzling move by a company that could do no wrong. The German auto maker had chalked up three decades of increasing sales, profits and dividends, transforming itself from a maker of micro cars into a worthy competitor for Mercedes-Benz. In the process, it made the already wealthy Quandt family, which gambled on the near-bankrupt BMW in 1959, even richer.
BMW was not prepared for Rover, however. It failed to study the postwar history of Britain's automotive industry, which had been in terminal decline. In 1952, Rover was the fourth-largest auto maker in the world (after Detroit's Big Three); four decades later it had dropped to 20th.
Over the years Rover had demonstrated an alarming appetite to consume cash. Taxpayers in Britain knew only too well about its performance, because it was under state ownership until Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher sold the majority shares -- for a pittance -- to British Aerospace in 1988. Rover, known variously over the years as BMC (British Motor Corporation), British Leyland or BL, was a byword for unreliable products, late deliveries and inefficiency. Its anarchic labor relations were largely responsible for what became known in the rest of the world as "the British disease."
By the time BMW took over, Rover was a smaller, better-focused group following various company selloffs, factory closings and terminations. And in spite of this, labor relations were good. Technology transfer agreements with Honda had helped Rover improve its products and manufacturing, though investments were paltry by international standards when the state and British Aerospace were in control.
BMW decided that, given proper financing and supervision, Rover knew how to get the job done. It doubled investment in Rover, established broad strategy and left its British subsidiary to get on with its own models, engineering, purchasing, production, sales and distribution.
BMW and Rover were separate companies under the ownership of one of them.
That turned out to be a mistake.
The reluctance to take a heavy hand was understandable given the histories of Britain and Germany during this century. Rover was all that remained of the once-extensive British auto industry. Having it run by an "enemy" it had helped to defeat in two terrible world wars would require careful public relations in Britain.
In the mid-1980's, Mrs. Thatcher was desperate to give up state ownership of BL. She encouraged Ford to take over the passenger-car group (then called Austin-Morris) and General Motors to buy the Land Rover and Leyland truck businesses. The deals were almost done when the Prime Minister uncharacteristically reversed position in response to anti-American protest from her own supporters and from the opposition.
Ford and G.M. were squeezed out. Mrs. Thatcher then found a safe national savior in British Aerospace. It was clearly a political solution rather than an industrial one. Yet, six years later, there was curiously little opposition when Rover was sold to a German company. What had happened before, though, made BMW sensitive to the nationality issue. It kept Rover at arm's length.
At his first press conference last March, Joachim Milberg, who took over as BMW chairman in February, said: "The multibrand strategy which was pursued was right in principle. The type of group leadership, however, proved to be wrong." It was an oblique reference to the dissenting Mr. Reitzle, who wanted to abandon the ailing Rover car brand.
During the press conference, Mr. Milberg also said, "Our strategy is the strategy of the entire BMW board of management. And since this is demonstrated by all of us, you will not see any of us developing and announcing his own strategies."
That grand plan amounts to a more sophisticated, high-end version of the seminal one defined in the 1920's by Alfred P. Sloan Jr. for General Motors: a car for every purse and purpose. In BMW's case, its portfolio of brands would occupy the upper niche (translation: fat profits) of each market segment while collectively providing a full range of products.
The company has its successes, of course. BMW and Land Rover are flourishing. The MG name was successfully revived with the introduction of a midengine roadster (not sold in the United States).
This summer the flagship 75, a luxury Rover sedan, was introduced in Europe to favorable notices, and executives of both companies have pointed to the car as a sign of things to come. "Anybody who has driven the 75 will know that Rover is capable, with BMW's help, of designing and engineering some of the best cars in the world," Bernard Carey, a Rover spokesman, said earlier this year.
Helmut Panke, BMW's chief financial officer, said he expects the 75 to provide a boost to Rover's worldwide sales, which were down 33 percent in the first half of this year. In the meantime, however, new versions of the aging 200 and 400 midlevel models will not be ready until 2002 at the earliest. Given the quality of the competition, many auto analysts believe, that's a long time to wait.
The combination of the sales slide and the $2.8 billion investment that BMW has committed to developing new models and rebuilding the main factory in Birmingham means that Rover will be a continuing financial burden on the company for a long time.
It's a good thing those BMW's and Land Rovers are so popular.

HEADLINE: CURRENTS: ARCHITECTURE;
Minimalism Still Finds Shelter in the West

BYLINE: By Frances Anderton

 BODY:

Los Angeles design ranges from the neo-Baroque to neo-Pop, but there is still a taste for the minimalism and economy of materials that characterize prewar and postwar Modernist architecture.
Koning Eizenberg Architecture and Daly, Genik, two contemporary Los Angeles practices, are keeping the minimalist tradition alive. Daly, Genik has done residences like the Valley Center House in north San Diego County (inset top). Another stringent design is its slender family house (top), called the Slot/Box House, which is tucked discreetly into a yard set back from a street in Santa Monica. The Slot/Box House cost just over $200,000 to build and is 2,000 square feet. It consists of two and a half levels over an open garage, with bedrooms on the opaque upper level and public areas on the lower levels behind floor-to-ceiling translucent polycarbonate panels that open the interior of the house to the outside. Daly, Genik acted as contractors on the house, which is made of steel frame and concrete block, with surfaces of plaster and birch. 
 In another corner of Santa Monica is Pluralistic School 1, a private school for children from kindergarten through the sixth grade (left), which was designed by Koning Eizenberg Architecture. The building is intended to express the philosophy of the school, which Julie Eizenberg, a partner in the firm, said empowers the children to think in a noninstitutional environment.
To this end, she said, there are "no cute icons of school," like gable roofs or primary colors. Instead there is a bracing composition, in exposed concrete, steel and wood, of two linear buildings with walkways. And natural light beams in through large windows.
