HEADLINE: DESIGN NOTEBOOK;
No Slouching, Please, Toward a Well-Tailored Millennium

BYLINE: By Liz Seymour

DATELINE: HIGH POINT, N.C., Oct. 16

 BODY:
Once upon a time, everybody wanted to be in pictures. Now, every able-bodied celebrity or demi-celebrity wants to be in the furniture business.
Christopher Forbes, the vice chairman of Forbes, the magazine publishing company, was here to introduce furniture, lamps, rugs and bedding from a variety of makers inspired by the domestic trappings of his father, Malcolm S. Forbes, the Tangier-living, Elizabeth Taylor-squiring, Harley-Davidson-riding millionaire, who died in 1990. 
 A few blocks away, at Vanguard Furniture, Kathy Ireland -- the Sports Illustrated swimsuit model and "a modern Renaissance woman" who is "one of America's most respected women of achievement," in the words of the company's news release -- conducted tours of a 3,000-square-foot display dedicated to a furniture collection bearing her name. (She already lends her wholesome good looks to a signature clothing line for Kmart, which Women's Wear Daily has declared the seventh-most-popular brand of women's clothing in the country.)
Elsewhere, Jack Palance, the great B-movie actor, was touting the virtues of Action Lane's reclining leather chairs and sofas. It was one of this furniture season's most inspired pairings: limber upholstered pieces and the septuagenarian actor, who dropped to the stage of the Oscar ceremonies a few years back to execute a flurry of one-handed push-ups like a demonic Jack LaLanne.
Even the trend forecaster Faith Popcorn, who has long scolded the male-dominated furniture industry for giving short shrift to its largely female consumers, put her money where her mouth is: her own home office collection for Hooker Furniture designed to appeal to women.
"Business is just real good right now," said Jerry Epperson, a financial analyst with Mann Armistead & Epperson, an investment banking firm. The combination of a strong economy and the steady march of baby boomers toward midlife affluence was projected by the American Furniture Manufacturers Association to bump consumer demand for furniture to $61.1 billion in 1999, an increase of 5.5 percent over 1998. With 2,400 exhibitors and eight million square feet of showroom space -- and another million square feet to be added in the next six months -- the twice-a-year International Home Furnishing Market is the biggest wholesale furniture market in the world. It opened last Thursday and runs through tomorrow.
The mood in the opening days of the market was as buoyant as Mr. Forbes's on-site accessory, a Faberge-egg-shaped hot-air balloon that bobbed in the sky above a weedy vacant lot where Mr. Forbes made his presentation (bejeweled Faberge eggs were one of his father's passions). After years of grumbling about sluggish sales and thin margins, manufacturers were worrying about meeting demand. Few of them were rocking the boat with startling new products, however, preferring to concentrate instead on what was already selling. "There's more merchandise being deleted than being added," Mr. Epperson said. "Why change?"
Showroom building corridors were filled not just with furniture buyers, but with buyers from office supply stores, home improvement stores and home electronics stores as well. (In one odd-couple matchup, Bose, the maker of high-end audio equipment, will start carrying Mitchell Gold furniture in some of its mall stores this fall.) Catalogue companies like Pottery Barn and Crate and Barrel were given credit for rehabbing furniture's dowdy image among consumers.
"All of a sudden there started being all this good stuff available through catalogues," said Thomas O'Brien, 38, a cofounder of the hip SoHo design firm Aero Studios, who was introducing a resolutely modern-minded collection for Hickory Chair, for 99 years a bastion of traditionalism. Mount Vernon reproductions, Mark Hampton historicism.
In general, two nearly antithetical style directions vied for attention, sometimes side by side in the same showroom. On the one hand, sophisticated retro-modern design continued to gain strength, and dark woods, especially mahogany, had all but displaced the light birch and ash of just a couple of markets ago.
Mr. O'Brien's vision for the millennium is sleekly elegant eclecticism with a gentle Mixmaster edge: a bit of 1940's Chinese here, some embossed velvet there, a slipper chair with an exaggerated towering back, a seriously scholastic scroll-arm chair based on a Greek Revival original that Mr. O'Brien has owned since he was in college. Even Stanley Furniture got into the modernist act. Its Reflections of the 20th Century collection was similar in feeling to Mr. O'Brien's serene chic -- but priced to reach the midmarket consumer rather than Hickory Chair's typical posse of well-heeled suburbanites.
The prevalence of clean lines, tight upholstery, exposed legs, sexy little ottomans and silvery hardware at almost every price level proved that modern design had lost its shock value. Or just maybe, the American consumer, though still in love with tradition, has begun to accept the obvious -- that it is 1999, not 1799.
The entire second floor of Mitchell Gold's cobalt-blue headquarters, once the epicenter of the slouchy slipcover look, was devoted to severe tailoring. "I wouldn't make them if they didn't sell," said Mr. Gold, the president of the company, whose stylish upholstery is a staple at Crate and Barrel and other outlets.
Other introductions, however, took a distinctly baroque route. Thomasville's Bellasera, Stanley's Coronation, Lexington's California Legacy, and Bernhardt's Coronado were Euro inspired and heavily ornamented, combining metal, stone and glass with light woods and painted finishes. The pieces were also scaled to behemoth proportions, aimed at consumers with bodacious suburban homes to fill and a weakness for flashy effects. It could have been called "Married to the Mob."
Despite Ms. Ireland's pronouncement that she was "making it safe for people to take risks," she gamely trotted out furniture that was neither controversial nor new: a bun-foot damask sofa, a whitewashed side table with barley-twist legs and nonthreatening rattan dining chairs.
By contrast, Baker's Continental Collection was a quietly elegant treat. Culled from surprisingly diverse sources -- Baltic manor houses, anyone? -- the 16th-, 17th- and 18th-century designs proved that clean, crisp design knows no era. The Biedermeier-style center table, for example, could be pure Eames.
The most notable Euro-style holdout was Lane Furniture, which introduced Colonial Williamsburg designs. But the introduction had more to do with marketing savvy than a devotion to history. In making the move from Baker, which had been licensed to produce high-priced reproductions for a small and rarefied market, to Lane, whose new "interpretative" pieces are priced to appeal to a much larger audience, Colonial Williamsburg joined a mainstream trend: aggressive licensing.
In an industry notably short on household-word brands, an increasing number of companies hoped that a borrowed name -- whether of a museum, a designer or simply a celebrity, even a dead one, like Thomasville's Ernest Hemingway range, released last spring to consumer acclaim and critical drubbing -- would help create instant recognition. "Branded furniture stores such as Ethan Allen are doing very well," Mr. Epperson said. "It's logical that brands would become more important in the future."
If so, the industry will have to grapple with another challenge: how to sell brand names over the Internet. In an industry traditionally fiercely protective of sales territories, the Internet's borderless markets are both attractive and threatening. Nonetheless, a growing number of furniture companies gingerly crossed the line between E-information and E-commerce.
Directions, a Georgia-based manufacturer of contemporary upholstered and occasional furniture, maintains its own Web sit and is selling selected products through an E-retailer called Living.com. "If we're going to jump into it, this is the time to jump into it," said Al Lewinger, president of Directions. "We're ready."
Although on-line retailing still accounts for less than 1 percent of all furniture sales, representatives of Internet companies set up tables and monitors in every available space.
"The furniture industry is highly fragmented and a little primitive," said Linda Lewi, vice president of marketing for Home Portfolio, a Web site (www.homeportfolio.com) that offers access to a wide range of home products, from kitchen appliances to paint. "But there's a vortex of energy out there right now. Something's happening in furniture."

LENGTH: 1034 words

HEADLINE: Creator of the Fantastic Four Is Ready to Spin More Tales on Line

BYLINE: By FRANK HOUSTON

 BODY:
NEXT to his superheroes, Stan Lee has the most recognizable name in comic books. The longtime writer and editor for Marvel Comics helped create, among others, the Fantastic Four, Spider-Man, the Silver Surfer and the X-Men. In his 60-year career, he has become perhaps one of the best-read authors in the United States.
But ask Mr. Lee about his effect on popular culture, not to mention his influence on the literacy of a couple of generations' worth of comic-book readers, and his voice takes on a hushed, disbelieving tone. "I'm constantly amazed to meet people who grew up reading these things," he said. 
 Now, at age 76, Mr. Lee wants to spin his own Web. In December, his site will introduce a new comic-style story called "The Seventh Portal," Mr. Lee's first new series since assuming the publisher's seat at Marvel in 1972 (www.stanlee.net).
Mr. Lee, who is writing all the plot lines for "The Seventh Portal," said that the five-minute episodes would offer "the equivalent of a 10-page comic, but with a lot more detail and a lot more going on." The series is about an international team of beta-testers who are transported through the Internet into another dimension, where they gain superhero powers and battle the evil Mongorr.
"The idea is that there are seven portals that lead to other dimensions," Mr. Lee explained. "Mongorr has conquered the other six; the seventh leads to Earth. It's up to these heroes to keep him from finding it."
Mr. Lee made his career in pen and ink, and he hopes that his on-line comics stimulate renewed interest in the paper kind, too. Comics publishers could use the help. Marvel's bankruptcy, in 1996, was only one symptom of an industrywide slump, which occurred after a brief speculative boom in the early 90's. Sales are back to where they were 10 years ago, but most observers agree that comic books have been hurt -- and even supplanted -- by home video games and the arrival of the Internet, technologies that are aimed squarely at comics' core audience.
Like Slate and Salon, original magazines that first appeared on the Web, comic books have been quietly developing on line since 1996, with artists and writers experimenting with the form in a variety of ways. The Web comics range from reproductions to blends of comics and animation, but few have thus far attracted much notice.
"The nice thing about it is that it's a wide-open field," said Buddy Scalera, the on-line editor of Wizard, a comic book fan magazine. "Nobody has come out on line with the definitively must-read comic book that everybody is talking about. If anybody could do it, it probably would be Stan Lee."
Marvel's characters landed on America Online in 1996 in a series of weekly Cybercomics, and the stories have evolved on the Web with tales of Spider-Man, Wolverine and several others. (Cybercomics are also available, after free registration, at www.marvelzone.com.) New episodes were recently scaled back to a monthly basis, said Marvel's president and chief executive, Peter Cuneo, and will be tied in more directly with Marvel's newsstand offerings.
Part of the difficulty facing writers and artists who produce on-line comics is recreating the comic book's particular blend of words and pictures. Utilizing Macromedia's Shockwave software, Marvel's Cybercomics have the polish of comic books. Readers guide the action by clicking through word balloons and following panels.
Although complete with animation, sound effects and music, the Cyber-comics "are still very much in the comic book or strip genre," Mr. Cuneo said. The result is a cross between comics and animation.
For example, in a panel from "Doom Control," a Marvel series currently running on Macromedia's Shockwave site (www.shockwave.com), Dr. Doom's "mechanism for seizing mental control" takes over the roof of the Chrysler Building. The building juts into the frame at an off-angle, and weird electrical impulses are seen and heard crackling from the device.
Ron Mann, director of the documentary film "Comic Book Confidential," said he was very interested to see the development of on-line art and storytelling. "The page is completely different on a computer screen," he said. "You can endlessly scroll down. The screen itself is a frame."
Mr. Mann has experimented with rendering comic book panels on line. The CD-ROM version of "Comic Book Confidential" includes reproductions of seminal comic books on big pages that can be moved for different views, as well as background information on major artists, including Mr. Lee and his long-time collaborator, Jack Kirby.
Still, Mr. Mann said, "because there are too many bad comics on line, it is harder to find the good comics." One Web-only comic that has sparked interest within the comics industry is a companion site to the film "The Matrix" (www.whatisthematrix.com /cmp/comic_index.html). Comic-book-style stories are evolving in the gap between the hit movie and its planned sequels. Current tales are by writers and artists from Dark Horse, DC and Marvel.
Scott McCloud, a comics creator, theorist and author of "Understanding Comics," a comic book about comic books, has created several strips on line (www.scottmccloud .com) that explore the outer reaches of single Web pages, including Choose Your Own Carl, a reader-guided comic strip long on nonlinear narrative and short on flash.
"Comics are a kind of temporal map," Mr. McCloud said. "As you move from one inch to the next, you're actually moving from one moment to the next. That's a really powerful idea, and a really simple one." It's also one that may not be preserved in on-line comics, he said. "The moment you have broadband, you can have full animation," he said.
Can on-line comics ever match the vitality that sprang from Mr. Lee's dialogue and Mr. Kirby's panels? No matter how close they come, of course, the industry feels secure with its books. "A computerized piece of art is going to appeal to different senses," said John Jackson Miller, editor of Comics Retailer. "It almost takes you out of the realm of literature. Getting comics to work on the screen takes a transformation of what the thing is into something different."

HEADLINE: Darkly Mythic World Arrives From Japan;
Master of Animation Tries Hollywood

BYLINE: By RICK LYMAN

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 20

 BODY:
Admirers of Japanese animation, including many of the leading figures in the American animation community, get a certain catch in their voices when they mention the name Hayao Miyazaki, as though describing someone not quite human, like one of the ghostly forest spirits who populate his work.
"From a pure filmmaking standpoint, his staging, his cutting, his action scenes are some of the best ever put on film, whether animated or not," said John Lasseter, director of "Toy Story," "A Bug's Life" and the upcoming "Toy Story 2." "Watching one of his films is the best medicine when you have writer's block. When we at Pixar feel that we're beating our heads against the wall, we go in the screening room and put on a laser disc and watch one of his films and it's like, whoa, look what he did. It's inspiration to power through that brick wall." 
 Barry Cook and Tony Bancroft, co-directors of the Disney animated feature "Mulan," said simply in a recent tribute: "Miyazaki is like a god to us."
So it's a little disconcerting to find the great man himself, seated quietly on an outdoor patio at the Four Seasons Hotel, a pack of cigarettes nearby, his plain dress shirt open at the collar, a cascade of salt-and-pepper hair hanging across his forehead and an oblique grin on his face. A translator is nearby, as are three or four aides (their faces and numbers shift as they blend in and out of the surrounding tropical foliage) and a handful of publicists and representatives from Miramax, the company that will distribute "Princess Mononoke," the legendary animator's latest work.
"I believe that we must betray the expectations of the audience in order to keep them," Mr. Miyazaki said as those around him hung on every word. "The best thing is to try to make a movie that you don't have a clue how to make."
"Princess Mononoke," which opened in Japan in 1997, earned more than $150 million and became the most popular Japanese film ever to be released in that country and second only to "Titanic" on Japan's all-time box-office list. It was only the latest in a string of critical and popular successes for Mr. Miyazaki, 58.
Yet Mr. Miyazaki is largely unknown in the United States, outside of a small, cultlike following, most likely because until recently his films could be obtained only with difficulty and only in the original Japanese. Recent efforts to introduce the films of Studio Ghibli, the animation company that Mr. Miyazaki founded with his longtime associate, Isao Takahata, in 1985, in English-dubbed versions have begun to lift the veil.
Now, many admirers are hoping that the release of "Princess Mononoke" with a new English script and a major American distributor will finally get Mr. Miyazaki the wider recognition he deserves when the film opens on Oct. 29 in New York and three other cities. Wider distribution is to follow on Nov. 5.
Miramax certainly has high hopes for the release of this dubbed "Mononoke" -- especially with its English-language script by Neil Gaiman, a novelist and author of adult-oriented comic books and himself a highly respected figure in the animation world, and the participation of such actors as Billy Crudup, Claire Danes, Minnie Driver, Billy Bob Thornton and Gillian Anderson. But no one expects that it will turn into the smash phenomenon that it was in Japan.
Like most of Mr. Miyazaki's work, it is too long, too sprawling, too darkly nuanced and, ultimately, too unresolved for that. "It does not have the cathartic ending where the hero conquers the villain and justice wins the day," Mr. Miyazaki said. "And it is too long, more than two hours, which is difficult, no matter how brilliant you make it. I tried, but the film would not allow me to make it shorter."
Still, there are hopes that the film, even if it is not a commercial blockbuster, will expand the audience for sophisticated Japanese animation in the United States and maybe even lure people into sampling the rest of Mr. Miyazaki's work.
"Whether it's going to be a commercial success, I don't know and I don't care," Mr. Gaiman said. "I'm just proud of being a part of it."
Mr. Gaiman said his goal for the "Mononoke" script was dialogue "that didn't sound like Saturday morning cartoons" and that gave American audiences as close as possible the richly textured experience that Japanese audiences had. The challenge was to match his dialogue to a finished film: he tried to be scrupulous about writing lines that required no more mouth movements than were in the movie. Normally, dialogue is recorded before a film is animated so that the drawings can match the sound, but with a dubbed version this is not possible.
"Sometimes, I would come up with a really beautiful line that would take four or five mouth movements and I would only have three," he sighed. "So it had to go."
Mr. Gaiman said he did all of this without meeting the animator. Indeed, the two did not meet until last month, in New York. "I nervously went over and asked him for his autograph," Mr. Gaiman said. "He gave me a hug and told me how pleased he was."
Nervous? Why was he nervous?
"Actually, I was terrified," Mr. Gaiman said. "Why? Because he is Miyazaki."
Mr. Miyazaki's work is praised not merely for its scope and ambitious themes, but also for its filmmaking virtuosity, the way it subtly expands upon the conventions of live-action filmmaking, especially in his action scenes (he is particularly famous for his flying sequences), which rush across the screen with a vertiginous, roller-coaster intensity.
And there is also the simple issue of artistry. "People ask me what my favorite moment is in 'Princess Mononoke,' and I tell them it's when you see a rock and a raindrop hits it, and then another raindrop and then another and then it's slick with water and it's a moment of simply unutterable beauty," Mr. Gaiman said. "Sometimes the point of what you are seeing is simply that what you are seeing is beautiful."
Mr. Miyazaki was born in 1941 to a well-to-do family. His father was the director of Miyazaki Airplane, which made rudders and wing tips for Japanese Zero fighters. He remembers making drawing after drawing of airplanes and battleships as a youth, but when he began to seriously entertain the idea of becoming an animator he found that he was clumsy at drawing people.
S, he became a political science and economics major at Gakushuin University, where he also became a Marxist, remaining there until the late 1980's. In 1957 he saw his first Japanese animated feature and decided that this was what he wanted to do. After graduating in 1963, he joined the staff at Toei Doga, the largest animation studio in Asia.
Eventually Mr. Miyazaki left Toei, first to join another company, then to try to start his own, all the while building his reputation as an animator until, in 1984, with "Nausicaa of the Valley of the Wind," he drew serious international recognition. The story, set in a future where the world has been poisoned by industrial waste and other ecological horrors, is about a young girl in the wilderness fighting giant insects and clashing tribes. (As a tribute, the makers of the television series "Star Trek: The Next Generation" named one of their alien races Nausicaans.) On the strength of the film's success, Mr. Miyazaki helped found Studio Ghibli, where except for one brief and unsuccessful attempt to retire, he has worked ever since.
"Nausicaa" was followed in 1986 by "Laputa: The Castle in the Sky," a science-fiction adventure with some stunning action sequences. Then, in 1986, he released "My Neighbor Totoro," about a pair of Japanese children who move to the countryside when their mother falls ill (Mr. Miyazaki's own mother was bedridden for nine years) and who discover a world of forest spirits. His 1989 action-adventure, "Kiki's Delivery Service," was the biggest box office hit of the year in Japan, but an even bigger success was 1992's "Porco Rosso," a strange adventure about a biplane pilot with the face of a pig (Mr. Miyazaki often draws himself with a pig's face) who battles smugglers in the skies over the Mediterranean.
And then "Princess Mononoke" in 1997. A sprawling adventure that runs for more than two hours, it is Mr. Miyazaki's first Japanese period piece, set during the Muromachi period (1392-1573) and drawing on the era's folk tales, though its central characters are outcasts and working people rather than the samurai and village elders that normally populate such stories. The film's hero is a young prince forced into exile who comes to the edge of a wilderness where a fortresslike community of iron forgers is in conflict with the aging animal spirits in the surrounding forest. There, he meets Mononoke, a wild-child who lives with the animal spirits and is a kind of echo of the young girl in "Nausicaa."
At first, the animator said, it was he who resisted the idea of allowing someone to write an English script for a dubbed version. He was not convinced that the film's strong Japanese elements would translate for American audiences. "All I have is a vague sense of the lives and dreams that American children have," he said. he was also uncertain that young American audiences, accustomed to lighter fare, would be willing to embrace a film that is, at its deepest level, somewhat despairing.
"I think that if you are very genuine in doing films for young children, you must aim for their heads, not deciding for them what will be too much for them to handle," Mr. Miyazaki said. "What we found was that the children actually understood the movie and what we were trying to say more than the adults."
In Japan, he said, "Mononoke" was never sold as a children's film, though he envisioned his ideal audience as anyone over the age of 10. The downbeat tone is a mirror of the world children actually face, he said. "I wanted to be honest with the young audience, to tell them that human society is not fundamentally blessed," he said. "I do this not out of a desire to reassure children, just to say that this is the world that we all live in, children and adult, that we share this despair."
That oblique smile again.
He hopes American audiences will embrace "Mononoke" and, perhaps, develop an appetite for more sophisticated animation. "But you know, I hope the same thing for Japanese audiences," he said. Bad animation is a problem the world over, he said.
Why is that? He shrugged.
"There are too many animators making junk," he said. "And too many people who want to see junk."

HEADLINE: S. L. Dritz, 88, Retooler of Zipper And Other Handy Sewing Items

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN

 BODY:
Stanley L. Dritz, the last of four brothers whose gadgets made their family name a household word for generations of people who sew, died Saturday at the White Plains Hospital. He was 88.
Mr. Dritz had lived in Palm Beach, Fla., since his retirement more than 30 years ago. 
 When he was president of John Dritz & Sons, the company catalogue listed hundreds of items, ranging from hooks, snaps, buttons, pins and needles of all shapes and sizes to a see-through plastic T-square ruler with slots that allowed the user to make precise markings before cutting fabric.
Retailers like J. C. Penney and Sears, Roebuck mounted lavish displays of Dritz products in their stores. Among the most popular were the seam ripper, which made quick work of unwanted stitches and was much safer to use than a razor blade, and the electric scissors, an egg-shaped instrument that fit snugly in the palm of the hand. The scissors sold for $9.95 in 1953.
Toward the end of his life, Mr. Dritz told members of his family that to promote sales of a type of fastener he had first seen in Britain, he coined the word "zipper."
"The scientific name was hookless fastener, but he knew that term was awkward," said his wife, Dorothy. "He said it made a zipping sound and that's how he made up the name."
Others have also claimed to have named the zipper. No less a figure than the industrialist B. F. Goodrich is credited with using it for the Zipper Boots he sold in 1923, according to "Extraordinary Origins of Everyday Things" by Charles Panati (Harper & Row, 1987).
But it was Mr. Dritz who helped heighten the consumer appeal of the zipper by making it of plastic and rust-proof metals and by creating attractive packaging and displays.
He promoted his business by introducing high school teachers of home economics to new techniques and products -- from Dritz.
Stanley Leon Dritz was born on June 15, 1911, in New York City. After graduating from Syracuse University, he joined the business founded by his father, John Dritz. The venture focused on the production and sale of beaded handbags.
Eventually, the family business included Mr. Dritz's brothers, Lawrence, Eugene and Arthur. Together, they brought an extensive array of products to home sewers.
In the 1960's, Mr. Dritz served as president of the National Notion Association, an industry trade organization, which sponsored the semi-annual Notion and Novelty Market Show in New York City.
Mr. Dritz was president of the family business in the 1950's and 60's. The company was sold when he retired. It is now owned by the Prym Dritz Corporation of Spartanburg, S.C., a division of Prym, of Stolberg, Germany.
In addition to his wife, Mr. Dritz is survived by a son, James Dritz of Armonk, N.Y.; three grandchildren, and three great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Population and Anarchy

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Weakness in Numbers" (Op-Ed, Oct. 18): 
 I disagree with Robert D. Kaplan's argument that high population growth makes many countries "increasingly hard to govern except through tyrannical means."
Why, despite the tremendous growth in world population, has the standard of living of most people in the world (including India and China) increased?
And despite its being the most populous country, why is China on the road to becoming one of the world's most powerful economies?
Anarchy is not caused by increasing population, but largely has to do with a country's willingness to give its people opportunities to make their lives better.
 
ASHUTOSH VARSHNEY
Edison, N.J., Oct. 18, 1999

HEADLINE: How Congress Was Cornered

BYLINE: By Leon E. Panetta; Leon E. Panetta served as President Clinton's chief of staff, director of the Office of Management and Budget and chairman of the House Budget Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The Congressional budget process has been in place for 25 years. For those of us who have worked on Federal budgets during that time, there is one unavoidable lesson: No budget is effective if it has no support, and no budget will have support unless it is credible.
This is a lesson the present leadership in Washington refuses to learn. The problem today is that the leadership wants to spend more than it is willing to admit to the public. Rather than being honest about this reality, it is trying to bluff its way through the budget process. 
 How? Congress and President Clinton are hiding behind budget caps. In the 1990 budget agreement, spending caps were established as a way to control the total amount that could be spent for discretionary programs like education and defense. If appropriations bills exceeded these caps, across-the-board cuts would automatically bring down discretionary spending. (Emergency spending -- usually for disaster relief or wars -- was not to be counted against these limits, and they did not affect spending that isn't discretionary, like Social Security payouts or interest on the national debt.) Congress and the President could change the caps, but they would have to change the law to do so.
In 1997, they did just that. In that year's balanced budget agreement, new, more restrictive caps were adopted, calling for drastic reductions in spending, totaling $775 billion over 10 years, with the first $25 billion cut due in fiscal year 2000. It was acknowledged at the time that these targets would be difficult, if not impossible, to achieve and would most likely have to be revised.
Unfortunately, both the President's budget and the Congressional budget stuck to the caps, and the country's leaders painted themselves into a corner: They would not support credible revisions in the caps, but at the same time, they wanted to spend more for their own priorities.
Congress has tried to drive a $30 billion to $40 billion spending truck through the budget walls, increasing financing for the military and veterans' programs, among other things. President Clinton is urging increased spending for education and law enforcement.
Given the caps, there is no way to increase this spending without using every possible gimmick. Everything from financing for the 2000 census to home-heating assistance to the maintenance and operations portion of the defense budget is now labeled emergency financing. Congress is relying on the lowest spending estimates it can find. And it is using accounting sleight of hand to spread this year's budget into next year's.
The result is that the Congress is making a mockery of the Federal budget.
In the past, the budget process succeeded because there were those who were willing to provide leadership and to take the risks necessary to do the right thing. President George Bush was right to agree to the 1990 budget agreement, even though it may have contributed to his defeat in the 1992 election. President Clinton was right to push through his economic plan in 1993, even though it may have cost him a Democratic Congress in 1994. That is the price of leadership.
Today, members of Congress are ducking their responsibility -- hoping they can sneak out of town without having to face the tough choices necessary to enforce a credible budget. Instead of using gimmicks, they should vote to change the spending caps. They should be willing to vote for the taxes and spending cuts necessary to pay for additional spending.
While members of Congress may convince themselves that they are trying to adhere to the caps, all they are doing is passing responsibility on to the next President and the next Congress. The tragedy is that they believe they can fool the American people. In the end, they can only fool themselves. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Albright Vows To Increase Aid to Nigeria

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI

DATELINE: ABUJA, Nigeria, Oct. 20

 BODY:
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright praised the five-month-old democratic Government of Nigeria today and pledged more financial support for the nation.
Dr. Albright, who is on a weeklong visit to Africa, said Nigeria was undergoing a historic transformation that could potentially rank alongside "the Czechoslovak 'Velvet Revolution' and South Africa's long walk to freedom." 
 The United States, she said, will try to insure that democratic change continues in Nigeria, which has emerged from 16 years of military rule. She proposed raising aid to the country threefold or fourfold from its current level of $27 million a year.
Early this week, President Clinton vetoed a $12.6 billion foreign aid bill passed by the Republican-led House. The amount was $2 billion less than the President requested.
Nigeria is Africa's most populous country and supplies 8 percent of United States oil imports.
In her tour of Africa so far, Dr. Albright has also pledged $55 million in aid to Sierra Leone, where a agreement has been signed to end an eight-year-old civil war. The Clinton Administration has been accused of neglecting Africa while responding quickly to Kosovo and East Timor.
Dr. Albright arrived here late Tuesday and held a two-hour meeting with President Olusegun Obasanjo, who is to visit the White House next week.
A State Department official who attended the meeting said President Obasanjo pledged to pursue an aggressive campaign against corruption no matter "whose goat is gored." Cronies of the late dictator Gen. Sani Abacha are already targets of the anticorruption drive.
President Obasanjo also said he expected a "democracy dividend" in the form of debt relief, according to the official. Nigeria's shaky economy cannot get back on its feet and its leaders will find it hard to sustain democracy if the country has to spend more than 30 percent of its export revenues to service its $30 billion debt, the official reported him as saying.
The Obasanjo Government has "already done much to restore Nigeria's democratic institutions," Dr. Albright said in a speech here to a West African economic organization. But she said the Government still needed to repeal repressive laws and to reform its judiciary and military fully.

HEADLINE: Airlines Continue to Report Weak Quarterly Profits

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN

 BODY:
The nation's airlines continued to report weakened third-quarter earnings yesterday as rising fuel prices, the growing number of airplane seats and bad weather helped to reduce profits from last year's record highs.
US Airways, Trans World Airlines, and the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, all disappointed Wall Street, while the AMR Corporation, the owner of American Airlines, was the lone bright spot. 
 After four consecutive years of record profits, many airline executives contended they had finally learned how to increase profits consistently in the notoriously cyclical industry. But even as the domestic economy remains strong, carriers are having difficulty maintaining past earnings levels. Third-quarter profits were also down at some other major carriers. Part of the problem is that the number of new seats is growing faster than the number of new passengers.
"It's frustrating in a reasonably good operating environment, year over year, that we haven't been able to keep our shareholder returns up," Gerard J. Arpey, AMR's chief financial officer, told reporters yesterday.
UAL said its net income fell to $456 million, or $3.75 a share, from $516 million, or $4.02 a share, in the corresponding period last year. Revenue rose 1.3 percent, to $4.85 billion from $4.78 billion. UAL, which is the nation's largest employee-owned company, reports results as if all employee shares have been distributed.
The earnings just missed the $3.76 a share average estimate of analysts polled by First Call/Thomson Financial.
Rono Dutta, UAL's president, said the performance of United, which is the world's largest airline, was strong in July and August. But last month, Hurricane Floyd forced the airline to cancel 750 flights, costing it $15 million. Revenue per seat declined 3 percent domestically during the quarter, while it rose 12 percent overseas. The airline's costs were up 3 percent, mainly because of higher wages and salaries, Mr. Dutta said.
AMR said Hurricane Floyd cost it $17 million after it canceled 700 flights. But a hurricane also upset American's operations last year, neutralizing the effect of Floyd on this year's earnings.
Profits declined 36 percent during the quarter to $279 million, or $1.76 a share, from $433 million, or $2.49 a share in the third quarter last year. Revenue rose 2.1 percent, to $5.1 billion from $5.05 billion last year. The average estimate of analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial was $1.69 a share.
Mr. Arpey of AMR said the average cost of jet fuel had risen 3 cents, to 56 cents a gallon, in the quarter.
Separately, Mr. Arpey said an offer made on Monday by Air Canada to buy the rival Canadian Airlines with the financial backing of UAL and Deutsche Lufthansa A.G. was not credible. The Air Canada bid counters an offer, backed by AMR, from the Onex Corporation, a Canadian buyout specialist.
"There is nothing in it for any of the Canadian constituencies," Mr. Arpey said of the Air Canada proposal, "and there is certainly nothing in it for AMR shareholders."
US Airways, which is the nation's sixth-largest airline and has struggled all year, continued to disappoint Wall Street. It lost $85 million, or $1.19 a share, during the quarter in contrast to a profit of $142 million, or $1.51 a share, in the period last year. Revenue fell to $2.1 billion from $2.2 billion last year. Analysts had predicted a 33-cent loss.
"These results are clearly unacceptable," said Rakesh Gangwal, the president and chief executive of US Airways. "Our operational difficulties during this quarter have taken a significant toll on our financial performance."
In addition to Hurricane Floyd, which forced the airline to cancel 1,500 flights, US Airways suffered from shortages of pilots and airplanes because of slowdowns in its training and maintenance operations. As a result, the capacity, or number of seats, fell 6.6 percent. Its costs, which were already the highest in the industry, soared to 13.51 cents per seat-mile flown from 12.26 cents in the third quarter of 1998.
T.W.A. said it had suffered from rising fuel costs and the threat of a strike by its flight attendants and machinists. Its loss widened to $36.2 million, or 61 cents a share, from $923,000, or 11 cents a share, in the period last year. Revenue rose 1.5 percent, to $876 million from $863 million in 1998. Analysts polled by First Call had expected T.W.A. to lose 52 cents during the quarter.

HEADLINE: Unesco's New Director Is Envoy From Japan, Its Biggest Donor

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING

DATELINE: PARIS, Oct. 20

 BODY:
The Unesco executive board today chose Japan's Ambassador to France, Koichiro Matsuura, as director general of the organization. Mr. Matsuura's nomination for a six-year term is expected to be confirmed by 186-nation general conference of Unesco when it meets here on Nov. 12.
The Japanese diplomat had long been considered a strong contender, because Japan is the largest contributor to the $544 million biannual budget of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization. He also benefited from intense lobbying by his Government, which has in recent years been seeking a higher profile in international organizations. 
 Mr. Matsuura, 62, the front-runner in the first two ballots conducted by the 58-nation executive board this week, won a majority, with 34 votes. Ghazi Algosaibi, Saudi Arabia's Ambassador to London, was second, with 13. This election was the most open to date. But the outcome was no less conventional than in previous years.
In recent weeks, the Unesco headquarters here has been buzzing with rumors that the Japanese and Saudi Governments had promised generous aid packages to several third world countries in exchange for their votes. Japanese and Saudi diplomats strongly denied engaging in such "checkbook diplomacy."
The election has nonetheless brought to the surface widespread unhappiness with the way Unesco and its 2,326-member staff have been run by its current director general, Federico Mayor Zaragoza of Spain.
Mr. Mayor promised sweeping change in 1987, when he succeeded Amadou Mahtar M'Bow of Senegal, whose left-leaning scandal-ridden tenure prompted a walkout in 1985 by the United States and Britain.
But in recent years, Mr. Mayor has come under increasing criticism. An external audit requested by Canada last year said Unesco was wracked by inefficiency and nepotism.
Although candidates to succeed Mr. Mayor did not directly attack his administration, some made it clear that they believed that Unesco needed a thorough shake-up.
Mr. Matsuura, though, was decidedly more cautious, noting in a campaign statement that "I hope to make it a more dynamic, efficient and harmonious organization" and to win recognition of Unesco's "usefulness and dynamic potential."
In an apparent reference to the United States, where he studied economics at Haverford College in Pennsylvania in the late 1950's, Mr. Matsuura also said he would extend an invitation to nonmember states to join. Although Britain returned after Prime Minister Tony Blair's Labor Government took office in 1997, Congressional hostility toward Unesco still appears to stand in the way of the United States' rejoining in the near future.

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
Jack of All Trades, Master of Treasure Hunts

BYLINE: By JAN HOFFMAN

 BODY:
AT a table at the Avenue of the Americas flea market, Alan Boss spotted a hefty down payment for his children's college tuition. He paid $3,000 for two engraved silver peace medals, commissioned by President Washington in 1793. Several years later at a Sotheby's auction, a medal identical to one of Mr. Boss's sold for $50,000.
From this we learn that: (1) Mr. Boss has a sharp shopper's eye and (2) Mr. Boss can afford to plonk down that kind of money to an outdoor vendor. 
 Both make more sense when one learns that Mr. Boss is the president of the Annex Antique Fair and Flea Market, which is a fancy way of saying he's the guy who in 1976 had the bright idea of renting an outdoor parking lot on the Avenue of the Americas on otherwise quiet Sundays. He then rented tables to dealers of antiques and collectibles ("whatever that means," he says with a shrug). His now-famous weekend markets are home to upward of 700 vendors.
He also coordinates the 70 sidewalk vendors who sell 24-7 outside the Coliseum at Columbus Circle. It's they who are tugging at his heartstrings at the moment, because today finishes Mr. Boss's lease on their behalf with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which has sold the property to developers.
"One poor African guy just came and implored us to find him another place to sell," Mr. Boss says. "But we have to close up, lock, stock and barrel. Kaput."
In truth, Mr. Boss, 59, doesn't seem so perturbed over his vendors' plight. That's because he hopes to find another location. But he's also a scrappy sort, son of a Bronx corner grocer, who reinvented himself from failure many times over, with bluster, brio and a willingness to try just about anything to make money, as long as he didn't have to wear a suit to work.
Here is how Mr. Boss talks: "I've been to Fidel. Fidel knows who I am."
Quizzical eyebrow.
"It's Dec. 20, 1998, and I'm in Havana at a synagogue Hanukkah party and Fidel walks in," to address the congregation, it turns out, during which Mr. Castro happens to shake Mr. Boss's hand.
But within the bluster are nuggets of bluntness: "It's 1969, I'm living on the Lower East Side" -- which had a sizable Eastern European population -- "and I'm seeing hand-crocheted peasant blouses from the Ukraine and Poland. I decide to knock them off." The young Mr. Boss, armed with an economics degree from City College and a talented girlfriend, imitates the design, starts a sweatshop, makes a burst of money, and then gets muscled out of the garment district and loses everything.
MORE adventures of the flea king, recounted at his Cuban art and ephemera-filled Chelsea office, which houses his latest gamble:
After blouses, an East Village macrobiotic restaurant with a Japanese friend: "I was the do guy, he was the cook guy. But I had a short attention span."
Next, hauling furniture with a moving van, till his back gave out.
Next, managing a fruit and vegetable stand.
Next, a failed attempt at an antiques market under the Brooklyn Bridge.
By now, Mr. Boss is in his late 30's, a bachelor still, annoyed he hasn't shown his worried family and the world that his restless nuttiness and entrepreneurial zeal will amount to something. He's coming home at 5 A.M. -- hey, it's the 70's -- to his loft on the Avenue of the Americas at 24th Street just as the flower vendors arrive. He looks up the avenue and notices the vacant parking lots. He thinks. He talks. He rents one for $75 for a Sunday.
"We started with 11 vendors and, with my great marketing abilities, we attracted at least 9 or 10 customers," Mr. Boss says.
It took several years for the shoppers and antiques vendors to bond, and a few more for the markets to become, despite the rezoning and development of Chelsea, a tour book stop, with three lots, an indoor garage and, soon, several storefronts.
"I'm there almost every Sunday," Mr. Boss says. "I've seen Brooke Shields, Gloria Vanderbilt, Goldie Hawn, Barbra Streisand, Matt Dillon and Queen Sofia of Spain. Michael Jackson has been there. Catherine Deneuve is a regular." (Remember the Fidel factor. Discount accordingly.) Nearly five years ago, Mr. Boss was the logical choice when the M.T.A. sought a coordinator for a vendor market outside the Coliseum.
Not surprisingly, Mr. Boss has restored antique furniture and now collects Plains Indians artifacts and 18th-century Japanese ceramics. His relationship with his good friend Fidel dates to the late 50's when, as a lifeguard in a Borscht Belt hotel, Mr. Boss heard a Cuban dance band and become a lifelong collector of the music.
The treasure hunt business has been very good to him. This year, he plowed $2 million of his and the bank's money into 30,000 square feet of raw space in a Chelsea loft building, which he rents for conferences and events.
When he was 46, he decided he had earned enough money and had enough therapy, so he allowed himself to marry Annette Kurek, a former actress who collects angels and reads everything about Robert E. Lee. The couple adopted two children from India and live in Park Slope.
Mr. Boss pronounces himself pleased at last. "I'm a New York boy," he says. "I learned how to survive. I even survived myself."

HEADLINE: Passivity Is the Word On Year 2000 Marketing;
Most Big Companies Playing It Low Key

SERIES: COUNTING TO 2000: The soft sell

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
Considering the once-in-a-millennium marketing opportunity that potential Year 2000 computer malfunctions present, the nation's large manufacturers and retailers of consumer products -- even many that stand to benefit from fears of disruption -- have been remarkably restrained.
"We are not going to exploit this," said William J. Spain, a senior vice president for public affairs at Del Monte, the largest producer of canned fruits and vegetables. "We don't think that's responsible." 
Even companies that have enjoyed soaring demand from the limited ranks of consumers who appear to be stockpiling goods in advance of what many now refer to as Y2K have been strikingly passive.
"We have never mentioned Y2K on our Web site or in marketing letters," said David R. Kauntarich, president of Crown Point, a packager of ready-to-eat meals in Mullins, S.C., whose main customer is the United States military. Mr. Kauntarich said he was happy to see commercial sales for Crown Point, which is part of the Unaka Corporation, rocket up from an average of about 7,000 cases a month to a peak of 42,000 in March, mostly on the strength of Year 2000 advertising by independent distributors. But he did nothing to try to reverse the subsequent slide back to the current level of about 12,000.
"We don't want people to say we were fanning the flames, and I don't want to be labeled as a Y2K product," Mr. Kauntarich said.
To be sure, legions of entrepreneurs at the fringe of the economy have avidly promoted products like dried foods and home power generators that might help people through potential disruptions. And a few subsidiaries of major companies have been aggressively trying to persuade consumers -- or at least the retailers that sell to them -- that the potential for Year 2000 disruptions justifies loading up on their wares.
"Y2K is a marketers' dream, an opportunity created by the media and a date change," said Edward C. Brice, director of business development for Sony Media Solutions, a unit of the Sony Corporation that is based in Oradell, N.J., and makes data storage products. Mr. Brice says he has been working with wholesalers and retailers to "get Y2K on people's minds."
And in recent weeks, some big names like Staples Inc., the nation's largest office supply chain, and the Eveready Battery Company, the Ralston Purina unit that makes Eveready and Energizer batteries, have begun promotional campaigns highlighting how their services and products can help protect consumers from Year 2000 troubles.
Such steps are still unusual, though, and most companies with Y2K-linked promotions have been careful to make it clear that they are not predicting how the transition to next year will unfold.
Among those taking this low-key approach is Giant Food, a supermarket chain that serves the Washington and Baltimore areas. The company, a subsidiary of the Dutch supermarket giant Royal Ahold, has sponsored radio messages proclaiming its readiness for Year 2000 and is providing customers with lists of items the American Red Cross recommends for Y2K preparedness, like batteries and bottled water for use in the event of utility failures.
"We're not telling people to buy it now, but, if you're worried, it's available," said Barry S. Scher, Giant Food's spokesman.
The Year 2000 problem stems from the inability of many computers to handle year 2000 dates. Preparedness advocates argue that an accumulation of foul-ups, most of them tiny, could shut down some crucial services like electrical power and gum up others next year. The risk of last-minute panic buying, these advocates say, increases as major companies shun aggressive marketing of products that consumers might want in the event of shutdowns.
"People aren't going to panic if they are prepared," said Paloma O'Riley, a preparedness advocate based in Louisville, Colo. Consumers are more likely to stock up gradually and sensibly if retailers raise Y2K awareness, she said.
Perhaps, but there is scant evidence of that so far. The Hannaford Brothers Company, which has 155 supermarkets from South Carolina to Maine, began adding inventories of items on the Red Cross preparedness list this summer and displaying them at the ends of aisles with preparedness information.
"It came in handy when Hurricane Floyd hit," said William L. Homa, Hannaford's chief information officer. But aside from the run on such items in the North Carolina stores when the storm struck last month, sales of such items have not significantly increased.
That could change if the number of reported computer failures involving dates rises noticeably this fall, a development that consultants like the Gartner Group in Stamford, Conn., say is likely.
For now, even though many companies are preparing contingency plans for serious disruptions, betting on such trouble looks like a no-win situation to many corporate marketers. Most agree with the Government's current view that the computer date problems are unlikely to produce more than minor, short-lived problems around most of the country. That makes pushing the sale of preparedness products seem like a high-risk strategy.
The risks are partly a matter of corporate reputation. If a last-minute wave of panic leads to food hoarding, runs on banks or other chaotic behavior, companies with advertising programs reinforcing the climate of fear will be branded as reckless and greedy. And consumers faced with bare shelves might focus their blame on companies that had advertised themselves as sellers of Year 2000 preparedness.
Many companies say that financial considerations also point to a cautious approach. Consumers may well stay calm and leave merchants who fill their shelves with Year 2000 goods choked with inventory at the end of December, when taxes on everything they own are calculated. And most retailers do not want to do anything that adds to the seasonal problems of handling Christmas exchanges.
"What if customers load up on Y2K merchandise in December and then bring it back in January?" said Janice R. Drummond, a spokeswoman for Sears, Roebuck.
Sears recently began telling purchasers of home generators that they will have to pay a "restocking fee" of 20 percent of the sale price if they return the generators next year.
Returns are a major concern for smaller retailers. McGuckin Hardware, a family-owned store in Boulder, Colo., has sold several hundred kerosene heaters so far this year, up from just a handful two years ago. The heaters and other big-ticket Y2K items like generators carry "no refund, no return" stickers.
"There is no way I can take hundreds of heaters back," said Harry Ransom, the assistant store manager in charge of McGuckin's Y2K program. The store has set aside a Y2K section with ready-to-eat foods, heating and lighting equipment and even theme T-shirts.
Reluctance to exploit Y2K fears does not mean that retailers and manufacturers have not thought long and hard about how consumer behavior might change as the rollover approaches.
Some are taking the approach of banks, which have made arrangements to refill automated teller machines more quickly than usual if consumers begin withdrawing large amounts of cash as the New Year weekend approaches.
The bottled-water businesses of Nestle, including brands like Perrier and Poland Spring, have begun increasing production and shipments to handle post-Christmas sales that some in the industry expect to surge 25 percent, to peak summer levels. But a rival, Groupe Danone, maker of Evian, is still searching for signs that such a demand spike is coming.
"Behavior assumptions can be very tricky," said Michael J. Neuwirth, a spokesman for Danone's North American water operations.
Wall Street is certainly not expecting any spectacular financial returns as a result of Y2K-inspired consumer-goods purchases. The industry leaders for many of the products on popular preparedness lists are units of large, diversified multinationals. A major jump in end-of-year disposable diaper sales, for example, would not move the Procter & Gamble battleship much. The same might be said of the Gillette Company and its Duracell batteries or Eli Lilly & Company and insulin for diabetics. In addition, analysts expect that most of the extra purchases in 1999 will reduce demand for such products early next year.
Still, some major companies are beginning to back modest marketing efforts. Last month, Staples announced a program for both Y2K preparations and "sound record-keeping practice at the end of every year." Staples, which is based in Framingham, Mass., is waiving fees through Dec. 31 for downloading and reading computer files that small- business owners and home office workers send to its copy centers for backup.
And Eveready recently sponsored advertising inserts in newspapers to start an $11 million campaign highlighting the advice by the American Red Cross to set aside three days' to a week's worth of supplies -- including batteries -- for Y2K, treating it like a major storm. It is also donating $100,000 worth of batteries to local Red Cross units.
The working assumption for most merchants is that any surge will begin after Thanksgiving and hit hardest after Christmas. A few companies say they are gearing up already to court such business. The 7-Eleven Company, which normally runs monthlong advertising promotions for its 5,000 stores, is currently leaning toward introducing banners promoting Y2K preparedness products along with its New Year's party goods on Dec. 26. It has also added Sony Walkman radios to its inventory in part because portable radios are on most Y2K preparation lists.
"It's a great opportunity to deliver on our promise of convenience," said Margaret A. Chabris, a spokeswoman for the company.
Much of the planning is mere guesswork, though. After all, American business has little incentive to do much research.
"There's no ongoing return for learning how to do this," said Robert C. Blattberg, a marketing professor in the J. L. Kellogg Graduate School of Management at Northwestern University. "It's a one-time event."

 Articles under this heading throughout 1999 are examining efforts worldwide to prepare computer systems, and their users, for the year 2000.

HEADLINE: A Tolerant and Inclusive Muslim Tradition Thrives

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20

 BODY:
The election of Indonesia's most important Muslim religious leader as its first democratically chosen President was welcomed today by Western Governments and human rights advocates. They describe the new leader as a champion of human rights and religious tolerance.
Islam as practiced by the new President -- Abdurrahman Wahid, leader of what amounts to the largest Muslim political party in Indonesia -- is a faith in which religious and cultural differences between neighbors are carefully respected and in which free speech is a right. 
 His rise to power puts human rights groups in an unusual -- and, they said, welcome -- position, greeting the rise of a foreign religious leader.
Human rights advocates often cringe when religious leaders control a government, fearing the intolerance of Muslim-governed nations like Iran or Afghanistan or recalling the first months after Hindu nationalists took office last year in India and were accused of orchestrating violence against Muslims and Christians.
"This is going to be very important in terms of showing the rest of the world such a tolerant Muslim leader," said an Indonesia specialist, Sidney Jones, Asia director of Human Rights Watch.
Although she is critical of some of Mr. Wahid's alliances, Ms. Jones said that he "has personally been a staunch defender of human rights" and that his election begins "an experiment to see whether an overwhelmingly Muslim country can be a true democracy."
"People despair of that ever happening," she said. "Maybe Indonesia will be the first."
With 220 million people, 90 percent of whom describe themselves as Muslim, Indonesia is home to more followers of Islam than the Middle East.
The faith found its way to Indonesia beginning in the 13th century aboard the trading ships from the Indian subcontinent. Islam was not forced on the population, and it did not replace traditional Indonesian spirit worship and mysticism. Rather, it was layered on Hindu and Buddhist practices.
For most Indonesians, the fact that they are Muslims is just one element of their identity, and not necessarily the first to come to mind.
"Islam in Indonesia has never been an extreme orthodoxy," said James Clad, a professor of Southeast Asian politics at Georgetown University who recently returned from Indonesia. "It's a religion there that has been in tune with traditions that are open to tolerance and a willingness to disagree. Broadly speaking, this is a place where Islamic fundamentalism finds the soil pretty thin."
When Muslim political parties were first formed in Indonesia early this century, few called for an Islamic state. Instead, historians say, they reflected a desire to defend their basic political and economic rights from encroachments by the Dutch colonialists.
When Indonesia won its independence in 1949, its Constitution guaranteed freedom of religion, and Hinduism, Buddhism and Christianity are widely and openly practiced.
In recent decades, no one has been a more important champion of religious and cultural tolerance than Mr. Wahid, leader of the Council of Islamic Scholars.
In the 80's and early 90's, Mr. Wahid was outspoken in his condemnation of human rights abuses by the Indonesian Army in East Timor.
"The richness of Indonesia, its diversity, is also its weakness," he said in an interview in 1993. "Look at what has happened in Yugoslavia and the Soviet Union. That's what I'm afraid of in Indonesia -- disintegration."

HEADLINE: Trade Deficit Narrowed in August as Exports Grew

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

 BODY:
Reflecting some long-awaited gains from economic recovery abroad, the huge American trade deficit narrowed in August for the first time in four months as exports rose faster than imports.
Financial markets reacted calmly to yesterday's Government report, a sharp contrast to the previous month, when currency and bond markets fell after the Commerce Department reported a large increase in the trade gap at a time when Japanese authorities were doing little to reverse a worrisome rise in the yen. Indeed, indications that the trade gap may no longer be widening appear to have contributed to a powerful rally in stocks. 
 The latest tally showed a gap between exports and imports of $24.1 billion, down from $24.9 billion in July.
With economies in Asia, Latin America and Europe on the mend, demand for American exports of goods and services is finally improving. But some experts worry that such gains will only further stoke a United States economy that is already operating at a pace that leaves the Federal Reserve nervous about revived inflation.
"This confirms that economic growth overseas is taking hold," said Sung Won Sohn, chief economist at Wells Fargo & Company in Minneapolis. Noting a near-doubling of American exports of aircraft, he added, "Asian airlines are buying again because their traffic has built tremendously."
At the same time, however, the United States deficit with China soared to $6.9 billion, the largest ever with any country, from $6.3 billion in July.
This prompted a fresh expression of unhappiness in Washington, where support for China's efforts to join the World Trade Organization seem to be fading. "U.S.-China trade remains a troubling story," William Daley, the Commerce Secretary, said yesterday.
American imports from China exceeded exports by an additional $6 billion so far this year compared with the similar period in 1998. Mr. Daley said that at talks set in Seattle next month he would keep pressing the Chinese to remove obstacles to American companies seeking to do business there.
"Everywhere you look, you see stuff made in China," said James E. Glassman, senior United States economist at Chase Securities, adding that the primary "culprit" causing the widening of the nation's trade imbalance in previous months was recession in Asia rather than any lack of competitiveness on the part of American business, as was the case in the 1980's.
The Government's statistics on trade between individual countries, which are not adjusted for normal seasonal variation, also showed that the deficit with Japan shrank in August to $6.4 billion, from $6.8 billion in July.
Over all, the report showed, exports climbed $2.9 billion in August, to $82 billion, while imports rose $2.1 billion, to $106.1 billion. That reduced the trade gap $800 million, with July's gap, upon revision, moderately lower than first reported.
This was the eighth consecutive monthly rise in imports, reflecting the continued domestic boom and by far the largest of three consecutive gains in exports.
"We're starting to see evidence of global healing," Richard Berner, chief United States economist at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, said.
Still, while encouraged by rising exports, he said the trade deficit could easily expand again in coming months since exports must grow 30 percent faster than imports at current levels merely to keep it steady.
James E. Annable, chief economist at Wingspanbank.com, also expressed concern about the impact of American consumers' strong demand for foreign goods. If this doesn't subside, he said, the deficit could swell enough that the dollar would weaken, tending to bring inflation, higher interest rates or both.
For now, though, the deficit raises far fewer alarms than it did in the 1980's; it is less than 3 percent of gross domestic product, about half a percentage point less than a decade ago.
That is largely because American industry is making immense investments in new equipment that should raise productivity. Moreover, consumers are likely to slow spending since rising interest rates have nearly ended home refinancings which, along with the stock market, had helped fuel the current binge.
"We're not in the worst of all worlds yet," Mr. Annable said.
The United States's trade deficit with Canada, muddied by border-area production for tax reasons and other issues, climbed to $3.5 billion in August, from $3.1 billion while the deficit with Mexico was essentially unchanged at $2.2 billion. The American deficit with Western Europe narrowed to $4.4 billion, from $6.1 billion.
For the industrialized countries of the Far East -- Hong Kong, South Korea, Singapore and Taiwan -- the gap shrank to $1.7 billion, from $2.5 billion.
The biggest rise in imports in August was for industrial supplies and materials -- mainly crude petroleum that has risen sharply in price this year. Petroleum imports rose to $5 billion, from $4.44 billion in July as the price for a barrel jumped to $17.40, the highest level since March 1997.

HEADLINE: The Big City;
Ventures Feed The Pleasures Of Indolence

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY

 BODY:
IF you are a New Yorker whose favorite cooking appliance is the telephone, or if you can't make it as far as the corner to pick up your dry cleaning, then you are already part of what Ross Stevens calls the city's "delivery culture." But your indolent pleasures have only just begun.
Suppose that one evening you are overcome with the urge to watch "This Is Spinal Tap" accompanied by popcorn and soda, or to read E. B. White's "This Is New York" while eating ice cream and listening to Marc Anthony's latest CD. With one phone call or a few clicks of a mouse, you can have it all delivered within an hour for no more than you'd spend if you schlepped to all the stores. 
 You can order directly from kozmo.com, a company in Greenwich Village that started last year and now sends its blue-uniformed messengers on several thousand deliveries a day from its two warehouses in Manhattan. Operating from 10 A.M. until 1 A.M., the messengers go out on bikes and motor scooters to rent videos and sell books, CD's, magazines, Krispy Kreme doughnuts and assorted other snacks.
Or you can order from Dr. Stevens's new company, urbanfetch.com, which started delivering last weekend throughout Manhattan and Brooklyn Heights. Besides matching kozmo.com's guarantee of delivery within an hour, urbanfetch.com is offering round-the-clock service and a revolutionary innovation: delivery guys who refuse tips.
That might sound incredible -- I stood dumbfounded in the doorway the first time the green-uniformed courier waved away the cash and said, "No, the tips are already built into my salary" -- but after three tests I have yet to find an urbanfetch.com courier who can be bribed. There may be no free lunch, but there does seem to be free delivery -- and free pickup, too, when you're finished with the video.
"There are such efficiencies in our business that we can afford to pay our couriers well above the market wages," said Dr. Stevens, a former hedge fund manager with a doctorate in finance and statistics. "We've eliminated tipping because it's a source of anxiety -- how much do I tip the guy? -- and it can be a significant extra expense if all you're ordering is a $4 movie rental and a Coke."
Both companies are touting their large inventories -- hundreds of magazines, thousands of books and CD's, more than 15,000 movies -- and frantically expanding their offerings. Soon, they promise, their couriers will be delivering sandwiches, liquor, flowers, medicines, toiletries, and electronic items ranging from Palm Pilots to VCR's. They expect a brisk demand for emergency gifts wrapped and delivered within an hour.
"In our research with focus groups," Dr. Stevens said, "the number one word that was used by New Yorkers to describe their lives was 'hectic.' The New York spirit was summed up by one woman in a sentence: 'If I could get everything delivered, I would.' "
MR. PARK, a former investment banker, came up with the idea for kozmo.com (named for the "Seinfeld" character) from his own frustration at waiting for books from Amazon.com. "Our business marries the economic advantages of Amazon.com with the instant gratification of local commerce," he said. "We're the Polaroid of E-commerce."
Although he and Dr. Stevens don't claim to be making money yet, they both insist that they can provide free instant delivery while still operating more cheaply than traditional stores. "Unlike a brick-and-mortar retailer, we don't have to pay to be in lots of prime real estate locations," Dr. Stevens said. "We can serve all Manhattan and Brooklyn from two locations. And we can fit the inventory of a Virgin megastore in a warehouse one-hundredth the area."
But how does it get from a shelf in the warehouse to someone's door so quickly? Neither Dr. Stevens nor Mr. Park will say. They won't even disclose where their warehouses are.
"It's basically a localized same-day Fed-Ex system," Mr. Park said. "Everything is tied to the integrated data pipeline connected to the Web."
Dr. Stevens puts it just as opaquely: "We have a hub-and-spoke network. The heavy lifting in this business is in designing the internal fulfillment and external distribution systems, and ours is proprietary. We have heavy-duty algorithms that route orders in optimal fashion."
Whatever that means, it seems to work in less than an hour.

HEADLINE: A New Inflexibilityin Overhauling U.S. Financial Laws

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20

 BODY:
After more than 20 years of battles, truces and unholy alliances over legislation to reshape the nation's financial system, the measure's fate rests on what has turned into a bitter and perhaps symbolic political fight between President Clinton and Senator Phil Gramm.
More than seven hours of negotiations today involving Mr. Gramm, Republican of Texas and chairman of the Senate Banking Committee; Secretary of the Treasury Lawrence H. Summers, and Gene Sperling, the President's top economic adviser, inched closer to a resolution. But the talks failed to yield agreement on the proposed legislation's effect on a 1977 law aimed at eradicating discrimination in lending. 
 Tonight the Treasury Department issued a statement indicating that the negotiations had broken down. The statement said, "No proposal has yet been put forward that the President can accept." It also said that the legislation was deficient because it permitted banks to expand into new areas of business even if they had poor records of making loans to the disadvantaged.
The statement, and an earlier one by Mr. Gramm, suggested that the two sides had begun to harden their stances over the merits and shortcomings of the Community Reinvestment Act of 1977. As a result, legislative prospects for overhauling the banking system have begun to fade.
Both sides seem to recognize political benefits in standing firm as the 2000 election cycle begins, even as the most powerful financial interests in the country clamor for a new law. Mr. Gramm and other Republicans would undoubtedly blame the White House for failing to approve a bill long sought by Wall Street and corporate America. Mr. Clinton and Vice President Al Gore might similarly assail the Republicans, accusing them of retarding decades of progress in civil rights.
"When symbolic politics begins to get elevated, it gets harder to make a deal," said a Democratic Senator who wants to see the financial overhaul measure signed into law.
Lobbyists who champion the legislation agreed. "If there is not a bill," said Paul A. Equale, a lobbyist for the Independent Insurance Agents of America, "it will be because the White House and the Treasury Department feel very strongly about the Community Reinvestment Act, and Senator Gramm feels equally strongly, and both sides think they will win the White House next term and can get a better bill."
Already today, there was talk on both sides that foreshadowed what may be to come. "The array of anti-minority sentiment expressed almost each week now by Republicans is historic," said Senator Tom Daschle, the Democratic minority leader, citing Mr. Gramm's view on the Community Reinvestment Act, among other things. "I have never seen a party become this defiant when it comes to protecting minority rights in my time in public life."
The political parties exchanged accusations over race as these related to several issues. Page A18.
Mr. Gramm said that "in the end the Administration has to decide if they want a bill or not."
"It may be that we have to wait 15 months for a new Administration to approve this bill," he said.
The long history of the banking legislation has read like a plot line from "The Perils of Pauline," and it is impossible to accurately handicap the outcome of the negotiations.
For years, efforts to overhaul the financial system failed in Congress because three of Washington's most powerful lobbying interests -- banks, insurers and securities firms -- were at war, each pressing to defeat the interests of others. Their efforts led to many stalemates, but ultimately the three became allies, as the distinctions between the financial products they offered began to blur.
Still, the prospects for the legislation remained dim because of a turf war between the Treasury and the Federal Reserve over which agency should oversee the new financial conglomerates. Last week, the Fed and the Treasury reached an agreement to share that authority, and the mood brightened considerably among advocates for wholesale change in the 66 years worth of laws that have made it difficult for banks to expand into securities and insurance.
Now, the partisan fight remains between Democrats and Republicans over the meaning of community lending and the philosophy behind the Community Reinvestment Act, a law intended to eradicate red-lining and other forms of economic discrimination.
While the provisions under debate apply to relatively obscure elements of the act, they are powerfully symbolic, affecting core constituencies of both parties. Mr. Gramm has repeatedly criticized the way regulators have interpreted the act, saying that the Government should not be in the business of "reallocating capital" and that the law imposes unnecessary and burdensome requirements on small banks and savings associations.
His critics say that the Financial Services Act of 1999, as his bill is called, would roll back the Community Reinvestment Act. Those critics include the Congressional Black Caucus, a group that helped save Mr. Clinton's Presidency during the Senate trial proceedings early this year.
There were fresh signs today that Democrats and Republicans were hardening their views. Nine Republicans sent a letter to Mr. Gramm urging him to hold the line and not make any significant concessions on the issue. At the same time, the Rev. Jesse Jackson said in an interview that he was urging the White House to hold firm and that a compromise on the Community Reinvestment Act would undermine the President's commitment to raising capital in poor areas.
Some Democrats criticized the White House today, saying it had caved in to industry pressure by abandoning the fight to put provisions in the legislation that would make it harder for financial conglomerates to share confidential customer information with other businesses and telemarketers.
"They inexplicably pulled the rug out from underneath us," said Senator Richard H. Bryan of Nevada, who had been leading an effort in the Senate for provisions that would have strengthened the privacy-protection elements of the legislation.
