HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In /Rowayton, Conn.;
A Neighborly Enclave on the Sound

BYLINE: By LISA PREVOST 

 BODY:
EDGING its way down the Five Mile River to Long Island Sound, the community of Rowayton shows telltale signs of creeping exclusivity. Some young families moving in are enlarging older ranches and even tearing them down to build bigger homes.
This has set longtime residents to grumbling about oversized mansions and obstructed water views. 
 But some things about this coastal enclave of Norwalk never change, and that's a comfort to the people who chose it for its traditional village appeal. The chain-link fence surrounding the old schoolyard off Rowayton Avenue still serves as the community bulletin board. The locals still hang out at Rowayton Hardware in the village center. And every December, the outdoor Christmas pageant, complete with live donkeys, still brings people out in the cold to sing carols together by flashlight.
"This is a real community," said Barbara Garfield, a designer who raised her four children in Darien before moving to Rowayton four years ago. "I go for a walk every morning and people come out and say hello to me. Two little old ladies who'd seen me walking by their house every day even came out and invited me in for tea."
The layout of what is officially known as the Sixth Taxing District of Norwalk encourages such familiarity. Houses are closely spaced along narrow streets -- "As I'm washing dishes, I'm looking into a neighbor's living room," joked Andrew P. D'Alessio, a district commissioner.
Rowayton's mere 1.28 square miles, as well as a shortage of parking spaces in the village center, encourage residents to do their errands on foot. Mingling naturally follows, said Victoria Hirsch, 32, who regularly hoofs it behind her 2-year-old son's stroller.
"When we moved here in the summer of '98, I thought I was going to horn in on my cousin and her friends here," said Ms. Hirsch, who is renovating a ranch with her husband, Gary, 36, a lawyer in Manhattan. "Now I know more people in Rowayton than she does because she works during the day and I'm out and about."
Founded by farmers and fishermen in the 1600's, Rowayton has gone through several metamorphoses. In the mid-1800's, it was a major oystering center, shipping tens of thousands of bushels annually. In his history of the village, "Rowayton on the Half Shell," Frank E. Raymond, a native of the community, notes that the eastern side of what is now Rowayton Avenue was then known as "Oysterman's Row" because the large Victorian homes on the street were all owned by oystermen.
By the turn of the century, when oystering had begun to decline, Rowayton had become a tourist destination. Steamboats and trolleys delivered crowds of visitors to Roton Point Park on the Sound. In addition to its beaches, the park featured a merry-go-round, dancing pavilion, roller coaster and other amusements.
Now a suburb with several office buildings along Rowayton Avenue, Rowayton has used its taxing authority to maintain a degree of independence from Norwalk. In addition to Norwalk taxes, residents pay a Sixth District tax to maintain their own street lights, parks, beach, public library and community center. But the illusion of separation is briefly shattered every morning when a the lengthy caravan of United Parcel Service trucks comes rumbling through town from a nearby Norwalk industrial park.
Still-smaller fiefdoms have grown up within Rowayton in the form of the private beach communities of Bell Island, Pine Point and Rowayton Beach. Mr. D'Alessio, who lives in Bell Island, notes that current tastes for larger homes are rapidly transforming these communities. Bell Island, for instance, once consisted primarily of small, one-story houses. "Now, they spend $500,000 to $1 million for the property," Mr. D'Alessio said. "Then they bring in a Dumpster and put the house in it."
Houses with views of Long Island Sound typically start at about $500,000, says Fran LeMoult, a sales associate for Prudential Wheeler Real Estate in Darien. Waterfront properties seldom go for less than $2 million, she said.
HOUSING styles vary widely, from modest Cape Cods and cottages, to charming English cottages neatly penned in by hedges, to grand Victorians. New four-bedroom colonials currently on the market are priced from $795,000 to $895,000.
Rowayton's only condominiums are at Thomas Place, a luxury development along Wilson Cove on the Sound. Four three-bedroom apartments are in one building and one without water views is under contract for $899,000, said Ms. LeMoult. In addition, there are 21 detached colonials, one of which, a four-bedroom house, sold earlier this year for $1.125 million.
With a dry-cleaner, a post office and a hardware store, the village's commercial center on Rowayton Avenue provides some of the necessities, as well as a few luxuries. Rowayton Market caters to gourmet tastes. And the relatively new River Cat Grill features tapa-sized portions for sampling with a wide selection of wines by the glass.
Other eating establishments include Rowayton Pizza, Wendell's 101, a deli and ice cream shop; Rowayton Seafood and Bistro Du Soleil, which its Chilean owners say has "a global cuisine."
Elsewhere along the avenue's riverfront, boatyards rent moorings and slips. The district operates its own community dock on the river. On Wilson Cove, the private Rowayton Yacht Club at Hickory Bluff provides moorings and launch service.
Roton Point Club, on the former grounds of the amusement park, offers members a private beach, pool and tennis courts. Adjacent to the club, Bayley Beach is open to all Rowayton residents. Named for Neville Bayley, the amusement park's last owner, the beach is enhanced by a picnic area, playground and tennis courts, making it a favorite spot for families.
The influx of young families to Rowayton over the last few years has gradually swelled enrollment at Rowayton School. The student body at the K-5 school has grown from about 270 in 1990 to about 400, said Leslie Pattengill, the principal. However, class sizes are still holding steady at around 20 students, she said.
The school emphasizes the arts throughout its curriculum. "It's a very artsy community and it's the philosophy here that to be a really well-rounded person you want to have exposure to the fine arts of all kinds," Ms. Pattengill said. Internet resources are also incorporated into classroom learning.
Roton Middle School, with an enrollment of 435, serves grades 6 through 8. The school's science curriculum makes considerable use of an onsite planetarium. And students get a jump-start on the high school's focus on foreign languages, offering courses in French, Spanish and Japanese.
The 1,200-student Brien McMahon High School, which serves Rowayton and South Norwalk, draws others from outside the district to its Center for Japanese Studies. According to Joseph Rodriguez, the school principal, the center uses an interdisciplinary approach as well as an exchange program to immerse about 75 students a year in Japanese culture. The school offers a total of seven languages.
ANOTHER of the high school's strengths is its music department, which Mr. Rodriguez calls "absolutely powerful." The school marching band was the lead band in the ticker-tape parade following the New York Yankees' World Series victory last year. And the school's chamber singers performed last year at both Carnegie Hall and Lincoln Center.
Mr. Rodriguez said that the school's student body is "wonderfully diverse in many senses of the word: racially, linguistically, and economically."
Average S.A.T. scores for the 1998-99 school year were 482 for verbal and 470 for math; state averages were 510 for verbal and 509 for math. Last June 84 percent of 235 graduating seniors went on to higher education.
Outside of the schools, community life tends to revolve around the public library and community center, which are housed in the same building. While the library offers a variety of children's activities, the community center plays host to everything from a farmer's market to the monthly meetings of the district commissioners. And every year on a Saturday in mid-June, area residents begin lining up outside the center as early as 4:30 A.M. for the 375 parking stickers for the Rowayton train station. (About 40 people are currently on the waiting list.)
Perhaps the village's greatest treasure is Pinkney Park, high on the bank overlooking Five Mile River. The park has become all the more prized as commercial development has blocked the river from view.
The midsummer River Ramble, featuring canoe races, live music and kids games, capitalizes on the park's location. And during the last two weeks in June, thousands of area residents descend on the park for Shakespeare on the Sound, a free professional outdoor festival.
More than 100 volunteers help with the evening performances, which have grown so popular that the group is considering extending its season, said Betsy Sprague, the current president. The year 2000 production is "A Winter's Tale."
"People bring their chairs, their blankets, their picnics and their bottles of wine," said Ms. Sprague. "It's a very family-friendly thing."

WARTIME PROSPERITY: Connecticut shoreline towns were frequently raided by the British during the Revolutionary War, and Rowayton was no exception. The British and their Loyalist allies were aided in their nighttime attacks on Rowayton by Capt. Esaias Bouton, whose home sat at the head of Wilson Cove. According to Frank Raymond's "Rowayton on the Half Shell," Bouton signaled to British whaleboats that the coast was clear by lighting a fire in his fireplace. In return, Mr. Raymond wrote, Bouton was said to have been given a cut of the booty from the raiders. Ironically, says the author, Bouton's grandson Nathaniel gave the principal address at the 75th anniversary of the Revolution in 1851.

HEADLINE: Q&A/Dr. Mandana Nakhai;
Professor Sees Changes in Native Iran

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
HERE in the United States, Dr. Mandana Nakhai is a professor at Concordia College in Bronxville. But because she is an Iranian citizen, each time she returns to visit her home country, as she did this summer, she can only come back into the United States after obtaining written permission from her husband.
The inequities of Iranian law toward women is something about which Dr. Nakhai feels passionately. At the same time, she said she is hopeful that things will continue to open up in Iran, a process that she says has begun in the last two years since President Mohammad Khatami took office. 
 Dr. Nakhai, 49, left Iran at 18 to pursue her education at the University of Tennessee. There she met her Iranian-born husband, then a nuclear engineering student. Today the couple live in Stamford. She has her doctorate in English and has been at Concordia for 12 years, where she teaches English literature and is director of the Writing Across the Curriculum Program. This summer she spent a month in Iran, where she was supposed to have lectured at the University of Teheran, but was unable to do so because of student riots, which centered largely on the issues of freedom.
Here are excerpts from a recent conversation with Dr. Nakhai:
Q. When you were growing up, at the time the Shah was still in power, did you feel you had freedom as a woman?
A. Under the Shah, in a superficial way, I would say we had some freedom, because, of course, we had the freedom to go outside unveiled. Women did not have to cover themselves from head to toe as they have to today. But still we lived in a very patriarchal society. In the area of education, women were really not encouraged to continue their education. They were not encouraged to emerge in the social or political arena.
I had more freedom in certain areas, but the very same laws that oppressed women today still existed then. So, yes, we had some freedoms during the Shah, but not freedom in a sense that women experience in the West. Patriarchal attitudes were still prevailing in our society even before the Iranian Revolution.
Q. What events caused you to come to America for your education?
A. Even as a child I was very independent, very stubborn and I was very good at arguing with my parents about this and that. So I suppose they gave up on me. I always had a passion for studying languages, and they really didn't see that as a threat. In other words, I wasn't going to study political science; I wasn't going to study engineering. So they agreed to send me abroad.
I chose English because I fell in love with English literature. To me language is memory, identity, culture. Once you master a language, then suddenly you gain access to another consciousness, another way of thinking. So my parents encouraged me. But they had serious concerns about me leaving home and especially going to America with the ugly stereotypes of permissive women. I had been very sheltered. And they were really reluctant to let me go to graduate school and continue my education, but they were consoled because at that point I was married and they didn't have to worry about their daughter becoming an old maid.
Q. Have you been going back to Iran regularly?
A. Not as regularly as I wished to, but I think in the last three or four years I have felt more comfortable going back to Iran. In fact, one summer I taught at the University of Teheran, and it was a wonderful experience.
Q. How hard is it for you to go from the American society, which is generally free for women to navigate, to Iran?
A. It was very difficult, of course. Here in the United States we take this freedom for granted -- the freedom to say what we want, to be direct and honest. Even though whenever I think of home I think of warmth and an embracing place, yet at the same time I did not feel completely secure. And there were, in fact, things there that made me angry. The situation of women, especially. The revolution of 1979 supposedly realized every citizen's dream -- and I say every citizen's dream -- of democracy. And now two decades after the revolution, sexually discriminating laws still prevail in Iran.
Our new president, Khatami, has said frequently and firmly that he stressed the word of God, the rule of law. The challenge for Iranian women now is to reconcile the Islamic code as understood and interpreted by Muslim theologians with their quest for identity and self-respect. There are really gross incongruities between this ideal of equality and the rights of women in Iran.
Q. What are some examples?
A. Women still, as you know, cannot be seen in public without covering themselves from head to toe. If a woman chooses to go outside wearing the hijab (or veiling), that's fine to me. It should be her choice. When the father of our former Shah came to Iran, he forced women to take off their hijab, and I think that was wrong also. Another thing: a woman can't travel outside the country without her husband's consent. Here I am an educated woman, but every time I want to go somewhere I have to get my husband's consent on paper because I'm not an American citizen.
Also, a man today is allowed to have up to four wives and several concubines at the same time. When I spoke to some people among the clergy they explained to me that nowadays they have added a little article to this law that it should be with the consent of the wife. But you see, it's very, very easy to get around this. A man can threaten his wife that he will take away the children from her and make her consent to the second marriage. And women are at a disadvantage in divorce cases. Men can divorce their wives at their whim, without even notifying her. And in custody battles men always have the edge.
Q. When you were in Iran this summer, did you find things changing for the better?
A. Yes. I interviewed some university professors, lawyers, educated women. I was really impressed by all the reforms. I was told that of the thousands of students who took the university entrance exam last year, for example, women constituted 52 percent of those admitted, and that's wonderful. The entrance exams are extremely difficult. That in itself shows that women are now motivated, that they have hope. Another thing that I found out is that one out of three Iranian physicians is female. I was also impressed by the female filmmakers. I saw a movie, "Two Women," directed by Tahmineh Milani. I was amazed they gave her permission to release the film.
Q. What will be the driving force toward reform?
A. A combination of factors. Education, of course. This is, after all, the Islamic Republic, and how can one forget the Prophet Mohammed's command that you have a responsibility to educate your daughters? I think, also, economic needs. It's impossible right now with the rate of inflation in Iran for a one-income family to live comfortably. Dual career marriages are becoming very common.
Q. How are you treated when you visit Iran? Do Iranians envy you for living in America or resent it?
A. There was ambivalence. There was always a sense of admiration, "You did the right thing." At one point I had asked my friends, What is it you most envy about my life in America? They always said the fact that you're free to choose, that no one tells you how to dress, speak or behave yourself.
They are so afraid of becoming schizophrenic. And that term was used so very often that it scared me, because they live double lives. At home, behind the closed doors, they live a certain way, where men and women socialize and are free to laugh together. But you can't do that outside the home.
In terms of resentment and bitterness, yes, I felt that at times. A friend of mine who is a university professor said it was very easy for us to leave the country, but "we stayed and it has been tremendously difficult but the important thing is we stayed and we resisted this oppression and now things are getting better." But she also said, about women, "In addition to academics we also practice acrobatics." She was trying to tell me the risks women have boldly taken to advance their causes.
Q. Is there any possibility that you would return to Iran to live?
A. I don't think I would go back. I think it's too late for me. But this could be a pivotal moment for Iranian women. I just hope that they won't sabotage themselves by alienating themselves and going about this movement in a negative way. I'm so afraid that if they use extremist methods, there will be a backlash and they will go down. So far they seem on the right path. But it means it will take time and it will take patience.

SECTION: Section 14CN; Page 1; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1471 words

HEADLINE: Airport Expects Great Things From Airline;
Growth Tends to Follow Southwest

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
IN 1997, the first year after Southwest Airlines brought its widely touted low-cost fares to T. F. Green Airport outside Providence, R.I., Green became the nation's fastest-growing airport, with an 88 percent increase in traffic. In 1998, Southwest began service to Manchester Airport in New Hampshire, and it became the top-growing airport in the nation last year.
Now Connecticut officials are hoping for a similar phenomenon at Bradley International Airport in Windsor Locks, where Southwest begins operating on Saturday. 
 Bradley, which has until now had the sixth-highest average air fares in the country, according to industry surveys, should begin dropping quickly down the list as Southwest's arrival spurs competition, say officials of the state Department of Transportation, which runs the airport. The department projects that Bradley traffic will increase from 5.6 million passengers last year to at least 6 million this year, and that will likely double in the next five to seven years, although no one expects that Southwest will generate all those additional trips.
"If history is any indication, based on Southwest's startup at other airports, the other airports revisit their own pricing structure, and as the fares come down that leads to more travel," said Stephen E. Korta, Bradley's administrator. "The overall effect is almost always an increase across the board for all carriers."
Robert F. Juliano, head of aviation and ports for the State Department of Transportation, said even before Southwest has actually begun operating out of Bradley, there are signs that the other airlines are responding. Delta Express, the low-fare subsidiary of Delta, has announced that it is adding daily flights to Orlando and West Palm Beach from Bradley.
Mr. Juliano said Bradley has been trying to convince Southwest to stop in Connecticut for six years, but the last he heard there were 140 airports requesting Southwest's service, so he wasn't sure how long it would take. The arrival of the airline will add momentum to the state's planned $156 million expansion at Bradley, expected to begin late this year, which will include a new terminal and additional airport ramp area. In addition, he said the airport is seeing increased interest from private developers for projects such as a parking garage.
"By the time we conclude development in this next phase it could be close to $300 million in public and private investment, and that's only the beginning. The next step would be international service," Mr. Juliano said.
Andre J. Libert, director of marketing for the Department of Transportation, said he expects Southwest to have a much greater impact on the Connecticut economy than the 44 jobs at the two gates where it will begin service. Having a low-cost air carrier at Bradley will be one more feature that can attract business to the state, he said.
Southwest, which operates more than 2,400 flights a day, is probably best known for its low prices. The introductory fares for service out of Bradley included one-way $99 tickets to more than 30 cities, and regular-price advance purchase tickets such as $39 to Baltimore-Washington International, $126 to Kansas City, and $188 to San Diego.
But Southwest is known for more than its prices. According to the Federal Department of Transportation, it consistently has one of the best on-time arrival records and the fewest number of customer complaints.
Christine A. Turneabe-Connelly, a spokeswoman for Southwest in Dallas, would not disclose advance sales, "but the bookings have been very good," she said.
She said Southwest looks at several things when considering whether to add an airport to its network. It must be convenient for customers to get there, it must not have exorbitant landing fees, and away from the "hub and spoke" systems of other airlines, where overcrowding can lead to flight delays.
"We look at a lot of factors, and every one of them has to be a 'yes,' or we don't go there," Ms. Turneabe-Connelly said. "We get asked all the time when we're coming into Colorado, but it's so expensive to fly into Denver we wouldn't be able to keep our prices low. Basically, we look for a market that is overpriced and underserved, and that was certainly the case in Hartford."
Clearly, Southwest has had a major impact on a number of other airports in the region. At McArthur-Long Island Airport in Islip, traffic has more than doubled since Southwest began service in March, said Trish Pasciutti, the spokeswoman for the airport. Not once in the March-to-August period last year did the number of passengers go much above 90,000, and for two months the counts were below 70,000. In the first month after Southwest came in, the traffic hit almost 130,000, and it climbed to more than 200,000 per month in July and August.
The experience has been very similar at T. F. Green, said Patti A. Goldstein, a spokeswoman for the Rhode Island Airport Corporation.
"Our traffic was at 2.4 million passengers a year at the end of 1996," Ms. Goldstein said. "The following year, with a new terminal and Southwest here, that went to 4.1 million, then 4.6 million the next year, and this year looks like it will top 5 million. After six months, Southwest said they needed more gates."
Ms. Goldstein said she does not expect that having Southwest offering service out of Bradley will slow down the growth.
"People asked us the same questions when Southwest went into Manchester, whether it was going to affect us," Ms. Goldstein said. "It didn't. We're both drawing from Boston. They draw from Logan north, and we draw from Logan south."
Southwest started with 12 flights a day out of Green and now is up to 23. Ms. Turneabe-Connelly said the same thing could happen at Bradley, where it will start with 12 daily nonstop departures to Baltimore-Washington, Chicago, Nashville and Orlando, as well as 29 connecting flights, and Saturday service to Las Vegas starting Nov. 6.
Ms. Turneabe-Connelly said Southwest's growth has been even more pronounced at other airports. Its first service on the East Coast started in Baltimore in 1993 with eight daily flights and is now up to 87, growing soon to 93 with six a day between Baltimore and Hartford.
"Baltimore is not a typical city for us -- our growth up there has been off the charts," she said. "Not all of our cities grow that much, that fast. But we've seen growth in most of our markets, and we will always look to extend flights to wherever our customers want them."
Mr. Libert predicted that at lease some of the growth Bradley will see will come from people who are new to flying.
"Everywhere Southwest goes, you see people come out of the woodwork who have just never flown before," Mr. Libert said. "There are a lot of people who have never been on an airplane." But he said Bradley will be marketing in new areas as well. For the first time, it has a billboard in Norwalk, and it will be advertising in Danbury, Westchester County, N.Y., and other areas south and west of its usual area.
"We've drawn a few travelers from Albany before now, but we would expect to draw from as far east as Albany in a much bigger way," said Mr. Libert. "And we expect to start picking up more people from Norwalk, even Stamford and White Plains. To the east, we expect to see more people from New London, Willimantic and Worcester."
Mr. Libert said in the past Fairfield County has accounted for perhaps 2 or 3 percent of traffic at Bradley; today, it is up to 10 percent, and he expects that to grow.
"I have seen people drive to Providence from New York City, before Southwest started flying out of Islip," Mr. Libert said. "For the college kids, it'll be absolutely super. I don't think you can take a bus to Baltimore for the price that Southwest is charging."
Sheila M. Burbank, a supervisor at Chartrek Travel in Norwalk, agreed that Southwest will significantly increase traffic from her corner of the state. Currently, she said, some of her customers drive much further to get better fares.
"This is very important to business travelers," she said. "We have people right now who are driving to Providence for the fares, depending on where they're going. If you're traveling from New York or Hartford to Chicago, it's very expensive, and it makes the drive worthwhile. But if Southwest is going to be offering the same fares at Bradley, it would only make sense that they'll go there."
 With a 9,500-foot runway at Bradley, Southwest has been talking to the airport about more long-haul flights, Mr. Libert said. Bradley has the capability to service nonstop west-coast flights.
"Traditionally, Bradley has been a north-south airport. I guess most of the East Coast airports are," Mr. Libert said. "But once you get this east-west movement going, it will be dynamite."

HEADLINE: Officials Call for Defeat of Pipeline

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
IT is called the Millennium Pipeline, and the company that wants to build it says the 442-mile underground pipeline will insure that the Northeast has an adequate supply of natural gas for decades. But critics question the wisdom of ending the line in a crowded section of Mount Vernon and, more broadly, whether it is really needed at all.
"This is going into a very crowded and tiny concentrated corridor that already holds three aqueducts, major roads, three railroad tracks and one of the most concentrated census tracks of folks in the Northeast," said Katherine S. Carsky, a county legislator from Yonkers. "Mount Vernon is not the only place in the world this could go." 
 And with Consolidated Edison, Westchester's distributor of natural gas, saying the line is not needed, Louis A. Mosiello of Yonkers, another county legislator, said, "I want to feel comfortable that there is a need for this for the people of Westchester County, and not just a need for the pockets of the Millennium builders."
Those two officials, along with Clinton I. Young and Vito J. Pinto, county legislators who represent Mount Vernon and Bronxville, respectively, are the authors of a nonbinding resolution calling for the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to turn down the application of Columbia Gas Transmission, based in Fairfax, Va., to build the $650 million Millennium Pipeline. The resolution is before the Board's Environment Committee, which is not likely to vote on it soon, said its chairman, Legislator Michael D. Kaplowitz of Somers. "I remain concerned about the environment, but we haven't heard enough, in my opinion, to say the project should be killed," he said.
The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission is expected to act on the application within the next two to six weeks. If the project wins approval from the commission by December, there would still be the final environmental impact statement required by the state before it could go forward, Bentley K. Archer, manager of government affairs for Columbia Gas, said.
Columbia's entry into the region's gas market is the result of deregulation of the industry in the 1980's.
Companies like Columbia can transmit energy from far away and hook into local distribution systems. The transmission systems have been likened to superhighways with the distribution systems as the local roads.
Con Edison is a distributor of gas, not a transmitter. Neither Con Ed nor Columbia supply the gas itself, but instead their lines are leased by the natural gas companies, which then supply it to customers.
The Millennium Pipeline would be 24 inches in diameter, laid in 5-foot-deep trenches with 3 feet of cover. For the most part, the project would use existing rights of way and utility corridors, thereby minimizing impact on the area, Mr. Archer said. "The Millennium Pipeline does offer the residents of Westchester County important benefits such as reasonably priced energy, the ability to improve the reliability of existing utility service, new economic development potential and cleaner air," he said, in a recent letter to members of the Board of Legislators.
As proposed in 1997, the pipeline would start at the Canadian border in Lake Erie, go through northern New York State and wind its way down from Rockland County and cross under the Hudson River.
Here is a description of the Westchester route:
The line would go into Westchester near the Montrose Veterans Affairs Hospital in Cortlandt. It would go along a road next to the hospital, then under the Metro-North line in Croton-on-Hudson and Route 9. It would then enter the Con Ed power line easement and turn south. While on the power line easement, the pipeline would be installed under Furnace Brook Lake, under Teatown Lake and under the Croton River. It would stay in the power line easement until about Millwood in the town of New Castle. It would cross Route 100 and then Chappaqua Road, and then Route 100 a second time. South of Millwood, the pipeline would leave the Con Ed easement for a short distance and follow an abandoned railroad adjacent to the power line easement.
The line would pick up the Con Ed easement once again at the Hawthorne police barracks just to the north of Elmsford. It would cross under I-287, continuing on the power line through Greenburgh and Ardsley. Just south of Ardsley, the pipeline would leave the Con Ed easement and track the edge of the Sprain Brook Parkway and then the Bronx River Parkway. Just before crossing into Mount Vernon, the line would move slightly east from the Bronx River Parkway to be installed along an abandoned trailway, which will be improved. Then the line would continue into southeast Mount Vernon (somewhere around Seventh Avenue and Seventh Street) where it would connect with Con Ed's existing distribution system. From there (the so-called terminus) -- a small building that would have to be built -- gas could be delivered to customers.
"Obviously on a project of this magnitude in every region there is potential for concern, and each area has concerns that are unique to that region," Mr. Archer said. "And the way we've approached it -- we've been out there for some time -- is to get to know each of those areas and their unique concerns and try to develop solutions and strategies to address those needs."
In response to concerns of the members of the Board of Legislators, Columbia recently agreed to pay all expenses of an independent engineering consultant, which the county would hire to oversee the project. In response to concern from the Teatown Reservation, Columbia is considering paying to dredge Teatown Lake.
In writing the resolution calling for the regulatory commission to reject Columbia's application, Mrs. Carsky and the other legislators argued that there should be a better terminus than Mount Vernon. Mr. Archer said his company was willing to consider other sites, but Con Ed had not offered alternatives.
James P. O'Toole, director of public affairs for Con Edison, said there is no better site.
"We really don't have a good spot for this pipe to end," he said. "Of all the spots we have, Mount Vernon is the best of the worst." He added, "It would cause us to incur a cost that we do not want to incur." The cost would ultimately be borne by gas customers, he said.
Mr. O'Toole also challenged Columbia Gas's claim that the region has an inadequate transmission system to meet future needs. He said that existing pipelines, owned by other gas companies, could handle 50 percent more natural gas. Columbia, however, asserts that the need is great and that it already has customers lined up to receive all of the projected gas, including the International Business Machines research center in Yorktown.
Mr. Archer said the I.B.M. center has no natural gas pipes connecting to Con Ed's distribution system and that the nearest potential connection is not economically feasible because it is too far away. The proposed line by Columbia, by contrast, he said, comes very close to the I.B.M. center.
Part of the regulatory commission's task in evaluating Columbia's application is to assess need. This is something that the County Planning Department lacks the expertise to do, said Joyce M. Lannert, the Commissioner, who told the Environment Committee that the county would defer to the Federal agency on the matter. The administration of County Executive Andrew J. Spano has not taken a position on the pipeline proposal, she said.
Nor has Federated Conservationists of Westchester County, a coalition of many of the county's environmental groups, its executive director, Gudrun LeLash, said.
Many of the elected officials in the affected areas of Westchester have expressed concern but seem to be willing to let the Federal assessment process move along. Richard Halevy, director of public affairs and community relations for Yonkers, said of the project, "We'd rather not see it happen," but the pending plan is better than an earlier version that would have been more disruptive to his city. Mayor Ernest D. Davis of Mount Vernon could not be reached for comment, but Mr. Young, the county legislator who represents Mount Vernon, said, "It will, without question, be a real interruption to that community."
Mayor Nancy D. Hand of Bronxville also voiced concern to the Environment Committee. Supervisor Linda G. Cooper of Yorktown, said that she has so far been impressed with the Federal review process and with the efforts of Columbia Gas to deal directly with the town's concerns. "Our concern is what happens when the nice people who come through and tell us all about it leave and the construction crews come through."
Columbia hoped to begin construction in April, Mr. Archer said. The pipeline is built, he said, "in a rolling assembly line," meaning a crew prepares one area, moves on and then the construction crews come into the first area, followed by crews that make sure the area is restored. "In any given area, you may be disturbing things for three to four weeks, then you're gone," he said.
Once completed, the line will transport 714 million cubic feet of natural gas a day, enough by one estimate to heat approximately 500,000 houses.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: A $21-Billion Mortgage Initiative;
Fannie Mae Eases Loans

 BODY:
Mortgage programs aimed at making home ownership more accessible for recently arrived immigrants, low-income families and people with poor credit histories in New York City, Nassau, Suffolk and Rockland Counties were announced last week by Fannie Mae, the nation's largest purchaser of mortgages from banks and other home-mortgage originators.
In one of the programs, aimed particularly at immigrants, Fannie Mae plans to purchase $50 million in loans that have been granted on properties that include co-ops and two-family homes. When their credit worthiness is being assessed, applicants seeking the mortgages under this program will be allowed greater flexibility in counting part-time or multiple-job income, and greater use of income from relatives who live with the home buyers. 
 A new program for people with poor credit histories, to be made available by the end of the year, will offer mortgage rates as much as 2 percentage points lower than typically charged such borrowers.
Fannie Mae, which purchases mortgages and packages the loans in pools for sale to investors, announced that $21 billion in mortgage financing would be made available through these, as well as existing community revitalization and development programs in the New York area over the next five years.
For more information, including participating lenders and guidelines, call (800) 732-6643.

HEADLINE: Adding New Floors Atop Old Buildings

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
FIST-THICK bolts have been punched through 53-foot-long, 18,000-pound girders, forging a platform for four new floors atop the masonry walls of an 1860's building on Warren Street in TriBeCa -- an ornate structure that once warehoused munitions for the Remington Arms Company and, later, row upon row of champagne bottles for the G.H. Mumm Company.
By spring, the developer hopes to have sold the four full-floor condominiums being fashioned in the old building, the 6,000-square-foot apartment with a deck on the newly created sixth floor and, perhaps, the new triplex that will top it all off -- for prices ranging from $1.4 million to $4.3 million. 
 At 40 Prince Street in Little Italy, three new floors are being added to create a total of 20 apartments in a 1950's building that already has offices, art studios and residences. At 90th Street and Amsterdam Avenue on the Upper West Side, scaffolding skirts a six-story 1920's building in preparation for the addition of five floors and a penthouse -- virtually doubling the building's size.
The Manhattan residential market, where demand has long outstripped available acreage, has long inspired developers to reach for novel architectural forms -- from the so-called sliver building, rising high from a narrow lot, to the lollipop building (kind of a sliver building topped by T-shaped wings over adjacent brownstones and town houses). These days, it is increasingly spurring construction of piggyback buildings: more floors -- in one case 11 -- added onto an existing structure. At least a dozen piggyback buildings are currently in some state of construction.
"It's definitely a trend," said Richard C. Visconti, acting commissioner of the New York City Department of Buildings. "The strong economy is driving a tremendous amount of residential development."
And as certain areas of the city have been rezoned from commercial to residential use, Mr. Visconti said, developers find it feasible -- particularly in lower Manhattan where many older buildings retain unused development rights -- "to buy buildings and add two, three or whatever the lot will yield in the way of additional floor area."
The phenomenon has generated considerable controversy, particularly from neighbors of buildings experiencing unanticipated growth spurts and, in some cases, people already living in the buildings.
There are immediate concerns, like the din of construction, fear of falling debris and fire safety; and longer-term issues, like access to light and air, the structural integrity of the old building, the historic character of the community and, in grittier districts, the frustration that "there goes the neighborhood" (upscale).
Not to mention sudden loss of that precious commodity: view.
The Department of Buildings cannot quantify the trend in what it refers to as "vertical enlargements" because they are lumped together with applications for all sorts of building alterations. "We have no statistics that say so many permits have been given for vertical enlargements." Mr. Visconti said. "But across the board we're up 31 percent in our alteration applications" -- from 46,214 in 1995 to 60,631 this year. "What is new," Mr. Visconti said, "is that everyone is seeing more and more of it."
Charles Dunne sees it every day -- and not just at the old munitions and champagne warehouse that his company is piggybacking.
Mr. Dunne is a partner in the 60 Warren Street Company. "I live downtown and I see it," he said. "Many buildings are doing one or two floors; I know of five to 10. But I'd say another four or five are adding four or five floors."
"One reason you're seeing this is because the price of raw space has gone up dramatically," Mr. Dunne said. "So to make a project economically viable it's not always possible just to keep and renovate the existing structure. That leaves you two choices, either knock the building down and start from scratch or do what we did.
"We didn't just go out with the idea of adding to a building," Mr. Dunne said. "We found a building we thought was beautiful and tried make it economically viable while preserving it."
Some people are not applauding, their reservations ranging from esthetics to fear of collapse.
Andrew Dolkart, an architectural historian and author of "The Texture of TriBeCa" (TriBeCa Community Association, 1989), pointed out that 60 Warren Street is representative of the first generation of imposing buildings that, starting in the 1850's, transformed what is now called TriBeCa from a neighborhood of Federal-style row houses with sloping roofs and dormer windows into a commercial and manufacturing district.
"It's five stories," Mr. Dolkart said. "That's typical because these buildings predate the elevator. It's an Italianate-style building with segmental arches on the windows of three floors and round arches on top -- a nice variation in the rhythms."
Such buildings were carefully proportioned for their height, Mr. Dolkart said, "so when you add stories you destroy the proportions."
"I hate this stuff," he said. "The Warren Street building is a really significant structure and doesn't deserve to be the base for a taller building. I'd rather see it torn down."
Roger Byrom, a graphics designer, lives across the street from 60 Warren and worries that the building, with its old wooden joists and beams and load-bearing walls, could come tumbling down -- especially if a fire starts in the dry-cleaning plant on the ground floor.
"I've asked structural engineers, 'Am I crazy here?' and they all say no," Mr. Byrom said.
"With that structure on the roof," Mr. Byrom asserted, the building will press the limits of its load-bearing capacity. "Can you imagine," he said, "if any of the integrity of the 100-year-old brickwork is in question, that the building will just buckle and fall over?"
NOT a chance, said Joseph Vance, the architect. "It was built to handle a lot of weight, stacked-up ammunition," Mr. Vance said. "So it was extremely well built."
One wall, on West Broadway, for example, Mr. Vance said, "is two feet thick at the bottom and tapers to 17 inches at the top." And engineers have calculated, he said, that the east wall -- a so-called "party wall" shared with the neighboring building -- "can not only support what we are doing, but a four-story addition on their building as well."
The neighbors were not convinced.
The co-op board at 56 Warren Street filed suit, primarily because of concerns that wood beams inside the old warehouse could catch fire and, with them, the building collapse. In June, City Councilwoman Kathryn E. Freed wrote to the Buildings Department, echoing those concerns.
"This problem is not unique to this project," the letter said. "Several other buildings in lower Manhattan have been renovated without attention to this critical safety issue. Even a minor fire in one of these buildings could cause a major catastrophe!"
Last month, the Buildings Department responded, saying, in part, that the builder "will be installing noncombustible bracing at required intervals."
Explaining his architectural design, Mr. Vance said: "We are creating a platform on top of the building, spanning from the west wall to the east wall, with three-foot-deep steel beams that transfer the weight of the entire four-story addition to the exterior masonry walls."
To deal with the issues raised by Councilwoman Freed and the neighbors' lawsuit, Mr. Vance said, it was decided to add fireproof steel bracing within the existing fourth floor.
"What they were concerned about is lateral stability," he said. "If you are standing up and someone stands on your shoulders you're wobbly -- laterally unstable. But if you're sitting on the ground and someone stands on your shoulders, you wouldn't wobble as much."
"The fourth floor," Mr. Vance said, "is where the walls are thinnest. And we have, through quantifiable calculation, determined that with the fourth-floor steel beams, every joist in the building could be removed and it would still be stable." On that basis, and with other issues addressed, the lawsuit filed by the board of the neighboring building was settled.
Asked if she was satisfied, Councilwoman Freed said yes and no.
"What the Buildings Department originally approved lacked these additional safeguards," she said. "If the department is saying it is now safe, what was it before?"
While questions of load-bearing capacity are quantifiable, those of esthetics are, as usual, in the eye of the beholder.
The addition was designed to be "modern, distinct from the building below," Mr. Vance said. "We didn't want a Disneyland version of the old building."
For Ms. Freed, "it's an ugly addition, but ugly isn't against the law."
THREE miles north, a sleek, seemingly seamless building dominates Seventh Avenue between 23d and 24th Streets -- the 18-story, sandstone-hued Chelsea. Two years ago, it was a squat, rather featureless seven-story presence. Then, like 60 Warren Street, it sprouted.
But the Chelsea was no relic. When the seven-story base was built in 1987, the developer, the Lazar family, installed a foundation and skeletal beams to eventually bear their higher aspirations -- 11 more floors, an atrium and landscaped decks to blend smoothly with the existing facade.
Still, there were growing pains, particularly because people were already living in the building.
Work on the addition began in February 1997, but came to a halt when tenants went on rent strike to demand compensation for the inconvenience caused by construction -- a dispute eventually settled in Housing Court with the landlord, Ethan H. Lazar, granting one month's free rent to existing tenants.
Compensation, however, could not ameliorate inconvenience.
"For the first few weeks the noise was almost intolerable," said Guy Winch, a psychologist who lives on the sixth floor. "As it went up, it got less."
Dr. Winch, who had recently moved into the building, said that "on one hand I was getting reassurance from management that they were doing it by the book and, on the other, people were going around like Chicken Little."
"My experience was," he said, "it was comparatively not dirty. And if anything went wrong, they were on top of it. I had a couple of leaks and they were fixed within 10 minutes. I called and they came right up. But I'm not saying that was everyone's experience."
Certainly not Salvatore Randazzo's.
Mr. Randazzo, a computer consultant and head of the tenants' association, lives and works on what had been the top floor of the Chelsea. "I have a tape recording of Mr. Lazar," Mr. Randazzo said. "His exact quote was: 'The noise will be a whisper in the distance.' Not so."
"It went on for months," Mr. Randazzo said: "Relentless pounding, jackhammering. Grunge covering everything; you couldn't open the windows. Water damage because of leaks. Total disruption to anyone's life style, especially for people at home during the day." Mr. Lazar declined to comment.
Asked if it was worth the legal battles, the uproar, Mr. Randazzo said: "Well, of course, it's nice now, it's done. But we put in countless hours to fight for a fair rent abatement and, really, to create a safe environment for people living under a construction zone. If landlords, the Buildings Department, the Mayor's office implement initiatives that take into account residents' safety and quality of life, then, yes, it was worth it."
What the contentiousness swirling around piggybacking is all about -- unused development rights -- is commonly referred to as air rights. And Sybil Pollet, a land-use lawyer, believes prospective renters and buyers should be aware that the little building next door offers no guarantee of permanent sunlight, air circulation or that spectacular view.
"Every district in the city has a designated floor-area ratio, or F.A.R., determined by planners' studies relating to building heights in the district and what they think is appropriate going forward," Ms. Pollet explained. The ratios are written into the city's Zoning Resolution, adopted in 1961.
"What you can build is based on this F.A.R., multiplied by the area of the lot," Ms. Pollet said. "That determines the maximum floor area for the entire building."
For example, if the F.A.R. for a particular district is 4, and the lot size is 100 by 100, or 10,000 square feet, then the building is allowed a total of 40,000 square feet of floor space -- subject, of course, to regulations about setbacks, side yards and distance from the street.
When a building has not used all of its allowable floor area, the air rights can be transferred, typically to contiguous properties. Or, the unused floor area can be used by a developer to piggyback onto the existing low-rise building.
"If you want to protect your view and you are concerned about the next building acquiring air rights from an adjacent property," Ms. Pollet said, "you need to do some research in the Office of the City Register" -- or insist that your lawyer exercise due diligence in examining the records.
"You look at the tax map for contiguous properties that are potential sources of air rights," Ms. Pollet continued, typically low buildings or vacant lots. Complicating matters, however, is the fact that a building down the block or across the street may have unused development rights that could eventually cast their shadow.
That specter so haunted residents of a co-op on Riverside Drive at 86th Street that the police were called in on the day two years ago when construction started for a 10-story addition atop a five-story town house on the adjacent lot. The lot is 25 feet wide.
It was, perhaps, the most dramatic moment in a long legal struggle that, with a twist, ended only last January.
The turn-of-the-last-century town house, called the House of Free Russia, had served as a haven for Russian emigres since the 1917 Revolution. But it was left out of the Upper West Side Historic District that the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission created in 1990 -- rendering it ripe for development.
"Old buildings should not be used as footstools for the exploitation efforts of developers," said Arlene Simon, president of Landmark West, a nonprofit preservation group.
Residents of the Normandy, the 18-story co-op adjacent to the House of Free Russia, agreed -- and filed suit to prohibit construction.
"We were not only saving the views," said Elisha Birnbaum, president of the Normandy board. "Our building has two wings with a big courtyard inside and if they had built this thing, it would have been a dark courtyard. It would have blocked light and air to more than 100 apartments."
JEFFREY DIAMOND, a partner in the law firm hired by the Normandy, Marcus, Rosenberg and Diamond, said, "We found a restrictive covenant in the deed from the turn of the century, which gave us the grounds to fight the building."
The covenant, dated March 12, 1900, read, in part: "No tenement flat or apartment house shall be erected on the premises." And so, on April 24, 1997, Justice Louise Gruner Gans of State Supreme Court in Manhattan issued a preliminary injunction barring construction.
But when it came to a permanent injunction, Justice Gans changed her position, citing the fact that the Normandy -- built in 1939 -- had itself violated the covenant.
In her decision, she wrote: "The Normandy, itself 18 stories high, seeks to avoid the suffocating effect which the presence of a 13- to 15-story structure only 10 feet away from its northeastern flank is likely to create. Yet construction of the Normandy created the same effect to the detriment of 349 West 86th Street."
"Despite the obvious undesirability of the proposed building to the Normandy," the justice continued, "it is inequitable to prevent defendants from developing 349 West 86th Street simply because construction of the Normandy violated the restrictive covenant first. Plaintiff has not come into a court of equity with the clean hands necessary to entitle it to enforce the restrictive covenant."
In January, after arduous negotiations, said Mr. Birnbaum, the Normandy bought the air rights above the town house for $1.35 million.

HEADLINE: POLITICS;
Referendum Is Set on Where Lottery Money Goes

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
Thirty years ago, voters approved a constitutional amendment by a 5-to-1 margin to permit New Jersey to begin a lottery. The amendment specified that the money raised -- now some $700 million a year -- must go to "state institutions."
After all that time, and all that money, some lawmakers recently got upset because according to state treasurers, "state institutions" has included penal institutions. 
 As a result, a referendum will appear on the ballot Nov. 2 as question No. 3 to fine-tune the the New Jersey Constitution to stipulate that lottery proceeds cannot go to benefit or support prison inmates.
The actual fiscal impact of this referendum will be minimal. The issue came to a head while former Treasurer James DiEleuterio was in office, and he openly told lawmakers that the referendum really had no point.
Some revenues are specifically earmarked by law or by the Constitution. Gasoline tax revenue, for instance, can only go to support the debts of the Transportation Trust Fund. Unemployment insurance taxes are supposed to go into the reserves used to pay out unemployment benefits.
But generally, most state revenue goes into a general coffer and is spent for general purposes. Such is the case with lottery funds. The loosely defined dedication to "state institutions and state aid for education" is a category that comprises at least half of the $19.5 billion state budget. Lottery dollars can be spent anywhere within those broad confines.
Mr. DiEleuterio said it was a matter of bookkeeping to align lottery revenue next to prison spending. The referendum, if approved, would require a change in this bookkeeping, and would not disrupt prison or education financing.
Lawmakers including Senator John Matheussen, Republican from Gloucester, and Senator Raymond Zane, a Democrat from Gloucester, claimed the use of lottery funds for prisons had been kept a secret. They said voters in 1969 intended for the money to benefit school children and the aging, not criminals.
Mr. DiEleuterio disagreed with the secrecy charge, noting that the annual budgets have always been plainly public documents incorporated into legislation.
But the treasurer amd governor have no say on proposals to amend the state Constitution. Such questions are placed on the ballot by the Legislature, and the Senate and Assembly passed this item unanimously.
Senator Robert Littell, a Republican from Sussex, was a member of the state Assembly in 1969 when he wrote the lottery law. He said it was plain the financing would go to all kinds of institutions. "The truth of the matter is that it was very clear when we passed it," he said during Senate debate in July.
Still, the Senator backed the idea of having a referendum
"I think it is good idea to give the public a say on this," he said.
 
The Question Before the Voters
Following is the text of Public Question No. 3 and the interpretive statement that will appear on the ballot Nov. 2:
Ballot Question: Shall the amendment to Article IV, Section VII, paragraph 2 of the Constitution agreed to by the Legislature, providing that state lottery net proceeds shall not be used to pay for the confinement, housing, supervision or treatment of, or education programs for, adult criminal offenders or juveniles adjudged delinquent or for the construction, staffing, support, maintenance or operation of an adult or juvenile correctional facility or institution, be approved?
Interpretive Statement: This constitutional amendment would provide that state lottery funds would not be used in any way to support prisons or prison programs. It specifically provides that lottery funds would not be used to pay for the confinement, housing, supervision or treatment of, or education programs for, adult criminal offenders or juveniles adjudged delinquent or for the construction, staffing, support, maintenance or operation of an adult or juvenile correctional facility or institution. Lottery funds could continue to be used to support other state institutions, such as state hospitals and state veterans homes, and for state aid for education.

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
September Unemployment Rate Stays Below 5 Percent

BYLINE: By KAREN DeMASTERS 

 BODY:
New Jersey's unemployment rate was under 5 percent in September, for the 23d month in a row, and the number of people employed continued to climb, the state Department of Labor said last week.
The unemployment rate was 4.7 percent, down from 4.8 percent for August, but still above the national average of 4.2 percent for August and September. 
 "We are at virtually full employment," said Brian Burns, a spokesman for the Department of Labor.
The number of people working rose by 6,600 in September to 3.8 million, a number that has gone up in each of the last eight months. The unemployment rate was at its lowest in February, at 4.1 percent and hit 4.9 percent in June, its highest this year. KAREN DeMASTERS

HEADLINE: MIDSTREAM;
When Late IsToo Late

BYLINE: By JAMES SCHEMBARI; James Schembari is an editor at The Times. His column on the prime earning, spending and striving years appears the fourth Sunday of each month. E-mail: jimschem@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
AS baby boomers, we have had amazing fortune. A strong economy has given many of us comfortable careers and the stock market has made us more comfortable still. Many in our group are successful, wealthy and not nearly done yet.
But that sense of endless possibility is causing us to make a familiar mistake. Although we are prescient enough to prepare for our children's education and our retirement, we have the same inability as past generations to contemplate our own deaths while we're young. That means many of us are not preparing wills or doing the other things that smooth the way for our heirs. 
 "Boomers are probably the best generation as far as investing," said Stuart Kessler of Goldstein Golub Kessler, an accounting firm in Manhattan, "but in other areas of planning, like wills, they are one of the least-equipped generations."
Mr. Kessler said boomers were also falling short in other areas. They lack disability insurance, a durable power of attorney if they become incapacitated, or even a simple letter of instruction -- telling survivors where, for example, to find the key to the safe-deposit box.
I've bought disability insurance, but I lack the others -- including a will. I keep putting it off because it's not a priority. Besides, if I die without a will, won't my wife end up with everything anyway?
Not true, Mr. Kessler said. In my state, Connecticut, assets held solely in my name would be divided automatically among her and the children. Generally, states divide the assets by giving the surviving spouse a portion of the assets, often $50,000, then splitting the remainder 50-50. New York and New Jersey do it that way; in Connecticut, the spouse gets the first $100,000. When there are children of a previous marriage involved, the formula is often adjusted.
David M. English, a law professor at the University of Missouri at Columbia, said that only 14 states, mostly in the Midwest and West, give the surviving spouse 100 percent of the assets.
A 50-50 split may sound benevolent, but my wife may need all the money to keep the household running. Although the court would appoint my wife to be the children's guardian, it may name someone else, like a lawyer or a bank, to watch over their money until they are 18. These guardians charge a fee for that service, which includes making sure that money is handled appropriately.
Depending on the circumstances, Mr. Kessler said, some courts would make the surviving parent pay for school, or the hiring of a nanny while the parent worked, out of the parent's, not the child's, share. Mr. Kessler recommends a will that leaves assets to the parent and money in trust for the children, with the parent as the trustee.
Albert L. Sica, 37, of Staten Island, doesn't have a will, but is seeing a lawyer about getting one. He always put it off, but now that his children are 10 and 13, he recognizes the need to provide for them.
"I knew we needed to get a will, but it's not like we have $20 million in the bank," Mr. Sica said. "It was not in the forefront of our minds, but, God forbid, if my wife and I were to die, what about the kids?"
Mr. Kessler said that having to make decisions about the children sometimes kept people from making a will. One reason "is that they can't agree on the guardians for the children" if the parents die together.
Charles Sabatino, assistant director of the American Bar Association's Commission on Legal Problems of the Elderly, didn't get a will until he and his wife were leaving for a trip overseas many years ago, without their two children. The night before they left, he said, they were in a lawyer's office signing documents. The biggest point of discussion was who would take care of the children. They decided on his sister-in-law.
"People often don't start thinking about estate planning until they have little kids and are about to travel," he said. "Kids are a great motivator."
The biggest motivator may be our own parents. "Boomers think they'll live forever," said Scott R. Severans of Severans & Bennett, an Indianapolis law firm specializing in the elderly. "But we will see a surge of boomers getting wills when they encounter their parents' failure to plan and the mess it creates or the relief, at a moment of crisis, that their parents have a plan."

HEADLINE: FIVE QUESTIONS : for JUAN SOMAVIA;
Making Markets Work for All

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
FOR decades, the International Labor Organization has been derided as an ineffectual, anticapitalistic talking shop, when it has been noticed at all. But its new director-general, Juan Somavia, is intent on changing all that.
With 2,300 employees and a $480 million budget, the Geneva-based organization, an agency of the United Nations, has broad responsibilities, among them leading the worldwide fight against abuse of child labor, promoting job creation in poor countries and defending workers' rights to form unions. Mr. Somavia arrived in March believing that the organization need not be anti-business to achieve its objectives. 
 With his thick beard, Mr. Somavia, a 58-year-old Chilean diplomat, looks like an Amish farmer, but he talks like a pragmatic politician and social theorist. He served as Chile's representative to the United Nations and was chief organizer of the 1995 World Summit for Social Development in Copenhagen before taking his new post.
Mr. Somavia took time from attending the A.F.L.-C.I.O. convention in Los Angeles to discuss his plans. Here are excerpts from the conversation. STEVEN GREENHOUSE
 
Q. Why should Americans pay attention to the International Labor Organization?
A. The I.L.O.'s Philadelphia Declaration from 1944 stated that poverty anywhere constitutes a danger to prosperity everywhere. You can't be indifferent to what's happening in the rest of the world. The global economy is not distributing its benefits sufficiently to people -- to workers in America or to workers around the world. If I had to synthesize what the I.L.O. is trying to do, it is, "How do we make markets work for everyone?"
What does the I.L.O. do when it finds that markets are not working? We have to promote entrepreneurship. Unless you generate more work in the world, we'll continue to have a series of problems. And to insure decent work, there's no substitute for organize, organize, organize.
Q. The I.L.O. has long had a reputation as a lethargic bureaucracy. How will you reinvigorate it?
A. I want to basically do two things: focus and modernize. And I plan to concentrate on four areas. First is protecting the rights of people at work. The second is employment and job creation, access to work. That's what people in the street want.
The third focus is social protection like Social Security, pensions, safe work. A central reality of the global economy is that a majority of people don't have basic social protections of any kind. The fourth focus is dialogue. The I.L.O. is one of the only places where you have employers, workers and government engaging in dialogue, talking things out to find common solutions.
The global economy is bringing I.L.O. issues to center stage, and consequently I arrive at a moment that we have a very good mandate. But we have to be much more pointed in how we go about it.
Q. Sometimes your goals to create jobs and eliminate poverty seem to overlap with those at the World Bank and International Monetary Fund. How do you avoid conflict?
A. I was very glad to see the I.M.F. and World Bank put the elimination of poverty on their agenda. Our job is to be a social pillar, to make sure they're taking care of the social dimension. Many of the things that were done to make structural adjustment work meant that an enormous number of companies went broke. Somebody has to have an eye on what happens to people.
We in the international community have to agree on the issues on which we should all be pushing in the same direction. I suggest the reduction of poverty, creating employment (it's the first step out of poverty) and having more inclusive societies.
Q. How do you respond to critics who say your organization's agenda is anti-business?
A. Our historical mandate is to look at life at work. Our mandate is to promote workers' rights, but that's not the only thing we're about. We're also about tripartism between employers, workers and government. We're about dialogue, about creating jobs and entrepreneurialism.
Q. Why is the new child labor convention so important?
A. There is a growing consciousness that we should not have child labor. Child labor is a complex issue. It's strongly linked to development and whether parents have a job or whether children can go to school.
The new Convention on the Worst Forms of Child Labor was approved in June, and now it has to be ratified by different countries. It was the first time you had global unanimity on child labor issues.
There are a lot of tensions on child labor, and some countries have not ratified existing child labor conventions, but finally we have been able to put together complete unanimity on the worst forms of child labor that should be banned -- prostitution, pornography, hazardous mining, serving as soldiers. The most important thing is to ban all of the morally abhorrent situations that no family would like its children to live through.

SECTION: Section 12; Page 1; Column 1; Automobiles 

LENGTH: 1687 words

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Fiat Multipla and Ford Ka;
Making the Scene, Avant-Garde Europeans Hit New York's Streets

BYLINE: By JAMES G. COBB 

 BODY:
AZ SNIDER was making his way through the afternoon crush of pedestrians in Rockefeller Center when the sight of a green, four-wheeled, six-passenger frog stopped him cold.
"Man, that is one ugly car," Mr. Snider, of Manhattan, volunteered even before he could be asked his opinion of the Fiat Multipla parked near the "Today" show studio. Just short of dumbfounded, he seemed unable to take his eyes off the oddly shaped mini-minivan, which has sold briskly in Europe in the year since it went on sale. After sitting at the wheel, though, and poking around in the spacious cabin, Mr. Snyder assessed the car more charitably, conceding that the unusual design incorporated a number of tricks that made the Multipla practical and pleasant. He even mellowed a bit toward the styling. 
 "It's ugly," he affirmed again before disappearing into the rush hour. "But I'm not into style. Look at me -- I wear bow ties."
Mr. Snider was among many New Yorkers brought up short by the Multipla and by another tiny car, the Ford Ka, that stood out in Manhattan like snowplows in Miami. Motorists pointed in traffic and crowds gathered wherever the two cars were parked, proving that although many Manhattanites are blase about automobiles, they respond enthusiastically to daring designs and the lure of the new and different.
Consider the success of the Museum of Modern Art's recent exhibition entitled "Different Roads: Automobiles for the Next Century," which closed last month. The Multipla and the Ka were among the nine futuristic auto designs in the exhibit, which was organized by Christopher Mount, assistant curator of the museum's department of architecture and design, with Phil Patton as curatorial consultant.
While new to Americans, the two cars are on their way to becoming common sights on the streets of Europe. But neither is destined to be sold here in the land of the garantuan sport utility, where faint demand for small, fuel-efficient, odd-looking vehicles cannot justify the costs of meeting American crash and emissions standards. Furthermore, Fiat has not had an auto-sales network in North America since 1983.
There is another hurdle: Neither car offers an automatic transmission. That is no problem overseas, where small-car drivers disdain automatics for sapping the power and reducing the economy of tiny engines. But relatively few Americans are able or willing to shift for themselves.
Nor is efficiency high on most American car shoppers' lists of essential characteristics. Still, a number of recent designs, including two inexpensive cars that have just gone on sale in the United States, the Ford Focus and Toyota Echo, demonstrate that economy can happily co-exist with spacious cabins, distinctive styling, responsive handling and people-friendly features.
The Ka and Multipla go a couple of steps further, with designs that may be too extreme for American tastes. While successful as hands-off displays in the Modern's sculpture garden, does their function match their form when they roll onto crowded streets? Can they be appreciated for the way they drive and ride, as well as for their innovative use of space?
Fiat and Ford, which had brought extra cars to New York in conjunction with the Modern's exhibit, made them available recently for test drives. Both the Multipla and the Ka proved even more impressive in traffic than as static sculptures of sheet metal. Indeed, each car offers answers to some questions posed by internal-combustion cars in the concrete jungle of New York.
 
Multipla: Space Before Style
Beyond the Fiat Multipla's frog-eyed face -- due to the rounded front and high-beam headlamps up near the windshield, like amphibian eyes -- the car is most striking for its bolt-upright side windows. "It is a vertical car," said Paolo Vannini, vice president for corporate communications at Fiat USA.
Though the high design looks ungainly, its beauty lies within, where six tall passengers sit high and comfortably. Huge windows make the cabin exceptionally airy. The driver's view is superb, if not as high as that from the biggest sport utilities (though one cannot see even a bit of the downward-sloping hood from behind the wheel).
The name of the car, which sells in Italy for the rough equivalent of $16,000 to $20,000, denotes its multiplicity of uses -- as sedan, station wagon, van or what the Europeans call a multi-purpose vehicle, akin to an American sport utility -- as well as its four potential power sources. The car's impressive interior volume defies its overall length of 157 inches -- half a foot shorter than a Volkswagen Golf. The space trick was accomplished by topping a low basic body module (the working part of the car, which is no larger than necessary) with a high greenhouse of glass for the passengers. A low waistline separates the two pieces and forms a line atop the fenders. The side windows are as tall as the body beneath them, and because they do not curve inward, they do not intrude on passenger space.
Another benefit of this design is safety. In a crash, the lower module absorbs the impact, in theory, instead of the cabin.
Getting in or out is easy, thanks to high, wide doors and seats that are comfortably but not excessively high. There are three identical seats up front and three in the back; they are all equally roomy. They can also can be detached and removed by lifting latches -- flush with the floor and designed with Italian flair. The middle seat up front, in fact, can be replaced with a console that includes an insulated box that can be heated or chilled. A small refrigerator can slip into the spot occupied by the middle rear seat.
The cabin floor is flat, and there is a surprising amount of cargo space behind the second row of seats. There are storage compartments everywhere, including neat bins that fold out of the roof above the sun visors. Controls are clustered in the center of the dashboard, including the manual shifter, which protrudes from a pod to the driver's right and frees the floor for legs. With the speedometer in the middle, the space ahead is available for the screen of an optional navigation system. This screen can also be plugged in on the passenger side and operated by remote, giving children in the rear something to occupy their time.
The interior is flamboyantly Italian, down to the modern fabric that covers the top of the dash, to the asymetrical sun visors -- one small, one huge -- and a tiny lid on the floor that lifts to reveal the ID number.
Its odd look is only part of what makes the Fiat different. It was brought to the Modern in part because of the choices of power sources it offers: gasoline only, diesel only, a dual Bi-Power system that can be switched from gasoline to natural gas and, yet to come, a gasoline-electric hybrid.
The car I drove in New York was the Bi-Power version, but its natural gas tanks were empty at the time. On gasoline, the four-cylinder engine (1.6 liters, 16 valves, 103 horsepower on gasoline) moved briskly through midtown traffic with three occupants on board. The car's small size, solid chassis and light, precise steering made it easy to maneuver around stopped cabs and slow trucks. With independent suspensions at front and rear, the car rode smoothly over streets ravaged by pre-millennium construction. The outside mirrors, which include a separate, convex portion for a wider view, retract electrically in tight quarters.
But it is inside where the Fiat makes the biggest impression. The roomy cabin; comfortable, flexible seats; excellent outward view, and well-though-out amenities lead one quickly to the thought that this would make an ideal taxicab in New York.
Indeed, Fiat is selling a taxi version in Europe. Big-boned New Yorkers would find a Multipla cab comforting, too, but they are unlikely to get a chance to hail one.
 
Ka: Commuting Module With Flair
While the Multipla seems a dandy alternative to yellow, metered Ford Crown Victorias, the Ford Ka has more room than a crowded car on the D train, handles a lot better than the M104 bus and offers some of the fun of in-line skates in a safer, weather-resistant package. It is a commuting device with style and a smile.
The Ka, in short, is a tiny city car -- too small to rate three letters, perhaps. Its layout is conventional (it uses the front-drive platform and 1.3-liter four-cylinder engine of the Ford Fiesta sold overseas), but the design is bright. The styling is New Edge, with rounded planes broken by creases, wrapped around a passenger cabin that is higher and more spacious than the exterior would lead one to believe.
To hold down costs in Europe, where cars are generally more expensive, Ford used cheap materials; the headliner is molded foam, and a thin feltlike material masquerades as carpeting. But there are plenty of clever touches, including an oval bin that pivots to reveal slots for cassette tapes on one side or a small, hinged storage box on the other. There are depressions in the floor, front and rear, that hold coins or other small items. A postmodern analog clock punctuates the minimalist dash.
In town, 60 horsepower never felt so good. The short-throw shifter is light and precise, and the Ka is geared to zoom when the light turns green. Quick steering lets the Ka dart around backed-up buses and trucks like a minnow in a school of tuna, and tiny curbside gaps become feasible parking spots. On a drive with Kathleen Hamilton, who works in Ford's New York office, we encountered a semi-truck backed up to a loading dock, blocking nearly the entire width of West 28th Street. After pausing for a second to judge the scant remaining space, we roared ahead and squeezed through the gap with fractions of an inch to spare.
And when we encountered a backup near the Lincoln Tunnel entrance from Ninth Avenue, we discovered that a fleet of Ka's could do much to relieve gridlock. Caught in the intersection as the light turned red, I shifted to first, gunned the engine and jammed in between a bus and a truck.
It is impossible to block the box in a car as a short as a Ka.
