HEADLINE: Fishing Gear Makers Are Now a Prize Catch

BYLINE: By KATE MURPHY 

 BODY:
LIKE toy and hardware makers before them, small manufacturers of fishing gear are being acquired by aggressive competitors looking to build economies of scale.
The sports-fishing equipment industry has long been the province of labor-of-love specialty companies -- supplying, say, just rubber bait for catching walleye in the Great Lakes region. Although several chief executives still answer their phones with a "Howdy do!," economic reality applies even to fishing tackle. 
 "You can't survive in this business working out of your garage anymore," said William H. Wilson, chief executive of Pradco Inc., a privately held company in Fort Smith, Ark., which owns 11 popular brands of fishing lures, including Smithwick and Quik-Hit, many of them acquired in the last five years.
Steve C. Greer, chief financial officer of the United States division of the Rapala Normark Corporation of Finland, another maker of fishing lures, said "product distribution is driven by the major marts and big-box sports chains who don't want to talk to you unless you can supply a range of products in large volume." Analysts say mass-market retailers and a handful of equally demanding cataloguers sell 75 percent of fishing tackle.
Sales in the industry -- encompassing lures, rods, reels, line and other accessories -- were estimated at $1.9 billion in the United States in 1998, and close to $3 billion worldwide. "It's a lot of little stuff that makes up a very big market," said Tom B. Doyle, vice president of information and research at the National Sporting Goods Association in Mount Prospect, Ill.
Rapala, with $106.6 million in sales -- nearly half in the United States -- went public late last year on the Helsinki Stock Exchange and used part of the proceeds to buy a competitor, Storm Manufacturing Inc. of Norman, Okla., for $13.2 million in January. After 59 years as a closely held family business specializing in hand-carved balsa wood lures, Rapala has "moved into acquisition mode," Mr. Greer said, to increase market share and capture "that all important peg space at Wal-Mart."
Similarly, Pure Fishing, a privately held company in Spirit Lake, Iowa, has bought out several tackle manufacturers, including the rod maker Fenwick in 1988 and, since 1995, the reel maker Abu Garcia, the Red Wolf line of fishing accessories and Coleman Family Fishing. Pure Fishing is known for its Berkley brand of bait and fishing line that was started in 1937 by the father of the current chief executive, Tom Bedell.
Also growing by acquisition are two other industry leaders, the Zebco Corporation of Tulsa, Okla., and Johnson Worldwide Associates of Sturtevant, Wis., which produces other outdoor equipment as well and is majority-owned by Samuel Johnson, the chairman of S. C. Johnson & Son, the household products company, and his family. Mid-level players like the Mason Tackle Company of Otisville, Mich., and the Castaway Rod Company of Conroe, Tex., have been buying competitors, too. Typical is Mason's recent purchase of the Hildebrant Corporation, a Logansport, Ind., company that is more than 100 years old.
It is better to buy existing brands than to create new ones, because "customers in this market tend to be extremely loyal to the old names," said Jeff Pontius, president of Zebco, a division of the Brunswick Corporation in Lake Forest, Ill.
"There's been so much consolidation, it's hard to keep track who belongs to who anymore," said Deborah Johnson, managing editor of Fishing Tackle Retailer, a trade magazine published in Montgomery, Ala.
Membership in the industry's trade organization, the American Sportsfishing Association based in Alexandria, Va., has declined to 450 members from 600 members in 1995. "But the number of products out there has remained pretty much the same," indicating that the decline results almost entirely from acquisitions, said Mike Hayden, president and chief executive of the association.
But consolidation is only one step in modernizing the tackle industry. Fishing is a seasonal sport, and the required gear varies by region and fish species.
"It's a very complex category to manage once you enter the broader market," said Mr. Bedell of Pure Fishing, which invested $4.5 million three years ago in a computerized inventory system and warehouse. "Before we were just like most everybody else in this business, writing out all the orders by hand."
PURE FISHING and others are also pouring money into research and development -- building huge aquariums, for example, to test how fish respond to new products.
By increasing product lines and updating technology, tackle companies are not only in a better position to serve the likes of Wal-Mart. The efforts also help them enter the almost untapped export market.
"Our read is that the U.S. market is essentially flat, and we need to look elsewhere to increase profits," particularly in recreational fishing hot spots in Asia, Australia and South America, said Mr. Pontius of Zebco, which has expanded its international operations 33 percent in the last five years.
Similarly, Pure Fishing has set up divisions in 11 countries since 1995.
Mr. Wilson, at Pradco, said the fishing tackle industry is "kind of behind" some others in globalization and consolidation. "It's probably because we spend so much time fishing," he said.

HEADLINE: An Oil Outsider Revives a Cartel

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
THE price of crude oil has doubled since early last year. Higher prices for gasoline, heating oil and other products are hitting every consumer's pocketbook.
Is OPEC flexing its muscles again? Not exactly. There's a new oil cartel in town, and after a shaky start two years ago, its members have achieved -- for now, at least -- the unity necessary to hold to their production quotas. And that means higher prices. 
 In a sense, this cartel is simply the 11 members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries plus two -- Mexico and Norway. But the world's oil-producing and exporting nations are wielding power this time around mainly because of a shove not from the Middle East but rather from Mexico -- and especially from its persistent energy minister, Luis K. Tellez, a novice in the world of oil.
When Mr. Tellez began his mission, he was worried about the devastating impact that falling oil prices were having on the economy in Mexico, which in 1997 relied on oil for 38 percent of its revenues. But his leadership has been felt the world over. "Without Tellez, this coalition would not have been possible," said Dr. Gary Ross, chief executive of PIRA Energy Group, a consulting firm based in Manhattan.
The coalition has shown such cohesion that some analysts predict that crude oil could rise to an extraordinary level -- $30 a barrel -- by the end of the year, a price not seen since January 1991, during the Persian Gulf war. Already, the price of crude oil has more than doubled, to $23.45 a barrel from $11 early this year.
Not that the coalition is home free. Prices hit $24 a barrel last month, but slipped back when traders thought they saw hints of cracks in the cartel's solidarity. After all, if one country breaks ranks, the cartel's tenuous grip on the world market could crumble.
For the moment, though, there seems little easing in the cartel's united front or in rising oil prices.
For one thing, the bullish global economy strengthens the group's grip. World oil inventories have been declining, but in the past year demand has been rising sharply. Most Western economies are in high gear, and as Asian economies have recovered from their turmoil last year, their need for oil has grown, too. World demand, now about 76 million barrels a day, could outrun supply by about three million barrels a day as early as this quarter, said Frederick Leuffer, an oil analyst at Bear Stearns.
"If the oil exporters stay with their cuts, inventories of oil will run down hard and push the price up to close to $30," Mr. Leuffer said, echoing a view shared by many oil experts. "Everyone is on the edge of their seat about when the discipline will break or when the first increase will be made in the production quotas."
EVERYTHING was different in the early months of 1998, when the coalition was forged. With oil prices at $15 to $16 a barrel, oil producers were hurting. Mexico was in particularly dire straits, forced to make a series of painful cuts in government spending that hit its people where it hurt most: in health, education and other basic services.
Mr. Tellez, an economist who had no previous experience in the oil industry, decided to try to steer the world's oil-producing nations in a new direction. When he became energy minister in 1997, the soft-spoken Mr. Tellez knew neither his colleagues nor much about the arcane world of oil politics.
But he jumped headlong into the oil patch, and within a year he was able to persuade a few key oil ministers and officials from Saudi Arabia and Venezuela to form a new coalition of oil-producing nations.
"It certainly demonstrates a new configuration," said Daniel Yergin, the chairman of Cambridge Energy Research Associates, a consulting group based in Cambridge, Mass. "Mexico's role has become central, whereas before it was more peripheral."
Unknown in the industry just two years ago, Mr. Tellez has become a force. "Tellez is now a significant player in the world of oil," Mr. Yergin said. How long he remains one depends upon Mexico itself, for he made no promises about Mexico's participation in the group beyond the end of next year.
In some ways, Mr. Tellez seems an unlikely world-shaker. A short, slight 41-year-old with receding dark hair, he was trained as an economist specializing in international finance, and his experience in government had been largely with a contentious project that gave tenant farmers title to the land they farmed.
In a recent interview in the lobby of the Four Seasons Hotel in Manhattan, where he spoke at a meeting of oil industry experts, Mr. Tellez reminisced about his plunge into the murky waters of oil diplomacy.
After getting his doctorate in economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1986, Mr. Tellez, who runs and plays tennis to remain trim, taught economics at his alma mater in Mexico for a time.
In 1987, he joined the Finance Ministry, and two years later helped to put together a plan, led by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, that reduced Mexico's foreign debt. In 1990, he moved to the Agriculture Ministry, and in 1994 was made chief of staff to President Ernesto Zedillo, whom he had known since his early days as an economist.
Then it was on to the Energy Ministry, where the last months of 1997 were particularly bleak, he recalled, with oil prices falling to $17 a barrel in December.
At one point, "we sold a shipment of oil for $7 a barrel," he said. "Such a price has not been seen since the Great Depression." As revenues plunged, Mexico had to cut its budget twice.
Oil producers seemed unable to change the disastrous policies that led to the price spiral. But Mr. Tellez managed to break through this wall of paralysis, mainly with what he called "gentlemen's agreements" among Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and Mexico.
In February 1998, he began his effort to break the logjam by consulting with President Zedillo, who gave him his full support. He then contacted Erwin Arrieta, oil minister of Venezuela, a founding member of OPEC. Mr. Arrieta agreed on the need for action, and the two men met in Miami, discussing, among other things, the possibility of Mexico forging a coalition with Norway, another major non-OPEC producer.
It was an unusual initiative, one that could be politically touchy back in Mexico, which as a big oil exporter -- particularly to the United States -- had long kept its distance from OPEC. Any sign of change would raise concerns that Mexico was giving up its carefully guarded independence.
Still, with the support of Mr. Arrieta, and using various oil experts as intermediaries, he tried to find out whether Ali Naimi, the Saudi oil minister, would be willing to talk to him. Word came back that he would.
The Saudis, who as the world's largest exporters play a leading role in OPEC, had helped set off the latest crisis in oil prices by pushing through a higher production ceiling for OPEC late in 1997. Mr. Naimi's support would thus be crucial in any attempt to halt the slide.
WHEN Mr. Tellez called him at his office in Riyadh in February 1998, he found that they had similar concerns. Their countries' budgets were being torn to shreds by falling oil revenue, and no one seemed to be taking any action to limit production.
"It was simple," Mr. Tellez said. "It was important to do something."
Mr. Naimi invited him and Mr. Arrieta for secret talks -- the first time a Mexican oil minister had been granted such a meeting.
On the way, Mr. Tellez made a stop in Norway, also a big oil exporter, to see what position that country would take. The Norwegian energy minister, Anne Enger Lahnstein, and other Norwegian officials listened to him, he said, but did not commit themselves. Only later did Norway, which also had a tradition of not cooperating with OPEC, go along with production cuts.
With only one assistant in tow, Mr. Tellez flew to Riyadh, where he and Mr. Arrieta, who arrived with a full staff on a private jet, sat down with Mr. Naimi in a luxurious official guest house in March 1998.
With oil prices still languishing around $14 a barrel, the three wasted little time, taking only one day to agree to cut the coalition's production by 1.6 million to 2 million barrels a day.
Mr. Naimi had the formidable, and delicate, task of getting other major OPEC producers to agree. Through an intense day of telephone calls, he lined up the often fractious group to support a cut of 1.6 million barrels a day.
Because their talks had been secret -- and because Mexico had never before cooperated with OPEC at such a level -- the announcement of the deal on March 22 came as a surprise to experts and analysts.
Despite skepticism that the new group would be able to stick together, oil prices began to recover quickly, from $14.65 a barrel in March to $17 a month later.
The recovery, though, was short-lived. With most Asian economies going into a severe downturn and demand falling from big oil importers like Japan and South Korea, the glut of oil started to build again.
Especially remarkable in the story of this ad hoc group has been its members' willingness to abide by the cuts through thick and thin -- even when prices kept falling last year because of the decline of the Asian economies. Skeptics were even more stunned when the group agreed on an additional series of production cuts this year -- totaling about 5.3 million barrels a day -- after its initial cuts last year.
According to Mr. Yergin, the author of "The Prize," a history of the oil industry (Simon & Schuster, 1991), it was the "specter of $5-a-barrel oil" -- a price so low that it would devastate the economies of many oil-exporting nations -- that inspired the group's cohesion.
"The source of the discipline is dire necessity and trauma that these countries went through because of the collapse in prices," he added.
And Dr. Ross, of PIRA, said: "What these countries found is that they have a common interest. The low oil prices were extremely painful to them since it cut their revenue."
Another reason, he said, has been the willingness of political leaders of the three nations that lead the coalition -- Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and Mexico -- to back up their top oil officials.
"Everyone thought OPEC was declining and losing members," he added, particularly after 1997, when the organization seemed to lack the will to break the disastrous pattern of pumping more oil, even as prices were plunging.
BUT now, again, a single coalition accounts for more than half of world oil production, a share that OPEC itself had not held since the 1970's. And this cartel could be around for a while. Many longtime observers of OPEC and the oil industry say that the new coalition will remain potent and that it could well be a stabilizing influence on world oil prices over the long term.
One vital component of this stability is Mr. Tellez's effort: by bringing Mexico and Norway together with OPEC, he has eliminated a big reason that past productions cuts have often been ineffective.
In the old days, Mexico and Norway often acted as a thorn in the side of OPEC. When the cartel tried to cut production, they pumped all the oil they could. Sure enough, OPEC members would follow suit to protect their markets, and OPEC's resolve to keep prices stable would crumble.
This coalition also has a different look. Even after two years, the group remains informal. While OPEC has a large staff and an elaborate headquarters in Vienna, the new group has no name or offices. It subsists largely on the growing trust among the sharply different personalities of the coalition's energy officials.
They communicate mainly by telephone, E-mail and periodic meetings.
"We're getting to know each other," Mr. Tellez said. "Building up trust is very important." And he saw no reason to change this informal approach.
Trust will be vital if the cartel is to last. Mr. Tellez said that current prices were not too high and that he saw no reason for the group to increase production. He said that there were no plans to discuss such a step at a meeting to be held on Nov. 17 in Riyadh with Saudi and Venezuelan officials.
Oil traders clearly thought differently. When word of the meeting leaked out, crude oil, which had been trading in the $24 range, slid to $22.
Mr. Leuffer said the market's reaction might have strengthened the group's resolve not to raise production, since it proved what could happen if it showed the least sign that it might do so.
The United States, of course, looks on from a different angle, because it imports 56 percent of its oil, making its economy vulnerable if prices soar. For now, though, higher energy prices have not had a large-enough effect to fuel inflation, said Patrick Jackman, an economist at the Bureau of Labor Statistics, which puts together the Consumer Price Index.
Average prices for regular gasoline have risen from 95 cents a gallon last winter to about $1.29, and heating oil this winter will cost about $1.04 a gallon, up from 80 cents last winter.
"Nothing bad has happened yet, but it is something you have to keep your eye on," said William Dudley, the chief United States economist for Goldman, Sachs, adding that the core inflation rate was running at 2 percent so far the year.
Still, if the price of crude oil keeps rising, the impact on the American economy will be substantial, Mr. Jackman said, because oil is used in so many consumer products.
The full impact is yet to be felt in Mexico, either. Higher crude oil prices have helped the Government begin to recover from a huge drop in revenues in 1998, when spending cuts caused widespread hardship. Mexico's oil revenues totaled $9.7 billion in 1997, plunged to $6.4 billion in 1998 and are estimated to recover to $8.5 billion this year. But Mr. Tellez -- who can claim a great deal of credit for that recovery -- is not being hailed as a hero. That is because the money is going mainly to shore up the battered peso, not to restore services.
NONE of this has been easy for Mr. Tellez, who for most of his career was rarely in the limelight. When oil prices were still falling in 1998, even after Mexico and others had made cuts, he bore the brunt of increasing criticism in the press and among some oil experts in Mexico that his initiative had only added to the misery. Mexico had cut its production but now, with plunging prices, it was getting even less revenue, the argument went.
Mr. Tellez recalled that at one point even his mentor, President Zedillo, had second thoughts.
"Every time you get together with your friends the price goes down," he recalled the President telling him once in jest. "So be careful."

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES;
In an Inflation Measure, A Way to Pan for Gold

BYLINE: By MARK HULBERT; Mark Hulbert is editor of The Hulbert Financial Digest, a newsletter based in Annandale, Va. His column on investment strategies appears every other week.
E-mail: strategy@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
WHAT makes gold soar will eventually make stocks swoon.
That simple truth explains much about the recent downward path of the stock market. The gold market came to life well in advance of the Dow's most recent correction, which started in late August. 
 The price of gold is up 20 percent since it began its rise on July 20, despite weakness last week. Moreover, gold mutual funds gained an average of 19.2 percent during the third quarter, according to Lipper Inc., the research firm, after a 2 percent increase in the second quarter, the first time in four years that gold funds have produced back-to-back quarterly gains.
Many investors may not make the connection between the rise of gold and the selloff in stocks because they see gold's rally as artificial. That is not entirely unreasonable, because the sharpest part of the rally was seemingly prompted by an external event that did not have much to do with gold's economic fundamentals -- the announcement on Sept. 26 by European central banks that they would limit their sales of bullion. The rally has been propelled further by another nonfundamental factor: Short covering from traders who had been aggressively shorting gold .
Still, after studying gold forecasting models tracked by The Hulbert Financial Digest, I have concluded that the fundamental cause for gold's rally was not the central banks' announcement, but increasing inflationary pressures, against which gold is a traditional hedge. In fact, one of the most successful models bases its buy and sell signals on inflationary trends, and it had turned bullish on gold in mid-September, well before the steepest part of the rise.
This forecasting model was devised by the Institute for Econometric Research of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., a newsletter publisher. The model is simple, based not on the absolute inflation level but on whether or not inflation is accelerating. Specifically, it compares the Consumer Price Index's most recent 12-month percentage change with the corresponding reading three months earlier. If the most recent reading is higher, then the model is bullish, and investing in gold funds and shares is recommended.
For example, the Labor Department announced in mid-September that the Consumer Price Index was at 167.1, or 2.3 percent higher than it was a year earlier. In June, three months before that announcement, the index was at 166.2, or 2.1 percent higher than in June 1998. The model thus indicated that inflation was accelerating, and it issued a buy signal for gold. (That trend was supported by the consumer price report last Tuesday, which showed inflation over the previous 12 months at 2.6 percent; in July, that figure was 2.0 percent.)
BECAUSE conditions were already ripe for a bullish move in gold, I believe that if the central banks hadn't provided the straw that broke the gold market's bearish back, sending gold prices up 14 percent in a week, something else would have. Those who analyzed the inflation data might well have seen what was coming -- 11 days ahead of the central banks' move.
Though the institute's record is not perfect, it is impressive. Over the last 15 years, by my calculations, an investor who switched a portfolio in and out of the gold market on the model's signals would have gained 2.6 percent, annualized. That doesn't seem striking until it is compared with the 0.2 percent loss, annualized, that he would have suffered by buying and holding bullion.
Picking specific gold-mining stocks is trickier. Many companies sell their gold production in the futures market. The hedging protects against declines in gold's price. But it means that they won't be benefiting immediately from higher gold prices. That is why one of the favorite mining companies among gold newsletters is Franco-Nevada Mining of Toronto, whose policy is to not hedge its production.
Among newsletters I track, the most-recommended no-load gold fund is American Century Global Gold. The stocks it holds are geographically diversified, use different hedging strategies and represent both high- and low-cost producers.

HEADLINE: GRASS-ROOTS BUSINESS;
Helping the Little Guy Fight the Big Guy

BYLINE: By JOEL KOTKIN 

DATELINE: LONG BEACH, Calif.

 BODY:
FOR two decades, Michael Sheldrake was the coffee king of Second Street here. With virtually no competition within 20 miles, his Polly's Gourmet Coffee dominated the market in the affluent Belmont Shores section of the city.
But Mr. Sheldrake's idyll, like those of many other small-business owners, was disrupted by the coming of the "category killer" chains. In his case, he found himself up against arguably the most formidable mass retailer of this decade, Starbucks. Polly's sales fell 10 to 15 percent when a Starbucks store appeared a few blocks away in Long Beach in 1994. And in 1998, another Starbucks opened just 78 yards from Polly's. 
 "We were getting despondent," Mr. Sheldrake said. "We were just trying to hang on. We had a chain problem and didn't know what to do."
Perhaps no phenomenon has more profoundly transformed American Main Streets in the 1990's than the "chain problem." From tony Annapolis, Md., to the Melrose district of Hollywood to bohemian Harvard Square in Cambridge, Mass., retail streetscapes have been steadily homogenized as heavily marketed national chains have outgunned and displaced locally owned rivals, whose resources and organization generally pale in comparison with the likes of Starbucks.
But the way Polly's responded to the chain problem demonstrates that resistance is not futile. In a turn of events that suggests some hope for small-scale retailers, Polly's fought back, and has managed to grow and thrive even with two Starbucks in its neighborhood. Sales rose 40 percent in 1998 and are on a pace for a 30 percent rise this year.
With help from a retail consultant, Bob Phibbs, who specializes in helping independent businesses cope with chain-store competitors, Polly's decided to take aim at Starbucks in two ways: beating the chain at its own game by operating even more efficiently, and exploiting the inherent vulnerability of many chains: "The problem with a chain is that it's like a mall: it's all mechanical, and there's no relationship with the customers," said Mr. Phibbs, 41, whose other clients have included independent hotels and pet stores. "I think people are getting sick of the megastores. People are disaffected."
In the case of Polly's, Mr. Phibbs advised the company to stress the fact that the store roasts its own coffee on site, which is impractical for a sprawling chain like Starbucks, and to emphasize the wider variety of coffees Polly's offers. Starbucks, considered trendy by many of its customers, was derided in Polly's local advertising as a mere purveyor of "ordinary" coffee.
But Polly's resurgence was built on more than positioning. Mr. Phibbs urged the store's management to adopt the chains' best organizational and management ideas, like putting an end to a plethora of special arrangements between employees and longtime customers for free or cut-rate services and tightening cash management procedures. Employees attended mandatory classes to improve their sales skills.
"The advantages of the chains are their procedures and administration," Mr. Phibbs said. "If an independent doesn't learn how to be just as efficient, they're going to be dead, fast."
Many retail experts say the chains' organizational advantages and economies of scale will eventually overwhelm most independent businesses, even if a few, like Polly's, swim against the tide for a time. Yves Sistron, a principal at Global Retail Partners, a venture capital company based in Los Angeles that invests in aspiring chains, observed that mass retailers are continually invading once secure small-business preserves, even in areas like cosmetics, educational toys, watches, fruit juices and Chinese food.
To Mr. Sistron, who has invested in successful chains like Jamba Juice and P. F. Chang's China Bistros, it is only a matter of time before well-financed and managed chains gobble up just about everything on Main Street. "Who gets beat up?" he said. "The smaller independent stores, the mom-and-pops. I'm not saying it's not dreary. But it's true." In the future, he said, if shoppers want to find anything like a traditional Main Street, "it's going to be Main Street, Disneyland."
Certainly, the continuing success of Starbucks lends credence to Mr. Sistron's view. The company's sales at stores open at least a year were 8 percent higher in September than they were in September 1998, and it has bought out one smaller competitor after another; it now has 2,500 stores, up from just 11 a decade ago. Starbucks' chief executive, Howard Schultz, has spoken of growing to 20,000 outlets, rivaling McDonald's 25,000 stores for sheer ubiquity.
 YET it is Starbucks's concentration on growth, Mr. Phibbs said, that gives companies like Polly's their opportunity. The bigger Starbucks gets, he said, and the further afield it goes, the more trouble it will have maintaining consistent high quality in its products and in customer service.
The chain's expansion into other kinds of drinks, including sweetened iced coffees, and Mr. Schultz's Internet ambitions to turn the Starbucks Web site into a dominant "premier life style portal" have not yet excited much enthusiasm on Wall Street, where analysts are concerned about a perceived lack of focus. Translated into Main Street terms, Mr. Phibbs said, Starbucks risks squandering its cachet as an upscale coffee house. "Starbucks is not a coffee business any more," Mr. Phibbs said. "It's a drinks business -- a McDonald's of the 1990's."
Starbucks doesn't see itself as Goliath to the independents' David. It says it doesn't look at competition on a neighborhood-by-neighborhood basis. "We couldn't be happier that this guy is doing great business," Arthur Rubinfeld, Starbucks' senior vice president for store development, said of Mr. Sheldrake and Polly's, because it enlarges the market for everyone: "More people are on the street looking for a coffee experience, and the higher end coffee ends up doing better." But he took issue with the claim that in-store roasting give Polly's a quality advantage over Starbucks. "It's not relevant in this day and age. We source and roast the best quality beans," he said.
Still, for entrepreneurs like Mr. Sheldrake, any weakness that might appear in the strategic focus of a powerful chain represents a chance to survive and thrive. But given the chains' marketing muscle, Mr. Sheldrake said, he knows that independents like Polly's can never afford to backslide or become lazy.
"A small business can stand up to a chain," Mr. Sheldrake said. "But you can only do it if you have procedures as good as theirs -- and better coffee, too."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
The QuietHelp Of Family Members

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS

 BODY:
LINDA K. WILLIAMS ticked off her expenses: rent for the small, neatly furnished apartment that she shares with her teen-age son, electricity, phone, groceries, medicine, life insurance, occasional evenings out, new clothing, the bus commute to work, the boy's allowance and lunch money. The expenses total nearly $19,000, but her take-home pay as a secretary is only $15,700. How does she make ends meet? Gradually, Ms. Williams explained how her sisters help, and also a boyfriend.
The boyfriend -- Ms. Williams is 43 and divorced -- shops with her occasionally for food and clothes and bought her the delicate gold chain that she wore during a recent interview at her apartment here. But the four sisters are Ms. Williams's real safety net. Each earns more than she does, and they often appear at her home with food or detergent or some other household item they have bought for her while shopping for themselves. 
 "If I let my finances get to me, I would be way down there, and I am way up here," Ms. Williams said. "If I lose my job, my backup plan is my sisters. They are going to help me, I know that."
So will government, of course, through unemployment insurance, Medicaid, food stamps and other support payments. But help from family and friends, particularly boyfriends in the case of single mothers, is turning out to be a huge part of the social safety net in an era when new jobs are constantly being created, most of them at $10 an hour or less. Millions of Americans like Ms. Williams find themselves struggling to make ends meet on family incomes below $20,000 a year. Roughly 20 percent of the nation's 104 million families fall into this category.
FAMILY help, in cash or in kind, is hardly new. It is routine practice in immigrant communities, and it became a means of survival during the Great Depression, when in-laws, elderly parents and close friends often shared an apartment or home, contributing what income they had to the household's upkeep. Until Social Security benefits began to increase annually just a generation ago, it was common for grown children to support their parents financially through old age. And among the wealthy, parents still often provide the down payment for a married son or daughter's first home in an upscale neighborhood.
But as the nation grew wealthier after World War II and the self-supporting nuclear family became the ideal, and often the norm, help from family declined somewhat, even among blue-collar workers and others at the lower end of the income scale -- only to rebound over the past decade. Sociologists have detected the widespread practice in recent research, and it was evident in interviews with low-wage workers in Middle American cities like Indianapolis, where incomes and living costs closely match the national average.
"We think of resources being shared within a nuclear family or a household," said Kathryn Edin, a University of Pennsylvania sociologist. "Our official statistics encourage that view. But resources are shared more broadly in a social network, which helps to explain why poor people are not flocking to homeless shelters or to charity in greater numbers.
"You might have a situation where your grandmother gives you money, and you might not pay her back in cash," she continued. "But you are expected to help her when she is sick, clean her house or shop for her. Reciprocity is important."
THE contributions of boyfriends or biological fathers, often not living in the household, are also undercounted, Ms. Edin has found. Her research, which has involved dozens of poor families in several cities over the last six years, found that such men often provide important if intermittent help in forms like cash gifts to a single mother, clothing for the children, or name-brand sneakers for a son. "If you add up the formal and informal, you find that twice as many families are receiving support as official statistics suggest," Ms. Edin said.
Parents and grandparents play big roles in the support network for many low-income households, partly because much of their working lives came before wage stagnation crippled the incomes of low-skill workers and before the minimum wage lost so much ground to inflation. Julie Pinner, 35, a receptionist and clerk, is plagued by break-ins and burglaries at the home she rents. She will soon move with her two children to a home in a better neighborhood that her father owns and that she will rent from him -- an improvement in circumstances that she says she could not have managed on her income of $15,500 a year without his help.
Her father worked for 34 years on a Chevrolet assembly line and has a union pension. "He picks me up in the morning and drives me to work," Ms. Pinner said. "If we don't have anything to eat, he'll help. Maybe once a month he pays for the shopping, and my aunt gives me a few dollars."
THE Clinton Administration views family support as a valuable supplement to government benefits like the earned income tax credit, rent subsidies, training and Medicaid. The Republicans emphasize community support for the poor, charity being one element and family help another. Missing from the policy mix of either party is strong endorsement of higher wages. That would be achieved in part through a greater increase in the current minimum wage of $5.15 an hour than either Al Gore or Bill Bradley, the two contenders for the Democratic Presidential nomination, have proposed so far.
Neither proposal would exert the sort of upward pressure on the wages of the poorest workers that the minimum exerted in its heyday back in the 1960's. And a higher wage, after all, is the solution favored by the working poor themselves.

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
The Slumber Is Over As La-Z-Boy Expands

BYLINE: By MICHELLE LEDER 

 BODY:
FOR years, La-Z-Boy Inc. had a somewhat sleepy image: a midsized Midwestern company that was modestly well run and known for its signature product -- a comfortable reclining chair. But a string of acquisitions -- three announced this year -- have some investors thinking there may be a lot of spring in this 72-year-old business, which is based in Monroe, Mich.
On Sept. 28, La-Z-Boy announced its biggest deal: a plan to acquire Ladd Furniture, based in Greensboro, N.C., for $267.2 million, including debt of $101.5 million; the deal is expected to be completed early next year. In March, La-Z-Boy announced that it would buy Bauhaus USA, a furniture maker in Saltillo, Miss., for about $60 million; that purchase closed in June. And in April it announced that it would acquire Alexvale Furniture of Taylorsville, N.C., for undisclosed terms. That deal is expected to close this year. 
 After all the acquisitions are completed, La-Z-Boy will be the largest publicly traded home furniture company, with sales of more than $2 billion, just ahead of Furniture Brands International. La-Z-Boy hit the $1 billion sales mark only two and a half years ago.
The deals will broaden La-Z-Boy's product mix. Ladd has done well in two markets where La-Z-Boy has had no presence: children's furniture and furniture sold to hotels and other institutions. The Bauhaus line of upscale contemporary furniture gives La-Z-Boy a path into chains owned by Federated Department Stores and May Department Stores, two big retailers with which La-Z-Boy has had few dealings.
"La-Z-Boy has been very successful at making acquisitions and going after niche markets, and they've been able to do that without missing a beat in earnings growth," said Elliott L. Schlang, managing director of the LJR Great Lakes Review, a research firm in Cleveland.
But the company has not neglected its core business. In April, La-Z-Boy introduced the Oasis, a recliner that sells for about $999 and features in one armrest a cooler that can store a six-pack; its sales are going well, according to Gene M. Hardy, La-Z-Boy's secretary and treasurer.
La-Z-Boy shares closed at $17.9375 on Friday, down 27 percent from a 52-week high of $24.5625 on July 1 and just 11.7 times analysts' estimates for fiscal 2000 earnings. Mr. Schlang has a 52-week target of $33 on the stock.
Analysts attribute the lackluster stock price to concerns that higher interest rates will slow new-home sales, thus dampening furniture sales. Rivals have suffered too. Furniture Brands, which closed at $17.75 on Friday, is down 34.9 percent this year.
Analysts expect La-Z-Boy to post profits of 41 cents a share when it reports fiscal second-quarter results on Nov. 3. That would be up 17 percent from the quarter last year.
For its first quarter, ended July 24, La-Z-Boy posted profit of 25 cents a share, nearly double the figure a year earlier and ahead of analysts' expectations of 21 cents a share.
Shelly Hale, an analyst at Bank of America Securities, recommends La-Z-Boy stock and has a 52-week target of $29. One worry is whether La-Z-Boy has the expertise to manage the various brands. "I have some concern that they are a bit disparate," she said.
Lance James, a longtime La-Z-Boy investor who runs the Babson Enterprise II fund, sees the stock's low price-to-earnings ratio as a buying opportunity. After the Ladd announcement, he raised his La-Z-Boy stake to 3 percent of the fund's assets. And La-Z-Boy itself has been buying back shares. "Whether you're a long-term investor or a value investor," Mr. James said, "this is everything you're looking for."

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS;
A Retiree's Work: How to Break the Nest Egg

BYLINE: By JAN M. ROSEN 

 BODY:
MANY Americans have taken to heart the advice to save for retirement, socking away some $2.61 trillion in defined-contribution plans like 401(k)'s, according to the Spectrem Group, a business research and consulting company in San Francisco.
Now, as the first members of the generation responsible for their own retirement savings begin to leave work, comes the second part of the equation: withdrawing money from these plans. 
 Don't assume that this is the easy part. To avoid running out of money, retirees need to consider every aspect of their finances and life styles. "The issues in retirement planning are very complicated," said Avery E. Neumark, who is in charge of retirement planning for Rosen Seymour Shapss Martin & Company, a New York accounting firm. Because few retirees can handle all the complications on their own, he recommends that they seek professional advice.
Joseph P. Healy, manager of retirement and advisory services for T. Rowe Price, the Baltimore mutual fund and investment advisory company, says that in addition to considering market volatility, interest rate shifts, inflation and tax laws, retirees must think about individual variables like their risk tolerance, life expectancies, living standards and whether they wish to leave money to children or anyone else.
Many people -- even some financial professionals -- look only at average rates of return. Say Mary Smith calculates that she will need $25,000 a year to supplement a pension and Social Security. She concludes that if she has $250,000 in her 401(k) plan, and it earns 10 percent, she will be fine.
Whoa. Her calculations have failed to account for possible wide swings in annual returns and for inflation. T. Rowe Price, having studied the performance of a wide range of portfolios from 1968 to 1998, concluded that a vicious bear market early in the period, like the one of 1973-74, could cause the rapid depletion of such a portfolio. That depletion would be further accelerated by the need to withdraw an average of 3 percent more each year to keep up with inflation.
The rich have long relied on investment advisers and fee-based financial planners to manage portfolios and devise withdrawal strategies. Nowadays, the middle class could also use professional help.
Some of Mr. Neumark's clients also receive retirement guidance from brokerage firms, among them Merrill Lynch.
T. Rowe Price aims at the middle class with a new service, costing $500, to analyze the options for people within two years of retirement, or who have retired recently.
Clients fill out detailed questionnaires, and the firm uses computers to consider hundreds of possible retirement income and withdrawal strategies, as well as possible market performance variations. From the results, it recommends three possible courses, tailored to individual goals and preferences. The cost includes an annual review for those who invest with Price.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER EAST SIDE;
'Threatening' Calls to Critic of Bars Lead to an Arrest for Harassment

BYLINE: By ERIC V. COPAGE 

 BODY:
Marcia Lemmon, a Community Board 3 member known for her opposition to bars in the neighborhood, said she thought at first it was a wrong number. Her phone would ring, and there would be an eerie silence when she picked up. But after a couple of times, she said, the calls became more than an annoyance.
"They started to get threatening," said Ms. Lemmon, a freelance corporate consultant who moved to the Lower East Side nine years ago. "The person would say, 'Lemmon, we are going to get you.' " 
 On Aug. 16, the police arrested Steven Gluck, charging him with harassment in the second degree, a misdemeanor, said Detective Walter Burns, a police spokesman. Mr. Gluck is to be arraigned tomorrow at Manhattan Criminal Court, according to the District Attorney's office.
Mr. Gluck's lawyer, Leonard Easter, said his client is a sales associate with Misrahi Realty on Rivington Street. Sion Misrahi, who owns the real estate company, did not return calls seeking comment.
In an interview last week, Mr. Gluck said it was all a "misunderstanding."
"I never made any threatening calls to her," he said. "I live a clean life." He would not discuss the charges.
Ms. Lemmon said that in June she started receiving hang-ups and then harassing calls from a 917 number she did not recognize. She had it traced, she said, and alerted the police.
Why might those calls have been made? "Because I have spoken out on what has happened to the neighborhood," Ms. Lemmon said. "I have spoken out on how the economy has become a monolithic nighttime-based economy of bars and clubs."
Gary Auslander, the owner of a lounge and restaurant called Baby Jupiter who has clashed with Ms. Lemmon, said, "She has an obsession against bars and restaurants."
Adam Silvera, a Democratic district leader on the Lower East Side, said Ms. Lemmon has drawn condemnation from some people in the neighborhood because she is "very powerful, very organized and efficient, and has a successful track record in fighting problem bars with the State Liquor Authority." HEADLINE: The Nation: Encyclopedia Green;
The High Road at a High Cost

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
AS Internet users stampeded to visit the Encyclopaedia Britannica's sleek new Web site last week, the venerable intellectual icon was nearly road kill on the information highway.
Britannica.com is busily adding computers to handle the more than 10 million people who tried to peruse its site. But the company also faces a much bigger question: Will its vaunted reputation for rigor be compromised by its decision to give free access to its vast stores of knowledge? 
 In the first half of this decade, annual sales of the familiarly bound volumes plummeted by roughly 80 percent as Britannica miscalculated, refusing to produce a cheap, computer-based version of the storied publication that most adults in America used in school and from which many cribbed at least one science report.
While Britannica was charging up to $2,000 for a 32-volume edition of books, Microsoft was often giving away CD-Rom versions of its Encarta encyclopedia to buyers of new computers. When Britannica produced a CD-Rom, it was $1,000 initially versus $50 retail for Encarta. And when Britannica first joined the World Wide Web, it did so with a subscription-only site, charging a fee for access in a medium where nearly all information sites are free.
Now, Britannica.com has joined the Internet mainstream with a free site that is supported by the sale of advertising and by links to an array of products for sale. But whether the new economics of the Internet age will allow the Encyclopaedia Britannica to support itself as a living document, constantly updated and renewed, is unclear.
"They certainly face an uphill battle," said Thomas S. Wurster, a vice president at the Boston Consulting Group and co-author, with Philip Evans, of "Blown to Bits: How the New Economics of Information Transforms Strategy" (Harvard Business School Press), which is expected to be published next year.
"Britannica was always thought of as a trusted adviser, known for its rigorous quality," Mr. Wurster said. "But on the Internet, others, like Yahoo, have a better identity with core users. Because Britannica will no longer be getting any revenues from their content, their success will very much depend on whether they can attract eyeballs to the site," and therefore be able to charge advertisers higher rates.
THE fact that the main competitors for Britannica.com are not other encyclopedias but on-line services like Yahoo and America Online is not lost on Britannica. By offering free content, it removes any advantage gained by serviceable but generally lesser products like Encarta, based on the old Funk & Wagnalls encyclopedia. And Britannica.com includes not only its entire encyclopedia but also articles from magazines like The Economist, Esquire and Sports Illustrated, news links, stock quotes, an Internet search service, links to Barnes & Noble's on-line bookstore and other commercial sites.
"Our intention is to be the premier knowledge destination site," said Kent Devereaux, senior vice president for product development and editorial at Britannica.com, based in Chicago. "We have found that the entire definition of the encyclopedia has to change. If that puts us into the same space as Yahoo and America Online, so be it."
Working to insure that its intellectual edge is not lost will be, in addition to the traditional team of Britannica researchers, a second group of content specialists. Their focus will be preparing weekly updates on current events -- a vast improvement over the biennial updates of the old print version -- plus taking advantage of the Internet's audio and video capabilities. While adding researchers, it has eliminated the door-to-door sales staff that accounted for most of the cost of the printed version.
The overwhelming response to Tuesday's unveiling of Britannica.com showed that the name Britannica retains its cachet in this country and around the world. If Britannica.com can continue to attract a passionate audience among the information generation, it will serve as a stellar example of how companies that are late adapting to new technologies can end up on top -- if they have a superior product. But such a brainy product must still compete in a medium based on entertainment and commerce as much as information.
And just think what might have been: Even if Britannica.com eventually completes an initial public offering of stock, it will probably never catch up to Yahoo's $46 billion market value. For succor, Britannica.com might consult its own Web site. The Encyclopaedia Britannica has no entry for "business failure." But type in those words on its search engine and a visitor will be offered the chance to buy a potentially helpful book -- titled "When Things Go Wrong: Organizational Failures & Breakdowns."

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
A Cyberspat Makes History

BYLINE: By KATIE HAFNER 

 BODY:
THIS month marks the 30th anniversary of the Arpanet, the Internet's predecessor. Then again, maybe it doesn't.
The University of California at Los Angeles was ground zero for the Arpanet. Then again, maybe it wasn't. 
 This anniversary of the Internet has been a particularly contentious one. Vice President Al Gore's misstatement to CNN last spring that he "took the initiative" in inventing the whole thing was roundly ridiculed by anyone with an inkling of the network's true origins. But in recent months, several more genuine contenders have stepped forward to stake a claim to this or that invaluable piece of the invention, giving rise to a number of public spats.
As barbs fly and longstanding friendships disintegrate, figuring out just who did what when is more difficult than ever.
I know about this problem at close range. In 1993, when I began researching a history of the Arpanet, the story seemed a relatively straightforward one. I scoffed when one of the Net's many fathers said to me one day: "Why are you even trying to write a history? No matter what you write, it won't be the real story."
While that may be true of history in general, anyone who tries to write the real story of the Internet right now will encounter a welter of contradictory material. Now graying, the scientists who took part in building the Net are busier than they ever were, not inventing new technologies but telling their side of the story to reporters, putting up time lines and history pages on their Web sites and shooting off E-mail messages. The goal, of course, is not to get rich but to secure a spot in history.
"What we're witnessing is a case of history getting revised in real time," said Peter J. Denning, a computer science professor at George Mason University who took part in the development of the Internet but has remained a largely silent observer. "We are watching the process of myth-making as it happens around us. Eventually certain people will emerge out of the myth and lots of what's been accomplished will be ascribed to them, even if they didn't do it personally."
The revision of history while the principal participants are still alive is not new. The author Stephen E. Ambrose said he grappled with the phenomenon recently when writing about the construction of the transcontinental railroad 130 years ago, an immense project in which dozens of luminaries like Senator Thomas Hart Benton and the industrialist Leland Stanford had a hand.
"You should see how those people fought each other," he said. "They would write letters to The Railroad Journal, or Horace Greeley's paper, saying, 'I'm the one who first suggested it's possible to build a railroad across the country.' "
To try to sort it out for himself, Mr. Ambrose relied on a well-established body of literature. His advantage was not having to fend off calls from Leland Stanford's p.r. agency. Nevertheless, he found no consensus. "I threw up my hands," Mr. Ambrose said. "Don't ask me who first thought of it. I could give you a lot of entries into the race."
Alan Brinkley, a professor of history at Columbia University, says it's a common problem. "History is constantly being revised in informal ways, in popular culture and in private conversations," he said. "There are always many different versions."
What's new, Professor Brinkley said, isn't the revisionism as much as the presence of the Internet as a revisionist's tool, providing an easy way to spread one's own version of events. The latter-day equivalent of fighting it out in letters to the editor is to spam the world with your take, using the Internet as an amplifier. Whoever is fastest with the send button, whoever has the lengthier "cc" list, is most likely to rise above the din.
Scholars are wondering if the Internet will make the process of historical inquiry more difficult. "The word definitiveness comes to mind," said Neil M. Postman, a professor of communications at New York University. "Print is more definitive. Books preserve information. The Internet moves information. So with information on the move, appearing and disappearing, and without gatekeepers, it diminishes the credibility of claims."
Not only do electronic versions of events have a way of drifting more quickly and easily into the public's consciousness, but they underscore how quickly other information can disappear from the record.
In the case of the continuing paternity battle over the Internet, Professor Denning pointed to 1989, a more subdued time in the Net's evolution, when a symposium commemorating the 20th anniversary of the Arpanet took place at U.C.L.A. Back then, the Net was still relatively obscure and there was nothing much at stake. In attendance were the very men slugging it out today. A transcript of the event has them lavishing one another with praise and credit. But that transcript exists not on the Internet but on paper tucked away in the archive of the Charles Babbage Institute of Computer History in Minnesota.
Whatever remaining solidarity there might be among the Net's founding fathers is increasingly strained. There is one contingent that stands by early September, when the network got its first node, as the birth date of the Arpanet. Others continue to claim it was late October, when the first electronic bits passed from U.C.L.A. to a computer at the Stanford Research Institute, about 300 miles to the north. Some profess to have invented packet-switching, the data transmission technology that made it all possible. Still others claim to have had the idea for a network in the first place.
FOR his part, Professor Brinkley does not believe the Internet will hamper historians' ability to gather facts. "I don't think the Internet has reinvented history," he said. "It's just expanding and complicating it a bit. History is always contested, and over time frivolous claims get discounted, and more serious claims get more attention, and eventually there's a consensus around a particular answer. You won't have the open-ended disputes that are going on today."
Time may also slow the rush for recognition. Every so often, the Internet is not glorified but blamed -- for inflation, for the slump in dot-com stocks, for widening the gap between haves and have-nots.
"When the true dark side comes along, you won't see people scrambling to take credit for that part," Professor Denning said. "It will be, 'That's not the part I had anything to do with.' "
Maybe they'll say that was Al Gore's part.

HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR;
An Old-Line Business Group Is Trying to Play Catch-Up

BYLINE: By JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI 

 BODY:
The 65-year-old Business Council, an exclusive club of 100 big-company chief executives like John F. Smith Jr. of General Motors and John F. Welch Jr. of General Electric, has been showing its age.
Despite its reputation for legendary speakers and deal-making opportunities at its thrice-yearly meetings, some chiefs from the fastest-moving sectors of the economy, including Bill Gates and Michael D. Eisner, have declined to join. 
 But the Business Council is trying to catch up with the times, as the two-day meeting beginning on Wednesday evening will show. On the scene in Boca Raton, Fla. -- a switch from Colonial Williamsburg, the site since 1992 -- will be two new-economy members who have joined in the last year, Scott McNealy of Sun Microsystems and John Chambers of Cisco Systems. Michael Dell became a member in May but won't attend this week.
The program includes old standbys like Alan Greenspan and Bill Bradley, but with the Internet as the main focus, some speakers will be decidedly younger. Four teen-agers will expound to their elders on "Growing Up Digital" in a panel led by Don Tapscott, who wrote a book by that name and is chairman of the Alliance for Converging Technologies in Toronto. Mary Meeker, the Internet analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, will moderate a discussion among four E-commerce chief executives whose names, even now, would never make the member list.
There is buzz, too, among some members that the membership committee may extend an invitation to Hewlett-Packard's Carleton S. Fiorina, who during the summer became the first woman to be named chief executive of a company in the Dow Jones industrials. If she joins, she would be right behind Crandall Close Bowles, the chief executive of Springs Industries, who became the group's first female member a year ago.
Oh yeah, and Bill Gates will be there, too -- not as a member, but as a Friday morning speaker. JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Playing Russian Roulette

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
The most important story out of Russia last week was buried in the business pages: Russia's top stock-market watchdog quit after declaring that Boris Yeltsin's government was simply not interested in enforcing laws to protect shareholders in Russia.
Imagine if you picked up the paper and found that Arthur Levitt, the chairman of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, had quit, saying that the New York stock exchange and our commercial courts were so corrupt that you were better off going to Las Vegas, and putting your money on red or black, than investing in the market. 
 Well, that's what happened when Dmitri Vasiliev, who led Russia's Federal Securities Commission, quit. This story gets to the core of what is wrong with Russia today. Think of countries as computers. Today we all have the same basic model -- the Free Market PC. The real question is: Which countries will get the operating system and the software to go with their Free Market computer so that when they plug into the Electronic Herd of global investors they can get the most out of it and cushion the worst. Operating systems are the basic macroeconomic policies needed to succeed in today's global economy and software is the rule of law, the courts, regulatory agencies, a free press and democratic institutions.
Russia is like a computer that plugged into the Electronic Herd with no operating system -- not even the basic DOScapital 1.0 -- and no software inside. If there is one thing we have learned since the end of the cold war it is how much more difficult it is for developing countries to get the software and operating systems than we thought.
Where does Russia even start when the head of its S.E.C. is quitting? I asked Bill Lewis, who heads the McKinsey consulting firm's Global Institute and has just completed an extensive study of the Russian economy. "To start with," answered Mr. Lewis, speaking from Moscow, "you need a whole different group of people at the top in Russia. Many people have pointed to the fact that Russia has consistently held free elections as a sign that it is basically going in the right direction. But the real question is, Do Russians have people to vote for? Do they have politicians who understand what Russia needs today and are ready to implement it? The answer is no."
Look at Russia: Most of its economy has been privatized, prices have been decontrolled and competition exists -- all the free-market hardware is in place -- yet the economy is stalled. Why? The answer, the McKinsey team found, lies in microeconomics. The Russian system is so rigged and full of corrupt, arbitrary officials and rules that an unproductive steel mill, based on outdated blast-furnace technology, can pull strings so that the government gives it free energy, just to keep its people employed. Meanwhile, a modern Russian steel factory, which is both productive and could be profitable, can't make a profit, grow its market share and drive out unproductive firms because the market is saturated with subsidized steel.
In post-Communist Poland, the economy sagged and then surged as reforms kicked in because the best companies were allowed to win. In Russia, no such level playing field exists, so the most corrupt companies win. "In Russia today you don't do well by doing better," said Mr. Lewis. "You do well by seeking favors, tax preferences and subsidies. This reduces the government's income and increases the deficits."
It has been said of America that it is a system designed by geniuses so that it could be run by idiots. What Russians need most from America today is not aid, and it is not advice per se, notes Mr. Lewis. Rather, it is an understanding of what is the real source of American prosperity -- that it's in the quality of the U.S. system, its legal and market software that usually allows the most productive player to win. Secret: One of the most important competitive advantages a country can have is a lean, flexible, honest civil service. The Russians not only don't have it; they don't get it.
"What Russia needs most is their version of our Roosevelt," says Mr. Lewis. "They need a shrewd, honest, savvy pol who can attract the right technocrats around him and lead a democratic process to put in place the social policies and limited, but enforceable, regulations that are the necessary foundation for growth. Unfortunately, that Russian Roosevelt doesn't exist today, and it's not clear when he will emerge."

HEADLINE: Harlem Development's Foes Show an Addled Attitude

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Harlem on the Brink" (Sept. 26): Harlemites opposing the new projects there show a typically addled New York attitude toward development. Lloyd A. Williams says that the new investors will "take money out of the community." In fact, they're putting money in -- $700 million, according to your article -- and they're entitled to take out high profits in exchange for risky, pioneering investments in this long-depressed area. They'll bring jobs into an area of desperately high unemployment, and if their stores and housing developments do well, they'll invest even more money in Harlem.
A preservationist, Michael Henry Adams, complains that "they're demolishing Harlem." While Harlem's spectacular architectural and cultural legacy must be conserved, anyone with open eyes can see a vast number of vacant lots and deteriorated, far-from-landmark quality buildings that no one will miss. 
 Exciting new retail (as opposed to the current schlock on 125th Street and vacant storefronts on Lenox Avenue) will encourage some of the tourists on buses to stop and spend their money, which once again will mean more jobs.
 
JAY WEISER
Associate Professor of Law, Baruch College

HEADLINE: DATABANK: OCTOBER 18 - OCTOBER 22;
Surprises from Jakarta to Wall Street

BYLINE: By PATRICK J. LYONS 

 BODY:
Funny how the election of a new president can send financial markets roiling, especially when it isn't the president everyone is expecting.
 Indonesia, whose population and economy make it too big to ignore but whose financial crisis and turbulent politics have long given investors palpitations, took a big and surprising step last week along a road that many think can lead to stable democracy and growth. Its parliament chose a moderate Muslim theologian, Abdurrahman Wahid, over Megawati Sukarnoputri, the fiery daughter of Sukarno, the former president, even though her political party won more seats than Mr. Wahid's in recent elections. The Jakarta stock market reacted mainly with enthusiasm, rising 6.39 percent for the week on 10 times the usual trading volume. 
 Back in North America, stocks were bounced around by less extraordinary headlines, mainly quarterly earnings reports that left bank stockholders delighted and technology stockholders scratching their heads in confusion. The Dow Jones industrial average and S.&P. 500 both finished the week with gains of more than 4 percent; smaller stocks trailed a bit. Bond rates continued to rise last week on inflation worries; the dollar gained slightly. PATRICK J. LYONS

HEADLINE: A New World of Finance

 BODY:
Even without new laws enacted by Congress, the financial world has hurtled through many changes in recent years. Now with the agreement in Washington on Friday to overhaul the nation's banking laws, American businesses and consumers face even more transformation. Legislation agreed to by the White House and the Republican leadership will sweep away the Depression-era curbs that have kept banks, securities firms and insurance companies from moving into one another's arenas. The proposed deregulation is designed to help American companies expand abroad and become more efficient at home. But the breakthrough agreement was made possible by the lawmakers' willingness to try to protect consumers and poor communities from being trampled in the process.
For more than 20 years, Congress has attempted without success to overhaul the nation's banking laws, while American financial institutions found loopholes to get around some of the old regulations. Banks have already moved in a limited way into the securities business, which was barred by the Glass-Steagall Act of 1933. The Travelers Group-Citibank merger seemed a harbinger of greater change. But as such steps accelerated, consumers had reason to worry about access to credit, as well as technological threats to their privacy. 
 The needed legislative overhaul was delayed as the various wings of the financial industry waged expensive lobbying campaigns. Often it seemed as if lawmakers were engaged in a big tease designed to shake down the industry for campaign contributions, overlooking the needs of consumers. Partisan hatreds in Congress at times made an agreement unlikely. But in the House, Representative Jim Leach, chairman of the Banking Committee, managed to bring all sides together and craft a bill that was mostly acceptable to the White House. Another step forward came this month when the Treasury Department and the Federal Reserve reached an accord to share oversight of banks entering into new financial activities.
The final impediment to a new bill was a series of disputes over the right to privacy of consumers and the rights of long-neglected poor communities not to be discriminated against. Both issues got resolved in a way that was, on balance, positive. But it remains to be seen how well the new regulations are to be enforced and what penalties will be available. The agreed-upon bill requires financial institutions to disclose their policies on collecting and using financial information, and gives customers the right to stop them from sharing information with other companies. States were left with the right to regulate insurance companies.
Most significant, a White House veto threat forced Senator Phil Gramm, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, to drop his attempt to eviscerate laws that have long required banks to lend in the same minority areas where they receive deposits. The White House, in turn, accepted compromise language on enforcing the law against redlining, pushed by Senators Christopher Dodd and Charles Schumer, two Democrats with insurance and banking industries among their most powerful constituents. Finally, Speaker Dennis Hastert and Trent Lott, the Senate majority leader, also pressed Mr. Gramm to accept the deal.
A sweeping deregulation like this one comes along rarely. There are sure to be unintended and adverse consequences, just as there were after the telecommunications deregulation of 1996. The bill that was put together over the last several weeks, with a marathon negotiating session into the early hours of Friday, was testimony to reasonableness on all sides. It is virtually certain to be passed in the Senate and House and signed by President Clinton. But it will also be important for Congress to continue monitoring the trends in the financial industry. The principle of freer competition is the economic engine of this era. But the other imperative is to demand openness, financial prudence and safeguards so that the vast new concentrations of wealth and power do not create new abuses.
