LENGTH: 1061 words

HEADLINE: UNIVERSITY PRESSES;
The Farmer in the Urb

BYLINE: By Keith Schneider; Keith Schneider, a journalist and columnist, is executive director of the Michigan Land Use Institute.

 BODY:

Of Cabbages and
 Kings County
 Agriculture and the Formation
 of Modern Brooklyn.
 By Marc Linder and Lawrence S. Zacharias.
 Illustrated. 478 pp. Iowa City:
 University of Iowa Press. $32.95. 
 The history of urban development in America is also the story of rural decline. The ever-outward spread of homes and businesses overwhelmed small towns and some of the nation's most productive farmland. Metropolitan Los Angeles, which now covers an area nearly as large as New Hampshire, grew out of citrus orchards and vegetable fields. The new suburbs of Chicago and Cleveland are sprouting on once fertile cornfields. But except by a handful of social critics like Jane Jacobs and Lewis Mumford, or land use advocates like Henry Richmond, the founder of 1,000 Friends of Oregon, the growth of the nation's cities and suburbs was celebrated as stirring evidence of a system that works. The American Dream, after all, defines the good life as a home, a big yard and space for a fleet of vehicles.
Of late, though, the unyielding advance of American civilization has taken on a different aura. Suburban development is increasingly viewed as a metastasizing smear across the countryside. The issue is so dynamic that an important component of Vice President Al Gore's campaign for the Presidency is finding new tools to stem the loss of of farmland to strip malls and subdivisions. In "Of Cabbages and Kings County" Marc Linder, a professor of law at the University of Iowa, and Lawrence S. Zacharias, a management professor at the University of Massachusetts, find considerable traction to explore these trenchant issues in, of all places, turn-of-the-century Brooklyn. As late as 1879, they report, Kings County was the nation's second county in terms of vegetable production, behind Queens. By 1919, almost nothing was left of a once thriving agricultural economy and the rural community it supported.
Brooklyn's swift transition from a pastoral landscape to a tightly packed 20th-century urban center with more than a million people came because of technological innovation (particularly refrigeration) and blind devotion to free-market principles that made land too expensive to farm. The question of what Brooklyn gained and lost from what the authors call "irrational deagriculturization" lies at the center of this thoughtful and well-written history. Linder and Zacharias conclude that human and community values suffered irreparable harm because Brooklyn's Dutch-influenced small-town culture was obliterated along with the agricultural landscape.
Can "the inevitability of agricultural dissolution in the face of urban expansion" be altered in the United States, they ask. Their answer is a guarded yes. First, Linder and Zacharias say, policy makers need to follow the lead of Suffolk County, N.Y., and states like Oregon and Maryland, which preserve the richest land for agriculture. Second, lawmakers need to be courageous in providing research and economic incentives that open new markets and keep farmers farming. Third, every level of government needs to reconsider the existing paradigm, which puts business development above any other value.
"What happened to farming was not the best of circumstances," Linder and Zacharias write of Brooklyn's experience. "The process was rigged in favor of congested land development and its quasi-universal effects. This form of urbanization foreclosed the possibility of creating an urban life style that proponents of urban farming today and even in the 1910's and 1920's recommended. New York and other cities thus forfeited numerous other possibilities for balanced population growth, more diverse and integrated self-sufficient urban economies, interurban public transportation and less costly environmental pollution controls."
Along with the thoughtful approach to the larger issues of land use, "Of Cabbages and Kings County" works wonderfully as a text brimming with new insights about Brooklyn's development in the 19th century. From the earliest days of the republic, Kings County was a bread, meat and milk basket for New York. As late as 1890, a visitor to what is now the corner of Church Avenue and Ocean Parkway could view a pastoral landscape of handsome farmhouses, open meadows and wagons filled with tall stacks of hay. The first big economic transition occurred in 1825, when the Erie Canal opened. The canal not only made it possible to ship grain inexpensively from the more productive Ohio Valley but also accelerated economic development and population growth in the city. Brooklyn's farmers took advantage of their close proximity and easy access to Manhattan's markets by cultivating high-value vegetables for sale to the growing middle and upper classes. By 1880, agriculture's zenith in the borough, more than 400 farms covered 12,359 acres and produced $1.2 million a year in farm products.
But such riches in the shadow of the metropolis were destined not to last. Industrialization drove up manufacturing wages, making it more difficult for farmers to hire workers, and by 1878 four steam railroads operated in Kings County, making it easy for settlers to reach the borough's interior. In 1883 the Brooklyn Bridge opened, and by 1890 new refrigeration techniques made it possible to ship vegetables out of the Deep South cheaper than Brooklyn could grow them.
Though New York was losing the capacity to feed itself, that thought was hardly a concern to the legion of business executives, developers and their friends in elected office who were racing to fill Brooklyn's idle fields with homes. By 1900, the future for the 72-square-mile borough as a center of manufacturers, small business and thousands of residences was plainly evident, and from 1900 until the Depression land values rose tenfold. Brooklyn's population reached nearly 1.2 million, and the acres under cultivation dropped to fewer than 6,500.
The authors cite Sweden and Germany as models for how public policy shaped real estate markets to preserve agriculture both within and near urban centers. In the 1970's, New York began to understand what it had lost and moved to reclaim at least a bit of its agricultural past, through farmers' markets and Green Thumb community gardens, especially in Brooklyn. There gardeners work about the same acreage as was under cultivation in 1929.

HEADLINE: None of the Above

BYLINE: By Andrew Sullivan; Andrew Sullivan is a contributing writer for The Times Magazine and a senior editor at The New Republic.

 BODY:

The Big Test
 The Secret History
 of the American Meritocracy.
 By Nicholas Lemann.
 406 pp. New York:
 Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $27. 
 It takes 349 pages to get there, but eventually Nicholas Lemann makes his point unequivocally in "The Big Test." It is that a democratic society should provide -- as a national, Federal matter -- free, excellent and multifarious education to anyone on demand, from high school through college. The only important test of ability should be one designed to discern if a person has mastered a nationally agreed-upon curriculum on graduating from high school. There should be no testing of what Lemann regards as the phantasm of "innate abilities," no SAT's and the like, and thereby no possibility of a putatively meritocratic elite emerging out of American democratic life. "Decent schooling, the absolute prerequisite to a decent life in America today, should be thought of as something that Government guarantees to every citizen as a matter of right. It shouldn't be left to local authorities to screw up, any more than flight safety should."
Anyone reading "The Big Test" would be well advised to read the afterword before embarking upon the engaging but also deeply frustrating narrative it follows. What the afterword does is provide the essential context to Lemann's long, episodic history of the Educational Testing Service and its role in creating the structure of American education today. For unless you share Lemann's view that the testing of academic ability is unacceptably narrow and elitist, that sorting students according to their capacity to profit from college is impermissibly exclusionary and that the Federal Government is the right institution to run our educational system, you might be a little bemused by the tone of the book you have just read. You might find it mystifying that Lemann constantly denigrates a system that helped open up higher education to millions of previously excluded people, or that his account of the nave idealists who genuinely believed in the promise of a meritocracy is so pervaded by condescension and anxiety. The story he tells -- and often beautifully -- seems such an obviously progressive one that framing it as a case study in failure seems willfully perverse until you reach the conclusion. And then it merely seems unpersuasive.
Lemann is a staff writer for The New Yorker and former national correspondent for The Atlantic Monthly, and his literary skills pay off in this story. His access to the archives of the E.T.S. gives him an unrivaled insight into the thoughts and motives of many of the players, and he is also lucky enough to have been able to interview many of the characters involved. So the book is part social history and part Bob Woodward -- with the sources on the record. It begins in the old Ivy League of the prewar years and ends with the passage of the California Civil Rights Initiative (better known as Proposition 209) to abolish government-sponsored affirmative action in 1996. It tells the unlikely story of the way in which scholastic aptitude testing came to dominate the process of educational selection in the United States, and how education itself came to play an increasingly important part in deciding who wins and loses in the American economy and class system. Throughout, Lemann is alert to the role of personality and serendipity, as good historians are. And he is sharp in his judgments of class and status, as good journalists are. He knows the difference, for example, between test prepping la Stanley Kaplan and test prepping la Princeton Review. The former buys into the notion of meritocracy; the latter mocks it.
And he does an excellent job of evoking characters in thumbnail sketches and a few memorable scenes. The story starts with one down-at-heels Henry Chauncey praying in a church. It was Chauncey, descendant of Puritans and classic product of the old Ivy League elite, whose fierce enthusiasm for the new science of intelligence testing played such a crucial part in the early days of the E.T.S. (He is a member of what Lemann nicely calls "the Episcopacy.") At the other end of the story, in both time and space, is Molly Munger, boomer, feminist lawyer in the era of Clinton, whose dedication to the meritocratic dream came unstuck in the Los Angeles riots of 1992. In between, there is, perhaps most memorably, Clark Kerr, peerlessly political pioneer of the University of California in the 1950's, epitome of that decade's optimism in planning, growth and social science. Lemann captures him artfully: "Kerr presided over his utopia from a Japanese-style house, plain but intricate, like him, that he and his wife had built in El Cerrito, on the eastern shore of San Francisco Bay. He often worked from home, going through stacks of memoranda and resolving whatever issues they raised by writing tiny, cryptic messages in the margins in green ink. He traveled regularly all over the world, a figure in an international community of modern scholar-administrators. In his spare time he would pick a period of artistic or literary history and master it." Kerr, of course, would later be swept away by a wave of 1960's student revolt.
If all Lemann were trying to do was to tell a fascinating and heretofore underreported story about the role of educational testing in forming modern American society, then this book would be a qualified success. Although there are times when the author's pretended omniscience can grate a little, the story belts along. The cast of characters is sometimes bewildering -- some are introduced for no apparent reason and then disappear -- but few are boring. To be sure, the prose sometimes overreaches. Lemann leans over backward to point out the lessons of various anecdotes just in case the reader might have missed them, remarking at one point, for example, that the Harvard president James Bryant Conant "never imagined that he and Henry Chauncey were actually creating a new kind of class system even more powerful than the old one." The book's subtitle, "The Secret History of the American Meritocracy," is typically melodramatic. It might be better called "The Obscure Records of an Underrated Institution." Lemann unearths no classified secrets from the archives of the Educational Testing Service, and, as he points out, the organization was often very receptive to outsiders and critics. Indeed, his sources seem to have been more than generous with their time and records -- even thrilled by the attention.
As well they might be. But the book's real flaw is not its loving inflation of somewhat recondite events but its propelling argument. What Lemann wants to show is that American education's thralldom to intelligence testing -- specifically in the form of Scholastic Aptitude Tests -- was neither inevitable nor desirable. He shows how the Educational Testing Service won critical Government contracts in part because it offered a quick and effective way of sorting out vast numbers of people during periods of great stress -- during World War II and the cold war. He then shows how it used these footholds to gain acceptance among some influential colleges by a measure of cunning, chance and politics. It had competitors and plenty of critics, internal and external. It dodged plenty of political and cultural bullets. But once it had established winners, they themselves had a vested interest in perpetuating the system and so, despite the odds and growing injustice, it prevailed. The result, in Lemann's view, is the accident of an oligarchic elite that "looks more and more like what it was intended to replace" and, in fact, for Lemann, is almost morally indistinguishable from its predecessor.
This is a nice irony to give shape and direction to the narrative -- but it is an obviously overdone one. America wasn't alone in embracing some form of testing in the middle of the century -- the British went far more overboard in the 1940's, as Lemann notes. And it seems more than a little strained to pretend that a system that sees thousands of children of Asian immigrants dominate California's universities in the 1990's is as iniquitous as an Ivy League peopled by wealthy, not-so-swift WASP's in the 1890's. It is easy to point out flaws in the aptitude testing system, and plenty of people have -- until one imagines a viable alternative. Lemann's vision of tests based on a national curriculum would seem to be even more susceptible to favoring the well-prepped children of the wealthy and well educated.
To be sure, the upper-middle-class game of getting one's children into the best colleges is in danger of creating an entrenched elite; elaborate prepping schemes somewhat undermine the promise of the tests, and good public high school education -- especially for the poor -- is an inarguable public good. But that doesn't mean that a reasonably reliable means of scholastic testing is inherently oligarchic and that it cannot sometimes help the less advantaged leapfrog their socioeconomic superiors in the struggle for social advancement.
One suspects that Lemann's deepest worries about the system stem from the problem of race, not class. The most original part of the book is its very perceptive analysis of the links between the rise of an educational meritocracy and the race debate in America. Lemann is surely right that without the dominance of testing, the shockingly poor performance of African-Americans in higher education would not have become such a pressing political issue, which is why the battle against affirmative action is a fitting climax to the book. As it is, low test scores among blacks have been fuel for both sides in the argument: for those who suspect that undeserving blacks are being admitted over whites to institutions of higher education and for those who suspect that the entire system is rigged against African-Americans in the first place. For Lemann, it is a virtual given that low black scores further prove that the system is unfair. But he oddly fails to account for how low black scores endure high up the socioeconomic ladder and how poor, and often newly immigrant, Asian-Americans seem to have made such a success of the system despite high economic and linguistic hurdles to achievement.
The Asian-American lacuna is particularly striking. Lemann's major Asian-American characters are left-liberal activists, including Bill Lann Lee, Assistant Attorney General for Civil Rights, whose attachment to old-liberal identity politics helped insure he never won Senate confirmation. For some reason, we are denied the far more typical story of poor Asian immigrants for whom the aptitude test is an invaluable opportunity -- not an entrenched injustice. Why, one wonders, does a test devised to perpetuate an upper-middle-class oligarchy seem to suit these poor, bright newcomers so well? To this, Lemann doesn't seem to have an answer. Given the ambitions of this book, he surely needs to.

SECTION: Section 9;Page 1;Column 1;Style Desk

LENGTH: 2427 words

HEADLINE: We Are Family: Mom, Dad and Just Me

BYLINE: By NANCY HASS

 BODY:
A FEW weeks ago, Mia Walker, a former television producer who is just about to have her second child, asked some friends to give her a "nonshower." Absolutely no presents, she insisted. Instead, as she tearfully told her girlfriends gathered in an East Side brownstone, she wanted them to assure her she wouldn't "disappear down a black hole" as a mother of two in Manhattan.
Although she was ecstatic to be having another baby, she said, she couldn't help but be a little worried about fitting her new double stroller into the elevator, or giving up the ease of jumping on the subway or visiting museums and restaurants with just a toddler, versus a toddler plus an infant. 
 Ms. Walker was experiencing a classic New York syndrome: two children puts you in a different universe. "I'm really happy about having another baby, but there is something looming about the onset of child No. 2 in New York," she said. "When you have one kid here you have the world at your fingertips."
In contrast to suburbia, where two or more children are the norm, Manhattan has become a veritable only-child paradise. Demographers, using figures supplied by the city, say that the single-child family is now the most-common family unit in Manhattan. More than 30 percent of all married women on the island in their early 40's -- that is, women who are largely past childbearing age and whose family size is most likely set -- have only a single child. Add to that the number of women under 40 with one child, and you have a raging plurality that the demographers, Andrew Beveridge and Susan Weber of Queens College, say could top 40 percent.
By contrast, the national figure for women ages 40 to 44 who have ever been married and have just one child is about 21 percent, according to Census Bureau data.
In the suburbs, only children are still often considered a curiosity, sometimes even a sad one. But in Manhattan, there is virtually no stigma attached to them. They are as much a part of the cultural fabric of the city as the unique circumstances that, in a word, breed them: small, expensive apartments, a huge proportion of women who delay marriage and childbearing to pursue careers, inadequate public schools and sky-high private school tuitions.
"There's nowhere else that the two-parent, one-child ratio is regarded so positively," said Len Covine, 46, an architect who lives in SoHo with his wife, Sophie, and their 5-year-old daughter, Lena.
"Walking on the streets here you can forget about the whole S.U.V. thing, the whole play-date thing, the whole soccer-mom thing," he said. "Instead, you can remember the museum thing, the Central Park thing, the matinee thing, the hop-into-a-taxi thing. Having a child here, one child, is completely different than the family experience anywhere else."
Another parent-of-one, Anita Farrington-Brathwaite, whose daughter, Monet, is 8, said: "I feel I have the best of both worlds. I have a career that's really meaningful to me, and I have a great deal of time to devote to my daughter. I really shudder at the thought of having to spread myself thinner."
Ms. Farrington-Brathwaite, an undergraduate dean at New York University, grew up in Queens and was herself an only child. She said she never thought of having more than one. "I grew up knowing that I had a really good deal, that my parents, who really didn't have that much money, were able to give me security I wouldn't have had otherwise," she said.
Ms. Farrington-Brathwaite, whose husband is also a college administrator, lives in a two-bedroom N.Y.U.-subsidized apartment and sends her daughter to the Little Red School House, a private school that has a large percentage of only children. "There is no way I could have done that if I had more than one child," she said.
Now that New York has been dubbed safe again and small-town schoolyard shootings are still fresh in the public's imagination, fewer couples seem to be moving out of town right after the birth of their first child. Then, a few years later, at the time most people decide to have a second child, these couples are loath to move. "New York," said Ms. Walker, who has returned to school to become a psychotherapist, "just gets in your blood."
But unlike Ms. Walker and her husband, who recently left a family business to start an Internet venture, many people simply decide not to have another child. Where members of an earlier generation might have felt guilty or conflicted about that decision, fearing they were depriving their child of sibling companionship, today a large body of research shows that only children do not suffer social or intellectual repercussions.
And a welcome aspect of having an only child in Manhattan is that such families do not stand apart, parents say. Amy Virshup, 40, a journalist who has a year-old son, Nicholas, lives with her husband, an architect, in an Upper West Side building that may stand as a microcosm of Manhattan: among the 24 apartments, there are seven couples with one child. Each of the children is old enough to suggest that the parents are unlikely to be planning more. "The only person who asks me when I'm going to have another kid is my cleaning woman," Ms. Virshup said. "She says I'm lazy."
With so many only children in town, the usual services and activities for infants and toddlers take on a special tinge. Play groups and luncheon clubs that specialize in first-time mothers -- a disproportionate number of the total mothers in the city -- have sprung up everywhere. "When I grew up as an only child, it was awful," recalled the novelist Dani Shapiro, 37, whose son, Jacob, is now 5 months old. "I was the only one in my entire private school class. But I know that if I don't decide to have another baby, Jacob will have lots of kids in his class who are only children. That really makes a huge difference to me."
While the percentage of only children in Manhattan is the highest in the United States, there has been a subtler boom in one-child families across the country. Only children are the nation's fastest-growing family demographic. Three-person families have grown from 10 million in 1972 to more than 15 million today, and between 1980 and 1990, the most recent census, there was a 76 percent increase among women nearing the end of childbearing with one child. That trend, plus the rising number of childless couples (nearly 18 percent), has lowered the United States birthrate to less than two per family. Demographers trace the decline to a rising divorce rate, higher costs to rear and educate children, a rise in the number of working women and a rising age of marriage.
Although choice is not always a factor in the decision to have an only child -- infertility is rising as women delay marriage and childbirth into their 30's -- more people than ever are consciously opting to have just one, experts say, especially in Manhattan. "Here there is a self-selection factor," said Dr. Kathleen Gerson, an N.Y.U. sociologist and the author of "Hard Choices: How Women Decide About Work, Career and Motherhood" (University of California, 1985). "They say, 'If staying in New York means having only one kid, I'll do it.' "
Only children may no longer be seen as deprived, but their parents still sometimes come in for criticism for being self-centered or for spoiling their offspring. "We seem to have a generation of Eloises in Manhattan," said Danielle Crittenden, a cultural critic and the author of "What Our Mothers Didn't Tell Us: Why Happiness Eludes the Modern Woman" (Simon & Schuster, 1999). "Our standards for what we think we need to give our children, in space and in things, is outrageous, absurd. Children are like consumptive items, like a Jaguar. It's very sad."
Dr. Gerson, who has a 16-year-old daughter who is an only child, said she is now interviewing 18- to 30-year-olds for her research, many of whom are themselves only children and "take having only one kid pretty much as a given."
Those decisions may well be influenced by the remarkable turnaround in the attitude of psychologists and child-rearing experts. Until the 1970's, the prevailing wisdom among experts, and society in general, was that having an only child was tantamount to cruelty. This view, shaped by turn-of-the century studies of the pioneering psychologist G. Stanley Hall, held that only children were spoiled and self-centered. "Being an only child," Dr. Hall wrote in 1892, "is a disease in itself." Dr. Hall's influence was profound: surveys throughout the years have shown that the primary reason people cite for having a second child is to make sure their first child isn't maladapted, Dr. Gerson said.
But in the last 20 years, there has been a 180-degree shift. Now, experts say there is virtually no difference between only children and first-born children in self-esteem, generosity, popularity and relations to parents. In fact, many studies show that only children score higher on I.Q. tests and are more popular with peers than children with several other siblings. The psychologist Toni Falbo published a review of 141 studies in 1984 and concluded, "Only children scored significantly better than other groups in achievement motivation and personal adjustment and were in all other respects indistinguishable from children with brothers and sisters."
Scanning volumes on child-rearing in Barnes & Noble, it is virtually impossible to find a condemnation of the choice to raise an only child. A new generation of name-brand experts in child-rearing has emerged, all of whom insist that Dr. Hall's studies had no basis in fact, including Ann Laybourn of the Centre for the Study of the Child and Society at Scotland's Glasgow University and Susan Newman, author of "Parenting an Only Child" (Doubleday, 1990). Last year, the journalist Bill McKibben wrote "Maybe One" (Simon & Schuster, 1998), an ecological defense of only childhood that used a battery of new studies as ammunition.
To cynics, and some parents of more than one child, it may be hard not to wonder if psychology is not merely reflecting changes in the societal landscape. With more women in the work force by choice or necessity, and higher rates of infertility, it may seem all too pat that new research shows that only children are not disadvantaged. "There is no doubt that we have a great ability to mold our ideas of what is good for our children based on what is good for us," Dr. Gerson said.
But that observation cuts both ways. The landscape of childhood has changed strikingly since Dr. Hall's time, and even since the 1960's. In the early part of the century, high child mortality rates and farms that needed extra hands likely influenced Dr. Hall's research showing that only children were a blight on society. Until the 1970's, when birth control burgeoned and women entered the work force significantly, having only one child was virtually never a conscious choice. The stigmatized only child was likely to be at home alone with his mother, a situation that might indeed have contributed to the perception that only children were overindulged.
"The whole obsession with the multi-child suburban family ideal flourished in the 1950's," Dr. Gerson said, "which was the height of the isolated nuclear family."
Now, many only children go to day care, since their mothers are more often employed than mothers with more children. "Children now learn socialization skills from other nonrelated children," Dr. Gerson said.
Mr. Covine, the architect, proudly flaunts a modern, boom-market attitude toward raising an only child. "Maybe a little selfishness isn't so bad," he said. "If it means my daughter goes to Harvard and over achieves, hey, I can live with that."
 
Where Wealth Begets Children
 
IN leafy suburban communities, there is nothing unusual about seeing a woman drive up in a sport utility vehicle with three children in the back. In much of Manhattan, however, such a sight is downright shocking, for a simple demographic reason: women who have more than two children are usually struggling economically. Demographic data analyzed by Queens College sociologists show that affluent parents almost always stick to one or two, if they have children at all.
But there is one neighborhood in which all bets are off: the Upper East Side. Although the actual percentage of women who have three or more children in Manhattan's toniest enclave is small -- only 6 percent (compared with 21 percent in Harlem) -- they are highly visible. That's likely because their resources are breathtaking. In Manhattan, three children can be a potent social signifier.
While the median income in almost every other neighborhood falls for families with three or more children, on the Upper East Side, it soars. In Chinatown, for example, the median household income is $36,000 for a family with one child, and $19,000 for a family with three or more children, according to the data compiled by Andrew Beveridge and Susan Weber of Queens College.
But on the Upper East Side, the median income for a one-child family is $120,000; for families with three or more children it nearly doubles, to $303,000 a year.
"Sometimes it really feels like there are virtually no regular people up here," said Erica Goldberg, who lives in a three-bedroom apartment on East 80th Street with her husband, Andrew, a management consultant, and three sons, all under 8. "And having a big family seems to be part of the package."
Ms. Goldberg, 36, said that 80 percent of her friends had at least three children. The last decade of extraordinary growth on Wall Street has contributed, she speculated, to a baby boom on Park Avenue and its environs. "I even know a woman who is having her fifth child. Personally, I find it really frightening, but she couldn't be happier or calmer."
Ms. Goldberg said her husband makes a very handsome living. Still, she doesn't count herself among the truly privileged, at least in East Side terms. True, they drive a Mercedes station wagon. They do not, however, have a second home.
In fact, while the youngest two children go to private school, they send their oldest son to P.S. 290, the well-regarded school in the neighborhood. "When I was trying to get the younger one into school, a friend who is incredibly well-to-do told me I should mention in the interview that my oldest child goes to public school," Ms. Goldberg said. "With a completely straight face she said the admissions people would like that because they were always looking for diversity." NANCY HASS

CORRECTION-DATE: October 31, 1999, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A chart in Sunday Styles last week with an article about the correlation between income and number of children in Manhattan families, with a mother age 40 to 44, included some erroneous figures. For families with two children living in Chinatown, the median income is $18,357, not $19,357; in Greenwich Village, those with three or more children have a median income of $60,150, not $80,150, and on the Upper West Side, those with one child have a median income of $99,550, not $98,650.

HEADLINE: We Are Family: Mom, Dad and Just Me

BYLINE: By NANCY HASS

 BODY:
A FEW weeks ago, Mia Walker, a former television producer who is just about to have her second child, asked some friends to give her a "nonshower." Absolutely no presents, she insisted. Instead, as she tearfully told her girlfriends gathered in an East Side brownstone, she wanted them to assure her she wouldn't "disappear down a black hole" as a mother of two in Manhattan.
Although she was ecstatic to be having another baby, she said, she couldn't help but be a little worried about fitting her new double stroller into the elevator, or giving up the ease of jumping on the subway or visiting museums and restaurants with just a toddler, versus a toddler plus an infant. 
 Ms. Walker was experiencing a classic New York syndrome: two children puts you in a different universe. "I'm really happy about having another baby, but there is something looming about the onset of child No. 2 in New York," she said. "When you have one kid here you have the world at your fingertips."
In contrast to suburbia, where two or more children are the norm, Manhattan has become a veritable only-child paradise. Demographers, using figures supplied by the city, say that the single-child family is now the most-common family unit in Manhattan. More than 30 percent of all married women on the island in their early 40's -- that is, women who are largely past childbearing age and whose family size is most likely set -- have only a single child. Add to that the number of women under 40 with one child, and you have a raging plurality that the demographers, Andrew Beveridge and Susan Weber of Queens College, say could top 40 percent.
By contrast, the national figure for women ages 40 to 44 who have ever been married and have just one child is about 21 percent, according to Census Bureau data.
In the suburbs, only children are still often considered a curiosity, sometimes even a sad one. But in Manhattan, there is virtually no stigma attached to them. They are as much a part of the cultural fabric of the city as the unique circumstances that, in a word, breed them: small, expensive apartments, a huge proportion of women who delay marriage and childbearing to pursue careers, inadequate public schools and sky-high private school tuitions.
"There's nowhere else that the two-parent, one-child ratio is regarded so positively," said Len Covine, 46, an architect who lives in SoHo with his wife, Sophie, and their 5-year-old daughter, Lena.
"Walking on the streets here you can forget about the whole S.U.V. thing, the whole play-date thing, the whole soccer-mom thing," he said. "Instead, you can remember the museum thing, the Central Park thing, the matinee thing, the hop-into-a-taxi thing. Having a child here, one child, is completely different than the family experience anywhere else."
Another parent-of-one, Anita Farrington-Brathwaite, whose daughter, Monet, is 8, said: "I feel I have the best of both worlds. I have a career that's really meaningful to me, and I have a great deal of time to devote to my daughter. I really shudder at the thought of having to spread myself thinner."
Ms. Farrington-Brathwaite, an undergraduate dean at New York University, grew up in Queens and was herself an only child. She said she never thought of having more than one. "I grew up knowing that I had a really good deal, that my parents, who really didn't have that much money, were able to give me security I wouldn't have had otherwise," she said.
Ms. Farrington-Brathwaite, whose husband is also a college administrator, lives in a two-bedroom N.Y.U.-subsidized apartment and sends her daughter to the Little Red School House, a private school that has a large percentage of only children. "There is no way I could have done that if I had more than one child," she said.
Now that New York has been dubbed safe again and small-town schoolyard shootings are still fresh in the public's imagination, fewer couples seem to be moving out of town right after the birth of their first child. Then, a few years later, at the time most people decide to have a second child, these couples are loath to move. "New York," said Ms. Walker, who has returned to school to become a psychotherapist, "just gets in your blood."
But unlike Ms. Walker and her husband, who recently left a family business to start an Internet venture, many people simply decide not to have another child. Where members of an earlier generation might have felt guilty or conflicted about that decision, fearing they were depriving their child of sibling companionship, today a large body of research shows that only children do not suffer social or intellectual repercussions.
And a welcome aspect of having an only child in Manhattan is that such families do not stand apart, parents say. Amy Virshup, 40, a journalist who has a year-old son, Nicholas, lives with her husband, an architect, in an Upper West Side building that may stand as a microcosm of Manhattan: among the 24 apartments, there are seven couples with one child. Each of the children is old enough to suggest that the parents are unlikely to be planning more. "The only person who asks me when I'm going to have another kid is my cleaning woman," Ms. Virshup said. "She says I'm lazy."
With so many only children in town, the usual services and activities for infants and toddlers take on a special tinge. Play groups and luncheon clubs that specialize in first-time mothers -- a disproportionate number of the total mothers in the city -- have sprung up everywhere. "When I grew up as an only child, it was awful," recalled the novelist Dani Shapiro, 37, whose son, Jacob, is now 5 months old. "I was the only one in my entire private school class. But I know that if I don't decide to have another baby, Jacob will have lots of kids in his class who are only children. That really makes a huge difference to me."
While the percentage of only children in Manhattan is the highest in the United States, there has been a subtler boom in one-child families across the country. Only children are the nation's fastest-growing family demographic. Three-person families have grown from 10 million in 1972 to more than 15 million today, and between 1980 and 1990, the most recent census, there was a 76 percent increase among women nearing the end of childbearing with one child. That trend, plus the rising number of childless couples (nearly 18 percent), has lowered the United States birthrate to less than two per family. Demographers trace the decline to a rising divorce rate, higher costs to rear and educate children, a rise in the number of working women and a rising age of marriage.
Although choice is not always a factor in the decision to have an only child -- infertility is rising as women delay marriage and childbirth into their 30's -- more people than ever are consciously opting to have just one, experts say, especially in Manhattan. "Here there is a self-selection factor," said Dr. Kathleen Gerson, an N.Y.U. sociologist and the author of "Hard Choices: How Women Decide About Work, Career and Motherhood" (University of California, 1985). "They say, 'If staying in New York means having only one kid, I'll do it.' "
Only children may no longer be seen as deprived, but their parents still sometimes come in for criticism for being self-centered or for spoiling their offspring. "We seem to have a generation of Eloises in Manhattan," said Danielle Crittenden, a cultural critic and the author of "What Our Mothers Didn't Tell Us: Why Happiness Eludes the Modern Woman" (Simon & Schuster, 1999). "Our standards for what we think we need to give our children, in space and in things, is outrageous, absurd. Children are like consumptive items, like a Jaguar. It's very sad."
Dr. Gerson, who has a 16-year-old daughter who is an only child, said she is now interviewing 18- to 30-year-olds for her research, many of whom are themselves only children and "take having only one kid pretty much as a given."
Those decisions may well be influenced by the remarkable turnaround in the attitude of psychologists and child-rearing experts. Until the 1970's, the prevailing wisdom among experts, and society in general, was that having an only child was tantamount to cruelty. This view, shaped by turn-of-the century studies of the pioneering psychologist G. Stanley Hall, held that only children were spoiled and self-centered. "Being an only child," Dr. Hall wrote in 1892, "is a disease in itself." Dr. Hall's influence was profound: surveys throughout the years have shown that the primary reason people cite for having a second child is to make sure their first child isn't maladapted, Dr. Gerson said.
But in the last 20 years, there has been a 180-degree shift. Now, experts say there is virtually no difference between only children and first-born children in self-esteem, generosity, popularity and relations to parents. In fact, many studies show that only children score higher on I.Q. tests and are more popular with peers than children with several other siblings. The psychologist Toni Falbo published a review of 141 studies in 1984 and concluded, "Only children scored significantly better than other groups in achievement motivation and personal adjustment and were in all other respects indistinguishable from children with brothers and sisters."
Scanning volumes on child-rearing in Barnes & Noble, it is virtually impossible to find a condemnation of the choice to raise an only child. A new generation of name-brand experts in child-rearing has emerged, all of whom insist that Dr. Hall's studies had no basis in fact, including Ann Laybourn of the Centre for the Study of the Child and Society at Scotland's Glasgow University and Susan Newman, author of "Parenting an Only Child" (Doubleday, 1990). Last year, the journalist Bill McKibben wrote "Maybe One" (Simon & Schuster, 1998), an ecological defense of only childhood that used a battery of new studies as ammunition.
To cynics, and some parents of more than one child, it may be hard not to wonder if psychology is not merely reflecting changes in the societal landscape. With more women in the work force by choice or necessity, and higher rates of infertility, it may seem all too pat that new research shows that only children are not disadvantaged. "There is no doubt that we have a great ability to mold our ideas of what is good for our children based on what is good for us," Dr. Gerson said.
But that observation cuts both ways. The landscape of childhood has changed strikingly since Dr. Hall's time, and even since the 1960's. In the early part of the century, high child mortality rates and farms that needed extra hands likely influenced Dr. Hall's research showing that only children were a blight on society. Until the 1970's, when birth control burgeoned and women entered the work force significantly, having only one child was virtually never a conscious choice. The stigmatized only child was likely to be at home alone with his mother, a situation that might indeed have contributed to the perception that only children were overindulged.
"The whole obsession with the multi-child suburban family ideal flourished in the 1950's," Dr. Gerson said, "which was the height of the isolated nuclear family."
Now, many only children go to day care, since their mothers are more often employed than mothers with more children. "Children now learn socialization skills from other nonrelated children," Dr. Gerson said.
Mr. Covine, the architect, proudly flaunts a modern, boom-market attitude toward raising an only child. "Maybe a little selfishness isn't so bad," he said. "If it means my daughter goes to Harvard and over achieves, hey, I can live with that."
 
Where Wealth Begets Children
 
IN leafy suburban communities, there is nothing unusual about seeing a woman drive up in a sport utility vehicle with three children in the back. In much of Manhattan, however, such a sight is downright shocking, for a simple demographic reason: women who have more than two children are usually struggling economically. Demographic data analyzed by Queens College sociologists show that affluent parents almost always stick to one or two, if they have children at all.
But there is one neighborhood in which all bets are off: the Upper East Side. Although the actual percentage of women who have three or more children in Manhattan's toniest enclave is small -- only 6 percent (compared with 21 percent in Harlem) -- they are highly visible. That's likely because their resources are breathtaking. In Manhattan, three children can be a potent social signifier.
While the median income in almost every other neighborhood falls for families with three or more children, on the Upper East Side, it soars. In Chinatown, for example, the median household income is $36,000 for a family with one child, and $19,000 for a family with three or more children, according to the data compiled by Andrew Beveridge and Susan Weber of Queens College.
But on the Upper East Side, the median income for a one-child family is $120,000; for families with three or more children it nearly doubles, to $303,000 a year.
"Sometimes it really feels like there are virtually no regular people up here," said Erica Goldberg, who lives in a three-bedroom apartment on East 80th Street with her husband, Andrew, a management consultant, and three sons, all under 8. "And having a big family seems to be part of the package."
Ms. Goldberg, 36, said that 80 percent of her friends had at least three children. The last decade of extraordinary growth on Wall Street has contributed, she speculated, to a baby boom on Park Avenue and its environs. "I even know a woman who is having her fifth child. Personally, I find it really frightening, but she couldn't be happier or calmer."
Ms. Goldberg said her husband makes a very handsome living. Still, she doesn't count herself among the truly privileged, at least in East Side terms. True, they drive a Mercedes station wagon. They do not, however, have a second home.
In fact, while the youngest two children go to private school, they send their oldest son to P.S. 290, the well-regarded school in the neighborhood. "When I was trying to get the younger one into school, a friend who is incredibly well-to-do told me I should mention in the interview that my oldest child goes to public school," Ms. Goldberg said. "With a completely straight face she said the admissions people would like that because they were always looking for diversity." NANCY HASS

HEADLINE: The Untouchables

BYLINE: By Mark Morris; Mark Morris teaches Japanese literature at Cambridge University.

 BODY:

THE CAPE
 And Other Stories From the Japanese Ghetto.
 By Kenji Nakagami.
 Translated by Eve Zimmerman.
 191 pp. Berkeley, Calif.:
 Stone Bridge Press. Paper, $12.95. 
 When Kenji Nakagami was awarded the Akutagawa Prize in Japan in 1976, it was a commonplace to observe that he was the first writer born after the war to achieve that recognition. It was a more astute critic who noted that Nakagami was likely to be the last such writer to come from a family whose members could scarcely read what he wrote. Nowadays most young people from his background, while often still disadvantaged concerning employment or higher education, are at least literate. Nakagami, who died in 1992 at 46, belonged to a generation of Japan's excluded minority burakumin, in which perhaps only one out of five completed high school. He was one of the lucky ones; among his elders 80 percent or more never got beyond elementary education.
Seventy years before Nakagami's success, a Japanese writer, Toson Shimazaki, inaugurated a new phase in literary realism with "The Broken Commandment," a moving portrayal of the spiritual sufferings and eventual social ostracism of a young burakumin teacher. There had been earlier attempts to tackle the fate of the burakumin in fiction, usually by liberal-minded reformers or Christian authors. After Toson's time, writers might occasionally use the buraku ghetto as the scene for bohemian slumming, or re-create it, particularly after the war, as the setting for political melodrama. There was also Sue Sumii's multivolume saga "The River With No Bridge." Although this story is often moving and does take risks (as in a bitterly comic scene concerning the Emperor and his privy), even burakumin activists on occasion found the heights of sentimentality explored by this left-leaning sympathizer hard to appreciate.
However ambivalent the achievements of the writers who dared to treat this hidden side of Japanese society, through the century establishment critics had almost nothing to say about literature and the ghetto. One short special section in a major literary review in 1956, an article in the 70's and one more in the 80's. The next selection of relevant articles in a major journal finally showed up in 1994. And they are mainly about Kenji Nakagami, the first writer from the ghetto to make it into the mainstream and from within it to attempt to tell other Japanese, however fictively or even fantastically, about life at the rough end of the economic miracle.
The story that won the Akutagawa Prize is "The Cape," finally available in Eve Zimmerman's confident translation. She has combined it with one earlier, related story, "House on Fire," and joined to both one of Nakagami's many erotic (some readers may opt for the term pornographic) tales, "Red Hair." All three were written between 1975 and 1978, at the beginning of the author's most productive decade. Zimmerman's selection is a excellent point of entry into two of the main lines along which his writing would evolve: the family saga of Akiyuki and stories saturated with sexual obsession.
While he exists in outline in "House on Fire," Akiyuki only first steps forward as a focal character in "The Cape," which is novella length. Akiyuki, 24 and a virgin, seems content to vegetate, laboring for his brother-in-law's small contracting outfit. "Construction work suits Akiyuki. All day long he digs and shovels up earth. . . . The sun is hot. The breeze feels pleasant on his sweaty skin. He doesn't think." As the story makes clear, whether he chooses to think about it or not, he is haunted by both an absence and an excess of family. "Here, in such close quarters, they laughed, celebrated, groaned, violating and heaping abuse on one another. Even the ones most hated had a place here. . . . It amazed him. He felt stifled. Oppressed."
His mother, the closest thing this family-despite-itself has to a centripetal force, had three children by a man now dead, became pregnant with Akiyuki by a man she later rejected, then moved in with another man and his son, leaving her first three children to fend for themselves. The most poignant of all the absences suggested by this chaotic genealogy is that of Akiyuki's older half-brother. Driven mad by loneliness, alcohol and drugs, he had turned against his mother and her new family. "Time and time again, his brother had come to the house with a kitchen knife. Sometimes he came with an ax." He hanged himself when Akiyuki was 12 and he himself was 24.
As troubling by his absence from any normal parental role as by his presence, lurking on the periphery of Akiyuki's world, is his biological father: Akiyuki's consciousness can't even accord him a proper name; he remains "that man." "His brother had had a beautiful face, a mix of the father, Uncle Gen, and the mother. But Akiyuki's face belonged to that man. The ugliest face in the world, the crudest face, a face full of evil." This skulking father, redolent of violence and transgression, is sketched out in vivid detail in "House on Fire," where a reader gains some hint of how a gambler and arsonist elbowed his way into what would become Akiyuki's life.
The story's style of narration is even more complex than that of "The Cape." Here too there are strong hints about the catastrophic direction in which Nakagami would propel that man and his son in later, longer texts, like the author's best novel-length work, "Karekinada" (an untranslatable place name, as jagged with consonantal music as the rugged coast of Nakagami's Wakayama Prefecture, glossed by the translator as "Withered Tree Straits"), and eventually "The Sublime Time at the Ends of the Earth," Nakagami's most eloquent failure of a novel.
"Red Hair," many similar short stories and perhaps most of all the longer work "Psalm" seem uncannily to prefigure fin-de-si<heart>cle narcissism about sexuality -- or at least the sort of sex fetishized by academic criticism. "Red Hair," with its relatively simple conjugation of one man with one woman, is a provocative warm-up for the gymnastics of Nakagami's later erotica.
In this strikingly designed paperback, Stone Bridge Press has allowed Zimmerman to back her translations with a preface, an eloquent afterword and a short biographical sketch. There is as well a helpful genealogical chart, an eloquent visualization of this rare author's circuitry of family romance as family despair.

HEADLINE: Credit Offerings Scheduled for This Week

 BODY:
The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and an auction of two-year notes on Wednesday.
By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.91 percent, and a six-month bill was 5.04 percent. In when-issued trading the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 5.90 percent.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
In Chaotic Markets, Fantastic Results

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT 

 BODY:

THE PREDICTORS
By Thomas A. Bass
309 pages. Henry Holt. $25.
Readers of an entertaining earlier book by Thomas A. Bass, "The Eudaemonic Pie" (1985), will recall how from 1976 until 1981 a group of California physicists worked to break the banks at Las Vegas by predicting the outcome of the game of roulette. They designed miniature computers that fit inside their shoes, walked into a casino, punched into their computers the Newtonian numbers that govern roulette and started placing winning bets. 
 Well, that was just the beginning of their adventures in forecasting. In his lively new book, "The Predictors," Mr. Bass reports how the two leaders of Eudaemonic Enterprises, Doyne Farmer and Norman Packard, set about finding more complex things to predict than the eventual resting place of a metal ball bouncing around a rotating wheel.
As pioneers in the arcane science of chaos theory, Mr. Farmer and Mr. Packard saw possibilities of exploiting chaos as a predictive tool. What you could do, it had been discovered, was send a probe into a turbulent system, like two gases flowing next to each other, in which coherent patterns called fractals could tell you about the system in its entirety.
And what phenomenon would they model this time out? Not a dripping faucet, a measles epidemic or smoke rising from a cigarette in an ashtray, all of which are potential subjects of chaos theory. No, instead the physicists would study what was in a sense an extension of roulette, the behavior of financial markets, which Mr. Bass, with his vivid introductory description of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, makes seem the very paradigm of turbulence.
By discovering the order within disorder of the markets, nice money could be made, Mr. Bass asserts. "How much money?" he asks. Take an initial $100 million investment, "leverage it by a factor of 5, secure a 30 percent return, collect 25 percent of this as a fee for your services, and pocket a cool $37 million a year in profit." He adds: "This is a nice balance sheet for Year One. After that, real money."
In "The Predictors" Mr. Bass describes how the two chaos theoreticians tried to achieve these results, how they set up shop in Santa Fe, N.M., hired a scruffy band of Ph.D.'s to think and write software for them,how they sought out financial advisers and investors, eventually contracting with the powerful Swiss Bank Corporation (not gnomes of Zurich but behemoths of Basel) and how they went about decoding and modeling the commodities, currency and equities markets.
Mr. Bass has good narrative fun contrasting the loose-jointed working style of the Prediction Company, as it came to be called, with the Masters of the Universe who ended up financing the project. He lavishes some of the richest prose on the scenery surrounding the project's computer-crammed shop and on the local rituals in which the predictors partook, like Fiesta and the burning of Zozobra, also known as Old Man Gloom, a 40-foot puppet erected on a hill nearby.
More edifying, however, is Mr. Bass's use of his narrative to teach readers about chaos theory as it relates to economics, about the increasingly recondite instruments of investment in the age of derivatives and, perhaps most important, about the evolution of financial markets toward automation.
As the Prediction Company approaches success, creating software that models not only all markets but also all the world's stocks, at least the ones traded with some frequency, you wonder increasingly what the effect on those markets will be. Several of the company's employees wondered too, asking if "to make money this way is to be a parasite upon the financial system rather than to serve it," as one person put it. "Furthermore," he added, "it is pretty clear that the only way to make money consistently with such a technique is to keep it secret."
Mr. Packard's answer to these concerns was that "finding predictable structure and trading on it makes the markets more efficient." He continued: "Such trades reduce the overall volatility of the markets, and thus the risk to participants is reduced. The profits that go to the successful predictor are like a fee that the markets pay for the service of making them more efficient and less risky."
Mr. Farmer's response was even more to the point. "Making predictions is fundamental to financial markets," he said. "If people didn't think prices were going to change, they wouldn't trade. Price setting can be rational only insofar as the predictions that drive it are sensible. By making predictions and trading on them, we are indirectly helping society set its goals, even if we're also trying to make a profit."
Did the Prediction Company succeed? Although the answer is a matter of public record, it will not be repeated here, out of respect for Mr. Bass's energetic, serpentine narrative. Whatever the outcome, his story serves as a useful device for describing the increasing abstractness of contemporary finances, where markets derive from markets that in turn derive from derived markets. (Some passages of "The Predictors" read like Greek in their abstruseness, although Mr. Bass rarely uses terminology without coming back to it and defining it further along.)
But certainly you have doubts about the success of the venture, given the recent growing volume of voices arguing that markets are patternless and therefore unpredictable. At one point, the Prediction Company jokingly considered taking as its motto Lux Solis Ex Cucumero, meaning Sunlight From Cucumbers and referring to the academy in "Gulliver's Travels" where the academicians engaged in such an absurd project of extraction have to be protected from falling off cliffs or doing themselves other bodily harm.
Reading "The Predictors," you often feel that the computers Mr. Bass's heroes try to get light from might just as well be cucumbers hidden in their shoes. That they could eventually make money by reading the madness of crowds bidding up the price of tulip bulbs seems equally unlikely, until Mr. Bass gets through explaining in this instructive and amusing book.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Cable and Wireless Denies It's Ready for a Takeover
As the telecommunications industry goes through a whirlwind of merger-and-acquisition activity in the United States and Europe, there is constant speculation that Cable and Wireless of Britain is ripe for a takeover and ready to sell out.
The company's chief executive, Graham Wallace, dismisses that notion. He is trying to shift the company's focus away from its consumer businesses toward its business customers. That has meant selling some operations, including a deal announced yesterday to shed its holdings in Israel's state-controlled phone company for $630 million. Page C4. 

When the Product Is the Plan
The desire to cash out big is not a new motivating force in the technology industry. But what is striking about today's Internet economy is how many entrepreneurs are focused on selling business plans for their own sake rather than planning viable businesses. And the ability to pull cash out of companies quickly and with impunity may soon begin to crumple those Internet businesses that can no longer get money from investors or the public markets. Digital Commerce. C4.
 
Columbia Rejects Nisource Offer
Columbia Energy Group rejected a $6.1 billion takeover bid from the utility Nisource and said it would begin exploring other alternatives, including a merger with another company. The announcement came one week after Nisource sweetened its bid. C2.
 
Bigger Tent Sought for Road Show
The road show, the longtime practice of giving sophisticated investors a preview before an initial public offering, is being challenged by people who say all investors should be allowed to take part in conference calls about important information. In essence, the debate pits an Internet-age drive to give all investors equal access against many companies' desire to conduct private forums with the investors who still dominate the financial markets. C2.
 
Word-of-Mouth Opinions Go on Line
A handful of companies are hoping to take advantage of the age-old effectiveness of word-of-mouth recommendations by creating independent Web sites that give common folks and bona fide experts a forum to voice their opinions and users a way to rate the pundits. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. C16.
 
PC Shipments Up 23% in 3d Quarter
The personal computer industry is continuing to show significant global growth, with third-quarter shipments increasing by 23.2 percent compared with those in the quarter a year earlier, according to a report to be issued today by Dataquest, a market research company. C4.
 
MTV Show to Have Web Players
In the latest attempt to attain true convergence of television and the Internet, MTV plans to start a music-trivia game show in which viewers can play along by logging onto MTV's Web site. The program, "Web Riot," will have its debut late next month, but MTV plans to start promoting it today and to let potential players begin downloading the required software. Media executives -- particularly advertisers -- will be waiting for MTV to prove that the time for convergence has finally arrived. C21.
 
Crichton Makes Box-Office Deal
The author Michael Crichton has made an unusual deal with Paramount Pictures for his newest novel. Instead of collecting millions of dollars by selling the rights to the studio, he has opted to take a sizable percentage of the box-office receipts. Executives said they could not recall a similar deal with a novelist. C6.

HEADLINE: U.S. Treasury Chief Meets Chinese Premier

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: LANZHOU, China, Oct. 24

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers and China's Prime Minister, Zhu Rongji, discussed economic issues and China's campaign to enter the World Trade Organization in almost three hours of talks today that Mr. Summers said were "very useful."
The two discussed how China's entry into the trade organization could benefit both countries, Mr. Summers told reporters. He had flown to Lanzhou, an industrial city in northwest China that Mr. Zhu was visiting. 
 "Premier Zhu and I had a very useful, warm and candid discussion on a full range of issues affecting both our economies," the Treasury Secretary said.
China's effort to join the trade organization has been held up by American, European and Canadian demands that it first do more to lower trade barriers to foreign goods and investment. China has said that opening its markets too far too fast would hurt it economically. President Clinton rejected trade concessions offered by Mr. Zhu when he visited the United States in April.
Mr. Summers, who arrived in Beijing on Saturday, is the first Cabinet-level official from the United States to visit China since NATO warplanes bombed the Chinese Embassy in Yugoslavia in May, killing three Chinese citizens.

SECTION: Section A; Page 31; Column 2; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 586 words

HEADLINE: Unnecessary Reform

BYLINE: By Gerald Posner; Gerald Posner is the author of "Citizen Perot."

 BODY:
Pat Buchanan is expected to bolt the Republican Party today to run for the Reform Party nomination, and Donald Trump said yesterday he too is joining the Reform Party in advance of a possible Presidential bid. But there is likely to be little celebration inside the Reform ranks, because while both men may generate a lot of national attention, they are unlikely to improve the party's diminishing prospects.
There are, of course, many reasons why the Reform Party has lost its bearings. Ross Perot's desire to control its every aspect has discouraged many serious candidates from running. Jesse Ventura, the wrestler turned governor, can talk himself into any amount of trouble. Social issues like abortion continue to divide the party. 
 But there is another important reason the Reform Party has become the butt of so many late-night jokemeisters: the strong economy.
Contrary to what many pundits have said, the Reform Party does have an agenda -- it supports fiscal conservatism and trade protectionism. That's not at all far afield from Mr. Buchanan's fiscal philosophy, nor does it seem to clash with what little we know of Mr. Trump's beliefs.
But if economic synergy has made a match of either Mr. Trump or Mr. Buchanan and the Reform Party, it may also keep the party from duplicating the success of Ross Perot in the 1992 Presidential election, when he won almost 20 percent of the vote.
Their economic policies just aren't relevant in today's economy.
During the heady days following the 1992 Presidential election, the Reform movement seemed poised to become the first viable independent party in several generations, one that might attract interesting political candidates who were misfits in the two major parties.
Mr. Buchanan also scored his biggest victories in 1992, winning a surprising 37 percent of the vote in the New Hampshire primary that made him a credible rival to George Bush. He won largely by capitalizing on discontent about the economy. (Likewise, Mr. Trump is now warning of a possible recession, hoping that such uncertainty might play to his strength as a savvy businessman.)
But calls for fiscal conservatism worked much better in 1992, when the economy was in poor shape. Today, the sky-high stock market, low unemployment and cheap interest rates have all taken the steam out of the party's issues.
With the Dow Jones at 10,000, it will take more than the North American Free Trade Agreement to get the average voter fired up. What would benefit the Reform Party -- short of a well-defined platform that addresses important issues like health care reform and Social Security -- is a recession, complete with spiraling inflation and rising unemployment. That might make voters wish for a pox on the houses of both the Republicans and Democrats and start looking in earnest for alternatives.
But the question is, would the Reform Party then turn to Donald Trump or Pat Buchanan? A recession might make the Reform Party seem more attractive to substantive candidates, like Lowell Weicker or Colin Powell, who have broader appeal and more credibility.
At the party's 1996 national convention, one of the delegates told me that it stood for "anyone but the other two guys." That's not enough anymore. Mr. Trump and Mr. Buchanan won't help the Reform Party unless they change their messages to suit the times and stop overplaying dire economic warnings. If they don't, it may cost both of them -- and the party itself -- whatever credibility they may have. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Forbes Lavishly Champions Austerity

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

DATELINE: CONCORD, N.H., Oct. 24

 BODY:
Steve Forbes, the multimillionaire publisher who is again running for President, brought his anti-tax crusade here this weekend, spending his own money lavishly in order to promote his view that the Government should have less and spend less.
Mr. Forbes, who is seeking the Republican Presidential nomination, came to unveil what he and his staff had promoted as the Forbes New Economy Plan. But the plan was largely based on same views that he has long advocated: shrinking Government, shrinking taxes, shrinking the Federal deficit and increasing individual wealth. 
 He promised that if his conservative economic plan were enacted, the decade ahead would be "dazzling": wages would increase 62 percent, 24.5 million new jobs would be created, and the United States economy would double its current growth rate and expand by 75 percent.
"We want to cut taxes and return the money to the people who earned it," said Mr. Forbes, in his stump campaign speech. Wherever he said it, the line drew loud applause.
At a campaign stop at the Oakledge Country Club in Sunapee, N.H., Steve White agreed: "We're overtaxed. We're unfairly taxed. Taxes are confiscatory. In New Hampshire, we are very fiscally conservative, and we don't like our money to go to the Government."
Mr. Forbes's plan, amplified with additional economic statistics, consists of his basic message, which is that enacting a 17.3 percent flat Federal income tax, replacing Social Security with individual retirement accounts for younger workers and making the Government smaller will bring about a supply-side economic boom.
To get his anti-tax message out, Mr. Forbes is spending heavily here. Forbes television commercials flood the airwaves, direct mail brochures blanket doorsteps, phone banks work constantly and Mr. Forbes is crisscrossing the state in a two-bus caravan filled with sophisticated electronic equipment enabling him to instantaneously transmit campaign events to his Web site.
His campaign pays such close attention to detail that even the pumpkins at his Manchester campaign headquarters were carved with Forbes 2000 logos. Altogether he is spending money at the rate of $3 million a month, according to his campaign manager, William Dal Col.
In spending, Mr. Forbes is running almost neck-and-neck with the Republican front-runner, George W. Bush. Mr. Bush has spent $20 million since January, compared with $19 million by Mr. Forbes, who has a net worth of more than $400 million.
The big difference, however, is that while Mr. Bush's campaign cash comes from donations, the bulk of Mr. Forbes's spending is from his own pocket.
Moreover, Mr. Dal Col said the Forbes campaign anticipates big spending ahead. With 113 people on the Forbes payroll and campaign offices in states as far-flung as Alaska, Arizona, Delaware, Iowa and Louisiana, among others, Mr. Dal Col said the campaign has sufficient resources to engage Mr. Bush both on the ground with grass-roots organizations and in the air with television commercials.
Mr. Dal Col said the Forbes campaign will not hesitate to use the same kind of hard-hitting television advertisements against Mr. Bush that Mr. Forbes used against Bob Dole, the Republican front-runner in the 1996 primaries. Those advertisements were criticized by many Republicans for being overly harsh on Mr. Dole and for causing his support to drop in key electoral states.
But Mr. Dal Col maintains that spirited attacks are what campaigns are all about.
The Forbes campaign is broadcasting advertisements in New Hampshire and just finished broadcasting ads in Iowa. These advertisements promoted Mr. Forbes's views on taxes and Social Security.
Yet for all the money Mr. Forbes is spending, he also engaged in traditional meet-and-greet sessions, often laced with humor.
At the Belmont Restaurant in Manchester, Mr. Forbes turned to a table of four men and, on this rainy morning, promised: "If I'm elected, I'll do something about this weather." To 7-year-old Maxwell Lawrence of Manchester, Mr. Forbes added: "And if I'm elected, you won't have homework."

HEADLINE: Mrs. Clinton Again Asks Minimum Wage Rise

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
With two economists and the head of New York's largest coalition of labor unions by her side, Hillary Rodham Clinton implicitly attacked Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday for not supporting an increase in the Federal minimum wage and suggested that he had not done enough to help the poor in New York.
"Despite the wonderful news about the national economy in general, poverty has gone up here in New York City," she said, in a visit yesterday afternoon to the headquarters of Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers in Flushing, Queens. "Now there are those who have opposed an increase in the minimum wage, arguing that it will cost jobs, and there are some people who say that we need still more studies. Well, they are wrong." 
 In what has become a customary tactic in her exploratory campaign for a United States Senate seat, the First Lady did not mention the Mayor, her likely Republican opponent next year, by name. Instead, she left the direct attack on Mr. Giuliani to Brian McLaughlin, an Assemblyman from Queens who is also president of the New York City Central Labor Council.
Mrs. Clinton listened attentively as two economists for the Fiscal Policy Institute, a nonprofit group in Albany supported in part by unions, challenged Mr. Giuliani's assertions that raising the base wage could result in jobs being lost and hinder welfare-to-work policies. Then, she quickly launched into her own veiled attack.
Mr. Giuliani, who has repeatedly said he would like to see more studies on the effect of raising the minimum wage, did so again yesterday. Mr. Giuliani also repeated his statement that he expects to come to support the wage increase eventually. "My stand on the minimum wage is that I have asked a study to be conducted to determine the impact it would have on poor people getting jobs," he said.
"If the impact is minimal," the Mayor said, "I'll support it. If the impact is substantial, then I'll try to find ways to ameliorate that, which is what I have done in the past. So I think what I am doing is actually much more caring and much more compassionate and that is not to just look at a poll and be in favor of something." Mr. Giuliani said he had asked the city's Human Resources Administration and the Economic Development Corporation to study the proposed increase in the minimum wage now being considered in Congress, to $6.15 from $5.15, over two years. "I anticipate that I'll eventually support it, but first I have to see what their study shows," he said.
At the union headquarters in Queens, Mrs. Clinton stood by Mr. McLaughlin, a Democrat, as he criticized the Mayor by name, just as she has stood by on other recent occasions as Representative Charles B. Rangel of Harlem, Borough President Fernando Ferrer of the Bronx and other Democratic elected officials rebuked Mr. Giuliani for his position on the Brooklyn Museum or the Republican Federal tax cut proposal.
"I have often heard that we live in the greatest city on earth," Mr. McLaughlin said, an apparent reference to Mr. Giuliani's habit of calling New York the capital of the world.
"Greatness is measured in how well we treat the less fortunate among us," he said. "And with 25 percent of this city living in poverty, we must strive and can do better."
Mr. Giuliani derided Mrs. Clinton for having no experience as a government official. "This is really the difference between substantive politics and more in the nature of pandering politics," he said. "It's the difference between actually having responsibilities in government and then not having responsibilities in government."
