HEADLINE: High-Tech Gets Low Priority in Berkeley

BYLINE: By KATIE HAFNER 

DATELINE: BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 22

 BODY:
In the midst of California's latest gold rush, here is a city looking for lead.
As high-tech companies sprout on all sides, this city of 107,000 people is making a concerted effort to preserve its low-tech core. In the process, lost in a Zeitgeist all its own, Berkeley has managed to deter the one industry that most cities are scrambling to attract. 
 Earlier this year, executives at Ask Jeeves, an Internet start-up that has expanded so rapidly it outgrew its offices here, began looking for a new building. The company's preference was to stay in Berkeley but, unable to find a suitable spot, Ask Jeeves moved to Emeryville, a half mile south.
"We wondered if someone from the city would try to contact us," said Curtis Vredenburg, a company executive who led the search for a new site. "But no one did."
Other local high-tech companies do not even bother with Berkeley. When Pixar, the animation studio of "Toy Story" fame, began looking for new space three years ago in anticipation of a growth spurt, Berkeley did not make the short list, in part because of the lengthy permit process. Pixar plans to move next year to Emeryville from Point Richmond, just north of Berkeley, leapfrogging Berkeley in the process.
No one here is surprised. But even those who say that Berkeley has recently grown less hostile to business are exasperated.
"They're stuck in the 60's," Mayor Shirley Dean said of those who stand firm on the city's manufacturing-friendly policies.
As an example, the Mayor pointed to last year's Colgate controversy.
Indeed, if Hollywood were looking for a spot to film an urban bomb scene, it would find a ready-made set in the abandoned Colgate-Palmolive plant, whose 10 acres of buildings have steadily deteriorated since the company left nearly 20 years ago.
Last year, a developer proposed an office complex for the site that would have drawn multiple software, multimedia and biotech firms to the city. But when the city decided that 20 percent of the site must be used for manufacturing, the proposal died.
"It was breathtaking in its stupidity," said Patrick Kennedy, a developer. "Here's the whole Bay Area booming, and what we've done is snub the whole world, basically."
Defenders of the policy say that unless the city preserves its manufacturing base, social and economic diversity will suffer. They argue, too, that the city simply does not have the space to serve as much more than an incubator to high-tech start-ups.
Nathan Landau, a senior planner with the city, credits the policy for a small increase in the number of manufacturing companies over the last decade. He said the issues surrounding manufacturing were widely misunderstood.
"These are parts of the economy that are often different from the university-based economy that a lot of us in Berkeley are used to, and I think it's not always necessarily visible," Mr. Landau said. "But that doesn't mean it's not happening."
The part of the city most mired in dispute, known as West Berkeley, is an eclectic assemblage of manufacturers, warehouses, parking lots and residences, with a smattering of upscale retailers, eateries and offices.
In 1985, when city planners and residents began working on what came to be known as the West Berkeley Plan, which calls for a small number of choice parcels to be set aside for manufacturing, leftists and left-leaning moderates alike were in favor of it. When the City Council approved the plan in 1993, people began to think it might be flawed. Now those same people are sure of it.
"West Berkeley is being held hostage to the sentiment on the part of some activists that the city has to return to the good old days of lunch-pail jobs and blue-collar industry," said Polly Armstrong, a City Council member. "They're a group of people who appear to be waiting for General Motors to come to Berkeley to launch a new Saturn plant."
The stagnation stems from a classic case of Berkeley's most earnest residents getting "lost in their own Berkeleyness," as a longtime Berkeley fixture named Wavy Gravy once described it when running for City Council on a platform of lightening things up. (He lost.)
The feather in the city's hard hat is the biotechnology center of the Bayer Corporation's pharmaceutical division. Bayer, the city's largest manufacturer, is now buying the Colgate site, partly to use for parking.
In stark contrast, Emeryville, a swatch of a place, is the most direct beneficiary of Berkeley's restrictive policies. Thanks to its lenient zoning and speedy permit process, Emeryville has an impressive roster of computer and biotech firms. Ask Jeeves's 300 or so employees, up from 50 a year ago, occupy 50,000 square feet in a building on the site of a defunct Westinghouse plant.
Alameda, another relatively obscure city south of Berkeley, is nurturing a high-tech boomlet of its own. And Mayor Jerry Brown of Oakland, hardly a capitalist tool, is promoting his city as this side of the Bay's newest "high-tech settlement."
And so high-flying Internet companies continue to leave Berkeley when they grow beyond a certain size.
Shortly before Cybergold, another high-tech company, moved from downtown Berkeley to Oakland in July, the chief executive, Nat Goldhaber, got a call from an official in Berkeley's economic development office asking why the company was leaving. Mr. Goldhaber said he needed a building big enough to accommodate substantial growth and wired for Internet access.
"The person from the city said, 'Oh. Have a nice time in Oakland,' " Mr. Goldhaber said.

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
A Clinton Whiz Kid Who's Still There and Still a Believer

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
GENE SPERLING, director of the National Economic Council, assistant to the President for economic policy and legendary workaholic, was alternating between Diet Coke and coffee at 10 P.M. on Thursday.
He was trying to reflect on his life, but the final negotiations on legislation to overhaul the nation's financial services industry were playing out on Capitol Hill, and Mr. Sperling was in the thick of it. So periodically an assistant would come to the door to announce a phone call from Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers or the like, requiring Mr. Sperling to retreat, take the call, return and then try to slip back into cosmic mode. 
 For example, why has he endured, when so many of the other Clinton whiz kids have not?
"When you ask what keeps somebody here, it really is that knowledge that you may never have the opportunity to have this kind of impact again in your life," Mr. Sperling said, somewhat wistfully. "And that you have a chance, at times, to do good things for people who may not have the power to be at the table."
He worried, a moment later, about sounding self-important; in reality, as he reminisced about the economic battles of the Clinton years, he sounded like one of the last true believers. Most of the Clinton believers who made the leap from the campaign are gone -- feeling burned out or betrayed or simply ready for something new. Mr. Sperling is enmeshed in his seventh season of budgetary combat.
His job, previously held by Robert E. Rubin and Laura D'Andrea Tyson, puts him in the center of the Administration's economic agenda; he brings a deeply political background. In addition to his role in last week's banking negotiations, Mr. Sperling is a prime strategist on the Administration's latest Social Security move, to try to shore up the program with projected Federal budget surpluses, and -- not coincidentally -- prevent the Republicans from seizing the political high ground.
Mr. Sperling was out berating the Republican opposition on CNN on Sunday, asserting that they had a "cynical strategy to say that Democrats are spending Social Security surplus when they are."
His sparring partner, Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, chairman of the Budget Committee, shot back, "This is typical of this White House, and I'm very sorry that the White House staff is not advising in a different mode."
In President Clinton's first term, Mr. Sperling was deputy director of the National Economic Council, and in the trenches for the budget battles of 1993 and 1995. He was economic policy director for the Clinton campaign in 1992. One of the advantages of his longevity, he says, is his relationship with the President.
"You know where his policy vision and his heart is," Mr. Sperling said. "And he knows you know where his policy vision and his heart is."
Mr. Sperling is 40 now, much better dressed, and no longer carrying the air of a grad student the day after an all-nighter. He has his workaholic tendencies under better control, he suggests: "Definitely have eased up some, but it's still at times too much." In fact, W magazine recently declared the never-married Mr. Sperling "one of the hottest catches on the Washington social scene" and "an unusually likable policy wonk." (This caused no end of amusement at the White House, including a "Dating Game"-style introduction by one of his colleagues in the press briefing room: "He loves tennis, rapid G.D.P. growth and romantic midnight walks on West Executive Drive.")
Mr. Sperling recently betrayed a touch of midlife crisis, going bungee-jumping on a Presidential visit to New Zealand. "It was a personal, conquer-your-fears challenge by a person who's seriously afraid of heights," he said.
BUT Mr. Sperling is still the same passionately political policy wonk that he was in 1988, when he was happily spinning reporters about the virtues of the college loan program proposed by Michael S. Dukakis, then the Democratic nominee for President. When asked about his best moments in the White House, Mr. Sperling tended toward budgets, like the passage of the 1993 agreement, "the sense that after all the campaign battling over the budget, you'd been part of a team that had actually done something significant, in terms of deficit reduction, in terms of the earned income tax credit."
When asked his worst moment, he cited 1995, when the Republicans had just taken over Congress: "The fear that very important protections in Medicaid, the earned income tax credit and food stamps would be undermined on your watch."
One of four children of a lawyer and an educational consultant, Mr. Sperling grew up in Ann Arbor, Mich., went to the University of Minnesota, received his law degree from Yale and attended Wharton Business School. He was one of a generation of young Democrats who came of age during the Reagan years and yearned to bring their party back to power with policies that broadened its appeal, particularly an economic message that could embrace both strong private-sector growth and strong Federal spending on social policy.
As the interview was ending, Mr. Sperling returned to the question about his best moments in the White House. What it came down to, he said, was "that special sense of camaraderie that you feel with certain people, when you have a mission and a cause you believe in." There seemed to be a lot of ghosts in the room, from Robert E. Rubin to George Stephanopoulos. Earlier, Mr. Sperling acknowledged that he missed them.

HEADLINE: Standoff on Budget Yields An Unexpected Dividend

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24

 BODY:
For all the political blood shed over President Clinton's spending proposals and efforts by Republicans to cut taxes, the standoff this year over budget policy has led the two parties into a third course, the slashing of the national debt, that could have enormous political and economic consequences.
Such a momentous decision, made almost by default as each side blocked the other's proposals for allocating projected Federal budget surpluses, has ramifications that are sure to eclipse the outcome of the current sparring over financing for education, across-the-board spending cuts and the like. 
 Despite the magnitude of the decision, it was made without an explicit vote or even a full debate in Congress and the country.
Although there were trillions of dollars in projected surpluses on the table in a town that has never had trouble parceling out money, the two sides essentially battled each other to a draw on what to do with that money. There was no big tax cut. There was no big surge in Government spending. There was no expansion of Medicare and no agreement on how to shore up Social Security.
Yet gridlock in this case meant that the surplus was left more or less intact. And because of the way the Government's finances work, running a surplus means that the excess revenues flowing into Washington will automatically go to paying down the debt the nation ran up during decades of deficit spending and doing so at a pace that would have been considered fantasy even a year ago.
Should the Government stick to the course on which it is setting out, it could eliminate the most important component of the debt, the $3.6 trillion in Treasury bonds owned by the public, in 10 or 15 years.
While the approach was never put to a vote or even fully debated in Congress, it yielded an outcome that most economists, including Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, consider very positive for the economy over the long run.
Reducing the publicly held debt would put pressure on interest rates to go down and free up capital for private enterprise to use in building factories or developing technologies.
It would reduce the Government's interest expense and increase the Government's capacity to borrow in the future if it needs cash for looming problems like the projected shortfall in Social Security's reserves.
"Buying down debt in large amounts is a truly momentous and entirely salutary decision," said Carol Cox Wait, president of the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget, a fiscal watchdog group. "It is the one thing we can do in the short term to put us in a much better position to deal with the problems we face in the long term."
Debt reduction was basically a fallback position for both parties, embraced in its own right only after President Clinton blocked the Republican effort to cut taxes and Republicans stymied calls by Democrats for higher Government spending.
"Neither party had debt reduction as its priority, but it ended up being the common denominator they could agree on through gridlock," said Van Doorn Ooms, research director for the Committee for Economic Development, a business-financed research group.
Politicians of all stripes quickly found that debt reduction, which they had long considered arcane and difficult to sell to voters as an accomplishment, had a political appeal far greater than they had anticipated.
President Clinton would return to the White House from speeches and tell aides that he had been unexpectedly interrupted by applause when he mentioned debt reduction. At town hall meetings, constituents would tell members of Congress that if a family were to receive a financial windfall, it should go to cleaning up credit card bills, not a new car or a vacation -- and that the Government should have the same attitude.
"It's a metaphor the American people instantly understand," said Representative John M. Spratt Jr. of South Carolina, the senior Democrat on the House Budget Committee.
Still, the support for debt reduction in Washington remains somewhat tenuous, and neither party sees continued gridlock as a long-term strategy, particularly since Washington has only deferred long-term problems like the solvency of Social Security and Medicare.
Some conservative Republicans maintain that tax cuts would help the economy more than debt reduction. Some liberal Democrats say higher spending on areas like education and health care would prove the best way to invest the surplus in the nation's future. Should divided government give way to a situation in which one party controlled both the White House and Congress, support for debt reduction might dissipate.
Moreover, changing economic circumstances could lead one or both parties to reassess their commitment to debt reduction as the first fiscal priority.
Should the economy turn down, both parties would probably support some form of tax cut as a stimulus to recovery, and there could also be backing for increased spending, especially on social welfare programs like unemployment insurance and job training.
"Debt reduction isn't everything," said Robert L. Bixby, executive director of the Concord Coalition, a fiscal policy group. "It happens to be a very good and responsible thing to do at this point in our nation's demographic and economic history, but in other economic times it might not be true."
But given that both Mr. Clinton and Republican leaders in Congress have pledged not to spend any of the portion of the surplus generated by excess Social Security payroll tax revenues -- a promise that could bring swift political retribution if broken by either side -- the fiscal debate in coming years seems likely to be biased toward debt reduction.
"The taboo against spending Social Security trust fund surpluses probably will be a continuing reality for some years to come," said Ms. Wait of the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget.
The national debt began surging in the early 1980's as Washington began running huge annual deficits, forcing the Treasury to borrow to make up the difference between tax revenues and spending. Debt held by the public went to a peak of $3.77 trillion, or 47.2 percent of the gross domestic product, in 1997, from $710 billion or 26.1 percent in 1980. Surpluses the last two years have allowed the Government to reduce the debt to $3.6 trillion, or about 40 percent of the gross domestic product.
National debt can also be defined to include money the Government owes to itself, primarily in the form of promises to pay future Social Security benefits. By that measure, the debt, now about $5.6 trillion, will continue to grow for the foreseeable future as the population ages and commitments to retirees mount.
More than anything else, it was the political power of Social Security that brought debt reduction to the top of the fiscal agenda.
Mr. Clinton started the process when he called in his 1998 State of the Union address for the surplus to be left untouched until the two parties had agreed on a plan to strengthen Social Security's financial condition before the retirement of the vast baby-boom generation.
His strategy, which proved successful, was to block Republicans on their signature issue by framing the fiscal choice before the country as being between saving Social Security and having a big tax cut. At the time, White House aides said, debt reduction was considered a nice byproduct of the strategy, but not the main goal.
But by early this year, with the size of the projected surpluses growing almost by the month, pressure was growing in both parties to do something with the fiscal windfall. So Mr. Clinton set out a new framework, saying that 63 percent of the total budget surplus over the next 15 years should be used directly or indirectly for Social Security, with the rest going to a variety of other programs, including the military and education.
Late last winter, Senator Pete V. Domenici, the New Mexico Republican who is chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, saw a way to trump the White House. He pointed out that Mr. Clinton's proposal would allow the Government to spend some of the portion of the surplus being generated by Social Security, a practice in which the Government had engaged for decades.
Mr. Domenici put forward a budget framework that allowed Republicans to claim that they would not spend any of the Social Security surplus, which amounts to roughly $2 trillion of the $3 trillion total surplus over the next decade. House Republicans like Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, the chairman of the House Budget Committee, were reluctant at first, fearing that the plan would limit their ability to press for an immediate tax cut. But they eventually went along with it.
Democrats, particularly in the House, were equally reluctant to sign on to a program of austerity at a time of fiscal plenty. But by early summer, Mr. Clinton had agreed that he too would leave the Social Security surplus untouched, and most Democrats in Congress, not wanting to cede the high ground as protectors of the New Deal social welfare legacy, went along.
The effect was a bipartisan consensus to allocate two-thirds of the total surplus to debt reduction, reached before either party had fully thought through the consequences.
Since then the two parties have been grappling with how to turn their pledge into policy, starting with a budget for the fiscal year that began on Oct. 1. It is still unclear that the two parties will be completely able to make good on their promise.
Republicans have resorted to all manner of budget gimmicks to pass spending bills that leave the Social Security surplus untouched this year, and are counting on spending cuts that Mr. Clinton has already said are unacceptable to him. Mr. Clinton has proposed a tax increase on cigarettes as an alternative to spending Social Security money, but has little support for the idea in Congress.

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer;
America Finds Democracy a Difficult Export

BYLINE: By TINA ROSENBERG 

 BODY:
Among the many effects of democracy's spread through much of the developing world in the last few decades is the birth of a new American industry, democracy promotion. Beginning in the early 1990's, Washington began a wide variety of programs worldwide to help third-world countries democratize, including training election observers, improving parliamentary libraries, cajoling political parties to form coalitions, teaching citizens' groups how to lobby and helping independent newspapers write business plans. Last year the American government spent $719 million on these efforts.
While democracy has given rise to democracy promotion, the reverse is less clear. There has been no systematic effort to find out what programs actually aid democracy. Journalists mainly focus on scandals or feel-good stories of democratic triumph. Groups that do democracy promotion, mainly the Agency for International Development, must wrest funding from a hostile Congress every year and are under pressure to report quick success. Evaluation is also complicated because many factors affect political development -- and few agree on how to measure democracy or even what it is. 
 Thomas Carothers's forthcoming book, "Aiding Democracy Abroad: The Learning Curve," seeks to draw some general conclusions about what works. Mr. Carothers, now vice president for global policy at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace in Washington, has worked in democracy programs in various countries. His book is a clear-eyed examination of attempts to reform legislatures, courts and political parties, and new efforts to promote democracy from the bottom up by helping local governments and civil society. He focuses on how these programs have worked in Romania, Guatemala, Zambia and Nepal.
Mr. Carothers's conclusion is that democracy promotion cannot make the difference. No American democracy consultant can affect the underlying conditions of a country that really determine its democratic progress -- concentrations of power and wealth, political traditions, the expectations of citizens.
But the right programs over the long term, he says, can do much in countries where a government genuinely wants democracy but lacks expertise -- nations such as South Africa, Slovakia or Chile. In dictatorships, aid to the besieged opposition can keep hope alive. But in nations that enjoyed some democratic progress but fell into strongman rule -- such as Peru, Haiti, Cambodia, Kazakhstan or Zambia -- classic democracy promotion efforts to reform government institutions have been thwarted by leaders who have little interest in sharing power.
Few veterans of the business would dispute these fairly straightforward conclusions. The democracy promoters at A.I.D., and at the political-party-run National Democratic Institute and International Republican Institute, are learning from their early mistakes. Hubris was one of them. Being American was once deemed synonymous with possessing expertise in democracy, and many consultants were campaign aides or Congressional staff people who knew little about the countries they visited.
Democracy promoters are also changing their earlier tendency to dictate pre-cooked solutions that do not fit reality. And even when Americans came in with good ideas, the lack of local input often kept them from being embraced and sustained.
A more persistent problem is the tendency to emphasize form over substance. Democracy programs have largely helped foreign countries replicate certain practices -- congressional hearings, for example. Today, Mr. Carothers believes, activists are beginning to see that these forms of democracy are easily manipulated by autocratic leaders, and that governments reform only when they want to. In Guatemala, he writes, a 10-year American effort to train the police did not limit police abuses. What did work was the election of new leaders who pressed the security forces to reduce brutality.
Today, Mr. Carothers writes, democracy promoters try to be more attuned to the political realities of the countries they work in. This understanding has not yet meant the abandonment of unrealistic efforts to work with authoritarian governments. But where governments resist reform, American consultants now try to strengthen democratic forces by boosting grass-roots groups, local governments and women's organizations. Americans increasingly stay for months or years of intensive work rather than a few days. In many places American organizations use regional experts, sending Filipinos to Indonesia or Poles to Bulgaria -- people who are often better received and know more about local realities.
What critics of democracy promotion often overlook is that the industry's mistakes have exactly mirrored the problems that bedevil American foreign policy in general, including hubris and the tendency to confuse surface reforms with deep-seated change. Democracy activists, moreover, seem to have learned more rapidly from their mistakes. Some in the Pentagon still believe that foreign officers will become less abusive if they rub elbows with the American citizen-soldier, and many in the administration and Congress argue that Myanmar's or China's dictatorships will soften if exposed to American business practices.
Few democracy activists today, by contrast, are naive enough to think that a tour of America will instill democratic values. The industry has carried out its share of useless programs. But it is learning -- and faster than its Congressional critics, who still fail to realize that building democracy in many developing nations is both crucial to American interests and resistant to instant solutions.

HEADLINE: Polytechnic U. Plans a Makeover Using Gift, but Not Everyone Is Happy

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
When we last left the Cinderella tale of Polytechnic University in Brooklyn, it was celebrating a bequest of $175 million from one of its former chemistry professors and his wife and grappling with the pleasant problem of how to spend it.
Polytechnic officials have developed a plan to use the gift not only to strengthen the university's technical programs, but also to serve students who are less technically oriented. The university will create a joint degree program with small liberal arts colleges, a bachelor of science degree in liberal studies and more education programs for executives. 
 But while the plan has drawn plaudits from many professors, students and others with knowledge of its details, which are to be formally released today, it has displeased Long Island's high-technology industries because it will mean shutting the university's undergraduate program in Farmingdale, which has about 375 students. The graduate program will remain there.
"Poly is a key economic resource for the region, and its closure is going to be a problem," said Ken Aupperle, president of Hauppauge Digital Inc., in Hauppauge, Suffolk County, and a member of the Farmingdale campus's advisory board.
Polytechnic officials said upgrading both campuses would be too expensive. "We can't afford to invest in two world-class facilities at once," said David C. Chang, Polytechnic's president.
The $175 million windfall is Polytechnic's share of a $340 million gift to five Brooklyn institutions from the estate of Donald Othmer, a Polytechnic professor who died in 1995, and his wife, Mildred, who died in April 1998. The couple, who lived in Brooklyn Heights, amassed enormous wealth by investing with Warren E. Buffett, a fellow Omaha native who is one of the world's richest men.
Polytechnic officials hope to turn their commuter university, which has 1,700 undergraduates and 1,600 graduate students, into a more nationally prominent institution by overhauling its curriculum and offering housing at its main site at the Metrotech Center in Downtown Brooklyn.
The plan calls for $100 million in construction and renovation, including a new five-story academic building and athletic center and a 400-bed dormitory at Metrotech. Polytechnic will also overhaul its main academic building, Rogers Hall.
The work will be financed partly by the $175 million gift and partly by $100 million being raised in the university's capital campaign. The university also plans to use $25 million to endow research through the creation of the Othmer Institute for Interdisciplinary Studies.
Dr. Chang said the university will also use the gift to extend its reach to students beyond its traditional base. "We want to educate students outside of traditional engineers and computer scientists," he said.
The university, he said, will form an alliance with small liberal arts colleges in the New York region to offer a new five-year joint degree program to their students. The students will take some computer programming and other technical courses in their junior and senior years and then spend a year at Polytechnic to earn master's degrees in computer science. The alliance will include Marymount College in Manhattan, St. Francis and St. Joseph's Colleges in Brooklyn, Manhattanville in Purchase, N.Y., and Marymount in Tarrytown, N.Y.
Dr. Chang said Polytechnic also hopes to play "a more pro-active role in economic development and creating jobs" through incubators for nurturing high-technology start-up companies and more active commercialization of its research.
But some critics have said that closing the undergraduate campus in Farmingdale, in Nassau County, is at odds with that goal. Mr. Aupperle of Hauppauge Digital said that the Farmingdale campus has been a steady supplier of rigorously trained computer professionals in a region that cannot find enough of them.
A graduate of the Farmingdale campus, he said he hires three or four engineers a year, one or two from the Long Island campus, and also hires several interns each summer. "I'm not pleased," he said.
Some faculty members on Long Island have expressed concern about their future. Although tenured faculty members will be guaranteed spots in Brooklyn if they want them, nontenured faculty and staff members may not be offered transfers. Those positions will depend on the needs at the Brooklyn and Farmingdale campuses, university officials said.
Polytechnic plans to expand the less-technical master's degree programs at its satellite campuses in Hawthorne, in Westchester County, and on Wall Street. Despite the phasing out of the undergraduate program on Long Island, Polytechnic officials say they hope to expand the graduate program there, and plan to set up a task force to determine the future of the 25-acre campus.
Dr. Chang contends that the university must focus its efforts and cannot afford to upgrade the Farmingdale campus the way it plans to improve its Metrotech campus. He said he hopes to increase the number of Long Island students the university serves by attracting more to the Brooklyn campus.
Polytechnic has told the undergraduate students at Farmingdale that it will keep the campus open until they graduate, but that they may also transfer to Brooklyn and would be given priority for the new dormitory. But some students said they were skeptical about how that would work out.
"They are really turning people's lives upside down," said Wayne Schmidt, a sophomore from Richmond Hills, Queens. He said the Brooklyn campus is far from the high-technology companies on Long Island, has no grassy place to play ball, and is not as safe.
"I could put a $50 bill on a cafeteria table in Farmingdale, and it would still be there 24 hours later," he said. "If I put a $50 bill on a bench in the commons in Brooklyn, there is a question about whether it would be there 10 minutes later."

HEADLINE: Compressed Data;
The PC Industry Shows Strong Growth

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

 BODY:
The personal computer industry is continuing to show significant global growth, with third-quarter shipments of machines increasing by 23.2 percent over the comparable quarter last year, according to a Dataquest report to be issued on Monday.
Dataquest, a market research company based in San Jose, Calif., cited strong growth in all regions of the world and lower prices as the foundation of the continued surge in computer shipments, which totaled 28.5 million in the quarter. 
 Compaq Computer remained the world's largest PC maker with a 12.8 percent market share, although that figure was down from 13.4 percent last year. Compaq shipped 3.65 million computers during the quarter, according to Dataquest.
In contrast Dell Computer, the No. 2 PC company, whose sales have grown along with the rise of Internet commerce, expanded its market share from 8.2 percent to 10.8 percent, shipping 3.07 million computers during the quarter.
Behind the two leaders were three other computer makers based in the United States: I.B.M., Hewlett-Packard and Gateway. Dataquest analysts said that companies like Compaq, Hewlett-Packard and I.B.M., which have typically sold to customers indirectly, had experienced slower growth than those like Dell specializing in direct sales over the Internet.
Despite Compaq's global leadership position, it dropped behind Dell in sales of machines within the United States. That was a milestone for Dell, according to Dataquest.
For the third quarter, Dell's domestic market share rose to 17.1 percent, up from 13.4 percent a year earlier -- a growth rate of 56.5 percent. Compaq's domestic shipments, meanwhile, rose only 24.9 percent, as its United States market share edged up to 15.3 percent, from 15 percent a year earlier.
Meanwhile, I.B.M.'s overall market share sank to 7.6 percent, from 8.4 percent in last year's third quarter. Last week, the company announced that it was exiting the retail market and in the future would sell its personal computers via the Internet.
Dataquest said that the quarter was unusual because of the rise of computer memory prices, a trend whose impact had been felt most directly by Dell, but also by many of the other computer makers, in terms of lower profits margins.
Dataquest said that Gateway's new partnership with America Online, announced last week, was an example of a shift to a "next-generation PC economic model," which would shift the emphasis in competition beyond high inventory turnover.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
You've Got Mail, Indeed

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
THE "check" is in the mail. So too are the "important national survey," the "Priority Express Gram" and other "time-sensitive material" that is "personal and confidential" as well as "extremely urgent."
At a time when the phrase "You've got mail" evokes images of virtual correspondence, the old-fashioned, ink-and-paper counterpart -- replete with the plethora of puffery quoted above -- is alive and well as marketers keep waging war on consumers' mailboxes. 
 The barrage of letters, catalogues and brochures that typifies the advertising medium known as direct mail continues unabated, peddling everything from magazines and computers to apparel and political candidates. Alive and well? That's an understatement -- and something you rarely find in direct mail.
In fact, direct mail, still widely dismissed with the sobriquet "junk mail," is proliferating faster than it did before the Internet, climbing to 44 percent of all pieces of mail handled last year by the post office from 41 percent a decade ago and 32 percent in 1978.
"It's becoming an information-loaded world and there's a minimal amount of attention span," said Barbara Weckstein Kaplowitz, editor of The DeLay Letter in Potomac, Md., which covers the direct marketing industry. "But direct mail is still working for many marketers."
According to the Direct Marketing Association, the industry's trade organization, direct mail generated $421.2 million in sales last year, an increase of 8 percent from $390 million in 1997 -- and a gain of 62 percent from $260.2 million as recently as 1992. The average compound annual growth rate of direct mail, at 8.4 percent from 1992 through 1997, is projected to accelerate to 8.6 percent from 1997 through 2002.
"If direct mailers go back to people who asked two years ago to be removed from their lists and say, 'We have something new; would you like to hear about it?' those are the best responders," Ms. Kaplowitz said. "They realize they miss it."
Most consumers, weary of the battle of the bulging mailbox -- and disgusted with materials they deem misleading from companies trying to sell magazine subscriptions -- might say they'd miss getting direct mail the way they'd miss getting bills.
"Don't get me started," warned Bob Bulmash, president of Private Citizen Inc., in Naperville, Ill., an organization that fights what he considers the considerable excesses of direct mailers and telemarketers.
"Junk mail is not going to slow down," Mr. Bulmash asserted. "As long as a marketing channel is there, it will continue to be abused."
Those in the industry would take issue with that castigation. Direct mail was once "pretty intrusive," acknowledged Howard Draft, chairman and chief executive at Draft Worldwide in Chicago, the world's largest direct marketing agency. "But now we're trying to understand what a consumer's needs are and create an invitational approach."
His agency, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, creates direct marketing campaigns for advertisers like American Express, Compaq Computer, G.M. and Sprint.
"More and more, direct mail seeks to communicate with consumers who have bought a product in the first place," Mr. Draft said, "to build loyalty to encourage future purchases." That approach, meant to keep the most profitable customers and minimize or even shed the less lucrative ones, is a departure from the industry's onetime ploy of blanketing consumers with mail.
"The notion of mass mailings, which used to be the rule, has become the exception," said Ian Baer, recently named president of the Chicago office of Rapp Collins Worldwide, the agency owned by Omnicom Group that handles direct marketing assignments for a client roster that includes the on-line retail operations of Barnes & Noble, Pfizer, the United States Navy and Western Union.
"Americans receive more unsolicited mail than any other people in the world," Mr. Baer said. "They're jaded. They lack the time and patience and inclination to go through mail they didn't ask for.
"So to get them to open a piece of mail, we have to take our efforts to a whole new level of relevancy," he added, "because with all the clutter, people will focus only on what they consider most relevant to them."
To make direct mail more relevant -- and thus more effective -- advertisers and agencies are intensifying their efforts to customize the pitches they send consumers. The aim: to deliver pleas as personalized and tailored as possible to appeal to the intended recipients and minimize the anger generated by receiving unwanted, unneeded communication.
That is, obviously, also the goal of Internet marketing, which many experts describe as an updated, high-technology version of direct mail.
"The common phrase we're hearing is that the Internet is 'direct marketing on steroids,' " said H. Robert Wientzen, president of the Direct Marketing Association, which is based in New York.
"The Internet allows targeting in a more efficient way," he added, "but ink on paper still provides a sensory experience and still does a good job."
"The secret is to build a relationship by providing people with relevant information," said Mr. Wientzen, who is in Toronto this week at the association's 82d annual conference, which 15,000 people are expected to attend. "The fact we're growing at more than twice the rate of retail sales says the consumer appreciates the efficiency and convenience of shopping at a distance."
The computer technology that makes the Internet possible is also helping direct marketers in their quest for the grail of relevancy by making it easier than ever to compile extensive information about consumers before any mail is sent.
" 'Data mining' is the term -- collecting, over time, information that allows you to figure out what people want and like and do," Mr. Wientzen said. "Our path in the information age is finding the ability to market to niches, which was never economically feasible before."
The data miners gather their information from the consumers themselves, poring over records of what was already bought and ordered: how recently, how frequently, how much was spent.
"Watch what happens when you can accurately match an E-mail address to a street address," said Ms. Kaplowitz, the newsletter editor. "They'll know not only how you act in the mail but how you act on line."
And direct mailers comb through data from outside sources like mailing lists, postal records, government agencies and other businesses.
"All we're doing is using information we have on our customers, with overlays of demographic or psychographic information, to enhance our knowledge of them and market back to them," said Mr. Draft of Draft Worldwide.
"The data bases are being used to target customers who really have a need for a product," he added. "What brings results today is the unique selling proposition you're making to make the consumer want this product."
Mr. Baer at Rapp Collins offered an example for a client, Western Union, which differentiates campaigns aimed at Spanish-speaking customers based on their countries of origin.
"Dominican-Americans are more established, often second-generation, sending money to relatives back home," Mr. Baer said, "while Colombian-Americans are more likely to be first-generation, sending money back to their families and then going back themselves."
But privacy advocates complain that data mining is more insidious, the marketing equivalent of strip mining.
"You have to fight back," Mr. Bulmash of Private Citizen said, offering these tactics: "Keep your name and phone number off all documents, as best you can. Don't fill out sweepstakes cards. Don't subscribe to magazines; buy them on the newsstand. Don't list your address in the phone book."
Consumers seeking to have their names removed from mailing lists can do so by sending their names, home addresses and signatures to: Mail Preference Service, Direct Marketing Association, P.O. Box 9008, Farmingdale, N.Y. 11735-9008. (Yes, you must use the mail to reduce the mail; about 3.4 million people have registered to date.)
The association, sensitive to the rising tide of complaints, has strengthened its privacy policies, with stipulations called the Privacy Promise to American Consumers taking effect July 1.
"Like all industries, we do have shady operators who push the line too far," said Mr. Weintzen, adding: "We don't want to lose the trust of the American people. If people don't like what you do, they don't buy from you."
The new policies did not impress Mr. Bulmash, who dismissed them as toothless because they involve the industry regulating itself.
"My dog says, 'I'll be good,' but he's not going to hit himself with a stick if he's bad," Mr. Bulmash said. "You've got to teach him to be good."
Other protests come from the advertising research industry, which is furious about a venerable direct mail gimmick: cloaking a pitch as a survey, pretending that the purpose of a letter is to seek opinions rather than sell a product or raise funds.
"It's a sham, it's dishonest and it does the survey-research business a tremendous disservice," said Jim Spaeth, president of the Advertising Research Foundation in New York. "Refusals to participate in legitimate surveys have been rising slowly and this certainly is a part of it."
"What drives me crazy is sometimes these are organizations I'm a member of and believe in," he added, referring to the fundraisers that sell under the guise of research. The foundation even has a name for such trickery, "frugging"; there's also "sugging," for selling under the guise of research.
There's one consolation for consumers tired of make-believe surveys, envelopes festooned with star bursts and addressed with simulated handwriting and letters with underlined sentences and a "P.S." at the end that looks to be an afterthought but isn't. Those gimmicks are likely to begin fading away.
"Every time we put material out there, that's the client's brand in the home," said Mr. Draft of Draft Worldwide. "You will not see the kind of clients we work with allow us to negatively affect the work they're doing in their general brand advertising.
"Star bursts, underlining, the 'P.S.' -- those don't affect results that much," he added. "If you come up with the big idea, the big offer, that's what drives business."

HEADLINE: U.S. and Africa: Unfulfilled Promises and Skepticism

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 24

 BODY:
As Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright visited six African nations last week, her twin goals seemed to be to reassure Africans that the United States was still interested in the continent's affairs and to persuade Congress that Africa mattered.
Using the backdrops of Sierra Leone, where a peace agreement just halted a brutal eight-year civil war, and of Nigeria, which recently emerged from nearly 16 years of military rule, Dr. Albright pledged to assist them with significant increases in aid. Inserting the two West African countries into the ongoing budget fight in Washington, she castigated Congress for wanting to cut President Clinton's $14.6 billion foreign aid request by more than $2 billion. 
 After a trip to Kano in northern Nigeria -- where city officials closed off streets for her visit but were unable to clear the sides of the usual mounds of garbage and refuse-chomping goats -- Dr. Albright said:
"They find it pretty hard to understand that we're going around saying we have the world's greatest economy, and that we have a huge budget surplus, and they are there digging themselves out of garbage."
The message conveyed by the Secretary, who returned to Washington on Sunday, underscored the unfulfilled promises of Mr. Clinton's historic visit to Africa in March 1998.
During that trip, the longest ever to Africa by an American President and the first in two decades, Mr. Clinton talked of a "new African renaissance" and a relationship rooted in partnership, not cold war paternalism. "The United States is ready to help you," he said at the time, promising a new approach to Africa.
Despite the President's emphasis on trade, Congress has yet to pass the Africa Growth and Opportunity Act, which would grant certain African governments greater access to the American market. Although Mr. Clinton called for direct aid to Africa to reach the highs of the cold war, development assistance has continued to decline, to the current level of about $700 million, down from about $870 million seven years ago.
Although he spoke of democracy, critics of Washington's Africa policy say the United States has not done enough to help resolve the many conflicts that have erupted or expanded in Africa since the President's visit -- at the same time that Washington and the West quickly poured billions into Kosovo and East Timor.
And so during Dr. Albright's first visit to Africa since the President's trip, there was skepticism among many ordinary Africans, in sharp contrast with the exuberance heard during Mr. Clinton's tour.
At an AIDS awareness event attended by Dr. Albright here, a participant, Stephen Otiemo, 29, said he had followed Mr. Clinton's 12-day tour very closely on the radio. "We heard him make many promises," Mr. Otiemo said, "but we have not seen much so far. But perhaps we had been hoping for too much. We cannot be angry because we cannot force somebody to do what he does not want to do."
"But somehow we are also angry because we have suffered for the United States," he said, mentioning the August 1998 bombing of the American Embassy here, in which more than 200 Kenyans were killed along with 12 Americans.
Another spectator, Peter Lasu Ladu, 32, a Christian refugee from southern Sudan, asked why Washington was willing to intervene so decisively in Kosovo, but not in his native country's civil war, where almost 2 million people are believed to have been killed in the last 16 years.
"He made a lot of promises," Mr. Ladu said. "But to talk of something and to implement something is different."
Even as Dr. Albright promised $55 million to Sierra Leone and a threefold to fourfold rise in Nigeria's current $27 million aid -- both will require Congressional approval -- she argued that the fulfillment of Mr. Clinton's promises had been blocked by a Republican-controlled Congress.
In line with other senior Administration officials, she blamed isolationism for their resistance. Republicans counter that they are not isolationist, but out to protect America's best interests. They and other critics also say the Clinton White House has failed to bargain with Congress to secure foreign policy goals.
Critics of Washington's policy toward Africa say the Administration shares the blame for what they describe as inattention toward the continent.
"The Administration hasn't made a particularly aggressive case on Africa specifically," said Salih Booker, a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations.
The Administration has raised Africa's profile and followed through on some issues, including increased training for African peacekeeping forces and pushing for debt relief, Mr. Booker said. But he added: "The real problem is that without a serious commitment of resources, the American Government can only talk. Talking is important, but U.S. credibility in Africa will be eroded if the Administration can't put money and human resources, too, where its mouth is."
Dr. Albright's tour -- which included Guinea, Sierra Leone, Mali, Nigeria, Tanzania and Kenya -- was clearly intended to regain the momentum on Africa. Asked to assess American relations with Africa since the President's trip, the Secretary said: "I believe that our Administration has spent more time, attention and money on Africa than any previous Administration. The fact that we haven't accomplished everything we want is unfortunate, but it isn't over."
The sober words were a long way from what Mr. Clinton told half a million ebullient Ghanaians only 19 months ago: "My dream for this trip is that together we might do the things so that 100 years from now, your grandchildren and mine will look back and say this was the beginning of a new African renaissance."
The change in tone reflects how much Africa, and Washington's view of it, have changed in those 19 months. During Mr. Clinton's visit, the Administration's darlings were a so-called new generation of leaders, pragmatic and competent men who would lead Africa to its renaissance. But the four men most often regarded as this generation's standard-bearers have all become embroiled in war since the Presidential visit.
Yoweri K. Museveni, the President of Uganda, and Paul Kagame, the leader of Rwanda, backed a rebellion against the Government of Congo and President Laurent Kabila, their former protege. Ugandan and Rwanda troops even clashed briefly in the Congolese city of Kisangani recently. Also, Meles Zenawi, the Prime Minister of Ethiopia, and Issaias Afwerki, the Eritrean leader, started a border war that has claimed tens of thousands of soldiers.
In 1998, Mr. Clinton's plane pointedly flew over Nigeria, the African giant and its most populous nation, to protest the repressive Government of Gen. Sani Abacha. Since then, however, General Abacha's unexpected death unleashed a sweeping political transformation that resulted in the inauguration of the first civilian Government in Nigeria in nearly 16 years.
During Dr. Albright's stop last week in Nigeria, she heaped praise on President Olusegun Obasanjo, who is due to visit Washington this week. There was no talk of a new generation of leaders; Mr. Obasanjo, after all, was Nigeria's military ruler in the late 1970's. But Dr. Albright described Nigeria as a potential "regional partner" for the United States in Africa.
"Nigeria's success in meeting the challenges of democracy will be a welcome inspiration across Africa," she said in her keynote speech of the trip and one of her most upbeat comments. "For our part, the United States will continue to be a strong supporter of democratic forces across the continent."

HEADLINE: Canada's Link to the Queen Grows Livelier

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: OTTAWA

 BODY:
In 1942, with Japanese troops occupying Hong Kong, a well-dressed Chinese family stood quietly on a dock waiting to board a ship for evacuation to Canada, a country then legally closed to Chinese immigration. A colonial inspector skeptically eyed the family, including 3-year-old Adrienne Poy, and then announced loudly that they did not look like Canadians to him.
"They were first turned away, because they were Chinese," Prime Minister Jean Chretien recounted in early October in a speech broadcast nationwide from Canada's gilded Senate chamber. Behind him, on a throne of scarlet velour and Canadian oak, sat Adrienne, now 60 and about to become Governor General, the personal representative of Queen Elizabeth II to Canada. 
 The fairy-tale rise of Adrienne Clarkson from wartime refugee to the nation's first immigrant Governor General has captivated Canada, created an uproar, and pumped fresh blood into monarchism in the country. This new attention to the monarchy comes as Australia, which Canada often uses as a benchmark, prepares to vote Nov. 6 in a referendum on whether to break with the British crown and become a republic.
Traditionally, Canada's Prime Minister has appointed a bland retired politician as Governor General. Although largely ceremonial, the post does carry the authority to dismiss the Prime Minister in time of crisis, a confrontation that has not occurred since 1926.
But with Madame Clarkson, as she likes to be addressed, Canadians suddenly have a media savvy woman with intellectual gravitas -- a skilled communicator familiar to virtually every household from Newfoundland to British Columbia. From 1963 until a few months ago, generations of Canadians grew up watching Adrienne Clarkson on public television -- book reviewer, investigative reporter, foreign correspondent and cultural program hostess.
She became such a television icon that one comedian lampooned her familiar introduction line, announcing imperiously, "I'm Adrienne Clarkson -- and you're not."
"Everyone knows Adrienne Clarkson; she's been on TV, for the CBC, for years," said David Giles, a cell phone repairman here. "She's something new and exciting and fresh. The others were old and stodgy."
The first Asian to become the Queen's representative here, she has also attracted some thinly veiled racist thunderbolts.
"This appointment degrades Her Majesty, the office of Governor General and Canada as a whole," Kenneth Lieblich, a leader of the Monarchist League of Canada, wrote to a newspaper from the Vancouver area, a region with a population that is 20 percent Chinese.
Of a woman who has written three novels, headed the nation's largest publishing company, served for five years as a diplomat in Paris, been host on an estimated 3,500 public television shows, and most recently headed the Canadian Museum of Civilization, he said, "Her qualifications are mediocre at best, and her loyalty to the crown is unknown and untested."
Others complained that she and her husband, John Ralston Saul, were leftists opposed to free trade with the United States and devoted to affirmative action for women.
"Ms. Clarkson emerged as a spokesperson for cultural and economic nationalism and the left in general," The National Post said in an editorial titled "A Governor General for half the country."
Two days later, this conservative newspaper went after her husband, a 52-year-old author and philosopher. "Like so many left-wing intellectuals, Mr. Ralston Saul appears to see the world from a book-lined cave without windows," an editorialist wrote. "The shadows that dance on his cranial wall are not Plato's imperfect representations of 'ideal' reality, but projections of capitalist ghosts and goblins."
Then reporters rummaged through the couple's personal life, discovering that after 15 years of living together they hastily married this summer after learning that she was in the running to become the Queen's representative. Digging further, they found that she feuded with her Toronto neighbors and was so estranged from her two adult daughters that she did not list them in her official biographies.
"She's been given a scandalous, rocky ride in the press," complained Margaret Atwood, the novelist and a friend. "She has had some press that I would consider basically sexist and racist."
But somewhere between the Sept. 8 appointment and the Oct. 7 installation, Canadians began to be fascinated by their Governor General designate.
"O.K., let's recap," a reader said in a letter to The Globe and Mail last week. "She has an ex-spouse who doesn't want to talk about her, daughters who are uninterested in her achievements and seem to prefer their stepmother. She fights with her neighbors and she gets married to keep up appearances with the Queen. It looks as if the Prime Minister has chosen a perfect royal representative!"
By the time the new Governor General walked into Parliament past the clicking heels of the Princess Patricia's Light Infantry last week, The National Post published a poll showed that 83 percent of adults surveyed called her appointment "good" or "very good."
In contrast, only one-quarter could identify her predecessor, Romeo LeBlanc, a former member of Parliament for the governing Liberal Party.
In the Senate chamber, as she alternated smoothly between British-accented English and Parisian-accented French, her words did not always match the velvet and ermine decor.
"We did not arrive as part of a regular immigration procedure," she said, looking fondly at her 92-year-old father, seated in a place of honor. Recalling how the family won a waiver to a Canadian law barring Chinese immigrants, she added, "There was no such thing for a Chinese family at that time in Canadian history."
Recalling her family's move to Canada's capital in 1942, she said, "The city of Ottawa, then, was small and white -- like most of Canada."
She was eager to learn French, she recalled, but was barred from enrolling at a local public French school because she was Protestant and the school was controlled by Catholics. Her journey to become a Canadian was eased by a series of Ontario public school teachers, she said, "who treated me only as bright -- not bright yellow."
The speech soon evolved into an eloquent ode to "the Canadian dream," peppered with citations from a dozen Canadian writers, ranging from Samuel de Champlain, the 17th-century French explorer, to Leonard Cohen, the contemporary songwriter.
"We must not see ourselves as a small country of 30 million people, floundering in a large land mass," she said, lecturing Canadians about their frequent lack of national pride and self-confidence. "We are among the healthiest, best-educated people in the world, with great natural riches."
The smoke from a 21-gun artillery salute was still in the air and the new Governor General's horse-drawn landau was clip-clopping from Parliament Hill to Rideau Hall when Canadian reporters started to rave about someone they usually ignore: the representative of the Queen.
At the 79-acre estate, the Governor General was greeted by aides addressing her as "Your Excellency." In an interview in a high-ceilinged drawing room of the 1838 viceregal palace, she serenely dismissed the press uproar of last month.
Wearing her new, nonpartisan, representative-of-the-Queen hat, the former television interviewer deftly ducked controversial subjects like Canada's detention this summer of about 600 immigrants who arrived without passports in boats from China.
But according to a friend, she was secretly pleased by one newspaper cartoon last month. In the cartoon, a Mountie sternly looked down at a huddled boatload of illegal Chinese immigrants, then warned a fellow Mountie to be careful because "one of them could be a future Governor General."
According to the complaint in a wrongful-death suit filed by Mrs. Lum against Carnival in Federal District Court in Miami, on the second night Mr. Lum complained that he was not feeling well. He vomited and spent the next day resting in the cabin. His wife, meanwhile, heard other passengers discussing people falling ill with diarrhea and vomiting.
At 1:30 A.M. on the third day, Mrs. Lum said in an interview, she woke when her husband collapsed outside the cabin's bathroom. She said she called the ship's infirmary but the nurse tried to discourage her from bringing him there because it was so late. Mrs. Lum said she insisted, and her husband was put on an intravenous solution to avoid dehydration.
After a time, the nurse took Mr. Lum's blood pressure and said he was improving and could return to his cabin. Tired but relieved, Mrs. Lum hurried to the cabin to get towels and a change of clothes, because her husband had soiled his pants.
"My daughter and niece were awake, and I told them he was fine and would be coming back," Mrs. Lum said. "I was gone about five minutes, and when I got back to the infirmary the doctor and nurse asked me to wait in the waiting room."
Sobbing briefly, Mrs. Lum said she waited for several minutes, wondering what was going on. Then the doctor and nurse returned.
"They came back and told me that he had taken a turn for the worse and he had died," she said. "I asked them how that was possible, and they said there was nothing they could do."
Mr. Lum was the only person to die among the 52 passengers and 16 crew members who came down with viral gastroenteritis on the cruise. His death was caused by extensive blood loss from a tear in his esophagus caused by vomiting, according to the family's complaint.
"Mr. Lum died of retching to death," said Erik Peterson, the family's lawyer.
Curtis J. Mase, a lawyer for Carnival, said in court papers that the company was not responsible, contending that the death was an act of God and that Mr. Lum had failed to seek timely or appropriate medical care.
"Russell Lum's own negligence contributed to his death and injuries," Mr. Mase said.

An article on Oct. 25 described the appointment of Adrienne Clarkson as Canada's governor general, the personal representative of Queen Elizabeth II. Ms. Clarkson, a Chinese-Canadian television personality, is the country's first immigrant governor general.

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
Arming Unsung Heroes of Health Care

BYLINE: By ABIGAIL ZUGER, M.D. 

 BODY:
Hospitals may not be called pest houses anymore, but they are still terrible places to be sick. They are all crawling with bacteria, with strangers who are sometimes kindly but sometimes not, with the potential for bad accidents; hospitals assault the senses from every direction, and then they send a bill.
No, from time immemorial it has always been far better, if possible, to be sick at home, surrounded by familiar comforts and tended by a devoted relative or friend. 
 But that part of the picture is changing fast. Those devoted attendants have much more complicated jobs than they once did. Medical science is saving more lives, at the price of creating more people with serious chronic medical problems who need continuing expert care. And the hospital is no longer the site of most of that care: increasingly portable technology (not to mention rising costs) means that the deep desire of every sick person to get out of the hospital right this minute can generally be accommodated.
But while the technology can easily travel home, no one has yet figured out a way to get the hospital staff home too.
So instead, a vast, silent volunteer army has grown up: millions of Americans who do unpaid service as health care providers, with many of the skills of the professionals but none of the salary, by caring for sick relatives and friends at home.
A study published in March in the policy journal Health Affairs estimated this work force at 25.8 million people as of 1997, each working an average of 18 hours a week. If they were all paid an hourly wage commensurate with their duties -- from the unskilled labor of changing bed linen to the highly technical work of adjusting machines and administering medications -- their economic value would come to $196 billion, about 18 percent of total national health care spending for 1997 and six times the $32 billion Americans formally spent on home care that year.
Legislators and policy makers pay attention to numbers like these, as witnessed by the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 and the tax credit proposal for home care givers now under consideration in Congress. But, as virtually anybody who has ever spent time caring for a sick person knows well, the professional custodians of the nation's health have yet to give these millions of new colleagues their due.
Doctors and nurses, therapists and social workers, well intentioned though they may be, still tend to think in the old authoritarian patterns. The patient is their patient; they are in charge; they know best. Just leave them alone to do their work. Please.
What little training the professionals get in the art of negotiating shared responsibilities is generally devoted to the tangled politics of getting along with one another. Doctors and nurses are still scrapping in the Hundred Years' War; few have the insight or energy left over to negotiate the same issues with third parties. In fact, in surveys that ask health professionals what makes their jobs most difficult, many immediately reply, "Families."
But consider this multiple-choice question (not to be found among the millions that line the path into the caring professions): A doctor sees a patient for 15 minutes once a month, a visiting nurse drops in once a week, a therapist spends an hour or so every few days, an aide comes in for the morning shift. A caretaking spouse, child or parent is there for the duration, learning what the pills look like and how they go down, how to change the bandages and what to do when the machinery at the bedside starts beeping at 3 A.M.
Whose patient is it?
It is small wonder that a grass-roots movement is slowly taking shape in the ranks of these family caregivers, asking for a little more acknowledgment from medical professionals, a little more education and a lot more respect.
One of their most eloquent voices has been that of Carol Levine, a health policy researcher with the United Hospital Fund in New York. Ms. Levine's work with children orphaned by the AIDS epidemic earned her a MacArthur Foundation "genius" grant in 1993. Now she spends most workdays on a long-term project that aims to bring family caregivers out of the shadows into the forefront of health policy decisions.
At night, she joins the caregivers' ranks, tending to her husband, Howard, 71, who was injured in an automobile accident in 1990. Once a sharp, energetic public relations executive, Mr. Levine is bedbound and largely paralyzed, with serious brain damage.
Nine years of hands-on caregiving have given Ms. Levine an intimate familiarity with the rough patches of the terrain. Unreliable ambulette service, irresponsible insurers and a new wheelchair that is an inch too wide to fit into the dentist's office are bad, she said in an interview. But any prolonged interaction with doctors and hospitals is generally even worse.
Mr. Levine has required periodic hospitalizations over the years, and making the transfer between hospital and home is always a nightmare.
"In the hospital, they think they're the experts and you're just the family," she said. "But I am an expert. I'm an expert in him."
And then, when it is time to go home, all the responsibility is suddenly hers again. She is the effector arm of the doctors' plans, the key to their success or failure. Even so, she is regularly sent off with a minimum of explanation or training for any new conditions, medications or equipment.
Ms. Levine has to date supervised the disbursement of about $1.5 million in grant money to hospitals in the New York area for an assortment of projects to help home caregivers do their job. But no institution has yet taken her up on her most revolutionary proposal.
"All professionals in training should spend a day entirely on their own in a household like mine," she said. Not to make a house call, or a home visit, she emphasized, or to accomplish a series of discrete tasks, but to live the total experience -- the stretches of boredom and the moments of sheer terror, all played out in the complete isolation of the home.
"One day out of all those years of training," she said. "Is that too much to ask?"
