HEADLINE: Experiment Seeks to Protect Ovaries From Cancer Treatment

BYLINE: By DENISE GRADY 

 BODY:
In an experimental operation last Thursday that one doctor called "great work" but another called "preposterous," surgeons in Brooklyn removed a woman's ovaries, sliced them into thin strips and implanted them into her arm.
The patient, in her 30's, has cervical cancer, and the reason for the seemingly outlandish procedure was to protect her ovaries from the radiation treatment she will be getting. The radiation would very likely damage her ovaries and plunge her prematurely into menopause, bringing on the bone-thinning disorder osteoporosis and other problems caused by the sudden loss of estrogen. (Menopause can be forestalled by estrogen-replacement therapy, but the woman, who allowed a reporter and photographer to watch the operation only on the condition of anonymity, refused the pills in favor of the experimental surgery.) 
 Now, when her pelvis is irradiated, she will simply have to raise her arm over her head to keep the ovarian tissue out of the way. No one knows whether ovarian tissue can live in a person's arm, but the surgeon who devised the procedure, Dr. Kutluk Oktay of New York Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn, said he hoped the strips would survive and act like a normal ovary, producing enough estrogen to prevent menopause.
Although the patient in Brooklyn wanted the ovarian surgery to prevent menopause, Dr. Oktay said that if the method worked, the real goal was to use it to preserve fertility in young women hoping to have children after being treated for cancer. Eggs might be easily harvested from a patient's arm, he said, and used for in vitro fertilization, in which they would be fertilized in the laboratory and then implanted in the patient's uterus to start a pregnancy.
The research is part of a larger pattern of efforts to find ways to enable people to have families after being treated for cancer, particularly young people who have good odds of being cured of certain cancers like leukemia and bone tumors. The approach is in a highly experimental field that has yet to make parents of anyone. Nonetheless, many patients have pinned their hopes on the research.
For young people with cancer, particularly those who have not yet had children, it can be devastating to learn that the chemotherapy and radiation given to save their lives will also leave them sterile. Taking steps to try to have children later may be the utmost expression of faith and hope.
But only men have been able to plan for a future, by having sperm frozen before undergoing radiation or chemotherapy. Women have not had a similar option.
Eggs, unlike sperm, do not survive freezing. Fertilized eggs do, but women with cancer may not be able to spend the time and take the hormones needed to stimulate the ovaries to produce the eggs needed for in vitro fertilization.
"For women who have not completed their families, being a parent is very, very important," said Dr. Lynn Hartmann, an oncologist at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn. "They may have a cancer with a good prognosis. To look for options for these women is very important."
One option under study is to remove an ovary, freeze it before cancer treatment and reimplant it later. The technique works in animals; mice and sheep have given birth after having frozen ovaries reimplanted.
Although some clinics have been experimentally freezing human ovaries, and at least one is selling the service, no woman has yet had a baby as a result.
But in September, Dr. Oktay and his colleagues announced that frozen ovarian tissue had begun working again after being reimplanted in the patient, a young woman whose ovaries had been removed at another hospital because of a noncancerous disorder. One of the ovaries turned out to be healthy and was cut into strips and frozen, and two years later, when the patient was 30, Dr. Oktay's team sewed the strips to a scaffold made of surgical foam, which they implanted in her abdomen.
A few months later, given hormones that made eggs mature, the woman ovulated and then had a menstrual period. Her case was the first on record in which frozen ovarian tissue began to function again. (She may be able to become pregnant, but would need in vitro fertilization, because her Fallopian tubes were removed.)
Dr. Oktay cautions that ovary freezing is unlikely to work for women over 30, because they have fewer eggs than younger women, and some eggs are lost in the processing. By the time the tissue is thawed, he said, there may not be enough healthy eggs left to achieve a pregnancy or to produce the hormones needed to keep menopause at bay.
That limitation on freezing for women in their 30's helped inspire him to try last week's operation. A standard procedure for sparing the woman's ovaries had been rejected: doctors sometimes surgically relocate the ovaries within the abdomen to get them out of the way of radiation. But in this case, the doctors did not think it would work.
So Dr. Katherine Economos removed the patient's ovaries, and Dr. Oktay sliced them into 16 thin strips that he and Dr. James Rucinski could slip under the skin of the arm. The strips would be better able than large segments to absorb nutrients from the nearby tissue and establish a blood supply.
The idea is not as farfetched as it may seem: a similar technique has been used successfully for about 20 years in operations on the parathyroid glands, which are sometimes transferred from the neck to the arm.
Still, no one knows whether it will work with ovaries. The woman will receive chemotherapy with the radiation, and the doctors could not be certain that the low doses given for cervical cancer would not harm the ovarian tissue. Higher doses given for other types of cancer do cause infertility.
The team estimated that it would take six months before they could tell whether the tissue was doing its job. Only one other woman has undergone the procedure, about six months ago, and Dr. Oktay said he still could not tell whether it had succeeded. In any case, even if the strips do work, there is no telling how long they will last.
"We're taking a chance," Dr. Economos said.
Dr. Oktay said it might eventually be possible to combine the two techniques he has been studying. If the fresh tissue transplanted into his patients' arms works, he said it might also work to put frozen ovarian strips -- from a patient whose ovary had to be removed before chemotherapy, for instance -- back into the arm instead of the pelvis. The advantage, he said, is that it would be much easier to harvest eggs from the arm for in vitro fertilization. But women with intact Fallopian tubes might prefer to have the tissue put back into the abdomen, to give them a chance to become pregnant naturally, without in vitro fertilization.
Dr. James Grifo, director of reproductive endocrinology at New York University Medical Center, said that for now, ovary freezing and relocating should be performed only as research, as Dr. Oktay is doing, and not offered to patients as if they were a proven treatment.
Patients must be informed that no babies have been born as a result, Dr. Grifo emphasized, adding that publicity about the research had misled people into thinking that the procedures had already been shown to work. He said some women had mistakenly believed that they could postpone childbearing, freeze an ovary and get it back years or even decades later to start a family. There is no proof that can be done, and it may not be good for a woman to have a healthy ovary removed needlessly.
Cancer patients who will become sterile anyway have less to lose by giving up an ovary, but they also must be told that the procedure is highly experimental, Dr. Grifo said. He does not perform it or recommend it.
"I had a patient with breast cancer who wanted me to take out her ovary and freeze it," he said. "I said I couldn't do it. When I told her we don't know if you can make viable eggs, she just lost it. People don't want to hear the truth. The technology is not there.
"Why would I expose somebody to the risks of general anesthesia and surgery, and then freeze the ovaries by techniques nobody has shown you can get a viable egg from? Why would you have eggs taken out at a time when you're very sick, so on top of the disease you're going through an expensive, time-consuming, physically draining procedure?"
Dr. Maurie Markman, director of the Cleveland Clinic Cancer Center, called the ovary transplant into the patient's arm "preposterous," adding: "An operation on a lady with advanced cancer so she can have estrogen coming out of her arm, so she can avoid taking a pill? It's nuts." But he said that if effective techniques were developed to preserve women's fertility after cancer treatment, "I wouldn't have a problem with that."
Dr. Grifo said: "This is great work. It should continue. There's a lot of things we can learn by doing it."
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Kutluk Oktay sliced a cervical-cancer patient's ovaries on Thursday as he prepared to implant them into her arm at New York Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn. The purpose of the experiment is to protect the ovaries from radiation and thus prevent premature menopause. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)
 
Chart: "Removed for Safekeeping"
In an experimental procedure intended to protect a woman's ovaries during radiation treatments for cancer, doctors have removed the ovaries and implanted the tissue in her forearm.
 
1. After removing the ovaries from the pelvis, the surgeon cut the ovary in half and discarded tissue from the center. The remaining egg-bearing tissue was sliced into thin strips, 2 inches long and less than a quarter-inch wide.
 
2. Working through a half-inch incision in the patient's forearm, the surgeon inserted 16 strips under the skin. The hope is that the strips will survive and secrete enough estrogen to keep the woman from going into menopause prematurely. (Juan Velasco/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: ARTS IN AMERICA;
A Home Of the Blues, Singing a New Tune

BYLINE: By NEIL STRAUSS 

DATELINE: CLARKSDALE, Miss.

 BODY:
Driving into this sleepy upper Delta city toward the crossroads where Highway 49 meets Highway 61, the first thing one sees is a sign that boasts "Clarksdale: Home of the Big Frog." There is little mention that Clarksdale is famous for more than amphibians: it is probably the most legendary blues site in the South. Dozens of blues legends were born or lived in this city or its county, Coahoma, among them John Lee Hooker, Muddy Waters, Charley Patton, Pinetop Perkins, Son House and W. C. Handy. Nearly every Delta blues musician of note performed in Clarksdale regularly, including Robert Johnson, Howlin' Wolf and Sonny Boy Williamson. And many of them died here, most notably Bessie Smith. To this day a visitor arriving on a lucky night can see a venerable musician rocking the barroom at one of the dozen crumbling juke joints downtown.
More than the blues came to life in Clarksdale: the soul singer Sam Cooke grew up here, as did Ike Turner and Jackie Brenston, who recorded what some credit as the first rock-and-roll song, "Rocket 88." Local legend has it that a young Elvis Presley used to come through and hang around the radio station (home to one of the country's first black disk jockeys) in hopes of getting a chance to sing on the air. 
 For decades, however, the only people who recognized the city's heritage were the international blues tourists who trickled in each year. There was little for them to see: a small, homey annual blues festival and a Delta Blues Museum tucked into the Carnegie Library there. The county had already let the House of Blues, the music club chain, dismantle the shack Muddy Waters once lived in and cart it off on a national tour.
But something strange has happpened in Clarksdale the last year or two. As if awakening from amnesia, many whites here have suddenly become aware of the town's blues heritage. Much of this is owed to a handful of unusual characters: John Ruskey, a blues fan who came floating down the Mississippi River on a raft from Memphis, landing in Clarksdale to stay; a home builder named Kinchen O'Keefe, better known as Bubba, who funneled his savings into creating a mini-tourism empire downtown; a former schoolteacher, and Molly Shields, who found a way to keep her aging boyfriend off the dangerous power lines he works on by opening what she calls a "blues pawn shop." There are Cathy and James Butler, who decided to subvert the legacy of the Hopson Plantation, inherited from Mrs. Butler's forebears, by renting out the sharecropper's shacks and turning the company store into a social club. Each has been trying to build a bridge to the city's cultural past, and a result may be to take Clarksdale into the next century as one of the South's most irresistible tourist meccas.
Or, as Mr. O'Keefe said, "We've got gold in the stream that needs mining."
With the new casinos in nearby Tunica County bringing in over one million visitors a year, Clarksdale -- which was a stop on President Clinton's four-day poverty tour this summer -- has experienced the impact that tourism can have on an economy. It has invested several million dollars into developing an area it calls Blues Alley (complete with a John Lee Hooker Lane) and it is working on putting its atrophied bus and train stations in order, partly to lure some of the tourists visiting Tunica and Memphis to the north.
"Everybody wants to keep the tourists in town for longer than 30 minutes," said Mr. Butler, who in addition to helping run Hopson is also the city's director of public works. "But the one thing I feel everybody's kept in their minds is that things can't get too clean and flashy. Keep it real or we won't have what we have now."
Clarksdale first came to life in the late 1800's as a lumber camp established by John Clark, whose daughter, Blanche, inspired the character of the same name in "A Streetcar Named Desire" by Tennessee Williams, who also made his home in Clarksdale. With the advent of railways, Clarksdale blossomed in the early 20th century, becoming one of the most prosperous cities of its size in the nation and known as "little New York" because of all its millionaires. The city was where the majority black population came to shop, celebrate and listen to music on days off. But with World War II and the mechanization of the cotton industry, the city's population ebbedas sharecroppers moved to cities in the North, and bankruptcy abounded. Today Clarksdale has been cited as one of the poorest cities in the poorest state in the nation, with 30 percent of Clarksdale's residents below the poverty level.
One of the city's acknowledged treasures for over 20 years has been the Delta Blues Museum. But last year the museum's director died, and a successor has not been appointed. Mr. Ruskey, a curator who had left the museum to work as a river guide, stepped in to take care of museum business along with Mae Smith, who ran the gift shop. They helped reopen the Delta Blues Museum on Oct. 10 in a beautifully remodeled freight station bought by the city in Blues Alley.
On opening day, visitors wandered through three rooms of temporary exhibitions, including a wax figure of Muddy Waters, a headstone that once stood on Mississippi Fred McDowell's grave (it had been replaced because his name was misspelled), photographs of blues legends and dozens of other displays chronicling the history of blues and soul in the Delta.
On a concrete stage outside by the old train tracks, local musicians, including Mr. Ruskey and many teen-agers who were taught to play by the museum's blues education fund (most notably the group J. T. Express, favorites at nearby juke joints like the Do Drop Inn), performed for the small crowd.
The bluesman and museum teacher Johnnie Billington, who closed the show, walked around in the sweltering afternoon in a coat and tie. Since instructing his students to always dress formally in public so that they will be treated with respect, he has never been seen otherwise, residents say, even when mowing his yard on a sweltering summer afternoon.
A block and a half from the museum festivities, Mr. O'Keefe stood behind the counter in his new store, the Sunflower River Trading Company, surrounded by the local crafts, music and videos he was selling. With the boarded-up, discolored and dilapidated storefronts around it, the store looks like a rose that somehow sprouted from quicksand. Like many others here, Mr. O'Keefe has a story about growing up in blues country without ever being a part of it. "Mississippi Fred McDowell used to pump gas for my father," he said. "He used to go to festivals in Europe, then come back and pump gas."
Now Mr. O'Keefe has embarked on a one-man publicity and renovation campaign for Clarksdale. Across the street from his new store he bought the building that once housed WROX radio. He turned the ground floor into a children's store and the top floor into a professional-looking dance studio for local children, including his own. Between those floors are the empty radio studios where a young Elvis Presley used to pay the owner money to sing on the air, Ike Turner worked as a janitor and Sam Cooke was a protege of the disk jockey Early Wright, the Soul Man. That part of the building, he said, will become a museum and studio celebrating the station's glory days. He also plans to build the city's first cafe in the building and to organize package tours of the area.
Several blocks away Ms. Shields and Mr. Brower opened one of the city's odder attractions in June. Mr. Brower was working on the city's power lines when they decided to find a different line of work. So they opened Carmen's Blues Pawn Shop (named after Mr. Brower's daughter) downtown, where they also sell tourist souvenirs like autographed CD's by newer area blues acts like Super Chikan, key chains, and T-shirts. On the wall outside, their nephews have painted the city's first blues mural: giant caricatures of John Lee Hooker, Bessie Smith and Muddy Waters.
Ms. Shields said she was brought up in Clarksdale but never knew how famous her home was in blues lore until recently. "We get people from all over the world here," she said. "Last week we got 31 Norwegians. When people come to town, other than the blues museum there's nothing. And we wanted to have something where they can stand outside and take pictures and say these three people on this mural are famous and they're from Clarksdale."
Overnight guests began coming this year to Hopson Plantation, where the first mechanized cotton picker was developed and used and where musicians like Pinetop Perkins and Wesley Jefferson, the Mississippi Junebug, once lived. But in a twist on Southern plantation tourism, visitors do not stay in the big house but rather in the sharecropper shacks out back, which still retain some possessions of the original occupants. The owners say they plan to invite touring bands for warm-up shows in what used to be the company store, which has been fitted with a small stage and converted into a social club.
For now, Clarksdale remains a city in transition. Mr. Butler said bankers tend to scoff when he tries to offer a sharecropper's shack as collateral on a loan. And days go by when Mr. O'Keefe doesn't sell a single item in his store.
"This weekend was a hard weekend, because you struggle and say, 'Why am I trying to do this?' " Mr. O'Keefe said. "But if I don't do it, who will? If you turn your back on them, buildings start to decay and the people with stories about them start to die."

MIDDLE EAST
 
ISRAEL: EX-TERRORIST TO MOVE -- At Yasir Arafat's request, Prime Minister Ehud Barak is permitting the former terrorist leader of a militant Palestinian political faction to move from Damascus to the Palestinian-governed Gaza Strip and the West Bank. Nayef Hawatmeh, 63, left, who as head of the Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine was held responsible for the killing of 24 Israeli schoolchildren in 1974, says he has renounced violence and wants to take part in politics in the Palestinian Authority. William A. Orme Jr. (NYT) 

TUNISIA: PRESIDENT RE-ELECTED -- In a result that was never in doubt, President Zine al-Abidine Ben Ali won a third five-year term with nearly 100 percent of the vote, official results showed. Mr. Ben Ali, 62, won 3,269,000 out of 3,287,000 votes cast, Interior Minister Ali Chaouch said. For the first time, two token opposition candidates took part. They got a combined total of just over one half of 1 percent of the votes cast. (Reuters)
 
IRAQ: U.S. JETS ATTACK -- American jets patrolling the no-flight zone over northern Iraq bombed an Iraqi missile storage center south of Mosul in response to Iraqi antiaircraft fire, the United States military said. An Ulster Unionist negotiator, Alan McFarland, said, "There is a degree of trust creeping in" between his party and Sinn Fein, the political wing of the I.R.A. Warren Hoge (NYT)

Her arrest came a day after the rebels announced tougher demands for resuming the stalled peace talks, insisting that Madrid must first agree to Basque self-determination and the withdrawal of all state security forces from the region. The Government dismissed the initiative as propaganda. Al Goodman (NYT)
 
GERMANY: 'GREENHOUSE' MEETING -- Representatives from 168 countries opened a two-week conference in Bonn intended to cut emissions of so-called greenhouse gases blamed for global warming. They will discuss a timetable for carrying out the agreement reached at the 1997 United Nations conference in Kyoto, Japan, which set global standards for reducing pollution, including a cut in greenhouse emissions by 5.2 percent for industrialized nations from 1990 levels by 2008-2012. Victor Homola (NYT)
 
BOSNIA: SUSPECT SEIZED -- NATO-led peacekeeping troops in Bosnia detained a suspected Bosnian Serb war criminal, Damir Dosen, who is under indictment for crimes against humanity. A NATO statement issued in Brussels said Mr. Dosen would be transferred to the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia at The Hague. It said he was shift commander in 1992 at a camp outside Prijedor, where detainees were "killed, sexually assaulted, tortured, beaten and otherwise subjected to cruel and inhuman treatment." (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Higher Mortgage Rates Push Sales of Existing Homes Down

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25

 BODY:
Sales of existing homes fell 2.1 percent in September as months of rising mortgage rates squeezed demand, but the housing market remains on track for a record year of sales, a real estate group said today.
The National Association of Realtors said existing homes sold at an annual rate of 5.13 million units, down from a 5.24 million pace in August. The September pace was below the 5.16 million units expected by economists but was still 3.4 percent above sales in September 1998. 
 September was the third consecutive decline since sales hit a record pace of 5.63 million units in June.
"Consumer demand for existing homes is still healthy despite several months of increased interest rates," said James Smith, the chief economist for the association. "The housing market will not be derailed, because economic factors that drive consumer confidence -- employment, inflation and household wealth -- are at healthy levels."
While demand for homes was weaker, the report held some good news for consumers as the median home sale price fell to $134,500 in September from $137,400 in August.
Mark Vitner, an economist at First Union, said the lower prices should offer solace to Federal Reserve policy makers as they consider whether to increase interest rates at their November meeting.
"The moderation in home prices has to be some comfort to the Fed," Mr. Vitner said. "While Alan Greenspan's comments about the stock market have gotten all the attention, the Fed chairman is also concerned about the prospects of excessive borrowing on inflated home values."
The interest rate on the average 30-year mortgage was 7.82 percent in September, modestly lower than August's average of 7.94 percent but sharply up from levels of 6.72 percent in the month a year earlier, according to Freddie Mac.
Despite the weaker home sales in September, the association said it still predicted a record sales pace of 5.2 million units this year, a 4.8 percent increase over the previous record of 4.97 million units, set last year. The group expects the housing market to cool further in the coming year, to a pace of 4.9 million units.

SECTION: Section A; Page 27; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 843 words

HEADLINE: Mega-Mergers, Mega-Influence

BYLINE: By Jeffrey E. Garten; Jeffrey E. Garten, dean of the Yale School of Management, was Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade in the first Clinton Administration.

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN

 BODY:
Congress is about to eliminate the legal walls that separate commercial banks, brokerage firms and insurance companies -- opening the doors to a new wave of mega-mergers. Critics worry that huge banks will dampen competition and pay less attention to the average customer.
But by itself, sheer size -- whether in finance or in other industries -- should not be a concern. The real problem could be the unchecked political influence of the new global goliaths. 
 In just the past few years corporate giants have emerged across all industries. Citibank and Travelers, Bank of America and Nationsbank, and Deutsche Bank and Bankers Trust are among the major mergers that have reshaped banking. In other industries, Daimler-Benz has linked up with Chrysler; AT&T with Mediaone; British Petroleum with Amoco; Aetna with Prudential Health. Still awaiting regulatory approval are some of the biggest combinations of all, including those between Exxon and Mobil, MCI Worldcom and Sprint, and Viacom and CBS.
We are likely to see much more of this. For starters, deregulation in Europe, Japan and countries like Brazil and South Korea is leading to many more possibilities for large acquisitions.
In the past, a similar wave of mergers would have produced an outcry over mass layoffs, but with unemployment at 30-year lows, few today are complaining. Nor are many alleging today that competition is being eliminated. Because the markets are global, no company is reaching the size and scale that should cause concern about monopolies.
If executives can manage these large entities effectively, Americans -- in their roles as consumers, investors and even employees -- ought to benefit from these new, competitive companies, receiving more and better goods and services at a lower cost.
The big problem is not with how these businesses are affecting competition, but with the inability of our political system to respond to potential problems resulting from economic globalization. Business leaders understandably operate on a global stage, while government leaders act in a way that fails to recognize the new global economy. Members of Congress spend infinitely more time dispensing pork in their hometowns than they do worrying about the stability of the global financial system or the strengthening of the World Trade Organization.
Their narrow perspective on globalization is reflected in their eagerness to slice the budgets of the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Justice Department's antitrust division, the two institutions that have some ability to watch over global companies.
To put it another way, the seesaw of private and public power is seriously unbalanced.
Here is some of the fallout. Mega-banks like Citigroup or the new Bank of America have become too big to fail. Were they to falter, they could take the entire global financial system down with them.
Many mega-companies could be beyond the law, too. Their deep pockets can buy teams of lawyers that can stymie prosecutors for years. And if they lose in court, they can afford to pay huge fines without damaging their operations.
Moreover, no one should be surprised that mega-companies navigate our scandalously porous campaign financing system to influence tax policy, environmental standards, Social Security financing and other issues of national policy. Yes, companies have always lobbied, but these huge corporations often have more pull. Because there are fewer of them, their influence can be more focused, and in some cases, the country may be highly dependent on their survival.
For example, corporate giants can have enormous leverage when they focus on America's foreign and trade policy. Defense contractors like Lockheed Martin, itself a result of a merger of two big firms, were able to exert extraordinarily powerful force to influence the Senate to approve the enlargement of NATO, a move that opened up new markets for American weapons sales to Poland and the Czech Republic.
Companies like Boeing, which not long ago acquired McDonnell Douglas, have expanded their already formidable influence on trade policy toward countries like China. Boeing is now the only American commercial aircraft manufacturer.
Corporations like Exxon-Mobil will negotiate with oil-producing countries almost as equals, conducting the most powerful private diplomacy since the 19th century, when the British East India Company wielded near-sovereign influence in Asia.
As long as the economy remains strong, the rise of corporate power with inadequate public oversight will not be high on the national agenda. But sooner or later -- perhaps starting with the next serious economic downturn -- the United States will have to confront one of the great challenges of our times: How does a sovereign nation govern itself effectively when politics are national and business is global? When the answers start coming, they could be as radical and as prolonged as the backlash against unbridled corporate power that took place during the first 40 years of this century.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
U.S. Official Finishes Talks In Beijing

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Oct. 25

 BODY:
The United States Treasury Secretary, Lawrence H. Summers, finished two days of meetings in China today with both sides extolling financial cooperation and exuding friendship. But there was no sign of progress on the overarching issue, China's entry into the World Trade Organization.
Still, by all accounts, the meetings Sunday with Prime Minister Zhu Rongji and today with the Finance Minister, Xiang Huaicheng, and other senior officials were friendly and free of rancorous talk -- perhaps an achievement in itself since the countries are still emerging from the icy silence that followed the NATO bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade last May. 
 Without discounting the difficult market-opening concessions that the United States demands of China before it will endorse membership in the global trade body, Mr. Summers and other American officials appeared optimistic that agreement was still possible in the coming month, before new global negotiations begin.
Mr. Summers and other senior economic and security officials came to China for a meeting of the China-U.S. Joint Economic Committee, a periodically scheduled exchange of ideas. Officials said no trade negotiations were held.
The leaders on both sides clearly wanted to present a cheerful public face and an exchange at today's news conference expressed the mood.
Asked about the prospects for a trade agreement, Mr. Summers said: "Any differences can be bridged with good will on both sides. But certainly there are differences that have to be resolved."
Mr. Xiang, smiling, replied, "I agree with the point that with good will, all the problems can be solved" -- subtly suggesting, perhaps, that a decision to give China some leeway was now required.
To which Mr. Summers quickly retorted, to laughs from the room of officials and journalists, "But there is something to be solved."
That "something" is, in the American view, concessions by China to allow global competitors gradually to enter protected, state-run sectors like financial services and telecommunications and to lower barriers to American farm products.
Mr. Summers, in meetings and in a speech today at Qinghua University extolling the merits of market forces and the free flow of information and technology, contended that China would be better off for allowing in competition. This is accepted in principle by many of China's leaders, but is difficult to carry out in a country with serious problems of unemployment, farmer unrest and a huge, dying state enterprise sector.
In a visit to Washington last April, Prime Minister Zhu Rongji was said to have made deep concessions that he hoped would secure the trade deal, but President Clinton decided the moves did not go far enough to satisfy Congress, which will ultimately have to cooperate.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasuries Recover a Bit After Big Fall Early in Day

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Treasury bonds recouped early losses yesterday after yields at one point during the day climbed to a two-year high of 6.40 percent, luring buyers to the market.
"We still have some of the highest yields in the world on our government bonds," said Carl Ericson, who invests about $6 billion as director of taxable fixed-income securities at Colonial Asset Management in Boston. "We're nibbling" in the Treasury market, he added. 
 Ten-year American notes yield 429 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, more than 10-year Japanese Government bonds, 73 basis points more than 10-year German bonds and 38 more than 10-year British bonds.
Late in the day the 30-year bond was down 2/32 at a price of 97 1/32, sending its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, up to 6.35 percent from 6.34 percent.
"Inflation is stepping up," said Steven Bohlin, who helps invest $1.9 billion at the Thornburg Management Company in Santa Fe, N.M. "This makes me say that the Fed's going to have to do more" in the way of raising rates. Bond yields may rise above 6.5 percent this year, he said, adding that he is stockpiling Treasury bills.
The Federal Reserve, which raised its target rate in June and September to the current 5.25 percent, said this month that it was leaning toward another increase. Policy-makers next meet Nov. 16.
The Fed is "slightly behind the curve" in fighting inflation, said Bruce Alston, who oversees $1.5 billion of bonds at Value Line Asset Management. He expects the Fed to raise rates at next month's meeting.
Treasury bond yields have risen more than 125 basis points this year, and consequently the benchmark bond has posted a year-to-date loss of 12.1 percent, taking reinvested interest into account.
In such an environment, the top-performing Government bond fund has spent 1999 betting against government bonds. Juno Fund, run by Rydex Mutual Funds in Rockville, Md., has risen almost 18 percent by following a strategy of short-selling, which allows it to climb when Treasuries fall, according to Morningstar Inc., a fund research firm in Chicago.
Following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of three- and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: Earnings Are Up 13% at American Express

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The American Express Company said yesterday that its third-quarter profit had risen 13 percent, meeting expectations, as customers spent more with its credit cards and increased investments with its financial planners.
The company said it earned $648 million, or $1.42 a share, up from $574 million, or $1.25 a share, in the period a year earlier. Revenue rose 12 percent, to $4.88 billion, from $4.34 billion. 
 The per-share earnings matched the $1.42 expected by Wall Street analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial, but the company's shares fell $5.25 yesterday, to $143.375. Most financial stocks fell as bond yields rose to their highest levels in more than two years. American Express had gained 10 percent in the five trading days before yesterday and was up 40 percent for the year.
American Express increased profits partly because its chairman and chief executive, Harvey Golub, and its president and Mr. Golub's heir, Kenneth Chenault, are working to persuade clients to use the company's cards at grocery stores, gas stations and for other routine purchases.
The company is also benefiting from increased marketing spending and a nine-year economic boom that has been driven by consumer spending. Earnings at the travel-related services unit, which offers credit and charge cards and travel plans, rose 14 percent, to $413 million.
Customers increased spending on cards 14 percent from the year-earlier quarter, to an average $1,935 each. The company gained 900,000 card accounts in the third quarter. It has 2.3 million more cards in customers' hands than it had a year ago, excluding 1.6 million cards lost when American Express dropped a Government contract last year. Card loans, led by the Optima card, rose 34 percent while charge-card receivables increased 9 percent.
To get those accounts and loans, American Express spent $340 million on marketing, up from $310 million a year earlier.
Loan write-offs fell to 4.7 percent of total loans, from 5.3 percent in the previous quarter and 6.4 percent a year earlier.
Even with a falling stock market in the third quarter -- the Standard & Poor's 500-stock Index fell 7 percent -- the company sold more mutual funds and other investments as it added 142 financial planners, giving it 10,631. Earnings at the company's money management subsidiary, American Express Financial Advisors Inc., increased 14 percent, to $240 million.
Profit at American Express Bank, which includes the company's travelers check business, fell 12 percent, to $38 million, from $43 million a year earlier.

HEADLINE: 3M Reports Its Profits for the Third Quarter Were 18% Higher

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: ST. PAUL, Oct. 25

 BODY:
The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, the maker of Post-It notes and Scotch tape, said today that its third-quarter earnings rose 18 percent, more than expected, as sales rose and the cost of raw materials fell.
Profit from operations rose to $462 million, or $1.14 a diluted share, compared with $392 million, or 97 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Sales rose 6.1 percent, to $4 billion. 
 Analysts had expected 3M to earn $1.06 a share, according to First Call/Thomson Financial, which tracks company earnings.
Earnings have now increased for two consecutive quarters after sliding the previous six. Sales in Asia buoyed profit by rising more than 30 percent as the region's economy recovered. In the United States, sales rose 3 percent, led by industrial and safety products and office supplies.
"They're producing good results, they are taking costs out, and that's what you like to see," said Rich Turgeon, an analyst at Society Asset Management, which owned more than 1.5 million 3M shares in June.
The company expects to meet analyst estimates of $1 a share for fourth-quarter earnings, Giulio Agostini, the chief financial officer, said in a conference call. The company also expects to reach its per-share earnings growth target of about 10 percent in 2000, he said.
Shares of 3M, based in St. Paul, rose 25 cents, to $92.8125. They have gained 30 percent this year.
The company took a series of gains and charges in the quarter. A $73 million pretax charge stems from a Federal jury's ruling that 3M violated antitrust laws involving its tape business. The company also had pretax gains totaling $69 million related to asset sales and to change the estimated cost of a restructuring. The company did not provide after-tax figures for the gains and charge.
The actions resulted in net income of $459 million, or $1.13 a share, in the quarter. In the period a year earlier, a charge of $214 million, or 53 cents a share, for job cuts and plant closings resulted in net income of $178 million, or 44 cents a share.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Ho-Hum. SlowDay at Office As Major Indexes Decline.

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Stock prices weakened a bit yesterday as traders in large-capitalization issues took some profits following last week's bounce in major averages. Market interest rates, which moved higher in the morning but later retreated and closed little changed, provided another source of instability.
For the most part, however, traders said the session was an unexceptional day at the office. 
 "It was a very slow day," said Bill Allyn, head of listed trading at Jeffries & Company. "Barring some big outside event, I think the market will stay in a trading range for the remainder of the year. But one more interest rate increase before year-end could be a negative."
Worries about higher interest rates, which could put a crimp in future earnings, helped to drag down the Dow Jones industrial average.
Despite good earnings reports from a number of companies that are included in the Dow, the blue-chip index fell 120.32, or 1.15 percent, to 10,349.93.
American Express, Exxon and Chevron, which all reported quarterly earnings that either met or exceeded Wall Street's forecasts, fell by 2 points or more.
The Standard & Poor's 500 index slipped 8.02, or 0.62 percent, to 1,293.63, pulled down by weakness in oil, financial service and drug stocks. The Nasdaq composite index barely budged, dropping 0.57, to 2,815.95. Declines in issues like Intel and Qualcomm were offset by big gains in Internet stocks like Amazon.com and Ebay. And the Russell 2000 index of small stocks slipped 0.93, or 0.22 percent, to 417.76.
Volume was light, and declining issues again outnumbered those that gained in price.
Richard McCabe, chief market analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company, said the fact that the broader market continued to fare poorly suggested that additional declines might be in the offing soon.
"The rally we had last week was the weakest in terms of depth and participation," he said. "The Dow, the S.& P. 500 and the Nasdaq were all up between 3 percent and 5 percent. Yet the advance/decline figures for the week showed more declining issues than advancing ones on all three exchanges. It's the same old story: the big stocks rally and the rest of the market languishes."
American Express and J. P. Morgan led the Dow lower.
American Express fell 5 1/4, to 143 3/8. Traders sold the stock even though the company reported that third-quarter earnings rose 14 percent, a performance that met consensus forecasts. J. P. Morgan shed 5 7/16, to 120 3/16.
Both stocks, along with other big financial service firms, posted sharp gains last Friday after the Senate Banking Committee reached agreement on legislation that would overhaul the financial services industry.
Exxon and Chevron both fell despite posting healthy earnings. Other oil stocks fell in sympathy.
Exxon lost 2 7/8, to 74. Chevron fell 3 3/4, to 90, even though its earnings were better than expected.
Elsewhere, MidAmerican Energy Holdings jumped 6 1/8, to 33 3/8, after Berkshire Hathaway said it was leading an investor group that would buy the company for $35.05 a share. The transaction would be the first energy purchase for Berkshire.
Internet stocks, which fell during the morning as long-term bond yields touched 6.40 percent, rallied as long-term rates fell.
Gains in stocks like Immunex, which rose 4 1/8, to 58 1/16, Amazon.com and Ebay helped to push TheStreet.com's Internet sector index up 2.2 percent.
Amazon.com gained 4 1/8, to 82 3/4, and Ebay jumped 8 1/4, to 150 7/8.
